The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO THE MOST HIGH AND MIGHTY MONARCH, CHARLES, BY THE GRACE OF GOD, KING OF GREAT BRJTAINE, FRANCE, AND IRELAND, DEFENDER OF THE FAITH, &c.
div.p:
YOu are juÅ¿tly placed in a glorious Å¿phere, elevated in a moÅ¿t conÅ¿picuous altitude above other inferiour and Å¿ubordinate Orbes, from whence (as a Å¿overaign Arbiter) you behold and judge of our Motions, as they either reliÅ¿h of worth or demerit, and (like the Sunne) impartially diÅ¿penÅ¿e the propitious beames of your favour, as well to the humbleÅ¿t plant, as the talleÅ¿t Cedar. As I am a recent and freÅ¿h exiÅ¿tent example of your life-tendring influence, for when depreÅ¿Å¿ed and trampled upon by the inÅ¿olency of an unkinde-adverÅ¿ary
that raiÅ¿ed me up to tread upon an equall BaÅ¿is with him, who lately had deÅ¿igned me for his foot-Å¿toole. An admirable example of Clemency and IuÅ¿tice, eminent vertues, and truely inherent in your moÅ¿t Royall boÅ¿ome: for which with all humility I bow, and thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e acknowledge, infinitely honouring them Å¿o conÅ¿picuous in your MajeÅ¿ty, and by you Å¿o frequently exerciÅ¿ed. Thus reÅ¿tor'd, I come charg'd with a Booke, which I moÅ¿t humbly proÅ¿trate at your feete, becauÅ¿e I feare it is not conÅ¿cious of Å¿o much worth, as to merit a kiÅ¿Å¿e from your Å¿acred hand. It is the Embrion of my Å¿tudy, travels, experience, and practiÅ¿e, and cannot arrive to forme and perfection without the reflection of your MajeÅ¿ties favour. It brings with it a front not altogether inglorious, of HorÅ¿manÅ¿hip and Ferriery; the firÅ¿t not incompetent with the moÅ¿t illuÅ¿trious title and Heroick Spirit; the Å¿econd not unworthy the knowledge, yea the practiÅ¿e of the moÅ¿t accompliÅ¿h'd Gentleman. I know this TreatiÅ¿e cannot hold proportion with Å¿o elated a patronage, as that of your MajeÅ¿ty, although it were inform'd with a farre nobler Genius; yet for all this infinite diÅ¿proportion, the Dedication of it unto your Å¿acred MajeÅ¿ty will not appeare much improper; for firÅ¿t I received the ability to proÅ¿ecute it from your Grace and favour: Å¿o that deriving its being from you, it belongs of right unto you, and muÅ¿t have recourÅ¿e unto your MajeÅ¿tie for its Å¿afety and protection. Secondly, it is the off-Å¿pring of my age, and cannot but leave a fatall participation in its Parents infirmity, and therefore (eÅ¿pecially in theÅ¿e cenÅ¿orious times) cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t without your Royall protection. LaÅ¿tly, as you have taken the rationall creatures of this your tripartite Kingdome into your titular care, Å¿o have you not excluded the irrationall, albeit in a different condition, much leÅ¿Å¿e the HorÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e GeneroÅ¿ity, and uÅ¿e have given him the precedency in your MajeÅ¿ties eÅ¿teeme, before all other bruit Å¿pecies; Å¿o that this Booke (which beautifies his Å¿hape, encreaÅ¿es his courage, delivers rudiments for his menage, preÅ¿cribes cures for his diÅ¿eaÅ¿es,
and in all, enables and advances his race and bravery) hopes to finde your MajeÅ¿ties hand extended and open to receive it. The worke concernes the Common-wealth in generall, and if accepted and peruÅ¿ed with as much zeale and care as I have us'd in the publiÅ¿hing of it; I preÅ¿ume it will not be found empty of profit. My many yeares have given me the priviledge to have Å¿eene and knowne this kingdome rich both in the number and quality of her HorÅ¿es, and it would infinitely grieve me that I now live to Å¿ee her reduc'd to Å¿o deplorable an indignity, but that I am confident I Å¿hall Å¿ee her reÅ¿tor'd to her precedent glory and opulency by your MajeÅ¿ty: and now that I have aÅ¿Å¿um'd the boldneÅ¿Å¿e to inculcate her poverty, my zeale and reÅ¿pect to my Country, tranÅ¿ports me yet a little further to diÅ¿cover the cauÅ¿es of it, together with the redreÅ¿Å¿es and remedies. FirÅ¿t, thoÅ¿e ForreÅ¿ts, Parks, Commons, Fennes, Moores, and other marriÅ¿h and waÅ¿te grounds, which paid yearely Å¿o rich a tribute of young, able, and Å¿erviceable HorÅ¿es to the univerÅ¿all uÅ¿e of this Kingdome, are at this time diÅ¿afforreÅ¿ted, diÅ¿park't, taken in, drain'd, laid dry, and converted to other (but much different) uÅ¿es, Å¿o that thoÅ¿e brave breeds and races of HorÅ¿es are much extenuated, or altogether intermitted. Then the Gelders, who in every Å¿hire Å¿o confidently and frequently exerciÅ¿e their faculty in a moÅ¿t unlawfull manner, and Å¿pay yong Fillies, by which meanes they become barren, the breeds of HorÅ¿es diÅ¿continued, and the Common-wealth highly prejudic'd and unfurniÅ¿h'd; for inÅ¿tance I can and will (upon occaÅ¿ion) produce a Gelder who Å¿payes more then a hundred Fillies. For redreÅ¿Å¿e of the firÅ¿t, your MajeÅ¿ty may be pleaÅ¿ed to command that thoÅ¿e Statutes which were enacted for the breeding of HorÅ¿es, may be Å¿peedily and exactly put in execution. For the Å¿econd, that you will likewiÅ¿e pleaÅ¿e by your Proclamation to inhibit all Gelders that unlawfull and prejudiciall exerciÅ¿e of their profeÅ¿Å¿ion, then Å¿hall your MajeÅ¿ty Å¿ee the noxious and exorbitant diÅ¿eaÅ¿e meet with a Å¿udden and eaÅ¿ie cure, and the whole Kingdome
derive a Å¿enÅ¿ible and ineÅ¿timable benefit from it. Now it reÅ¿ts that I make an humble Apologie for my boldneÅ¿Å¿e, which indeed would be a matter of trouble and difficulty for me to accompliÅ¿h; did I not know your MajeÅ¿tie to be a Prince infinitely tendring the good and welfare of your Kingdome; Å¿o that this treating of a buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e not inconÅ¿equent, I deÅ¿paire not of obtaining your Royall pardon, but promiÅ¿e my Å¿elfe from your benignity and clemency, a gratious acceptance of that I have moÅ¿t zealouÅ¿ly delivered.

closer.signed: Your MajeÅ¿ties moÅ¿t humble and faithfull Subject, THOMAS DE GRAY.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE, IAMES, MARQVESSE HAMILTON, EARLE OF ARRAN AND CAMBRIDGE, BARON OF EVEN, Aberbroth, and Ennerdale, MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e to his MaieÅ¿tie, Knight of the Honorable order of the Garter, and one of his MajeÅ¿ties moÅ¿t honorable privy Councell.
div.p: TO have preÅ¿ented this peece of HorÅ¿e-manÅ¿hip to his MajeÅ¿tie by any other hand then Yours, had beene very improper; as well in regard of the place your LordÅ¿hip beares, as of my reÅ¿pects to your Noble perÅ¿on.

Here is a Å¿ubject (my Lord) worthy of your conÅ¿ideration, and the imployments of your thoughts even Å¿erious; for in this moÅ¿t generous Creature, next unto Man, conÅ¿iÅ¿teth the pleaÅ¿ure, honor, and defence of a moÅ¿t flouriÅ¿hing Kingdome.

I have given part of my Youth to the inveÅ¿tigation of this
beautifull and uÅ¿efull Creature; I have Å¿earched many Nations for my better information; and albeit I have found Å¿ome Climates more Fortunate then this of Ours, in the production of a happie Å¿hape to this Creature, for the moÅ¿t part our HorÅ¿es not being drawne out with Å¿uch delicate Lineaments, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ome of them, I have (where care and diligence have beene uÅ¿ed in the Breed) of moÅ¿t abÅ¿olute, and perfect Å¿hape, and whereas frequently, the Barbary Iennet, Turke and Neapolitan CourÅ¿er, are cryed up for their beauties, yet as in Å¿ome Å¿hapes they excell, Å¿o in Å¿ome other th â¢ y may be found defective.

But if we regard the Spirit, Vigor, and doing of a HorÅ¿e, no Nation, or Soyle, produceth a more Active, then this our Iland of Great Britaine, as hath beene well experienced by many Noble and memorable Services.
Vnto which if we adde a due obÅ¿ervation in our Breed, both on the one Å¿ide of the Stalion or Sire, and the Damme, our loÅ¿t glory will be Å¿oone recovered.

But Å¿ince the laying aÅ¿ide of the great Saddle and Cannon, and neglect of the HorÅ¿e of Menage, Å¿ince the applying our Breed only to Racing, or, (as I may better Å¿ay) in furniÅ¿hing our Å¿elves with HorÅ¿es of Å¿peed to runne away from our Enemy, the moÅ¿t ancient honour of HorÅ¿eman-Å¿hip peculiar to this our Kingdome, and for which all other Nations highly eÅ¿teemed us, is now almoÅ¿t vaniÅ¿hed and loÅ¿t; inÅ¿omuch as were we preÅ¿Å¿ed with thoughts of defence (from which the moÅ¿t prudent and watchfull Eye of our moÅ¿t gracious Soveraigne, Guards us, through his moÅ¿t happie Government) we Å¿hould bee forced (I write this in bluÅ¿hes) to to pull HorÅ¿es from the Coach, and Cart, to fill up our Troopes.

Let it therefore bee recorded, (my Noble Lord) that whileÅ¿t you were MaÅ¿ter of the HorÅ¿e to his MaieÅ¿tie, an exact obÅ¿ervation was eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed throughout this whole Kingdome, for the due breeding of Å¿erviceable HorÅ¿es; to the furtherance of which moÅ¿t Noble deÅ¿igne, if theÅ¿e my ObÅ¿ervations Å¿hall, any way conduce, I Å¿hall bleÅ¿Å¿e my Pen that it ever waded in Å¿uch a Å¿ubiect: profeÅ¿sing my Å¿elfe to owe unto my Soveraigne and Countrey all I
have, and unto them my Labours as a moÅ¿t loyall Subiect and true Patriot, I moÅ¿t humbly offer.

And my good Lord, theÅ¿e ObÅ¿ervations gathered in my Youth, I was adviÅ¿ed and preÅ¿Å¿ed by Å¿ome Noble Friends (though now old) to publiÅ¿h for the generall good of this our Kingdome: OtherwiÅ¿e for my owne part I Å¿hould have rather Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ed them, as not being now Å¿o fit a Å¿ubiect for me to treate off, but the publique good hath over Å¿wayd me. Wherefore with theÅ¿e Oblations I Conclude, KiÅ¿sing your LordÅ¿hips Hands, and Å¿hall ever profeÅ¿Å¿e my Å¿elfe

closer.signed: Your LordÅ¿hip MoÅ¿t humble Servant. THOMAS DE LA GREY.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: WHen I doe conÅ¿ider (benevolent Reader) the inconvenience whereinto that Man is plunged, who brings himÅ¿elfe upon the publique Stage of promulgating his Bookes in print, be the Å¿ubject never Å¿o laudable, and the Author no leÅ¿Å¿e cautelous and Å¿ufficient, endeavouring with all diligence to prevent the brand of a black cole: nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e all induÅ¿try applyed, he Å¿hall not paÅ¿Å¿e without obloquy and aÅ¿perÅ¿ion.

This very conÅ¿ideration hath Å¿o afrighted and deterred me, that albeit I have had many great motives exciting me to make a tender of the Love, Duty, and Service I beare to my Country; yet when I doe contemplate the many cenÅ¿ures I muÅ¿t undergoe, I have beene evermore diÅ¿heartened as well from beginning, as going forwards in this my deÅ¿ired purpoÅ¿e. NotwithÅ¿tanding partly through the reÅ¿pect I beare to my Countries profit and honour, and partly by meanes of the importunity of many my right Noble and generous friends, who have been eye-witneÅ¿Å¿es to Å¿undry of my Cures, and thoÅ¿e not a few uncouth and rare: I have adventured even now in my declining dayes, to leave this Work as a Monument to enÅ¿uing times, no whit doubting, but that the judicious will friendly accept thereof; but as for the malevolent and ignorant, I am moÅ¿t confident that the quils they Å¿hall dart at me, cannot goe as from a Porcupine, and therefore will do me the leÅ¿Å¿e hurt or domage.

I therefore am bold to put into thy hand, this poore work of mine, which I have digeÅ¿ted into tw Bookes: In the firÅ¿t, I lay thee down rudiments how thou mayeÅ¿t breed HorÅ¿es to thy beÅ¿t advantage and liking; which albeit they may appeare unto thee to be recent and unknown, yet if thou wilt be pleaÅ¿ed to put them in ure, and make tryall (not digreÅ¿Å¿ing from my principles) thou wilt (I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure me) be Å¿o farre from diÅ¿liking them, as never hereafter to Å¿warve or diÅ¿Å¿ent from them. For if we Å¿hall Å¿eriouÅ¿ly ruminate in how high eÅ¿teeme that man is who is owner and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿or of good HorÅ¿es, how much commended, how much reÅ¿pected, how much talked of, and how well proffered for them: but when he Å¿hall be knowne to be a
breeder of Å¿uch good HorÅ¿es, will not his encomiums be the greater? but when together with theÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe Å¿hall be known to be exquiÅ¿ite in HorÅ¿emanÅ¿hip, whereby to cauÅ¿e his HorÅ¿e to Å¿hew himÅ¿elfe in his Pace, Menage, and all other his poÅ¿tures like as well becomes a right good HorÅ¿e, perfectly mouthed, delicately borne, obedient to the hand, and to anÅ¿wer the Switch and Spur, will not (I Å¿ay) that Gentleman be highly commended, and have more eyes upon him as he paÅ¿Å¿eth a long, than are commonly caÅ¿t upon a Comet or the Sun eclipÅ¿ed? yes undoubtedly. For if we doe but note when a handÅ¿ome HorÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿eth along, we may obÅ¿erve the people not onely gaze upon him as he commeth towards and againÅ¿t them, but to turn themÅ¿elves and looke after him Å¿o long time as he continueth within their view and Å¿ight: Mans love to the HorÅ¿e is generally Å¿o great.

Sithence then the HorÅ¿e is a creature Å¿o generous, and therefore Å¿o much liked and beloved of all, in my poore judgement, it Å¿hould Å¿uit very well with every Gentleman of worth, ranke, and quality, to endeavour (if not to breed, yet at leaÅ¿t) to be maÅ¿ters of Å¿uch HorÅ¿es (which he muÅ¿t keep) that Å¿hall be truely handÅ¿ome and comely, rightly bred, of good colour, cleane Å¿hape, well marked, and Å¿ingularly well ridden and made, and Å¿o he Å¿hall the better advance his honour and reputation.

Having now bred, or otherwiÅ¿e by thy diligent endeavours attained unto Å¿uch HorÅ¿es as be truely good, and for thy turne; the Å¿econd thing to be thought of, is, if they be not already made unto thy hand as thou deÅ¿ireÅ¿t to have them, that thou then doe procure Å¿uch a Rider, who is known to be a maÅ¿ter of his Art, or otherwiÅ¿e thou wilt be much deceived, and farre to Å¿eeke of enjoying thy wiÅ¿hed deÅ¿ires, and therefore I have given thee inÅ¿tructions how to make thy choice of Å¿uch a man, whereby thou Å¿halt not be wronged in thy expectation, nor thy HorÅ¿e marred in his firÅ¿t making and handling. Neither have I taken upon me to teach him his Art, (for that were a thing very impertinent) but thoÅ¿e documents which I have Å¿et thee downe muÅ¿t Å¿erve onely to Å¿hew thee how thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t Å¿oone finde whether the Rider may be for thy turne or not.

The third thing which thou art to take to thy conÅ¿ideration, is, the good or harme that may come unto thee by the choice thou makeÅ¿t of thy Groome or Keeper, who may either through his ignorance, or inconÅ¿ideration, Å¿oone make him unfit both for thy owne uÅ¿e, or any mans elÅ¿e: out of which reaÅ¿on I have depainted thee a Groom in his lively colours, and if his conditions and qualities Å¿hall be otherwiÅ¿e than what I have delineated, aÅ¿Å¿ure thy Å¿elfe thou doÅ¿t runne a manifeÅ¿t hazard of marring that HorÅ¿e thou didÅ¿t hope Å¿hould have been to thy hearts deÅ¿ire. And foraÅ¿much as it is a matter very much praiÅ¿e-worthy to be a MaÅ¿ter of good HorÅ¿es, to have them made perfect and ready, to have Å¿uch Riders, Keepers, and Groomes, as be
very perite in their faculties; yet if thy Stable be not every way Å¿itting and correÅ¿pondent, much diÅ¿profit and inconvenience may therby Å¿oone redound to thy HorÅ¿e. I have therefore preÅ¿cribed thee the meanes how thou mayeÅ¿t have a perfect and good Stable, with all commodities and accoutrements thereunto belonging: and therefore if thou wilt be pleaÅ¿ed to make uÅ¿e of theÅ¿e my rudiments, and punctually obÅ¿erve theÅ¿e my grounds and principles, aÅ¿Å¿ure thy Å¿elfe thou wilt in Å¿hort time aÅ¿pire to that which will be thy honour and renown.

And to the end thou mayeÅ¿t the more perfectly and eaÅ¿ily underÅ¿tand the full drift and Å¿umme of this my firÅ¿t Booke, I will here give unto thee an Epitome of it in a few lines, which may doe thee much pleaÅ¿ure in the peruÅ¿all thereof.

In the Introduction, I Å¿hew thee how needfull a creature the HorÅ¿e is beyond all others, and what admirable things HorÅ¿es in former times have perpetrated and done, whereof I produce thee inÅ¿tances of the famous acts of Å¿undry brave and generous HorÅ¿es, whoÅ¿e love to their MaÅ¿ters have been Å¿o great great, as hardly to be credited, if ancient HiÅ¿tories and Annals of good integrity, had not engraven them in the memory of never-dying poÅ¿terity. We reade of Bucephalus what he did for the good, life, and Å¿afety of his MaÅ¿ter; of the HorÅ¿e of DionyÅ¿ius, with what undaunted courage he comported himÅ¿elfe in battell for the reliefe and Å¿uccour of his Lord; it is recorded alÅ¿o of the HorÅ¿e of Antiochus, what ill Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e befell Centurettus, who when he had Å¿laine Antiochus, would needs backe the HorÅ¿e of his Å¿laine MaÅ¿ter. It is alÅ¿o noted what inly love Nicomedes his HorÅ¿e bare to his Lord and MaÅ¿ter, when after his death of meere griefe, famiÅ¿hed himÅ¿elfe. We reade of Aethon, the HorÅ¿e of Pallas, who was evidently obÅ¿erved and Å¿een to weep at the funerall of his MaÅ¿ter. Silius makes report of two famous HorÅ¿es called Pelorus and Ciraeus, the one eminent for his proweÅ¿Å¿e and hardineÅ¿Å¿e in warre, and the other for his unparalelled Å¿wiftneÅ¿Å¿e. Moreover we may reade, how that this poore creature hath Å¿o well merited of man, as that many have erected Monuments and Sepulchers, celebrated Exequies, builded and founded munificent Cities, Å¿et up Pyramidies, made Epitaphs, erected goodly Statues, inÅ¿tituted Playes and Games; and all theÅ¿e in honour of the HorÅ¿e; beÅ¿ides many other remarkable things right worthy of note.

In the way of Breeding, I do intimate unto thee the manner how, the Å¿eaÅ¿on when, the place where, together with the colours, marks, and Å¿hapes as well of thy Stalions, as of thy Race, or Stud Mares, and from what defects they muÅ¿t be free: what Signes are beÅ¿t wherein to cover, what courÅ¿e to take with them that they may conceive, what exerciÅ¿e is fitteÅ¿t for them as well when they be with Fole, as after foling; how to cheriÅ¿h thy Mares when their Colts Å¿hall runne by them, and how to breed up thy Colts till they come to handling,
backing, and riding, with other circumÅ¿tances very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be known: and thus much briefly for the firÅ¿t Book.

The Å¿econd Booke conÅ¿iÅ¿teth chiefly of the manner how thou mayeÅ¿t cure all Å¿uch diÅ¿eaÅ¿es and maladies (both intrinÅ¿ecall and extrinÅ¿ecall) whereunto either the life of the HorÅ¿e, or any of his limbs or members may be any way endamaged or in danger. This I have handled by way of familiar Dialogue, which I hold to be beÅ¿t, for avoyding of prolix and over-tedious diÅ¿courÅ¿es, by reaÅ¿on it will very much help the memory of the Reader, and keep his minde the better attent upon the Å¿tate of the QueÅ¿tion or Å¿ubject in hand, and by that meanes I may my Å¿elfe be the better able alÅ¿o to explicate and deliver my meaning, much more cleerely. In which Dialogue, I have introduced as prolocutors, three perÅ¿ons onely, viz. FirÅ¿t, Hippophilus a Gentleman, one who is the true lover of the HorÅ¿e: Secondly, Hippiatrus the Ferrier or MariÅ¿hall, one moÅ¿t expert in HorÅ¿e-leech craft: And thirdly, HippoÅ¿erus his Servant or Iourneyman, Å¿ometimes his apprentice bred up by him, from whom HippoÅ¿erus hath had his education and knowledge in this Art: theÅ¿e be all the Dramatis perÅ¿onae to this Scene. For when a Nobleman (V. G.) div.head: CHAP. I. THE INTRODUCTION.
div.p:
IF we will but take to our Å¿erious conÅ¿ideration how many great obligations we have to admire the infinite goodneÅ¿Å¿e of Almighty God in creating Å¿uch a marvellous number of creatures, meerely for the uÅ¿e and Å¿ervice of man, whereof no one of them can be wanting; and that amongÅ¿t them all, we have none more uÅ¿efull, or which can be leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿pared, then the HorÅ¿e; no dumb creature more generous, nor any that commeth Å¿o neere unto the pleaÅ¿ure of man, none can Å¿erve him better in time of peace and warre, none better for manuring and tilling the earth, and to cauÅ¿e it to produce its fruits; none more uÅ¿efull for bringing in the fruits of the earth; none more behoofefull to beare and carry him his long and tedious journeyes, in heat and cold, through thick and thin, by night and day; none better to carry him from danger, and to land his maÅ¿ter at the port of Å¿afety, then the HorÅ¿e: and for his paÅ¿times and recreations, no creature to be compared to this: neither is there any creature created by the great Creator of all things, which doth Å¿o perfectly underÅ¿tand and connive with the nature and minde of man, or that beareth a more inly love to man, as doth this poore creature the HorÅ¿e; for upon all occaÅ¿ions he Å¿weateth, he trudgeth, he toyleth, he drudgeth, he moyleth, he laboureth pro viribus, with great alacrity and cheerefulneÅ¿Å¿e (Å¿o long as his vitall Å¿pirits laÅ¿t) to give comfort and content to him that feedeth and cheriÅ¿heth him, yea and that (I Å¿ay) with Å¿uch joy and alacrity, as if (like to a reaÅ¿onable creature) he found himÅ¿elfe obliged thereto in the bond of all Å¿incere duty and gratitude. For Å¿hould I Å¿peake rather like a PhiloÅ¿opher then a ChriÅ¿tian, I could not but agnize nature to be admirable in all her works,
wherein man doth owe unto her infinite, and thoÅ¿e very great thanks, in that Å¿he hath accommodated and plentifully furniÅ¿hed him with all things needfull for his uÅ¿e, as alÅ¿o in that Å¿he hath propagated (amongÅ¿t all other) the HorÅ¿e, the moÅ¿t uÅ¿efull for the Å¿ervice of man, and who beÅ¿t acknowledgeth his MaÅ¿ter. And that this may be the better anatomized, I will Å¿hew you what I finde recorded by authenticall Authors of the excellency of this praiÅ¿e-worthy creature.

The Å¿o much-renowned Bucephalus, who carried his MaÅ¿ter through Å¿o many conquered kingdomes, Å¿erves for an example to all enÅ¿uing ages, who would not Å¿uffer any man but great Alexander to backe him, who Å¿eemed to be proud at what time he carried Å¿o glorious and victorious a charge, and it is alÅ¿o written of him, that being wounded at the Å¿iege and Å¿acking of Thebes, he carried him couragiouÅ¿ly through the troops and throngs of all the combatants, with incredible valour and courage, nothing at all eÅ¿teeming or prizing the loÅ¿Å¿e of his bloud, being moÅ¿t deÅ¿irous, and no leÅ¿Å¿e willing to do his maÅ¿ter all faithfull Å¿ervice, to the utmoÅ¿t of his power, and to the effuÅ¿ion of the laÅ¿t drop of his bloud, labouring to purchaÅ¿e unto himÅ¿elfe by his (not to be parallelled) valour, and his reÅ¿olute perÅ¿everance, a victorious advantage over the enemy. What never-dying high renown, the horÅ¿e of CaeÅ¿ar got, I hold little inferiour to that of Bucephalus? DionyÅ¿ius the tyrant of Sicily, in a great and well fought battell, was himÅ¿elfe Å¿o hard put to it, that he was conÅ¿trained to forÅ¿ake his horÅ¿e, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the poore beaÅ¿t made his way through the throngs of the enemy; who all bloudy and miery as he was, gat him to a randevous his Stable. Centaurettus of Galatia, having in battaile flaine Antiochus, he in a bravado mounted his horÅ¿e, who Å¿oone found by good experience, (albeit no whit to his advantage) that the Å¿aid horÅ¿e retained a reÅ¿entment of the death of his Å¿laine MaÅ¿ter, for the horÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿oone as he felt this his new Lord upon his back, never gave ouer flinging, yarking, plunging, and bownding, commanding the Bit with his teeth, launching out Å¿ometimes this way, Å¿ometimes that way, with Å¿o great impetuoÅ¿ity and fury, that at length he caÅ¿t his raÅ¿h rider to the earth, and then fell to him with his heeles, redoubling his Å¿trokes in Å¿o thick and violent a manner, not giving over till he had Å¿lain him out-right, whereby he gave him little cauÅ¿e to triumph and glory in his temerarious attempt. We reade of Nicomedes, King of Bithynia, whoÅ¿e HorÅ¿e Å¿o intirely loved him, as that his MaÅ¿ter was no Å¿ooner dead, but the HorÅ¿e preÅ¿ently forÅ¿ooke his meat, and Å¿o continued, untill Å¿uch time as he languiÅ¿hing for very griefe, dyed of famine. Virgil, the Prince of Poets, maketh honourable mention of Aethon, the HorÅ¿e of Pallas, Å¿onne of Evander, who Å¿aith that this Aethon being preÅ¿ent at the funerall of his maÅ¿ter, wept for Å¿orrow, as theÅ¿e two verÅ¿es do inculcate:
After came Aethon, bold in fight, now weeping,
And in his teares, his mournfull viÅ¿age Å¿teeping.

Silius Italicus in his ninth Book, doth highly extoll two horÅ¿es, to wit, Pelorus and Ciraeus, Å¿peaking of them in this manner:
Ready Pelorus was to th' hand and rayne,
Obedient Å¿till, and of a generous Å¿traine:
Hearing his MaÅ¿ters voyce, Ciraeus hies,
'Fore the beholders, and the winde of flies.

The tractableneÅ¿Å¿e and love that the HorÅ¿e beareth to man, have been the occaÅ¿ion that Å¿undry great perÅ¿onages have reciprocally anÅ¿wered it, by erecting of Statues, and by building of moÅ¿t famous Cities to their honour and memory. Alexander before mentioned, founded an opulent City in honour of Bucephalus, and gave it his name, and celebrated his exequies. The Egyptians erected moÅ¿t magnificent Piramides, and Å¿umptuous Å¿epulchres to Å¿uch horÅ¿es, as had Å¿erved them well in their warres. Octavius CaeÅ¿ar, and after him, Adrian the Emperour, interred their HorÅ¿es with great pomp and Å¿olemnities, and cauÅ¿ed famous Epitaphs to be engraven upon their monuments. The Emperour Commodus, did the like to his HorÅ¿e ParÅ¿inus, and commanded that he Å¿hould be buried in the Vatican. Romulus did inÅ¿titute Playes and Games called Equitiae, in honour of HorÅ¿es, and cauÅ¿ed them to be preÅ¿ented in the field of Mars. The Ethiopians did Å¿o highly eÅ¿teem of theÅ¿e noble creatures, as that they armed their Helmets with the skins of HorÅ¿es, Å¿uffering their eares to remain on, and they did weare their tayles upon their CreÅ¿ts, like as now a daies men uÅ¿e their plumes. Other nations have done the like, who held HorÅ¿es in no little eÅ¿teem. We reade of a Roman Emperour, who made his HorÅ¿e a Senator. The ancient AÅ¿trologers have likewiÅ¿e attributed Å¿o much to HorÅ¿es, that they have placed one winged amongÅ¿t the coeleÅ¿tiall Å¿ignes. The Poets hold that the Fountaine (where the nine MuÅ¿es uÅ¿ed to bath themÅ¿elves, and to drink) Å¿prang up, by the blow of the foot which PegaÅ¿us gave againÅ¿t the two topt hill, ParnaÅ¿Å¿us. Neptune, God of the Sea, is Å¿urnamed Hippius; by reaÅ¿on that (as the Poets doe fable) the firÅ¿t HorÅ¿e that was ever Å¿een, received his origen from him, or from a Å¿tone whereon Neptune had poured water. There remaineth much more to be Å¿aid in honour of the HorÅ¿e, then their hath been already delivered. Wherefore omitting further Encomiums, and attributes, I haÅ¿ten to matters of greater conÅ¿equence. Sithence therefore the caÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿tandeth, that this dumb creature is by Almighty God given unto man, as a creature of Å¿o uÅ¿efull importance, what thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e then are we bound to give unto him for Å¿o great a bleÅ¿Å¿ing and benefit? And therefore what diligence
is required of us; yea, and what carefulneÅ¿Å¿e ought we to uÅ¿e, in travelling to attaine to this Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary a creature in the moÅ¿t exact manner we are able? Nor can this poÅ¿Å¿ibly be acquired to our true content, unleÅ¿Å¿e we doe apply our beÅ¿t endeavours herein; for the Ancients have this Proverb, All rare and excellent things are hard to compaÅ¿Å¿e: and therefore we ought to apply all care and induÅ¿try to attain unto good HorÅ¿es, which can never be Å¿o well done, as by breeding them; for they muÅ¿t be the HorÅ¿es that will be able beÅ¿t to Å¿erve us in thoÅ¿e offices whereunto we Å¿hall intend them, according as hereafter Å¿hall be moÅ¿t exactly illuÅ¿trated.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the beÅ¿t manner of breeding.
div.p: THere are Å¿o many diverÅ¿ities of opinions Å¿o mainly defended pro & con, that maketh men fearefull to bring that to publique view, which long practice and experience hath brought them to know and underÅ¿tand to be moÅ¿t true and infallible: NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I preÅ¿uming that the more judicious may peradventure favour my reaÅ¿ons and grounds; allowing them at leaÅ¿t for probable and good, if they Å¿hall adventure to make triall, which if they be pleaÅ¿ed Å¿o to do, I am confident they will both allow and approve of this my manner of breeding, above all other wayes heretofore practiÅ¿ed; who finding it to be much better, will never be brought from the Å¿ame method, and therefore I would not have any man to condemne me before he Å¿hall firÅ¿t have made triall.

My counÅ¿ell therefore is, that Å¿uch generous Å¿pirits, unto whom Almighty God hath extended his benigne hand, would take to their conÅ¿ideration, how needfull a thing it is for them to lay hold upon this Å¿o noble and profitable a bleÅ¿Å¿ing and benefit, by applying their beÅ¿t care and diligence to breed, good, able, and Å¿erviceable HorÅ¿es, which may be as eaÅ¿ily performed, and in a manner with as little coÅ¿t, as in breeding Iades and Baffles, unuÅ¿efull and unprofitable. For by procuring a good and able Stud of choice Mares, and by endeavouring to get Å¿elect Stallions, which for mettle, Å¿pirit, Å¿hape, colour, marks, and the like, Å¿hall be known to be rightly bred, and truely generous, as well (I Å¿ay) the Mares as the Stallions; and theÅ¿e, young, handÅ¿ome, of Å¿ize indifferent, that is, neither too Å¿mall, nor too large, long-legged or under-bodied; but well knit, limb'd, and joynted; it will be beyond all peradventure but that you Å¿hall have HorÅ¿es fit wherewith to Å¿erve your Country upon all occaÅ¿ions, and your own turn and your friends, and acquire to your Å¿elfe no Å¿mall
honour and commendations both from your Prince, and the weale publique. And this the better to bee performed, you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that Å¿ome things are neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be conÅ¿idered. FirÅ¿t, that your grounds be fit for breeding, and thoÅ¿e not to be Å¿uch as be low, wet, fenny, mooriÅ¿h, or mariÅ¿h; but they muÅ¿t be paÅ¿tures upland, hilly, and in Å¿ome places Å¿tony and rocky, for grounds of this nature are very profitable for your Colts, to Å¿cope, run, and play in, it helpeth their winde, it knitteth their joynts, and hardeneth and maketh tough their hooves: Å¿ome of your grounds ought alÅ¿o not to be without Underwoods, BuÅ¿hes, FurÅ¿ells, Broome, and the like; theÅ¿e will Å¿erve for Å¿helter at what time the cold windes doe blow: the reÅ¿idue of your grounds ought to have Lawnes and Plains, wherein Å¿hould be better graÅ¿Å¿e then the former; and in theÅ¿e Lawnes, is needfull there Å¿hould be great Oakes, and Å¿uch like timber-trees for them whereby to Å¿helter them from the Å¿corching Å¿unne in the extreame heats, eÅ¿pecially during the time of the Canicular dayes; and theÅ¿e trees will alÅ¿o defend them from the buzzing and Å¿tinging Fly, which otherwiÅ¿e would greatly annoy and afflict them: you muÅ¿t alÅ¿o accommodate your grounds with partitions convenient, as well for change, which Å¿ometimes is moÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite, as alÅ¿o whereby to Å¿egregate each Å¿ort of cattell by it Å¿elf; as your young and old, raÅ¿e or breeding Mares by themÅ¿elves, your weanlings by themÅ¿elves, your Fillyes by themÅ¿elves, and your Å¿toned Colts by themÅ¿elves, according as your beÅ¿t judgement Å¿hall dictate; otherwiÅ¿e your breed will be in confuÅ¿ion, and come to nothing, and Å¿o you may run the hazard, to loÅ¿e both your coÅ¿t and paines. Places muÅ¿t be alÅ¿o made apart, wherin both your Mares with fole, and thoÅ¿e who have their Colts Å¿ucking upon them, may run by themÅ¿elves with all quietneÅ¿Å¿e and retiredneÅ¿Å¿e; and every of theÅ¿e partitions muÅ¿t be Å¿o Å¿ufficiently fenced, as that no one Å¿ort of cattell can breake into the other. And I doe yet further adviÅ¿e, that theÅ¿e grounds be well furniÅ¿hed with Å¿weet and wholeÅ¿ome water, whereof ought not to be any want, either in winter or Å¿ummer, for otherwiÅ¿e you may endanger the tainting and Å¿urfetting of them.

Furthermore, that certaine Sheds and Hay-houÅ¿es be erected for them to be fed in during the time of the winter, when graÅ¿Å¿e is Å¿canty and not Å¿o much nouriÅ¿hing, and the cold winds, froÅ¿ts, raines, and Å¿nowes, may greatly pinch and annoy them; in which houÅ¿ings, would be Å¿et up Rackes and Mangers whereat to feed them; there would alÅ¿o be laid cleane Å¿traw for them to lye upon, which will very much comfort and keep them warm: But above all, the greateÅ¿t care muÅ¿t be had to the fences in generall, whether wall (which is evermore the beÅ¿t) pale, quickÅ¿ets, broad ditches, or high banks, leÅ¿t they Å¿hould at any time breake forth, and treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e your neighbours to baÅ¿tardize, and wrong your breed: and you ought alÅ¿o to inÅ¿titute a truÅ¿ty and diligent Bayliffe or Å¿ervant, whoÅ¿e onely function Å¿hould
be to make his fence-walke morning and evening, as duly as any welexperienced Keeper or Wood-man doth his Pale-walke, to Å¿ee that the fences be faÅ¿t, and his cattell Å¿afe: and let him not faile every day once at the leaÅ¿t, to take a true tale and inventary of every Å¿ort of cattell he hath in his Å¿everall grounds, for feare any Å¿hould be miÅ¿Å¿ing, or Å¿ome misfortune befalne any of them; and it hee Å¿hall finde any wanting, let him not reÅ¿t Å¿earching, untill he hath found it; and if it be in danger or Å¿icke, let him not give over himÅ¿elfe if he can, (otherwiÅ¿e let him haÅ¿te to call company and Å¿trength enough) to free it out of harmes way.

Now as touching the grounds themÅ¿elves, as I would not have them too rich, or too rank and deep with graÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o muÅ¿t they not be too barren, Å¿hort, and moÅ¿Å¿ie; for as well in this Å¿ubject, as in all other things, the golden meane is evermore to be preferred. Having thus provided your Å¿elfe of a Stud of the choiceÅ¿t and ableÅ¿t Mares, for age, colour, Å¿hape, and marks, your Stallions alÅ¿o of like attributes your care muÅ¿t be to Å¿ee your Mares well covered, for in this chiefly conÅ¿iÅ¿teth the life and quinteÅ¿Å¿ence of your breeding. Be you therefore marvellous carefull, that neither your Stallion or Mare, have any of theÅ¿e enÅ¿uing defects; viz. neither Moon-eyes, watry-eyes, or Bloud-Å¿hotten-eyes, or other defect in their eyes or Å¿ight, no taint in their wind by Glanders or otherwiÅ¿e, no way Å¿ubject to Mainge, Mallender, Sellender, Splents, Spaven, Curb, Ring-bone, Scratches, Kybed-heeles, or any other the like Å¿orances; that they be not Cock-thropled, but their Throples very looÅ¿e; for let either Stallion or Mare have any of theÅ¿e maladies, then be you well aÅ¿Å¿ured their Colts will take them as hereditary from their Parents: inÅ¿omuch as when you eÅ¿teem your Å¿elfe confident of Å¿uch young HorÅ¿es, you Å¿o much deÅ¿ired to be maÅ¿ter of, you will be miÅ¿taken; for inÅ¿tead of a Stirrier or HorÅ¿e for mannage, you have bred him fit for nought elÅ¿e but the plough; and in the place of a Hunter, he proves a Mil-horÅ¿e; and in hope you had a HorÅ¿e for a CourÅ¿e, he proves for no better uÅ¿e but the Cart; and him you deÅ¿ire to have for your own Pad-Å¿addle, you will be conÅ¿trained to Å¿ell him to a Carrier, to beare a Pack-Å¿addle with a burthen.

To come to intreat of the time moÅ¿t fitting for covering your Mares, let that be Å¿o done, that they may caÅ¿t their Foles in the dead of winter; as either in December, or Ianuary: for during their time of going with Fole, to wit, from the day of their Covering, unto that of their Foling, is commonly 12 months, and 10 dayes; yet Å¿ome do aver, they doe want 11 dayes of 12 moneths, of which computation there is juÅ¿t three weeks oddes: others againe doe affirme, that a Mare goeth but only 11. months and 10 dayes, wherein is greater oddes: but I have found it to be a moÅ¿t certain rule which never did faile me (unleÅ¿Å¿e in a yong Mare upon her firÅ¿t Colt, who will want Å¿ome few dayes of the ordinary account) and long and frequent experience
hath made me to be very perfect, that a Mare goeth (unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ome miÅ¿chance or other accident hath otherwiÅ¿e occaÅ¿ioned) twelve moneths and ten dayes: for when at any time I have been preÅ¿ent when a Mare hath been covered, I have in the very minute entred into my Almanacke, the very day and houre in which Å¿he tooke the HorÅ¿e; and becauÅ¿e I would not be deceived, I have been preÅ¿ent at her foling, and I have found the time never to faile me. And therefore I could wiÅ¿h all breeders to obÅ¿erve with me the Å¿ame courÅ¿e, and they Å¿hall finde this account to fall out juÅ¿t as I have delivered. If your Mare be covered about S. Lucies day, which is the 13 of December, then will Å¿he fole about S. Thomas day the Å¿ame month in the yeare following: But before you Å¿uffer her to be covered, let neither the Stallion or Mare be at graÅ¿Å¿e, but taken into the houÅ¿e, Å¿ixe weekes or a moneth at the leaÅ¿t; during which time, let them be both very well fed with good old Hay and Oates well duÅ¿ted and Å¿ifted, to the end they may have Å¿trength and Å¿eed to performe the office for which you have them. But if you will have your Mare certainly to conceive, then take bloud from both Å¿ides of her necke, and let her bleed at either veine well nigh a quart; which muÅ¿t be done five or Å¿ixe dayes before Å¿he is to be covered; and the next day after her bleeding, give her in a quart of new milke, halfe a iij. of ArtimeÅ¿ia, alias Muggewort, chopped very Å¿mall, a piece of Å¿weet Butter, and â¥ 2. of London Treacle warm; all theÅ¿e put upon the fire till the Butter and Treacle be diÅ¿Å¿olved, and give this to the Mare bloud-warme in the morning faÅ¿ting, and Å¿o the next morning again, and let her drinke be white water. This drink is moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne to cauÅ¿e conception, it provoketh Å¿eed abundantly, it openeth the pores in the body, and cauÅ¿eth the Mare to keep the Å¿eed Å¿he receiveth from the Stallion; Moreover this drinke comforteth the womb and matrix very much: Å¿o as it is great oddes but that Å¿he being thus ordered, will be Å¿ped and conceive, unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he be a Mare of great Å¿terility, which Å¿uppoÅ¿ed, Å¿he is not to be kept for a race or breeding Mare.

Moreover, if you be deÅ¿irous to have your Mare to conceive a HorÅ¿e-colt, rather then a Filly; obÅ¿erve then this leÅ¿Å¿on I Å¿hall here give you, and you Å¿hall finde it an infallible rule, which will never miÅ¿Å¿e, viz. At what time you would have your Mare to be covered, Let it be done, when one of the firÅ¿t five maÅ¿culine Signes do raign, which are either Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Cancer, or Leo; but if Å¿he Å¿hall be covered when any of the Feminine or watery Signes are predominant, as Virgo, Libra Scorpio, Sagittarius, Capricornus, Aquarius, or PiÅ¿ces; then be you confident it will be a Filly. For this have I often tryed, and found it Å¿eldome or never to faile me, eÅ¿pecially if the wind be either WeÅ¿t or North (but WeÅ¿t is beÅ¿t) at the time of her covering, and you will finde this my rule to be moÅ¿t infallible, for experience hath taught it me: And I have attained unto more knowledge by experience, then I was ever able to aÅ¿pire unto, either by reading
and Å¿tudy, or by hearing what others have dictated, taught, or told mee: For we have a maxime, Experience is the beÅ¿t and ableÅ¿t miÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿e and moderatrix.

Now for the manner of the covering of your Mares, let her be brought into Å¿ome place abroad, and there faÅ¿tned to Å¿ome Å¿trong poÅ¿t; then bring out to her Å¿ome Å¿toned Iade firÅ¿t to dally with her, and he will provoke her to an aptitude and deÅ¿ire of coity; which done, let the Stallion be led forth towards her, betwixt two or more luÅ¿ty Å¿trong men who may be able to maÅ¿ter him if he Å¿hould prove unruly, and let him leap her; and let this be done in a morning betimes faÅ¿ting; which done, another man Å¿tanding by with a paile of cold water ready in his hand, in the very time when the HorÅ¿e is diÅ¿mounting, let him caÅ¿t the cold water upon her Å¿hape; which by reaÅ¿on of the coldneÅ¿Å¿e, the Å¿trength of the caÅ¿ter, and the Å¿uddenneÅ¿Å¿e thereof, will cauÅ¿e her to Å¿hrinke in, and truÅ¿Å¿e up her body, and it will be the meanes to make her retaine the Å¿eed in the matrix, otherwiÅ¿e the womb would not peradventure Å¿o Å¿oone encloÅ¿e it, but for Å¿ome time after, howÅ¿oever the womb would draw together, but not Å¿o Å¿uddenly, whereby upon the Mares motion, there might be Å¿ome danger of diÅ¿Å¿olving. Take then away the Stallion, and let the Mare be put into Å¿ome remote place alone, from Å¿ight and hearing of other HorÅ¿es and Mares, but let her neither eate nor drinke in foure hours after, neither let her have any water at all till night, and then give her either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water. After Å¿he hath been thus Covered, you Å¿hall know whether or not Å¿he hath either conceived, or loÅ¿t, or caÅ¿t her Å¿eed, by many evident Å¿ymptomes which will appeare to your eye; for if Å¿he retaineth a good Å¿tomacke to her meat, and Å¿o continueth, if Å¿he doe not neigh at hearing or Å¿ight of other horÅ¿es, if Å¿he do not piÅ¿Å¿e oft times in the day, caÅ¿teth not her eye about gazing continually at every noiÅ¿e Å¿he heareth, pricketh not up her eares, and that in three or foure daies after her Covering, her belly Å¿eemeth to be more gaunt, her hayre more Å¿licke and cloÅ¿e to her skin, Å¿hewing of a brighter colour, and Å¿he Å¿eemeth to fall away and become leane: if (I Å¿ay) any of theÅ¿e Symptomes doe appeare in her, then is it an evident Å¿igne Å¿he hath kept her Å¿eed and conceiveth, but if the contrary appeare in her, then hath Å¿he loÅ¿t it, and engendreth not.

But as for offering her the HorÅ¿e againe ten dayes after, together with Å¿uch like circumÅ¿tances, I hold them impertinent for this place, being Å¿o frequently knowne and practiÅ¿ed, and therefore my labour may well be Å¿pared. But for her keeping and ordring after her Covering, let her not drinke that Å¿he deÅ¿ireth, but continue her with the Å¿ame dyet which formerly Å¿he had before her covering for three weeks or a month after, leÅ¿t the Å¿eed might fortune to be impaired, before the Colt be Å¿ufficiently formed in the womb, and let her be kept Å¿weet and cleane as may be, and that without any labour or exerciÅ¿e during that three weeks or moneth: after which terme you
may if you pleaÅ¿e, inure her to moderate labour, wherein have a Å¿peciall care of foure things: firÅ¿t, that Å¿he be not at any time gallopped, or run off from her wind: Å¿econdly, that Å¿he be not put to carry heavy burthens: thirdly, that Å¿he be neither laboured or travelled in extreame heat: And laÅ¿tly, that her exerciÅ¿e be not Å¿uch which may provoke her to Å¿weat violently, for every of theÅ¿e things will cauÅ¿e her to miÅ¿carry.

Shee being thus with fole: Å¿hee muÅ¿t bee kept in the houÅ¿e untill mid-May at leaÅ¿t, and then let firÅ¿t her Å¿hooes be taken off, her feet pared well, the FruÅ¿h and heeles opened, and plates after the manner of running Å¿hooes (but not to come home to the heeles) Å¿et on; let her run in the drieÅ¿t ground you have, yet not Å¿o Å¿hort of graÅ¿Å¿e, but that Å¿he may at her eaÅ¿e fill her belly at leaÅ¿t once a day, and about the latter end of September, (if not before) let her be very carefully taken into the houÅ¿e, but Å¿o quietly that you Å¿hall not endanger the hurting of her belly, either by the ruÅ¿hing of other HorÅ¿es and Mares againÅ¿t her, or through her unruly leaping, or inconÅ¿iderate bruÅ¿hing againÅ¿t poÅ¿ts, dores, or the like. Let her be kept thus in the houÅ¿e to the time of her foling, and long after, and let her dyet be as before is preÅ¿cribed.

And when the time of her foling approacheth, let her keeper attend carefully upon her, putting her into a houÅ¿e convenient for her, unhaltred and untied, leÅ¿t in foling, the colt receive domage, by reaÅ¿on that Mares doe commonly caÅ¿t their foles Å¿tanding: wherefore let not the roome whereinto you put her, be too Å¿treight, but very warme, (for warmth is a great comfort as well to Mares with fole, as in foling) and let good Å¿tore of Å¿traw be layed, that the Fole may fall from the Mare the Å¿ofter, and be in leÅ¿Å¿e danger of harm, and let her (I Å¿ay) be watched for feare the Fole come not right; and Å¿o Å¿oone as Å¿he hath foled and licked it dry, let her keeper preÅ¿ently milke and Å¿troake her, and that before the Colt doe Å¿ucke her, which will both cauÅ¿e her to give down her milke, making the Å¿ame to multiply, and alÅ¿o keep the Vdder that the milke doe not clod, which if it Å¿hould doe, the Mare might happily in Å¿hort time become dry, whereof if there be any perill, I then adviÅ¿e you to draw as much milke from her as you can; and boyle it with the leaves of Lavender, or Spike, and Å¿o bathe her Vdder therwith warme, continuing Å¿o daily to doe, untill by this meanes you have broken the curd, knobs, and knots, cauÅ¿ing them to be diÅ¿Å¿olved. And as for the water which Å¿he is to drinke for Å¿ome time after her foling, let it be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white water, & a moneth after her foling, give her a MaÅ¿h, putting thereinto the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, or Savin, or the like, which will be a great preÅ¿ervation of the Colt; & then if Å¿he be moderately laboured either at Plough or Harrow, if Å¿he will draw, as well the Mare as Colt will proÅ¿per the better; provided Å¿he be kept from raw meat while Å¿he remaineth in the Stable, by which meanes Å¿he will the Å¿ooner recover
Å¿trength, luÅ¿t, and courage, and have Å¿tore of good milke, which will cauÅ¿e the Colt to thrive the better, and to grow to be of the greater bone, which above all things is a matter of greateÅ¿t conÅ¿equence. And that you Å¿uffer not the Colt to Å¿ucke the Mare when Å¿he commeth from worke, untill Å¿he be throughly cold, leÅ¿t thereby you Å¿urfet the Colt.

Thus much I have thought fit to handle of this Å¿ubject; and albeit I have laboured herein to attaine to brevity, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the premiÅ¿Å¿es well conÅ¿idered, I Å¿hall not greatly offend in prolixity, howÅ¿oever this my manner of breeding being different from the old received cuÅ¿tomes, will not (I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure me) paÅ¿Å¿e voyd of cenÅ¿ure. But as touching old cuÅ¿tomes, thus much I doe averre, that as they are in many caÅ¿es of that force, as no law is able to abrogate; Å¿o on the contrary part, many of them are Å¿o abÅ¿urd and ridiculous, as nothing can be more; for what Å¿aith the civill Law? ThoÅ¿e things which by event or Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e of time are found to be pernicious or hurtfull, even theÅ¿e things ought to be repealed, yea albeit they were at the firÅ¿t found profitable. Which ground holdeth good in nothing Å¿o much as in old cuÅ¿tomes, for of their abÅ¿urdities, I am able to produce inÅ¿tances not a few, howÅ¿oever with many, It is one of Hercules greateÅ¿t labours to beat many a man from his old cuÅ¿tomes be they never Å¿o bad, albeit CuÅ¿tome is a meere tyrant, and his Å¿overaignty moÅ¿t inÅ¿ufferable, as a grave Author very well obÅ¿erveth.

div.head: CHAP. III. How to make and order your Stable.
div.p:
HAving thus waded into this myÅ¿tery of breeding, I hold it a thing very behoovefull to be handled, how your Stable ought to be accommodated. FirÅ¿t therefore your Stable Å¿hould be Å¿cituate where the ayre is wholeÅ¿ome, pure, and good, and the ground dry: the Å¿tructure would be either of free Stone or Bricke, but Bricke is beÅ¿t, moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome and warmeÅ¿t: beÅ¿ides this benefit Brick hath, which Stone hath not, of being very dry, for Stone will weep, and Å¿weat drops of water againÅ¿t raine and miÅ¿ty weather, which begetteth damps, and cauÅ¿eth rhumes in HorÅ¿es. Your Stable ought not to have any unÅ¿avory Gutter, Channell, or Sinke neare to it; no Iakes, HogÅ¿ties, or Hen-rouÅ¿t, whereby to annoy it. It would be alÅ¿o Å¿eeled over head, and have Å¿trong doores, with lockes, bolts, and barres unto it. The Racke would not be made too high, or too low, but placed in an indifferent proportion, and Å¿o artificially Å¿et, that neither the duÅ¿t or hay-Å¿eeds may fall into his
Mane, or upon his necke and face. The Manger would be Å¿et at an indifferent height, made deep, and of one entire piece, as well for Å¿trength, as for conveniency to be kept Å¿weet and cleane. Let the flore be pitched with Flint, and not planked. The windowes would be made with handÅ¿ome Å¿huts and caÅ¿ements, and well glazed, as well to keep out cold and wind, as alÅ¿o (when there may be cauÅ¿e) to let in the coole and freÅ¿h ayre. Againe, take heed there be no lome wall or plaiÅ¿ter, Å¿o neare as that the HorÅ¿e may reach thereto with bis mouth: for upon that he will gnaw, which may doe him much prejudice, and be the cauÅ¿e of much dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, for Lome and Lime are Å¿uffocating things, they will infect and putrifie the bloud, endanger the Lounges, and be no friend to his winde: neither Å¿uffer any dung to lye neare him. Furthermore there would be made a faire Loft wherein to lay Hay, and convenient lodging chambers for your Groomes, whoÅ¿e neareneÅ¿Å¿e, together with their care and vigilancy might prevent many dangers and inconveniences which may accrue unto your HorÅ¿es by night. AlÅ¿o let a neat Saddle-houÅ¿e be contrived with Bings for Provender, and in it PreÅ¿Å¿es, wherein to lay up the Saddles, Bridles, and all other furniture appertaining to Horfes, and an Aqua-duct wherewith to bring water to the Stable. And laÅ¿tly, other Stals would be erected remote, wherein upon occaÅ¿ion to Å¿ever the Å¿icke from the Å¿ound. Many other accoutrements there are belonging to a perfect Stable, as partitions with boards, poÅ¿ts, and barres, with pins driven into every poÅ¿t, whereon to hang Bridles and the like; Å¿helves alÅ¿o faÅ¿tned to the wall Å¿erving for many uÅ¿es, to place neceÅ¿Å¿aries upon, &c. which being known to all men, will be needleÅ¿Å¿e for me here to repeate.

But you may peradventure Å¿tartle at paving, rather then planking your flore, preferring planks as warmer, and much better then flint or a pitched flore can be; as alÅ¿o for that it is a new thing, little practiÅ¿ed, and Å¿eldome heard.

But give me leave (I pray) a little to inform your underÅ¿tanding in this one point, by which means your judgement may fortune to be much bettered. FirÅ¿t therefore, whereas novelty may be objected, I Å¿hall moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily aÅ¿Å¿oile that point, even from the Å¿elfe-Å¿ame ground in the civill Law, which I inÅ¿erted in the concluÅ¿ion of the precedent chapter, viz. That things found to be prejudiciall, ought to be inhibited, although they might be thought needfull, and good in foreknown times. For that paving of Stables is better then planking them,Paving Stab â¢ much b â¢ then pla â¢
ing. I have reaÅ¿ons not a few wherewith to Å¿atisfie a reaÅ¿onable man. FirÅ¿t, it is much more durable and laÅ¿ting, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing the flore to be pitched by an expert workman: Secondly, it is leÅ¿Å¿e charge by much, and therefore in that point the better: Thirdly, for a HorÅ¿e to Å¿tand continually upon a pitched flore, it emboldneth his feet, and treading the more: Fourthly, it is the moÅ¿t excellent thing that may be for Colts, who are unÅ¿hod; for it hardneth their hooves, Å¿o as by cuÅ¿tome they
will be as bold to goe upon Å¿tones, rocky and hard wayes, as HorÅ¿es that are Å¿hod: neither will a pitched flore Å¿uffer the hoofe to goe abroad in manner of an OyÅ¿ter: beÅ¿ides the uÅ¿e thereof will make their hooves more tough, durable, and hollow, inÅ¿omuch as when they Å¿hall come to be Å¿hod, and to have exerciÅ¿e, they will carry their Å¿hooes much longer, better, and with more eaÅ¿e then otherwiÅ¿e, if they had been uÅ¿ed to a planked flore.

The inconvenience of a planked flore.Now on the contrary part, which concerneth the planked flore, that (I Å¿ay) cannot in reaÅ¿on be Å¿o good by many degrees. FirÅ¿t, it is more Å¿lippery, out of which reaÅ¿on a mettled horÅ¿e may Å¿oone be in danger to be lamed or Å¿poyled by Å¿ome Å¿udden Å¿lip, whereof I have had often experience, which a pitched Stable is not Å¿o Å¿ubject unto: Secondly, the planks often times Å¿hrinking, the HorÅ¿e (eÅ¿pecially if he be a Å¿tirrier who is accuÅ¿tomed to curvet in the Stable) may eaÅ¿ily breake a plank, and his foot getting into a hole, or between the planks, the horÅ¿e plunging and Å¿triving, may eaÅ¿ily breake his legge before he Å¿hall be able to get it forth, whereof I have more than once been oculatus teÅ¿tis: Thirdly, when you put forth your horÅ¿es to run at graÅ¿Å¿e all, or the moÅ¿t part of Summer, during which time the Å¿corching heats wil Å¿o Å¿iccicate and dry the planks, which will cauÅ¿e them to warp, and the pinnes which holdeth them down to the joyces will rot, and Å¿o the planks give way, eÅ¿pecially when horÅ¿es (who not being handled in Å¿ome moneths before) becomming wild, rammage, and unruly, are newly brought into the Stable, who feeling the planks to move, yeeld, and give way under them, will fall from Å¿tarting thereat, to Å¿linging, leaping, bounding and plunging, till they have diÅ¿located the planks, and thereby have endangered both themÅ¿elves, the reÅ¿idue of their fellowes, and thoÅ¿e who might come to their help and Å¿uccour, which is a thing very frequent in a flore of this nature: Fourthly, whereas you may imagine that a planked flore is warmer then a paved or pitched, I doe know the contrary; for your pitched flore hath no vaults or channels under them, like as hath your planked, wherewith to convey the water which paÅ¿Å¿eth from the horÅ¿es; hy which meanes the horÅ¿e lyeth over a moyÅ¿t and dampiÅ¿h place and vault; and beÅ¿ides that, the evill Å¿avour of the horÅ¿e-piÅ¿Å¿e will be evermore in their noÅ¿e, which is moÅ¿t unwholeÅ¿ome, noyÅ¿ome, and many times the cauÅ¿e of much infirmity; neither can it in reaÅ¿on be Å¿o warme as is the pitched flore, for that the chinkes and awger-holes bored through the planks (which muÅ¿t alwaies be kept open to let forth the urine) doth give way to the cold wind, which continually aÅ¿cendeth up to the horÅ¿e, as well lying as Å¿tanding, cannot but doe him much dammage. I doe therefore affirme, that if your Groome have a care to litter his horÅ¿e well, Å¿o as he may lye Å¿oft and warme, (which is a prime property appertaining to his office) your horÅ¿e will then proÅ¿per, and like much better upon a pitched flore, then he can upon a planked; provided your flore be laid even, not
higher before than behind, more then Å¿o much that may make the water to avoyd to his hinder feet, where there ought to be a Å¿mall gutter to cauÅ¿e it to paÅ¿Å¿e away, for in raiÅ¿ing your flore Å¿o much, I doe abÅ¿tract from the ancient ill cuÅ¿tome, by reaÅ¿on that a horÅ¿e Å¿tandeth higher before then he doth behind, his hinder legges will Å¿well, and Å¿o he becommeth lame; beÅ¿ides; it giveth him a taint in the backe and kidneyes; and to conclude, his long Å¿tanding in this uneaÅ¿ie manner, begetteth in the poor beaÅ¿t much pain and griefe, and this occaÅ¿ioneth unto him (which would not otherwiÅ¿e be) the putting forth of Windgals, Pains, Scratches, and Å¿uch like noyÅ¿ome Å¿orances.

Another thing may peradventure be thought Å¿trange, which I have handled in the former chapter, where I intreat of breeding; Of the tim â¢ of foling. in that I would have the time of the Mares foling to be, either in December or Ianuary, this being in the very depth of winter, as well when the Å¿eaÅ¿on is commonly coldeÅ¿t, and when little or no graÅ¿Å¿e is to be had, Å¿o as of neceÅ¿Å¿ity the Mare muÅ¿t be houÅ¿ed, and fed with hard meat, whereby her milke will be in Å¿o Å¿mall a proportion, as either to endanger the Å¿tarving of the Colt, or elÅ¿e at leaÅ¿twiÅ¿e keep him Å¿o poor and feeble, as not to be able to grow, thrive, or proÅ¿per to any purpoÅ¿e. To Å¿atisfie this Å¿cruple, I Å¿ay from long experience, that the winter Å¿eaÅ¿on for a Mare to fole in, beyond all peradventure, is the very beÅ¿t, as well for the Mare as the Colt, Å¿uppoÅ¿ing Å¿he be kept in a warme houÅ¿e; and as for her milke, Å¿he will have great plenty, and that much better and more nouriÅ¿hing than that milke which the Colt Å¿hall Å¿ucke from his damme at graÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o as thereby the Colt Å¿hall be more luÅ¿ty, Å¿trong, healthy, greater of bone and Å¿tature,The Colt better no â¢
riÅ¿hed in t â¢â¢ Stable, th â¢ at graÅ¿Å¿e ãâã winter. better able to endure hardineÅ¿Å¿e, better knit, cleaner limbed, more neatly joynted and hooved, and keep his fleÅ¿h better than that Colt that is foled in May, Iune, or any the hotter moneths: and my reaÅ¿on is, that albeit graÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿eth greater plenitude of milke, (which I deny not) yet is not the Å¿ame Å¿o good and nouriÅ¿hing: for the milke which the CoÅ¿t Å¿ucketh at graÅ¿Å¿e, is very thin and watry; and albeit winter food begetteth not Å¿o great a quantity of milke, yet the Å¿ame will be thicker, more Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall, and of greater nutriment, (the Mare being very well fed) which will feed the Colt very fat, and make him more luÅ¿ty and Å¿trong, (as I have Å¿aid) then if the Mare the whole Summer and Winter through, and in all the extremity of the heats and colds had been kept abroad. Moreover, the Colt beÅ¿ides the milke he draweth from the Mare, will alÅ¿o feed with her upon Hay, Oates, Bran, and Å¿uch like food, which will do him much pleaÅ¿ure: But Å¿ome againe will Å¿ay, that their teeth are Å¿o tender, as that they will not be able to chew and eate Å¿uch kinde of hard meates; I anÅ¿wer, they are very much miÅ¿taken, for, not onely my Å¿elfe alone, but Å¿undry others have with me been eye-witneÅ¿Å¿es of the contrary; therefore this needs no further Å¿olution. And wheras it hath been objected unto me, that that Colt which is foled in May, or SolÅ¿tice, in that Å¿eaÅ¿on,
the Mare will have Å¿tore of milke, thus much I doe ingenuouÅ¿ly confeÅ¿Å¿e, but then what manner of milke will it be? None other then Å¿uch as Å¿hall be marvellous thin and watriÅ¿h, (as I Å¿aid before) which abundance will alÅ¿o faile, even when the Colt hath moÅ¿t need thereof, that is, when the Colt beginneth to come up to Å¿ome Å¿trength, and at what time he Å¿hould receive moÅ¿t nutriment, to wit, when the winter commeth on, whoÅ¿e Snows, FroÅ¿ts, cold raines, and Flouds; will not a little nip and pinch the Colt, and enfeeble the Mare in Å¿uch terrible and deÅ¿perate manner, that Å¿he will want her former plenty of food, warme and dry lodging, and other neceÅ¿Å¿ary reliefe and Å¿uÅ¿tentation, and Å¿o in like manner, her abundance of milke, at what time her poore Colt Å¿hould depend upon the enfeebled Mare, who is not able to Å¿upply its own need: by meanes whereof it muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily fall out, that Å¿he muÅ¿t bring both her Å¿elfe and her Colt to extreame poverty, not being able to Å¿uÅ¿taine her own life, much leÅ¿Å¿e her Colts and her own, and Å¿o become feeble before winter be halfe Å¿pent; and over and above all this, the Colt will by his running abroad with the Mare, become Å¿o Å¿alvage and wilde, as that if any infirmity Å¿hould happen to Å¿eize upon it, its own unrulineÅ¿Å¿e will be Å¿o great, that the cure may thereby become the more difficile: for to Å¿peake truely, infinite have been, and daily are the numbers of Colts; yea, and thoÅ¿e many times rightly bred, which have miÅ¿carried and periÅ¿hed in this nature.

I doe therefore conclude, and as a friend to my Country averre, that the ableÅ¿t way to breed up the beÅ¿t and moÅ¿t Å¿erviceable HorÅ¿es, is (as I have before inculcated) after this methode and none other; and therefore I am bold to adviÅ¿e all noble Gentlemen who are lovers of good HorÅ¿es, and of this myÅ¿tery, to make triall, and to put theÅ¿e my rudiments in execution, and he will never (I doe well aÅ¿Å¿ure me) hereafter, either alter or Å¿werve from them; for of this kinde of breeding, I have had more then forty yeares good experience: during which time, I intimated theÅ¿e my grounds to a Knight, an intimate friend of mine, who was a great lover of good HorÅ¿es, and as great a Breeder, as a lover of them, and very well verÅ¿ed in HorÅ¿e-man-Å¿hip, who hearing my reaÅ¿ons, and throughly digeÅ¿ting them, approved of them Å¿o well, as that he fell to follow theÅ¿e my inÅ¿tructions, and eÅ¿teeming them Å¿ufficient, would never be brought from them after; he affirming, no way comparable to this: for he found by plaine demonÅ¿tration, that whereas in former times in breeding (as commonly he did, ten or twelve Colts yearly; when they came to Backing, Riding, and proofe of thoÅ¿e ten or twelve, he thought himÅ¿elfe well appayed, and his labour and coÅ¿t well beÅ¿towed, if two or three at the moÅ¿t proved right, and to his minde; whereas ever after in ten Colts thus bred and reared up, hardly any one miÅ¿Å¿ed, which proved not right and to his good liking: and this manner of breeding, made him more in love with this myÅ¿tery, then ever before, reaÅ¿on dictating it Å¿o well
unto him. For, moÅ¿t certain it is, when the Stallion and Mare are both right, and have all their true attributes, and the time, Å¿eaÅ¿on, and manner of breeding, with all circumÅ¿tances thereunto belonging, punctually and in every point duly obÅ¿erved; it will be a hard matter for the Colt to prove ill: but if otherwiÅ¿e, then marvell not if the Colt anÅ¿wer not your expectation, according to the Greeke Adage, which Å¿aith; ã in non-Latin alphabet ã , Iade Sire, Iade Colt. Wherefore if upon tryall it Å¿hall appeare to you, that you have hitherto been to Å¿eek of the true grounds, and of the originall cauÅ¿es why you have not bred Å¿o many good HorÅ¿es as you have deÅ¿ired, doe not then wonder that The cauÅ¿e of your errour, and of Å¿o great a miÅ¿chiefe hath Å¿tolne upon, and deceived you: for the great decay of good HorÅ¿es, together with thoÅ¿e infinite errors in breeding, and HorÅ¿e-man-Å¿hip; that increaÅ¿e that is, being in Å¿o vile a manner of baÅ¿e Iades; have Å¿o Å¿warmed in this kingdome, as that (a lamentable caÅ¿e to be related) of one rightly bred, we now adayes have a thouÅ¿and Iades; to the great diÅ¿honour, diÅ¿profit, and weakning both of King and Country. And what is the reaÅ¿on? I Å¿hall in a word tell you: It is impoÅ¿sible for a man to bring his work to its wiÅ¿hed perfection, who never knew the true grounds of his principles.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Marks, Colours, and Shapes of HorÅ¿es.
div.p:
THe next thing befitting our Å¿ubject, is to Å¿peake (albeit briefly) of the Colours, Marks, and perfect Shapes of HorÅ¿es: Wherein I will firÅ¿t deliver other mens opinions, and laÅ¿tly, mine owne. Some there be who hold that Colours, Marks, and Shapes are little materiall to make up a perfect HorÅ¿e, which I will not contradict, for my meaning is not to traduce or controule any man: but this I will Å¿ay, that if a good horÅ¿e have theÅ¿e properties adherent to his goodneÅ¿Å¿e, then is he queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e in much better eÅ¿teem, for if beauty be added to his other inward vertues, then is he (like to the Nightingale in the beginning of Aprill, heard and hearkened unto, more praiÅ¿e-worthy, and better prized. For a horÅ¿e, who if he be good and Å¿erviceable, well metled, bold, and hardy, of a gentle condition, of a round and comely trot and pace, lightly and well borne, obedient mouthed, Å¿ure on foot, tough, Å¿trong, and eaÅ¿ie; will (I Å¿ay) not Å¿uch a horÅ¿e be well eÅ¿teemed? But if together with theÅ¿e good properties, there Å¿hall be added, good colour, true marks, and perfect Å¿hape, which cauÅ¿eth him to appeare moÅ¿t beautifull to all beholders: will not theÅ¿e endowments Å¿et him the better forth? and cauÅ¿e him to be the better eÅ¿teemed,
of every man deÅ¿ired, and much more money offered for him? nay, Å¿hall not you (whoÅ¿e the horÅ¿e is) be come unto, be Å¿ued unto, have letters Å¿ent you from Å¿undry friends, and will not your Å¿elfe prize him at a higher rate than otherwiÅ¿e you would have done? yes aÅ¿Å¿uredly; and hereof I make no queÅ¿tion. True it is, and I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e no leÅ¿Å¿e, that a horÅ¿e may be very good, and performe his function very well, who hath neither good colour, true marks, or perfect Å¿hape; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e theÅ¿e extrinÅ¿ecall vertues are more frequently to be found, and better obÅ¿erved to be in good horÅ¿es, in whom are colour, markes, and Å¿hape; than in horÅ¿es which are otherwiÅ¿e. Wherefore becauÅ¿e theÅ¿e things are termed exteriour vertues, and therefore takes its object from the eye onely, I will conjoyne them altogether in this my diÅ¿courÅ¿e, and Å¿hew you what hath been, and is, the opinion of both ancient and moderne Writers. Virgil in his Georgickes, handling moÅ¿t accurately Å¿undry points of husbandry, among other things in his third book of Georgicks, deÅ¿cribeth the horÅ¿e, as well his breeding, and his Å¿everall Å¿orts of imployments, as his colour, Å¿hape, and markes; yea, and that in moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿ite manner: And thus he beginneth:
Let the Males goe
Without reÅ¿traint to venery, and Å¿o
By timely breeds, preÅ¿erve a perfect kind.
Their firÅ¿t age beÅ¿t, all wretched mortals finde;
After diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, and old age doe come,
Labour, and death's inexorable doome.
There Å¿till will be, whoÅ¿e bodies with thy will
Thou would'Å¿t wiÅ¿h chang'd. Therefore repaire them Å¿till;
And leÅ¿t thy kinde quite loÅ¿t thou finde too late,
Prevent the loÅ¿Å¿e, and yearely p â¢ opagate.
And Å¿uch a choice you muÅ¿t in HorÅ¿es make,
By him, whom you for Stallion meane to take,
As hope of all the race, elect with care
Even from a tender Fole Å¿uch Colts as are
Of generous race, Å¿traight, when at firÅ¿t they'r fol'd,
Walke proudly, their Å¿oft joynts Å¿carce knit, and bold,
Dare leade the way, into the rivers enter,
And dare themÅ¿elves on unknowne Å¿eas to venture.
Not frighted with vaine noyÅ¿es, lofty neck'd,
Short headed Å¿lender belly'd, and bro â¢ d back'd;
Broad and full breÅ¿ted; let his colour be
Browne-bay, or gray, white proves not commonly,
Nor fleÅ¿h-colour, when warres alarums Å¿ound,
His noÅ¿trils gather, and breath fire, no ground
Can hold his Å¿haking joynts, his feare advances
His thicke-curl'd Mane on his right Å¿houlder dances.
His back-bone broad and Å¿trong, the hollow ground
Trampled beneath his hard round hoofe doth Å¿ound.
Such was that HorÅ¿e, which Spartan Pollux tam'd,
Fierce Cyllarus, and Mars his HorÅ¿es fam'd
By th'old Greek Poets, or thoÅ¿e two that drew
Achilles Chariot: Å¿uch a Å¿hape and hew
At his wives comming, flying Saturne tooke,
And all high Pelion with Å¿hrill neighings Å¿hooke,
Yet when diÅ¿eaÅ¿e or age have brought to nought
This HorÅ¿es Å¿pirit, let him at home be wrought,
Nor Å¿pare his baÅ¿e old age. A horÅ¿e grown old
Though he in vaine attempt it oft, is cold
To venery, and when he's brought to try
(Like that great Å¿trengthleÅ¿Å¿e fire in Å¿tubble dry)
In vaine he rages; therefore firÅ¿t 'tis good
To marke his age, his courage and his brood,
With other arts; how Å¿ad a horÅ¿e will be
When overcome, how proud of victory.
DoÅ¿t thou not Å¿ee, when through the field in Å¿peed
Two racing Chariots from the LiÅ¿ts are fled,
The young mens hearts all riÅ¿e, as forth they Å¿tart,
And feare with joy confounded Å¿trikes each heart?
They give their HorÅ¿e the raynes, and laÅ¿h them on,
Their hurried wheeles enflaming, as they run;
Now low they goe, now riÅ¿e as they would flye
Through th' empty ayre, and mount up to the sky:
No reÅ¿ting, no delay, a Å¿andy cloud
Darkens the ayre, they on through Å¿houtings loud
Of Å¿tanders by, all Å¿weat, and fom'd doe flye,

div.p: And the Å¿ame French-man Å¿heweth, what be alÅ¿o the properties and mark â¢ s which a good horÅ¿e ought to have;Of the colours of a HorÅ¿e. whereof three are to be of an Oxe, three of a Foxe, three of a Hart, and three of a Woman. div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Office of the Rider and Groome.
div.p: HAving now bred Colts according to my inÅ¿tructions, which you may well hope will prove to your mind and beÅ¿t liking, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ome things there yet remaine whereof duly to conÅ¿ider; and that is; that when you have thus (I Å¿ay) bred your Colts which you may very well hope are right, your eye and judgement for Shape, Colour, and Markes promiÅ¿Å¿ing no leÅ¿Å¿e; it then behooveth you to be very cautelous in the Handling, Breaking, Riding, and wel-ording them, whether you intend them for Menage, CourÅ¿e, Hunting, or the Rode; in any of which an eÅ¿peciall care would bee had to provide you of Riders, Groomes, and Keepers, Å¿uch as Å¿hall be knowne to be expert in their faculties; in which principally conÅ¿iÅ¿teth either their direct making, or marring, and finall ruine. For we cannot Å¿ay, that a Colt (yet unhandled) at three or foure yeares of age, is or can be a perfect good HorÅ¿e, whilÅ¿t he remaineth (I Å¿ay) unridden, unhandled, and unmade, untill Å¿uch time, as he hath been taken up into the Stable, made gentle, taught to leade, content to be Å¿hod, to be Back't, Broken, Ridden, Wayed, Mouthed; and to bee briefe, brought to his utmoÅ¿t perfection. By this time, you will come to bee able to know and underÅ¿tand his true Worth, Vertue, Nature, DiÅ¿poÅ¿ition, and Quality, his Pace, his Raine, or Bearing his Toughnes, Strength, and Affability, his true worth and goodneÅ¿Å¿e, and what other attributes are befitting a generous HorÅ¿e.

What manner of man a Rider ought to be.His Rider therefore muÅ¿t be an expert and able HorÅ¿eman, and his Keeper every way as Å¿ufficient; otherwiÅ¿e what defects you Å¿hall finde in your HorÅ¿e, are not to be attributed to him, but either to his Rider, or to the Groome. Wherefore your care muÅ¿t be, that both Rider and Groome be knowne Å¿ufficient, leÅ¿t for want of true Å¿cience, your HorÅ¿e may eft-Å¿oones be brought to aÅ¿Å¿ume Å¿uch Å¿iniÅ¿ter conditions, from which he will not be weaned in a long time after. It is impoÅ¿sible for any man to teach that which hee never learned. And further a venerable Author Å¿aith, He that will be his owne Å¿choller, Å¿hall be Å¿ure to have a foole to his maÅ¿ter. For â¢ Å¿Å¿uredly, great folly and weakeneÅ¿Å¿e is to be obÅ¿erved in that man, who Å¿hall take upon him to be a maÅ¿ter or teacher, who never knew what it was to be a Å¿choller.

But I am loath to wade any further into this Å¿ubject, for this is not that I intended when I began: yet Å¿ithence I am thus farre imbarqued in it, I will give you a few rules which may be profitable both to the MaÅ¿ter and the Groome, which if they be well obÅ¿erved, you may undoubtedly keep your horÅ¿e long in very good eÅ¿tate and health.Rules f â¢â¢ be obÅ¿ â¢â¢
FirÅ¿t therefore before you put your horÅ¿e to graÅ¿Å¿e (I Å¿peake now of horÅ¿es which have been ridden and exerciÅ¿ed) Å¿ome foure or five dayes; or a week before, take bloud from him according as your diÅ¿cretion or the Ferrier by his Art Å¿hall dictate: the next day after, give gun the drink of Diapente, mentioned in lib. 2. chap. 7. Seaventhly, obÅ¿erve alÅ¿o if he put forth his foote more than uÅ¿ually hee was wont to doe; then aÅ¿Å¿ure your Å¿elfe the griefe lyeth either in the knee or Å¿houlder; if it be Å¿o, preÅ¿ently advertiÅ¿e the Ferrier, who knoweth what is beÅ¿t to be done with him. Eightly, when you are to take your journey with him, water him in the HouÅ¿e, and give him his break-faÅ¿t of good cleane Oates, Å¿weet, and wel-Å¿ifted; then bridle him and tie him up to the Rack, then curry, dreÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿addle him, but draw not the girts too Å¿treight till you come to take his back; then preÅ¿ently caÅ¿t his cloath over him leaÅ¿t he take cold, and when you come to take his back, draw his girts Å¿treight, and Å¿o on God's

This watering him thus, will very much refreÅ¿h him, cauÅ¿e him to forget his weariÅ¿omeneÅ¿Å¿e, and when he Å¿hall come to eate, it will be with very good appetite, which otherwiÅ¿e he would not have done. A mile at leaÅ¿t before you come to your journies end, Å¿lack your pace, and begin to go more Å¿oftly, to the end he may not be too hot when he Å¿halbe Å¿et up, have him without delay into the Stable warme, well littered up to the belly; but take heed you Å¿uffer him not to be either walked, or waÅ¿hed, for theÅ¿e two things are very pernitious, and moÅ¿t dangerous for him, and the cauÅ¿e of more Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿orances, and death to HorÅ¿es, then of all other things beÅ¿ides. So Å¿oone as you have brought him into the Stable, the firÅ¿t thing you doe, off with your Coate, and tie him up to the empty Rack; then litter him up to the belly, ungird him, take off his Saddle, rub his back with Å¿peed, and put his cloath upon him, and upon that his Saddle againe, and gird him with his SurÅ¿ingle, then make cleane his Å¿tirrops, Å¿tirrop-leathers and Girts, and rubbe him downe, both Legges, Belly, Body, BreaÅ¿t, Head, Face, and Neck, and Å¿o Å¿tuffe him up with cleane dry Å¿traw, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o upon the Bit an houre, evermore looking upon him leaÅ¿t he Å¿weat a new, which if you Å¿hall perceive, then to alay it, take away Å¿ome of the Å¿traw wherewith he is Å¿tuffed, and hee will coole againe; if you finde him in good temper, unbridle him, and waÅ¿h his mouth with water and Å¿alt, and waÅ¿h alÅ¿o his Bit, and Å¿o bridle him up againe, and give him Å¿ome good Hay in his Rack to champ upon, for halfe an houres Å¿pace. The next morning, come to him early; and firÅ¿t obÅ¿erve whether or not he hath layne downe; then looke upon his Ordure, whether it be laxative or coÅ¿tive, or if he hath avoyded any greaÅ¿e, which if he hath, give him with his Oates, a handfull or two of Hemp-Å¿eed, and Å¿o order him as you are accuÅ¿tomed, or otherwiÅ¿e as you in diÅ¿cretion doe find to be moÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite. Tenthly, as touching the furniture and capariÅ¿on which the horÅ¿e is to weare, the Groome muÅ¿t be carefull to keep them clean, bright, and handÅ¿ome: the Saddles, after Å¿weating and travell, well ayred in the Sun and wind, and after beaten and duÅ¿ted, the Å¿tirrops wiped cleane, with the Å¿trops and other Å¿uch like leathers thereto belonging and appertaining, and Å¿o put up Å¿afe and handÅ¿omely with their caÅ¿es and coverings upon them to preÅ¿erve them from duÅ¿t: the foot cloaths (if he have any under his charge) cleanÅ¿ed, bruÅ¿hed, and neatly folded up; the Bits taken from the Head-Å¿tals, and cleane waÅ¿hed, dryed before the fire; and wrapped up in an oyly cloath to keep them from ruÅ¿t and canker, and the BoÅ¿Å¿es carefully alÅ¿o made clean, together with their Bits, and Å¿o laid up in the PreÅ¿Å¿e or CheÅ¿t made for Å¿uch like purpoÅ¿e. sp.speaker: Hippophyl.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: VVE adminiÅ¿ter according to the nature of the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e, for that the pains in the head are Å¿everall and diÅ¿tinct diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, and therefore have Å¿everall cures.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A judicious and cautelous obÅ¿ervation is it whereby we doe know and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h all Å¿orts of maladies: for the HorÅ¿e being a dumb creature without reaÅ¿on and Å¿peech,Ach in th â¢ head. is not able (like as man can) to tell you where his paine lyeth, and therefore it muÅ¿t be the eye and judgement of the Ferrier, to be able to obÅ¿erve his true Å¿ymptomes whereby he may goe right to accompliÅ¿h the cure, otherwiÅ¿e he muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity faile. sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.

But not to verberate the Ayre; I affirme that a HorÅ¿e hath his Braines in as compleate meaÅ¿ure, albeit (as I have but now touched) not in Å¿o great a quantity as other beaÅ¿ts have, but in as ample, Å¿olid, and Å¿ufficient manner as any other living creature, together with the skinne, which ArtiÅ¿ts doe call Pannicles, which doth adhere to the bones conducted by the Cells or Conducts by which the Vitall Spirits doe give Å¿ome feeling, Å¿enÅ¿e, & motion to the body, from whence proceeds the cauÅ¿es of diÅ¿eaÅ¿es and Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e. And the Cure and Drinke is this: viz. Take wheate meale Å¿ix pound, or as much as will bring the Ingredients into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, AnniÅ¿eeds two ounces, Comin two ounces, wild or baÅ¿tard Saffron one dramme & half, white Wine foure pints, Fennugreke one ounce & two drammes, BrimÅ¿tone one ounce & half; good Sallet Oyle one pint & two ounces, EngliÅ¿h hony one pound & half; powder and Å¿earce what is to bee powdred and Å¿earced, then compound them together, and make it into one body into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and Å¿o keep it in a cleane Gally-pot cloÅ¿e covered for your uÅ¿e. And when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e it, make a Pill or Ball thereof, of the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a mans fiÅ¿t, and Å¿o lave and diÅ¿Å¿olve it into two Gallons of faire water; till it bee all molten into the water: Let your HorÅ¿e drinke hereof Å¿o long as you pleaÅ¿e hoth morning and evening, and let him have none other water to drinke, to the end he may be the better compelled to drinke of the Water, which in the end he will doe, and like it very well. â.

Of this cataplaÅ¿me I have made often uÅ¿e, and I doe finde it to be a Å¿overaigne Receit for many infirmities; it alÅ¿o preventeth much inward Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e; it raiÅ¿eth and battleth a HorÅ¿e much better than either GraÅ¿Å¿e or Provender; and it giveth him Life, Spirit, and Stomacke, and keepeth him in perfect health.
Our ordinary Country Smiths have yet another drinke, which they adminiÅ¿ter upon all inward cauÅ¿es, and truely it doth oft times hit right, eÅ¿pecially in cold cauÅ¿es, viz.

Take Fennugrick, Turmerick, Graynes, AnniÅ¿eeds, Licoris,All DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es.
