Long-Pepper, Comin, of each halfe an ounce, and of Saffron one dram: and of hearbs, take Selendine, Rue, Pelamontine, IÅ¿op, Time and RoÅ¿emary, of each, like much, but yet no more then will make of them all but halfe a handfull, FirÅ¿t chop Å¿mall theÅ¿e hearbs, and put them into a quart of good Ale, and when they have boyled a while, put in your Å¿pices finely powdred, and then boyle them again
with a Å¿mall fire; then take it from the fire, and Å¿traine it, and put to the liquor the quantity of an egge of Å¿weet butter, and halfe an ounce of London Treacle, give this to your HorÅ¿e bloud warme, and and ride him moderately after, and then Å¿et him up warme and well littered, letting him faÅ¿t foure houres after, and let his drink be either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water. This is very good againÅ¿t Feavers, Colds, and the Yellowes. â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Met not long Å¿ince with a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called S. Anthonies Fire, I pray is there Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yes Sir, there is Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, but it Å¿o Å¿eldome comes to a HorÅ¿e, as that few Ferriers have had occaÅ¿ion to cure the Å¿ame; by reaÅ¿on very few know it, and therefore marvell not in that they cannot cure the Å¿ame. Saint Anthonies Fire is that burneth in the fleÅ¿h moÅ¿t extreamely, and hath in it Å¿o great malice, as that look what you do apply to the place (unleÅ¿Å¿e you hit the cure right) it will doe it no good, but more harme, much after the nature of a Noli me tangere, or wild-fire. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is alÅ¿o called by Å¿ome the Å¿hingles in a HorÅ¿e, and like as the DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e it Å¿elf is very rare, and Å¿eldome known in a HorÅ¿e, Å¿o alÅ¿o is the cure as uncouth and Å¿trange. For my part I will not profeÅ¿Å¿e my Å¿elfe to be any whit more skilfull then indeed I am: this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e I never yet obÅ¿erved to be in any HorÅ¿e: I only have heard Å¿ome Ferriers talke thereof, but yet I never heard but of one man, who was ever truely able to make a Cure thereof; and this was a Knight of very good worÅ¿hip who taught it me, he averring confidently unto me; how that he had cured three Å¿everall HorÅ¿es of this very malady. I asked him whence this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e proceedeth, and what are the Å¿ymptomes whereby to know the Å¿ame; he anÅ¿wered me, that he could never rightly come to be mathematically aÅ¿Å¿ured how it breedeth, or occurreth to the HorÅ¿e, but by gueÅ¿Å¿e onely, and that himÅ¿elfe thought it came from Å¿ome cholericke bloud paÅ¿Å¿ing to his head into the braine and pannicles, which cauÅ¿eth the HorÅ¿e to become Å¿tarke mad, yea Å¿o truely mad, as to be deprived of his memory, in not knowing his Keeper, or any other body elÅ¿e; yea his fury is Å¿o great, as to reÅ¿iÅ¿t Å¿tripes, to Å¿light and contemne correction be it never Å¿o Å¿evere, he will endeavour what in him lyeth to perpetrate what miÅ¿chiefe he is able, by biting, Å¿triking, and endangering whom or whatÅ¿oever thing commeth into his way, and when he cannot have his minde of living creatures whereupon to wreake his malice, then will he doe it partly upon dead creatures, by biting and gnawing the Manger and Racke-Å¿taves, and by Å¿triking the poÅ¿ts and barres with his heeles, and partly upon himÅ¿elfe by beating his head againÅ¿t the wall and ground;S. Anthonies fire. he will alÅ¿o forÅ¿ake both his meat and Å¿leep, or naturall reÅ¿t, untill he dyeth, if he be not in time cured, which is thus.

Take firÅ¿t help enough, and caÅ¿t him, which done, take a worme which groweth in a Fullers TeaÅ¿ell, and put this worme alive, and without any hurt into a quill: then Å¿lit the skin of the fore-head of the horÅ¿e under the fore-top, and open the Å¿ame round about with your cornet, making a concavity an inch round every way and better, betwixt the skin and the bone: which done, blow the Å¿aid Worme out of the quill into the place which you made hollow as aforeÅ¿aid; but take heed you doe not kill the Worme in Å¿titching up the skin againe, becauÅ¿e that the Worme may not get forth: and after twenty dayes the Worm will dye, and in that time the HorÅ¿e will be throughly cured. This cure was taught me by the aforeÅ¿aid Noble Knight, with which he affirmed to me, that he had cured 3 or 4 horÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Å¿ay you to an Anticor?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I Å¿ay it is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e whereunto HorÅ¿es are oft times enclined, and it commeth Å¿undry wayes, to wit, Å¿ometimes with too much feeding without exerciÅ¿e, Å¿ometimes of too hard and immoderate riding or other labour; both which waies the bloud of the creature becommeth corrupted and inflamed, which maketh its reÅ¿idence in and about the heart, which if it Å¿hould not have a way to make its vent, it would quickly kill him, by which meanes many good HorÅ¿es dye Å¿uddenly, and the cauÅ¿e unknowne. This DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e is apparent to the eye by a Å¿welling which will ariÅ¿e in the middle of the breaÅ¿t juÅ¿t againÅ¿t the heart from whence it taketh its name, which if it be not Å¿oone prevented, will aÅ¿cend to the throat, and then it is certaine death. It commeth likewiÅ¿e by Å¿urfets taken by heats and colds, Å¿ometimes alÅ¿o by Feavers, which are malignant, and Å¿ometimes againe by feeding upon unwholeÅ¿ome meats. The Å¿ignes to know this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e before the Å¿welling doe appeare are theÅ¿e: he will be Å¿icke and grone many times when he is layed, he will hang down his head, and forÅ¿ake his meat; and then if he Å¿hould deÅ¿ire to eate, what meat he loveth beÅ¿t, whether Hay, GraÅ¿Å¿e, Provender, or Bread, lay it upon the ground before him, and if he hath a minde to eate thereof, albeit he make proffer to bring his mouth towards it, yet he Å¿hall not be able to reach it, but will Å¿ooner famiÅ¿h: when you doe perceive the Å¿welling to appeare, firÅ¿t draw bloud from both the Plate-veynes, but if you cannot finde them, then let him bloud on both Å¿ides of the necke to a good proportion; which done, you may give him the drinke of Diapente with Beere or Ale, putting thereinto one ounce of browne Å¿ugar candy, and halfe an ounce of London Treacle, which will drive the Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e and griefe from his heart; which done, annoynt the Å¿welling with this Oyntment.

Take Hogges greaÅ¿e, Bores greace, and BaÅ¿ilicon,Anticor. of each three ounces, incorporate all theÅ¿e well into one body, and annoynt and
rub the Å¿welling therewith every day till it come to a Å¿oftneÅ¿Å¿e, and then open it, and let forth all the corrupted matter: then waÅ¿h the Sore with your Coperas water mentioned in lib. 2. cap. 10. Â§ 4. and then put in your green Oyntment preÅ¿cribed you in capite ibidem, and it will be Å¿oon whole. â Thus have I cured many HorÅ¿es of this DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and I never failed if the HorÅ¿e had not been Å¿welled too high towards the throat or necke, before I took him in hand. â But MaÅ¿ter Blundeviles and MaÅ¿ter Markhams cure for an Anticor, is thus.

FirÅ¿t they let him bloud in the plate-veins, and then they give him this drinke. Take a quart of MalmeÅ¿ey, and put thereto halfe a quarterne of Sugar, and of Cinamon two ounces, and Å¿o give it him bloud-warme, and keep him warme in the Stable, eÅ¿pecially his breaÅ¿t, that no winde doe offend him; and for his drinke, let it be warm MaÅ¿hes, and Å¿uch meat as he will eate. And if the Å¿welling doe appeare, then beÅ¿ides letting him bloud, they doe Å¿trike the Å¿welling in divers places with their flegme, that the corruption may goe forth, and annoynt the place with warme Hogges greaÅ¿e, and that will cauÅ¿e it to weare away, or elÅ¿e grow to a head if it be kept warme. Thus MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, and MaÅ¿ter Markhams cure is in effect the very Å¿ame. MaÅ¿ter Markham alÅ¿o preÅ¿cribeth MalmeÅ¿ey and Diapente, which is uÅ¿ed alÅ¿o by others, and it is very good: and he alÅ¿o Å¿aith that Å¿ome do adminiÅ¿ter Doctor Stephens water, whith he affirmeth he hath Å¿een to have wrought in this kinde Å¿trange effects. For my part I Å¿ubmit, for that theÅ¿e Receits Å¿eeme very probable; howÅ¿oever I never did experiment any but that onely which I firÅ¿t inÅ¿erted, which I had of a famous Ferrier in France, and therefore I finding mine to be infallible, made tryall of none other.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Attaint upper. VVHat is that you doe call an Vpper Attaint?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p: It is none other thing but a Å¿welling of the maÅ¿ter or Back-Å¿inew of the fore-legge above the PaÅ¿tern-joynt, and moÅ¿t commonly commeth by an over-reach; that is, when the HorÅ¿e in running either down a hill, or upon deeps, or upon or over-thwart high furrowes of plowed lands, or upon other evill or uneven grounds, doe Å¿trike the toe of his hinder-foot againÅ¿t the great Å¿inew of the fore-leg. This I Å¿ay, we terme an Vpper Attaint.

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: How may a man come to know aÅ¿Å¿uredly that the griefe lyeth in that Å¿inew?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Your eye and hand (Sir) will Å¿hew it you very palpably; for the Å¿inew will Å¿well, and burne, and be Å¿ore, and the HorÅ¿e will hault therewith.

p.hi: What cure have you for it?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: We uÅ¿e to apply to the place a charge reÅ¿tringent which muÅ¿t be Å¿iccative.

p.hi: I Å¿hould rather think that by applying Å¿uppling or mollifying Oyles or Vnguents, you might cure it Å¿ooner and much better.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Herein Sir, under your favour you are much miÅ¿taken: For all things that are Å¿uppling are moÅ¿t noxious unto theÅ¿e kinde of Maladies, by reaÅ¿on that all Oyles and unguents will cauÅ¿e the Sinew to Å¿well much more than otherwiÅ¿e; and therefore we do apply Å¿iccative and drying things. Some uÅ¿e Cauterizings, which indeede will cure, and Å¿et the HorÅ¿e upright againe, but therein are two inconveniences; to wit: FirÅ¿t, albeit it taketh away his paine Å¿o as hee deÅ¿iÅ¿teth from haulting, yet will the place be ever after Å¿welled, which wilbe a continuall eye-Å¿ore, during his life; Secondly, the markes and Å¿troakes where the Iron went wilbe ever after Å¿eene, making the haire of a different colour; both which are great blemiÅ¿hes to the HorÅ¿e.

p.hi: Wherein then conÅ¿iÅ¿teth your beÅ¿t Cure in this caÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I alwaies uÅ¿e for a Sorance of this nature to apply this enÅ¿uing Charge.

Take Cantharides two ounces, MaÅ¿ticke foure penniworth,Attaint â¢
per or ba â¢ Å¿inew Å¿pra â¢
Venice Turpentine two penniworth, Euforbium foure drammes, Black-RoÅ¿in Å¿ix ounces, Aqua-fortis two drammes: beate the Cantharides and Euforbium into fine powder; then firÅ¿t melt the MaÅ¿ticke and Black-RoÅ¿in, then put in your Turpentine, which Å¿o Å¿oone as it is molten, put in your Cantharides and Euforbium, and let all boyle together, keeping them Å¿tirring, and have a Å¿peciall care it boyle not over; and when you have taken it from the fire, put in your Aqua-fortis, and Å¿o Å¿tir them well together, and put it into a glaÅ¿Å¿e or gally-pot, and Å¿o keepe it for your uÅ¿e. And when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e the Å¿ame, firÅ¿t waÅ¿h and bath the grieved place well, then with your Splatter, Å¿pread it upon the place being made warme, and clap flox upon it of the Å¿ame colour, and give him reÅ¿t, and he will doe well. But he muÅ¿t have time, and after a weeke that hee hath beene thus charged, let him be put forth to graÅ¿Å¿e if it be not in Winter, or the Winter or cold weather approaching. â. Another.

Take the whites of two new-layed Egges, and the powder of Bole-Armonack, and the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, incorporate theÅ¿e very well together with the powder of Sanguis draconis, and having Å¿haven away the haire as aforeÅ¿aid, Å¿pread it good and thick upon the grieved place, adding Å¿till more every three daies for fifteene dayes together, and then put him forth to graÅ¿Å¿e, and let him run a whole March, and after Å¿o long as you Å¿hall thinke to bee Å¿ufficient, and he wilbe Å¿ound againe. â. This I have alÅ¿o made tryall of, and I have found it to be right good.

A French MarÅ¿hall taught me a Medicine for an Attaint or Over-reach, whereof I did never make uÅ¿e; howbeit he proteÅ¿ted unto me he thought it one of the beÅ¿t cures that he could ever know, and I my Å¿elfe Å¿aw him dreÅ¿Å¿e a HorÅ¿e therewith, but how the HorÅ¿e became
cured I had not time to know, by reaÅ¿on I departed from Orleans before the Cure was performed. And the Cure was this. Take one or two handfuls of Saxafrage, and all the Sewet of a Loine of Mutton, and a pint of white Wine; chop the Hearb, and mince the Sewet very Å¿mall; and Å¿o boyle all theÅ¿e together, which being thus well boyled, take a Å¿ufficient quantity of HorÅ¿e-dung newly made by a HorÅ¿e that goeth to graÅ¿Å¿e, and putting it to the other Ingredients, worke it to a Salve, and apply it plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e to the place good hot, renewing it twice every day for Å¿o long time as you Å¿hall think to be convenient.

Now MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, and MaÅ¿ter Markham doe both agree in the Cure of an Attaint which is thus: FirÅ¿t, waÅ¿h and bath the place with warme Water, and Å¿have the haire Å¿o farre as the Å¿welling goeth; then Å¿carrifie the Å¿ore place with the point of a Razor, that the bloud may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth: Then take Cantharides and Euforbium, of each halfe an ounce, powdered, and mingle them together with a quarterne of Sope, and with a Å¿hy Å¿pread Å¿ome of the Oyntment over all the Å¿ore, Å¿uffering him to reÅ¿t in the place where you dreÅ¿Å¿ed him for one halfe houre after, and then you may take him into the Stable, there letting him Å¿tand without Litter, and Å¿o tyed that hee may not touch the Å¿ore with his Mouth, and then the next day uÅ¿e him in the Å¿ame manner againe; then the third day annoint the place with freÅ¿h Butter; continuing Å¿o to doe by the Å¿pace of nine dayes, and at nine daies end, make him this bath.

Take Mallowes three handfulls, a RoÅ¿e-Cake, and Sage of each a handfull: boyle them together in a Å¿ufficient quantity of faire water; and when the Mallowes are become Å¿oft, put in halfe a pound of Butter, and halfe a pint of Sallet Oyle, and then being Å¿omewhat warme; waÅ¿h and bath the Å¿ore place therewith every day once, till it be whole. This Medicine I confeÅ¿Å¿e I never tryed, but I think it very good. MaÅ¿ter Blundevile hath only this, but MaÅ¿ter Markham hath Å¿undry others: Å¿ome of which, I will relate, to the end the Ferrier may make his choyce. Another.
Take Dialthea, Agrippa, and Oyle, and mixing theÅ¿e together lay it to the Å¿welling. Another.

Take alÅ¿o FrankinÅ¿ence, RoÅ¿in, Tarre, Euforbium, Turpentine, Fennugrick, of each a quarter of an ounce, of Sewet one ounce, of Oyle one ounce, of Wax three ounces, & three quarters of an ounce of Myrrh; mix and melt all theÅ¿e together, and plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e lay it to the place till it be whole. Another.

Take alÅ¿o Sanguis-Draconis three quarters of an ounce, Bole-Armonack one ounce, Oyle as much, MaÅ¿tick three ounces, Suet, as much, and as much Swines greaÅ¿e: melt and mix all theÅ¿e together and lay it to the Å¿welling, and it will take it away.
Another Cure I found in an old ManuÅ¿cript, with which I have cured many horÅ¿es, which have been much Å¿welled, which is this: viz.

Take Turpentine, of Venice one ounce, and Aqua-vitae, three Spoonfulls: beat them together in a Bladder, or Å¿ome other convenient VeÅ¿Å¿ell, untill they come to a perfect Å¿alve, then annoynt the Å¿ore very well therewith, and heat it in with a hot Brick, or a hot Iron: and thus doing foure or five times, it will Å¿et him upright. â. This I have often tryed and it is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is that which you call a Nether Attaint?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
It is alÅ¿o an Over-reach Å¿ometimes, and Å¿ometimes againe it cometh by a Wrench, Å¿ometimes by a Strayne, Å¿ometimes by treading upon a Å¿harp Å¿tone or Å¿tub, and Å¿ometimes it cometh by a blow, and it is called properly a Neather Attaint, Atta â¢â¢â¢ Neath â¢â¢
by reaÅ¿on it being commonly upon the fore-legge like as is the other; it is nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e placed lower than the other is; for whereas the other is above the Fet-lock Ioynt, this is under it, for it is commonly upon the Heele or FruÅ¿h, nor is it oftimes viÅ¿ible to the eye, howÅ¿oever it may be felt, as well by the heat and glowing which will be upon the heele, as alÅ¿o by the Å¿oftneÅ¿Å¿e, for there will be a Bladder or bliÅ¿ter of viÅ¿cous corrupt matter like to Ielly, which will grow in the place; and beÅ¿ides it will make the HorÅ¿e to complaine, and it wilbe alÅ¿o Å¿omewhat Å¿welled. I have cured Å¿undry HorÅ¿es which have had this Malady, and they have done well again. The cure is thus,

Take a peece of Filliting and bind it above the PaÅ¿tern-joynt a little good and hard, which will cauÅ¿e the bliÅ¿ter or Å¿welling the better to appeare more viÅ¿ible to the eye; make inciÅ¿ion with your InciÅ¿ion-knife, and cruÅ¿h out all the corrupt Ielly, and congealed matter. Then heale it up by waÅ¿hing the Å¿ore with Coperas water, declared in lib. 2. cap. 10. Â§. 4. and after annoynt it with the Greene Oyntment mentioned in capite et Â§. Ibid. and Å¿o in Å¿hort time it will bee whole and Å¿ound againe. â. This is a very hard Cure for your ordinary Country Smiths to take in hand to performe, if they bee not well acquainted with the nature of this Malady. MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, and MaÅ¿ter Markham, have both this manner of Cure, only they differ from me in the healing Salve.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Cure have you for the Avives?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This terme Avives we have alÅ¿o gotten from the French, which our Ferriers doe call the Viues. It is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which growes under the Eares, and Å¿ecundum vulgus, Aviues. it is called the Fives or Vives from the Eares it creepeth downe towards the Throate, which when they begin to enflame will Å¿well, and not only paine the HorÅ¿e very much, but alÅ¿o prove mortall, by Å¿topping his
Wind they will kill him out right, if it be not in time cured; and I my Å¿elfe have Å¿eene and knowne HorÅ¿es dy of this malady. It proceedeth moÅ¿t commonly of RankneÅ¿Å¿e of Bloud: in the cure, care muÅ¿t be taken that you doe not touch the Graynes or Kernells with your fingers The Avives or Vives are certaine flat Kernells, much like Bunches of Grapes which grow in a cluÅ¿ter, cloÅ¿e knotted together in the place; the moÅ¿t certaine cure is to cut the Skin longeÅ¿t-wayes, and to lay the Kernells or Graines open, and then with an InÅ¿trument made like to a paire of Pliers to pinch forth the Graynes, then to apply unto the place eyther a linnen-cloth, or a few hurds Å¿teeped well in whites of Egges well beaten, and Å¿o bound on, and renewing it dayly, it will cure it: but you muÅ¿t heale up the Skin with the Greene-Oyntment before Å¿poken of in Cap. & Â§. Ib. â. But the common cure is to draw downe the Å¿ore with a hot Iron juÅ¿t in the midÅ¿t, Å¿o farre as the Å¿welling goeth, and then under the roote of the Eare, draw two other Å¿trokes of the faÅ¿hion of an arrowes head, then open the skin, and with a Å¿mall payre of plyers, pull out the kernels, and Å¿o cut them off, but have a care of the veine: that done, fill the place with Bay-Å¿alt made into fine powder, and after heale up the Å¿ore with the aforeÅ¿aid Oyntment. â. This have I alÅ¿o practiÅ¿ed, and performed the Cure, but with greater difficulty than the former, by reaÅ¿on of the Fire which I put to the place, and therefore I doe hold my former Cure the better, Å¿afer, and Å¿peedier. â.

MaÅ¿ter Blundevile and MaÅ¿ter Markham doe Å¿ay, that the Italians uÅ¿e to take a Å¿punge well dipped in Å¿trong wine vineger, and bound to the Sore, renewing it twice a day till the kernels doe rot; then they open the neather moÅ¿t part of the Å¿oftneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o let the corruption forth, and then fill the hole with Å¿alt finely brayed: and the next day they waÅ¿h away the filth with warme water, and the next day after, they annoynt the Sore with Honey and Fich flower mingled together till it be whole. This Cure I never made tryall of, but it Å¿eemeth to me to be a very good and probable Cure. Another for the Avives.

Take Tarre, tryed Hogges greaÅ¿e, Bay-Å¿alt, and FrankinÅ¿ence powdred, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, melt theÅ¿e on the fire all together, then with a clout faÅ¿tened to the end of a Å¿ticke, boyling hot Å¿cald the places 4 or 5 mornings one after another, untill the enflamed places doe become Å¿oft and ripe. Then with your inciÅ¿ion knife Å¿lit the skin, and let forth the corruption: then to heale up the Å¿orances, take tryed Hogges greaÅ¿e and VerdigreaÅ¿e made into fine powder, melt them upon a gentle fire, but Å¿uffer it not to boyle more then a waume or two at the moÅ¿t, then take it off, and put to it of ordinary Turpentine, as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o Å¿tirre all together untill it be cold. And herewith annoint the Å¿orances daily, till they be whole: â This is very good.

MaÅ¿ter Markham in his MaÅ¿ter piece, hath a Cure for the Avives,
which he intituleth; A moÅ¿t rare and certaine approved Medicine, which will cure the Vives without either burning, melting, rotting, or any Å¿uch like violent exerciÅ¿e. But as yet I did never experiment the Å¿ame. The cure is this.

Take a penniworth of pepper, beaten to fine powder, Swines greaÅ¿e a Å¿poonefull, the juyce of Rue a handfull, and of Vineger two Å¿poonfuls, mixe all well together, and convey it equally into both the eares of the HorÅ¿e, and Å¿o tye or Å¿titch them up, then Å¿hake his eares that the medicine may Å¿inke downewards: which done, you Å¿hall let him bloud in the neck-veyne, and in the temple-veine. And this (Å¿aith he) is an infallible cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that which we doe call the ArraiÅ¿tes?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
ArraiÅ¿tes is alÅ¿o a French Epitheton, which is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e we doe commonly call the Rat-tayles, engendring in the heeles of a HorÅ¿e, not much unlike to the Scraches, but that it is much more venimous and malignant. It commeth of too much reÅ¿t, and the Keepers want of care in the not rubbing and dreÅ¿Å¿ing him, as alÅ¿o by reaÅ¿on that the HorÅ¿e Å¿tandeth continually in the Stable, his fore-feet being higher than his hinder-feet: for by reaÅ¿on of his great reÅ¿t and pampering, the bloud corrupting in his body, falles down into his hinder-legges, and breedeth this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, which now we doe call the ArraiÅ¿tes, ArraiÅ¿tes or Rat-Tayles. Rat-tayle â¢
The beÅ¿t Cure for this Malady is, firÅ¿t, to let the HorÅ¿e be ridden till he be warme, whereby the veines will Å¿well, and the better appeare. Let him bloud in the fetlocke veins on both Å¿ides, making him to bleed well; and the next day after, waÅ¿h the Å¿ores with warme water, and then clip away all the hayre from about the Sores, then annoynt the grieved places with this Oyntment, viz.

Take greene Coperas, and Verdegreace, of each two ounces, and of common honey foure ounces; beat your Coperas and Verde-greace very Å¿mall, and Å¿o worke them with your honey to a perfect unguent, and herewith annoint the Sores daily till they be whole. â. And thus we doe conclude this Chapter.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is your beÅ¿t way to breake and heale the backe of a HorÅ¿e that is Å¿wolne?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: We have many wayes to cure a Malady of this nature: if the place be Å¿welled, and yet not ripe enough to be opened, then apply that remedy which you Å¿hall finde taught you hereafter, to reÅ¿olve or ripen the Å¿ame: and when it is ripe, put your inciÅ¿ion knife unto it, or a hot iron, and Å¿o open it in the loweÅ¿t part, Å¿o as the putrifaction may the more eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿Å¿eaway; then every morning inject this Lotion with a Seringe; which is thus to be made, viz.

Backe Å¿welled.Take Honey-Å¿uckle leaves, Plantine, Ribwort, Yarrow, BurÅ¿a-PaÅ¿toris, Knot-graÅ¿Å¿e, and Cumphrey, of each halfe a handfull, boyle theÅ¿e in a quantity of running water, till a moity be conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine the herbs from the water, caÅ¿ting away the hearbs, and then Å¿et the water upon the fire again, and Å¿o Å¿oon as it beginneth to boyle againe, put into the Å¿aid water hony of RoÅ¿es, one ounce, Allum and Alkenet, of each two drams, Å¿tirre all theÅ¿e well together, and let it boyle till theÅ¿e latter ingredients be well diÅ¿Å¿olved, then take it from the fire, and when it is cold, put it into a cleane glaÅ¿Å¿e, keeping it cloÅ¿e Å¿topped for your uÅ¿e. VÅ¿e this water every day five or Å¿ixe dayes together, and it will cure any Sorance in the backe, or other part of the body, provided that to skin the Å¿ore, you apply a rag made wet in the Å¿aid water. â Another Receit I have wherewith I have cured many galled backs, and other Å¿orances: which is as followeth.

Take water and Å¿alt, and boyle them well together, and firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the Å¿ore place therewith. Then take Pepper made into very fine powder, and Å¿trew it upon the Å¿ore, & it will heale it in very Å¿hort time. â. A third I have much more Å¿overaigne than the two former, which cureth not onely all galled backs, but any other wound whatÅ¿oever.

Take RoÅ¿in, and common Pitch, of each Å¿ixe ounces, MaÅ¿ticke, and IncenÅ¿e, of each one ounce, Turpentine, Galbanum, Bolearmonacke, of each three ounces, melt, diÅ¿Å¿olve, and incorporate all theÅ¿e together upon a gentle fire, and as they doe begin to coole, make them up into rolles, and when you would uÅ¿e this Salve, Å¿pread it upon a cloath or leather, Å¿omewhat thin; but if you be to uÅ¿e it without either cloath or leather, to any outward part that is not yet broken, then lay it on much thicker than you uÅ¿e to doe plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e; and whilÅ¿t it is warme, clap flocks of the Å¿ame colour upon it. This EmplaÅ¿trum as it cureth any Å¿welling, gall, wound, Å¿ore, or hurt; Å¿o it ripeneth, breaketh, and healeth all impoÅ¿tumations, biles, and puÅ¿tils. It is alÅ¿o a moÅ¿t excellent defenÅ¿ative plaiÅ¿ter for the Å¿taying and
drying up of all evill humours, and alÅ¿o very Å¿overaign for aÅ¿Å¿waging of Å¿wellings. â.
Another Receit I have taught me by a worthy Knight, but I never made uÅ¿e thereof.

Take the leaves of AÅ¿mart, and waÅ¿h them, and lay them all over the place; and albeit you ride him every day, yet will he heale very faÅ¿t. But if he doe remaine in the Stable without exerciÅ¿e, if you put the water of the leaves upon the place, it will heale him Å¿peedily.

Another Receit I have which was taught me by a French MariÅ¿hall, howbeit I made no tryall thereof, but he commended it to be tres-bonne; which is this, viz. Take three parts of Å¿heeps-dung, and one part of wheate or Rye-flower, and dry the flower, and then knead them together, and bake it a little, and apply it bloud warme to the place.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: IS there a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e in a horÅ¿e called the Barbes?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea Sir, there is Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and it groweth in the mouth vnder the tongue naturally, for every HorÅ¿e hath them,Barbes. nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e there is no harme in them, untill they doe become inflamed, and then they will Å¿well with corrupt bloud, proceeding from naughty humours, and become raw, and Å¿o trouble and pain the HorÅ¿e, Å¿o as he cannot feed without much griefe: for it commeth by meanes of evill humours, and inflamed bloud. I never heard of more Cures than two for this malady, which is to take hold of his tongue, and on either Å¿ide under it of the jaw you Å¿hall Å¿ee two teats or paps; clip them away cloÅ¿e, and then waÅ¿h the place with a little water and Å¿alt, and they are cured. The other Cure.

Take a paire of Sizers and clip them away from under the tongue, and let them bleed, then prick him in the palate of the mouth with your Fleame, that he may bleed the better, then waÅ¿h the places with white wine vineger, Bolearmonacke, and Bay-Å¿alt, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and for three or four dayes after, let him Å¿ee that no hay-duÅ¿t Å¿ticke upon the places Å¿o clipped, and he will Å¿oon be well againe.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good Receit have you to diÅ¿Å¿olve and dry up all ill humours in the body?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
The beÅ¿t thing that I could ever know,Bath for Humours to dry them up. is a certain Bath which I make, wherewith I bath him, and I doe finde it to be right good, which I make thus, viz. Take Sage and RoÅ¿emary, of each a handfull, of the barke of the root of Beech, three pound, and of the barks of young Elmes, Oakes, and AÅ¿he, of each a handfull, of Nep,
Penny-Royall, and of CheÅ¿t-nuts, the rindes being taken away, of each a handfull, three or foure white Onions cleane pilled and cut into Å¿mall pieces of Å¿lices, red wine three pottles, Å¿trong white wine vineger two pottles: boyle all theÅ¿e together, and cauÅ¿e your HorÅ¿e to be walked a quarter of an houre before, a good pace, that he may be onely warme, then let him be preÅ¿ently bathed with this Bath good and hot, and then Å¿et him up warme, and let his drinke be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water: bath him thus three dayes together, and feed him with Å¿uch meat as is Å¿weet and wholeÅ¿ome, and let him not be ridden into any water in eight or tenne dayes after, and this will diÅ¿Å¿olve and dry up all his bad humours. â. This I learned of an Italian Rider in Bruxels, whom I Å¿aw practiÅ¿e it very often whilÅ¿t I was there, and rode with him. And Å¿ince I have my Å¿elfe adminiÅ¿tred it to many good HorÅ¿es here in England, with which I have done very much good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: Now that we Å¿peake of Bathes, I would gladly know what are their vertues.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Bathes have been much more in uÅ¿e in former times than now they are, howbeit I and my MaÅ¿ter doe uÅ¿e them often, and we doe finde great profit by them: for they are fomentations, which be the moÅ¿t comfortable things of any to the joynts and limbs of a HorÅ¿e. Bathes diÅ¿Å¿olve all ill humours, and gives heat and warmth unto all the members that are benummed with cold, or for want of bloud; it comforteth and Å¿trengtheneth them; and it giveth very great eaÅ¿e to the pained Å¿inewes. BeÅ¿ides, it aÅ¿Å¿wageth Å¿wellings in or about any outward parts of the body; for legges Å¿welled, Å¿tiffe or benummed, or for any other joynt pained or grieved,Bath for Å¿t ffe legges. or for any Å¿tring hault, crampe, or convulÅ¿ion. I commonly uÅ¿e a bath, which doth in Å¿hort time cure all Å¿uch like Maladies. And my bath is this.

Bath 1 Take Muskadine and Sallet oyle, of each a pinte, Bay-leaves and RoÅ¿emary, of each two handfuls, let them boyle halfe an houre, and when you are to bathe your HorÅ¿e therewith, rubbe and chafe the grieved place with a wiÅ¿pe or hayre-cloath a pretty while, then put the foot into Å¿ome broad bowle or payle, whereby to preÅ¿erve the liquor and hearbs, and lave and bathe him thus a quarter of an hour which ended, binde upon the place a piece of Sheeps or Lambs skin, with the woolly Å¿ide to the legge, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o four and twenty houres: apply this five or Å¿ixe times, and it will be a perfect Cure. â.

Another bath I have which is moÅ¿t Å¿overaign to cure all gourdy, gowty, and Å¿woln legges, which commeth either by farcin, Å¿cratches, or the like, wherewith I have cured very many HorÅ¿es. And thus it is made.

Bath 2 Take the grounds of a Beere battell with the Barme, Smallage, Featherfew, Winter-Å¿avory, Cum â¢ ry, Mallowes, Rue, Set-well, Penny-Royall, Wormewood, Arch-angell, of each a good handfull,
and of the leaves and Berryes of MiÅ¿Å¿letow three or foure good handfuls, Sheepes Tallow one pound, tryed Hogges-greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, three or foure handfuls of Rie or Wheat Branne: boyle all theÅ¿e together untill all the hearbes and MiÅ¿Å¿letow become Å¿oft: but be Å¿ure you have liquour enough, and a little before you take it from the fire, put into it Å¿ome Hay: With this, bathe his Legges; firÅ¿t one, then the other, putting Å¿till that Legge which you are to bathe into a broad Bowle or Payle, as is afore Å¿hewed; and when you have bathed that Legge Å¿ufficiently, then take of the hay in the Bath, and making a Thum-band thereof, rowle it about the Leg above the uppermoÅ¿t or middle Ioynt, and put off the hearbes betwixt his Legge and the Thum-band and Å¿o uÅ¿e the other Legge or Legs which are Å¿welled and need bathing: Which done, powre of the liquour remaining upon the thum-bands: and thus let him bee bathed herewith every day once for Å¿o many dayes together as you Å¿hall thinke requiÅ¿ite, and it will bring downe the Å¿welling quite, and make him Å¿ound. â.
Another Bath I have no leÅ¿Å¿e excellent, wherewith I have done many rarecures. viz.

Take Smallage, Oxe-Eye, and Sheepes Sewet, of each like much, Bath 3 to a good quantity: Chop them Å¿mall together, and after Å¿tamp them in a Å¿tone Morter; then boyle them with mans Vrine, and bathe the grieved parts herewith warme, doing as before with a Bowle or Payle: then with Thum-bands of Å¿oft Hay made firÅ¿t wet in cold water, rope up the member, as well above as below the griefe. VÅ¿e this as oft as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, out if the griefe happen in travell, then by bathing him thus over-night and roping him up, he wilbe able to travell again the next morning without complaining. â. This I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure you is a moÅ¿t excellent Bath, and it cureth any LameneÅ¿Å¿e which cometh eyther by Å¿troke, Å¿trayne, or other Accident.
One other Bath I have whereof I never made uÅ¿e, taught mee by Bath 4 a Gentleman, who was well verÅ¿ed in HorÅ¿e-leech-craft. And his Receipt is this: viz.

Take Savine, and the Barke and Leaves of the Bay-tree, Pelletory, RoÅ¿emary, Sage, Rue, of each three ounces, boyle theÅ¿e in a Gallon of white Wine, untill halfe be conÅ¿umed: herewith bathe your HorÅ¿e as before is Å¿hewed, and whether the Griefe be viÅ¿ible or not, uÅ¿e it and you will finde it an approved Medicine. After this manner hath the Gentleman delivered me this Receit, which he proteÅ¿ted to me to be moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne; which I can neither commend nor diÅ¿praiÅ¿e by reaÅ¿on I never yet had experience thereof. And thus much of Baths, now let us paÅ¿Å¿e to other matters.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Pray you HippoÅ¿erus, can you Å¿hew me what is good to cauÅ¿e a HorÅ¿e in the Stable to Belly well?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: That can I Å¿ir, for many horÅ¿es by being kept long in the Å¿table (eÅ¿pecially yong horÅ¿es) wil Å¿eldome have good bellyes, for their bellies will Å¿hrinke up towards their Flankes, and they become as great as Running HorÅ¿es uÅ¿e to be, when they are dieted for a CourÅ¿e; which doth betoken great CoÅ¿tivenes in them, which proceedeth of much unnaturall heat in the body; and Å¿uch HorÅ¿es never thrive or like well, for they be naturally tender, and waÅ¿h, or flew of their fleÅ¿h: and therefore Å¿uch a HorÅ¿e I could wiÅ¿h you not to keepe, but to put away Å¿o Å¿oone as may be. For if he come once to hard labour, you cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly keepe him Å¿ound, but be often Å¿icke and unhealthy. The beÅ¿t cure which I have,Belly gaunt. was taught me by a French MarÅ¿hall, who told me that every horÅ¿e hath about his Cods two Å¿mall Å¿trings, which extend from his Cods to the bottome of his Belly, to wit, of each Å¿ide one; which Å¿aid Å¿trings you muÅ¿t breake with your finger, a thing very eaÅ¿ie to be done by thoÅ¿e that have practiÅ¿ed it; and when you have broken them, you muÅ¿t annoynt that place every day with freÅ¿h Butter and Vnguentum Populeon mixed together; this done, in Å¿hort time he will come to Belly well.
This I never my Å¿elfe tryed, but he that taught it me did much practiÅ¿e it, and hee brake many of thoÅ¿e Å¿trings of Å¿undry horÅ¿es in my Å¿ight.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat meanes have you to helpe the payne in the Belly of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that we call the Collick, which the Italians do call Colon, Belly paine. from whence our EngliÅ¿h Ferriers derive the word Collick: the French call it TranchaiÅ¿ons, which is a paine or griping in the Belly, comming Å¿ometimes of cold and wind, and Å¿ometimes of groÅ¿Å¿e Humours which ly in the Å¿mall Guts; Å¿ometimes by reaÅ¿on of abundance of Billions or Å¿harp Humours; and Å¿ometimes by inflamations in the Body cauÅ¿ed by feeding upon raw and bad meates, which occaÅ¿ioneth Crudities. But of this we Å¿hall have cauÅ¿e to Å¿peak more in its proper place of the Collick: Only thus much, that whereas paines and Gripings in the Belly do proceed ofttimes from the Liver, and the working of the Spleene, which is moÅ¿t vento â¢ ous. But I thinke it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to give you one Receipt wherewith to cure any Gripings or paynes which may at any time proceed eyther from the Liver, Spleene, or Milt. Neither have you any Signes whereby to know this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, but only the Å¿ame for the Collick. And the cure is this.

Take IÅ¿ope, CowÅ¿lips, Liver-wort, Lung-wort, of each like much, Å¿o as all when they be together, they doe not exceed halfe a handfull. Then take Gentiana, AriÅ¿tolochia Rotunda, Fennugrick, Enula-Campana, dried long-Pepper, of each halfe a Å¿poonfull, and one Å¿poonefull of Honey: chop the hearbs Å¿mall, and make the other Å¿imples into fine powder, and boyle them in a quart of Ale or MuÅ¿kadine which is much better, and give it him bloud warme, and ride him an houre after; then Å¿et him up warme, and foure or five houres after, give him boyled barley, and for three or foure dayes, let his drinke be either MaÅ¿hes or white water. â With this I have done many good cures.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to heale the tongue of a HorÅ¿e, which is hurt with the Bit or Haulter.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If the tongue of your HorÅ¿e be hurt or cut with his Bit or Haulter, or by any other accident or miÅ¿hap,Bit wher â¢ with the tongue h â¢â¢
the beÅ¿t way to cure and heale it, is:

Take Mell-RoÅ¿arum, and annoynt it therewith, with a linnen rag faÅ¿tened to the end of a Å¿ticke, let the Sore be Å¿o annoynted three or foure times a day, and let him alwayes after dreÅ¿Å¿ing Å¿tand upon the Trench one houre, and in Å¿hort time it will be whole. With this I have cured many HorÅ¿es, Å¿ome of which have had their tongues cut more then halfe through. X. Another Cure I have, which a Frenchman taught me, which is as followeth.

Take red honey, the marrow of powdred porke, quick-lime and pepper all made into fine powder, of each like much, boyle all theÅ¿e together, Å¿till Å¿tirring it till it come to an Oyntment, with which annoynt the Å¿ore twice every day till it be whole. With this Receit I have cured Å¿undry good HorÅ¿es, and I do know it to be very good. â.

sp.speaker: Hippop.
sp.p: HOw may a man Å¿tanch the bleeding at the noÅ¿e, or when a veine is cut, or a wound given, whereby a HorÅ¿e is in danger to bleed to death.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: We have many wayes wherewith to Å¿tanch bleeding,Bleeding Å¿tanch, as well at the noÅ¿e as elÅ¿ewhere. As thus, Take the tender tops of IÅ¿op, and Å¿tamp them to maÅ¿h, and put them up into his noÅ¿e, or lay and binde it to the wound or veine cut or broken, and he will be Å¿uddenly Å¿tanched. â. Another:
Take BurÅ¿a-PaÅ¿toris bruized, and apply it to the place, and this is very good. Another:
Take the powder of the Å¿tone called Emachile, and blow it up into the noÅ¿e, or lay it to the veine or wound, and the bloud will be Å¿tanched. Another.
Take his own bloud, dry it, and make it into fine powder, and apply it as is aforeÅ¿aid, is very good. â. Another:
Take the tops of the angrieÅ¿t and youngeÅ¿t red nettles, and Å¿tampe them very well, and laid to the place, will Å¿tanch bleeding. â. Another:
Take Hogges dung, and apply it as is aforeÅ¿aid, is very good, â.

Take alÅ¿o BumbaÅ¿t-cotten, woollen cloath, Å¿ilke, felt, all theÅ¿e burned, or the hearb called Clownes-all-heale, will doe the like. â. Al of theÅ¿e I have often tryed, and doe finde them right good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good againÅ¿t blindeneÅ¿Å¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: BlindeneÅ¿Å¿e BlindeneÅ¿Å¿e. may come many wayes, and therefore if it be that which commeth of filmes or thickneÅ¿Å¿e in the eyes, which of all other kindes of this nature is eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t to be cured; I will remit them to their proper places. But for filmes onely I will give you one or two Receits. But firÅ¿t it were fit you Å¿hould underÅ¿tand how this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth to a HorÅ¿e. If he be Å¿ubject to have a thickneÅ¿Å¿e or white filmes in his eyes; it commeth moÅ¿t commonly of a rhume which paÅ¿Å¿eth into his eyes from his head, which you may Å¿oone perceive by his continuall weeping, and Å¿ending forth watery moyÅ¿ture which will run from his eyes upon his face: which when you Å¿hall obÅ¿erve, let then his Keeper Å¿undry times every day waÅ¿h and bath his eyes with cold water newly drawn from the Well; and this will prevent his filmes, and cure that flux or rhume: but if the films doe come before you obÅ¿erve that he had any Å¿uch rhume or running at the eyes: then

Take mans dung, and put it into a Fire-pan, and Å¿o burne it untill it come to be a cole, then beat it to fine powder, and put thereof into a GooÅ¿e quill, and blow it into his eyes twice a day; and this will cleer his eyes againe. â.

Take alÅ¿o the tops of the angrieÅ¿t young red nettles, a handfull, and Å¿tamp them very well, then put it into a fine linnen cloth, and then dip it into beere a little, and Å¿o Å¿traine forth the juyce, which done, put a few graynes of Å¿alt, bay or white to it, and when it is diÅ¿Å¿olved, drop of this liquor into the grieved eye, one drop: and do thus morning and evening, and it will take away not onely a filme, and other Å¿uch like thickneÅ¿Å¿e which may hinder his Å¿ight, but it will alÅ¿o take away a Pearle. TheÅ¿e two Receits I have often practiÅ¿ed, and I have found them very good. â

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I have heard Å¿ome Å¿ay that they can make a HorÅ¿e Å¿uddenly blinde and yet after reÅ¿tore him to his perfect Å¿ight againe: but I think they doe boaÅ¿t and cracke of more then they be able to doe, how thinke you HippoÅ¿erus?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Why truely Sir, this is eaÅ¿ily done, and I will briefly diÅ¿cover
unto you the Å¿ecret, which is thus.

Take Saffron, and dry it, and make the Å¿ame into very fine powder as much as will Å¿uffice, and put of this powder into a quill, and Å¿o blow it into his eyes, and when it hath remained there by the Å¿pace of halfe a quarter of an houre, wipe this powder from his eyes Å¿o cleane, as that it may not be diÅ¿cerned, and this will make him Å¿tone blinde. But if you be deÅ¿irous to have him to reaÅ¿Å¿ume his Å¿ight again, then.

Take Garlicke, and chew it in your mouth, and then whilÅ¿t it is Å¿till in your mouth, breath into his eyes, and in five or Å¿ixe times thus doing, he will againe Å¿ee very perfectly. â But this latter muÅ¿t be adminiÅ¿tred within eight dayes after the Saffron was blowne into his eyes, otherwiÅ¿e his Å¿ight will never be recovered. â

p.hi: VVHat is good againÅ¿t the biting of a mad dog?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have onely three cures for it, whereof I never had occaÅ¿ion to make tryall; howbeit they were all recommended unto me for Å¿peciall good: the firÅ¿t is.

Take the tendertops of Rue, Boxe-leaves, and PrimroÅ¿e-roots,Biting of mad Dog. of each a handfull, pound them together in a morter, and put them into a quart of new milke, with London Treacle one ounce, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme. This proportion will Å¿erve very well for two HorÅ¿es. Another,

Take Hobgoblin, perewincle, and Boxe leaves, of each one handfull, firÅ¿t mince them Å¿mall, and then Å¿tampe them very Å¿mall in a Å¿tone morter, and with milke or beere adminiÅ¿ter it, both at the Change or Full of the Moone. A third cure I alÅ¿o have, which is this:

Take the hearb which groweth in dry and barren hils, called The Starre of the earth; you muÅ¿t give it three dayes together; the firÅ¿t time you muÅ¿t gather three of theÅ¿e hearbs with all the whole roots, and waÅ¿h them cleane, and wipe them cleane, then pound them well, looÅ¿ing no part of them; which done, give it your HorÅ¿e in Milke, Beer, Ale, or white Wine; but be carefull the HorÅ¿e take all the hearbs and roots: but if you will, you may make up theÅ¿e hearbs and roots in freÅ¿h or Å¿weet butter which will doe as well: the Å¿econd day give your HorÅ¿e five of theÅ¿e hearbs and roots, like as you gave him them the day before; and the third day give him Å¿eaven. Doe this punctually as I have here preÅ¿cribed you, and be you well aÅ¿Å¿ured your HorÅ¿e will be perfectly cured: for albeit I my Å¿elfe have never tryed this medicine, yet I doe know the party of whom I had this Cure, hath cured much cattell of all Å¿orts therewith, for it cureth all Å¿orts of living creatures which Å¿hall be bitten by a mad Dog; I my Å¿elfe can Å¿ay thus much of this Receit, that I knew it cure a whole kennell of Hounds of a Gentlemans, one Beagle excepted which they did not
Å¿uÅ¿pect to be bitten, which indeed was bitten, Å¿o he fell mad and dyed, but all the reÅ¿idue eÅ¿caped and did very well. Another time a Gentlemans Å¿onne of my acquaintance was unfortunately bitten by a mad Dog, who was cured by the party who taught me this Receit, and this young Gentleman (for he was then but a boy of ten yeares old) was Å¿o farre Å¿pent with the rancor of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, before this man tooke him in hand, as that his head began to he addle, and he to talke very idly, yet he cured him, Å¿o as he lived and did well, and is at this houre living, he being now come to mans Å¿tate, and a very handÅ¿ome and proper man, whoÅ¿e Parents whilÅ¿t they lived, I very well knew, and with whom I was very intimately acquainted. â

p.hi: VVHat remedy have you for a Spaven?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
We have two Å¿orts of Spavens: the one we call a Through wet, Bloud or Bog-Spaven; the other a Dry, or Bone-Spaven: the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e two is eaÅ¿ily cured; the Å¿econd may be cured, but Å¿uch a cure is not for every Ferrier to take upon him to compaÅ¿Å¿e: for that it is a Cure of very great difficulty, and of no leÅ¿Å¿e danger. To Å¿peake therefore firÅ¿t of the Bloud Spaven, Bloud-Spaven. it is a DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e which groweth upon the hough, with a Å¿welling which is full of bloud, which though it be greateÅ¿t upon the inÅ¿ide, yet the Å¿welling appeareth alÅ¿o upon the outÅ¿ide, being fed and nouriÅ¿hed by the great veine which runneth along the inÅ¿ide of the thigh, and Å¿o commeth along the inÅ¿ide of the hough, and Å¿o downe the legge to the paÅ¿terne, and Å¿o from the paÅ¿tern to the bottome of the foot. This malady commeth by meanes that the bloud is corrupted through hard riding, eÅ¿pecially when the HorÅ¿e is very young. Now the bloud being through over much heating too much Å¿tirred, it begetteth a fluxible humour, which being marvellous thin, falleth to running downwards towards its center, but it is Å¿topped in its paÅ¿Å¿age in the hough, where it reÅ¿ideth, and by that meanes Å¿welleth, and Å¿o becommeth a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, which peÅ¿tring that place, makes the joynt Å¿tiffe, whereby he becommeth Å¿tarke lame, not being able to goe, but with great difficulty and paine. The Å¿igne is moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ie, being moÅ¿t apparant to the eye. The beÅ¿t way to cure it, is: firÅ¿t, to Å¿have away the haire on both Å¿ides the Å¿welling, Å¿o farre forth as the Å¿welling goeth: then take up the thigh veine, and let it bleed well; which done, tye the veine above the orefice, and let the veine bleed from below what it will; whereby the bloud which was aÅ¿Å¿embled about the Å¿paven place, which cauÅ¿ed the former Å¿welling, is by this meanes Å¿ent away: then with your fleame or inciÅ¿ion knife, make two inciÅ¿ions in the lower part of the Å¿welling, and after prick two or three holes in each Å¿ide of the hough where the Spaven is, that the medicine may take the better effect, and when the bloud and water hath vented away Å¿o much, as it will doe, bind round
about it, plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e the whites of Egges and Bolearmonack very well beaten together, either upon hurds or linnen cloath, and make it faÅ¿t about the hough, Å¿o keep on the plaiÅ¿ter. The next day take it off, and waÅ¿h and bathe the Å¿orance with this bath, viz. Bath for Bloud-Spaven. Take M â¢ llowes and the tops of nettles, and boyle them in water till they be Å¿oft, and therewith bath him. Then take Mallow-roots, Brancha VrÅ¿ina, Oyle, Waxe, and white Wine, Å¿o much as wil Å¿uffice, and boyle them, binde this warme to the Å¿orance round about the hough, and Å¿ew a cloath about it, and Å¿o let it remaine three dayes more; and every morning Å¿troke it downewards with both your hands gently, to the end the bloudy humour may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth. The fourth day bathe and waÅ¿h it very cleane with the former Bath. That done, Take Carana, and Å¿tone Pitch, of each one ounce, and of BrimÅ¿tone a quarter of an ounce made into very fine powder: melt theÅ¿e together on the fire, and when it is almoÅ¿t ready to be taken off, put into it of Venice Turpentine halfe an ounce, and make a plaiÅ¿ter thereof, Å¿preading it upon leather, and apply it to the place warme, round about the hough, and Å¿o let it remaine untill it doe fall away of its own accord: or if it doe come off Å¿ooner than you might thinke fitting, then make another plaiÅ¿ter of the like ingredients, and apply it as before. â This is the beÅ¿t cure that I could ever know for this malady, with which I have cured many Bloud-Spavens. â Another for a Bloud-Spaven.

When the Å¿welling doth appeare upon the inward part of the hough, take up the thigh veine, and let it bleed from the nether part of the leg, till it will bleed no longer, and after give fire to the Spaven both longÅ¿t-wayes and croÅ¿Å¿e-wayes, and then apply a reÅ¿tringent charge to the place, and thus it will be cured. This I never tryed, but poÅ¿itively Å¿peaking, I hold it to be a very good Cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure the dry or Bone-Spaven?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This malady is not eaÅ¿ily cured but with great difficulty and danger: it is a great hard cruÅ¿t, yea as hard as a bone if it be let runne, Å¿ticking or indeed growing to the bone, much cloÅ¿er than the barke of an Oake to the body, and it is upon the inÅ¿ide of the hough under the joynt neere to the great veine of which I Å¿pake of before in the Cure of the bloud-Å¿paven? by which meanes the HorÅ¿e that hath Å¿uch a Spaven, cannot chuÅ¿e but hault. This bone-Å¿paven Bone-Spaven. commeth two wayes; the firÅ¿t, through hard riding, or other kinde of intemperate labour, whereby the bloud diÅ¿Å¿olving, falleth downe and maketh its reÅ¿idence in the hough, which doth in Å¿hort time become dry and hard as any bone, from whence the Å¿orance taketh its denomination. Secondly, the HorÅ¿e may have this malady by inheritance or kinde either from the Sire or Damme, as I have before Å¿pecified in the Å¿econd Chapter of the firÅ¿t Booke,
where I doe intreate of Breeding.

The Signe to know it, is evident enough; viz. by your Eye and hand, for it is both viÅ¿ible and palpable enough, and as eaÅ¿ie to bee Å¿eene and felt as the Legge it Å¿elfe. The beÅ¿t way to cure it, is firÅ¿t by taking up the thigh-veine, which cauÅ¿ed it, and fed and nouriÅ¿hed it, and let him bleed will, and Å¿o put him into the Stable, and doe no more to him for that day; the next day, Å¿have away the haire from off the Spaven, and rub it hard with a Rowling-pin (having firÅ¿t annoynted the place with Petroleum and chafed it well in with your hand) or Å¿ome other round and Å¿mooth Å¿tick, morning and evening for foure daies together, and at the fourth dayes end, Å¿lit downe the skin with your InciÅ¿ion-knife, the full length of the Spaven; but bee very carefull you do not touch the great Artery or Veine, both which do ly very neere; for if you do never Å¿o little hurt the great Artery, you utterly maime the horÅ¿e paÅ¿t all recovery; having thus done, lay to the place the Hearb called Flamula bruiÅ¿ed, and bind it on that it fall not off, for two dayes more; then for three daies after: Take Cantharides & Euforbium, & incorporate them well together, (being before beaten into fine powder) with black Sope, and Bay Å¿alt, and lay this to the place, and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e it every Morning: this will lay the Bone and CruÅ¿t bare. After take Fearne-roots, Hounds-tongu, and Bore-greaÅ¿e; incorporate all theÅ¿e together, and lay it to the place, untill you perceive the CruÅ¿t to be looÅ¿e, and to bee waÅ¿ted; aÅ¿Å¿ay now and then to looÅ¿en the Å¿ame with your Cornet or other InÅ¿trument, and if you can with conveniency take it off quite, doe Å¿o: Which done, heale up the wound with your greene oyntment preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. cap. 10. Â§. 4. you may alÅ¿o apply to the Sorance after the aforeÅ¿aid CoraÅ¿ives, a PlaiÅ¿ter of Å¿trong Aegiptiacum till it hath fretted off the fleÅ¿h upon the CruÅ¿t Å¿o bare as poÅ¿Å¿ibly may be, and Å¿o you may the better attempt the taking away of the Å¿aid CruÅ¿t, or by rubbing it with a Rowling-pin, or a HaÅ¿ell-Å¿tick annointed with Petroleum till the CruÅ¿t be converted into a mattrative Å¿ubÅ¿tance, or other thinner kind of corruption, which may very eaÅ¿ily be drawne away. And thus have I cured the Bone-Spaven Å¿everall times: Which diÅ¿eaÅ¿e I cannot eaÅ¿ily commend to be cured by any, but thoÅ¿e who have before hand Å¿eene Å¿ome other skilfull Ferrier to do it before him, and the Method he uÅ¿eth in the working, by reaÅ¿on that the Cure is Å¿o extreamely difficile, and over-dangerous. â. But when at any time you doe perceive a Å¿welling begin to be in the Spaven-place of your horÅ¿e, whereby you may Å¿uÅ¿pect it may prove a Spaven; for prevention whereof.
Take Naturall BalÅ¿ome, and having firÅ¿t Å¿haven away the haire, annoint the place with the Å¿aid BalÅ¿ome, for two or three daies: and after you Å¿hall repreÅ¿Å¿e the Humours with this Charge.

Take Oyle of RoÅ¿es three ounces, Bole-Armonack one ounce, wheat flowre halfe an ounce, and the white of one Egge; make all
theÅ¿e into one body, and every day (having firÅ¿t annointed it with BalÅ¿ome) lay on the Å¿aid Charge. â.

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: But let us looke backe againe to the Eyes. What Å¿ay you to Bloud-Å¿hotten Eyes?

For a Bone or Dry-Spaven or Curbe: FirÅ¿t take up the veine that feedeth it (whether Spaven or Curb) as well below as above, then give it fire, then charge the place with pitch made hoat, & clap flax upon it, then foure daies after, you muÅ¿t dulcifie the Å¿orance with the Oyle Pampileon and freÅ¿h Butter molten together upon a gentle fire, and when the Å¿carre Å¿halbe falne away, you muÅ¿t applie unto it a kind of Å¿tuffe which is called Blauco or white, made I think of IeÅ¿Å¿oe, and Å¿o continue it untill it be whole. â. This is very good.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
I Say Sir, that Bloud-Å¿hotten Eyes may eaÅ¿ily be holpen, if a right Cure be taken, and the Ferrier perite: for as touching Eyes, they are a tender Member, Å¿ooneÅ¿t hurt and offended of any part about the body of any living Creature; and therefore there ought the greater care to be taken in the Cure thereof: and take this by the way for a point of good CounÅ¿ell, and for a good Rule, that in adminiÅ¿tring to the Eyes, you be very carefull that your Medicine bee not too old, but often made and renewed; for by uÅ¿ing old made Medicines, either their Vertues do paÅ¿Å¿e away, whereby the Member dreÅ¿Å¿ed receives no good; or elÅ¿e, by being too old, the Medicines may moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily putrifie and corrupt, and Å¿o by that meanes do much more harme than good to the Member you hoped to cure; inÅ¿omuch as if you be not very cautelous in making and compounding your Receipts for the Eyes aright, you may moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily endeavouring to cure one Eye, not faile in putting out both. All diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the Eyes come only of two CauÅ¿es: viz. FirÅ¿t, either inward, or outward; Secondly, by meanes of Å¿ome Blow, Stripe, Prick, Cut, BruiÅ¿e, or Å¿ome Å¿uch like accident. The Inward CauÅ¿es do either proceed from evill Humours, which do make their reÅ¿ort to the Eyes, Bloud-Å¿hoten Eyes. or elÅ¿e by the meanes of Å¿ome cold taken, which breaketh forth at the Eyes into Å¿ome great Flux; or elÅ¿e by meanes of Å¿ome hot, Å¿harp, or Å¿alt Humours which doe make their reÅ¿ort to the Eyes; all which doe and will engender Bloud-Å¿hotten, weeping, or watery Eyes; and theÅ¿e doe proceed from Inward cauÅ¿es. Now theÅ¿e Maladies which have their Å¿ource from outward CauÅ¿es, are (as I have before mentioned) eyther by a Blow, Stripe, Prick, bruiÅ¿e, or the like, which will cauÅ¿e paine and anguiÅ¿h, and Å¿uch like inconveniencies, whereby the Member being diÅ¿tempered through heat, burning, glowing, &c. will weepe and Å¿end forth much moiÅ¿ture, which will produce not only Bloud-Å¿hotten and Weeping-Eyes; but alÅ¿o (if Art and Care be not added in time convenient) DimneÅ¿Å¿e of Sight, Filmes, Pearles, Pin and
web, Dragons, Serpentines, and Å¿uch numberleÅ¿Å¿e Sorances, yea and â¢ irect BlindneÅ¿Å¿e it Å¿elfe, without Å¿peciall providence and care uÅ¿ed by way of prevention. Wherefore for Maladies of this Nature, I will preÅ¿cribe you a few Receits, which Å¿halbe very good and approved. FirÅ¿t therefore, whereas the common cure in practiÅ¿e among our ordinary Ferriers and Smiths is, to draw bloud as well from the Temple-veines as for the Neck veins; my CounÅ¿ell is, which experience is taught mee by my MaÅ¿ter here, and it hath not a little profited and pleaÅ¿ured me) to be very cautelous how you draw bloud from weake and enfeebled Eyes, as bloud-Å¿hotten and Rhumatique-eyes, muÅ¿t bee (unleÅ¿Å¿e in caÅ¿es of extreme neceÅ¿Å¿ity) for by Å¿o doing, I have known HorÅ¿es in like caÅ¿es which before they had bloud taken from them were able to Å¿ee a little, but after bloud-letting they have become Å¿o blind as a Beetle; nor were they ever able (no Art wanting) to Å¿ee more, Å¿o as they after became very notable Å¿trong, & able MillhorÅ¿es. FirÅ¿t therefore I aver, that inÅ¿teed of opening a veine, I counÅ¿ell you to lay unto the Temple-veines a Charge, whereby to Å¿tay and hinder that Flux of noxious Humours which were the cauÅ¿e of this Malady; and let this Charge bee made thus.Bloud-Å¿hotten Eyes: a Charge. Take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, MaÅ¿tick, of each like much; melt all theÅ¿e together, and either apply it upon a PlaiÅ¿ter made of Leather cut round, or of Velvet, of that color or as nere to the colour of the horÅ¿e as may bee, or elÅ¿e lay it good and warme to the Temple-veines, with a cloth faÅ¿tned to a Å¿ticke, and before it be cold, clap Flockes of the Å¿ame colour to the place, and let it Å¿o remaine on, till of it Å¿elfe, it fall away. Then dreÅ¿Å¿e the grieved Eyes with theÅ¿e enÅ¿uing things.

Take the white of a new-layed Egge, Hony, Selandine, and red-Fennell of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice: Å¿tamp them all well together, and Å¿o bind it unto the grieved Eye. â. But if you do find, that the Å¿ight waxeth thick; and that you obÅ¿erve dimneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ight in him, through his weeping: Take then Lapis Calaminaris, and put it into the fire making it red-hot, which infuÅ¿e or quench in a pint of white Wine; which done, let the Å¿tone be made red-hot, and quenched in the Å¿ame Wine the Å¿econd time, and Å¿o in like manner the third time; and after the third quenching, when it is through cold, dry it; and beat it into fine powder, and put the powder thereof into a glaÅ¿Å¿e Viall, and put thereto your white Wine wherein your Stone was quenched, and after it hath Å¿tood and infuÅ¿ed one whole night at the leaÅ¿t; put one drop of the cleereÅ¿t of the Wine into the eye of the horÅ¿e, and Å¿o into the other eye alÅ¿o twiÅ¿e a day, till you have Å¿taied the Rhume & quite cleered his Eyes. â. Another.

Take the Iuyce of Selendine, Red-Fennell, Vervine, and Rue, of each a like quantity, viz. one Branch, or Sprigge of eyther; Å¿tamp them together, and Å¿traine it through a cleane fine linnen ragge into a little cleere running water; then put into it as much grated Ginger, and Bay-Å¿alt finely powdred, of each Å¿o much as will lie upon a two
penny piece, putting all theÅ¿e into a glaÅ¿Å¿e-viall, let it Å¿tand to Å¿ettle, and when you doe Å¿ee it as cleere as it will be, drop a drop of this water into either eye, morning and evening bloud-warme, &c. â Another:

Take alÅ¿o Ale-hoofe (which is indeed your true ground-Ivy) and Å¿tampe it well in a Å¿tone morter, and if it be too dry, put thereinto a little white RoÅ¿e water, or the water of Eye-bright diÅ¿tilled, then Å¿traine it into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, and annoynt, waÅ¿h, bathe, and taint (if need be) the Å¿orance therewith, and in Å¿hort time it will cure the eyes perfectly. â The reÅ¿idue of Receits I reÅ¿erve to their due places.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good cure have you for a bloud-running itch?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This Å¿orance commeth to a HorÅ¿e commonly by meanes of Å¿ome extreame heate giuen him in the body through over-violent exerciÅ¿e, whereby the bloud is enflamed,Bloud-r â¢
ning itch. Å¿ome whereof getteth betwixt the skin and the fleÅ¿h, which running too and fro, being Å¿alt and billions, it there doth itch and Å¿mart, provoking the HorÅ¿e many times to rub, Å¿crub, and bite himÅ¿elfe: Which diÅ¿eaÅ¿e if it be let run long, will come to be an Elephantique leproÅ¿ie, or at leaÅ¿t a terrible mainge: by which meanes he will Å¿oone infect all the HorÅ¿es which are in the Stable where he Å¿tandeth, for it is a contagious malady and loathÅ¿ome. The beÅ¿t way to cure this itch before it proceed further, is, Take Chamberly newly made, two quarts, Bay-Å¿alt a handfull, unÅ¿laked Lime a handfull, Enule-campana root dryed and finely powdred, a handfull, but if not dryed, then green, cut into thin Å¿lices, Hens dung a handfull; boyle all theÅ¿e together a while; then with a Å¿ticke with a clout faÅ¿tened to it, waÅ¿h the HorÅ¿e all over Å¿o hot as he may well Å¿uffer the Å¿ame: uÅ¿e this three or foure mornings together, and it will cure him, keeping him to a Å¿pare dyet, and giving him white water. â

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: VVHat is good to prevent Blowing and PurÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e in a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
You muÅ¿t firÅ¿t underÅ¿tand Sir, the true nature of this griefe, as alÅ¿o how he came by it, whereby you may the more eaÅ¿ily know how to cure the Å¿ame, for that there be Å¿undry wayes and meanes whereby a HorÅ¿e may come to be breathleÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿hort of winde, and every one of them may be a Å¿everall diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and Å¿o require a diÅ¿tinct remedy. But if you meane a Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of winde onely, then know that many HorÅ¿es are naturally thicke winded, as being cook-thr â¢ pled, narrow Chawled, &c.Blowing ãâã PurÅ¿ivene â¢
AlÅ¿o Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of winde may come unto him accidentally, as when being fat and over-laden with fleÅ¿h, or by being
too rank of bloud, or by too much glut and fouleneÅ¿Å¿e in the body, then is he Å¿ubject to Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath and purÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o as upon any motion or exerciÅ¿e he will Å¿weat, pant, blow, and heave at the flanks; and this commeth upon him by immoderate riding, eating, drinking, and reÅ¿t. And Å¿uch like exerciÅ¿e cauÅ¿eth the panch of the HorÅ¿e (if he be put to any Å¿udden motion or exerciÅ¿e) to be Å¿o hard and Å¿trutted out, as that he muÅ¿t Å¿o Å¿traine his longs, (the bellowes of the body) as to cauÅ¿e a diÅ¿location in them, by meanes whereof they cannot execute their office or function as they ought; and if care and remedy be not Å¿peedily had, he will in Å¿hort time be paÅ¿t all recovery; and then hee is brought to that diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which the vulgar doe call broken-winded: wherefore to prevent it, adminiÅ¿ter unto him this enÅ¿uing Cure.

Let all the hay he eateth, (nor let him eate all he deÅ¿ireth, for Å¿uch HorÅ¿es are commonly great feeders) be Å¿princkled and moyÅ¿tened with water, which will aÅ¿Å¿wage his exceÅ¿Å¿e of drinking, and very much coole his bloud, which cannot but be inflamed. Then give him every morning for foure or five dayes together, two egges Å¿teeped twenty foure houres in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white wine vineger you can get: give him (I Å¿ay) theÅ¿e two egges, and then the vineger after, then ride him Å¿oftly an houre after: which done, Å¿et him up warme, and three houres after, give him hay Å¿princkled with water, and at night when you do give him his Oats, wet them in Beere or good Ale, and let his drinke be white water. â Doe this ten dayes together, Å¿o that about the beginning of May, and about Michaelmas, he may be in breath: and Å¿o keep him to Å¿pare dyet, but with diÅ¿cretion. â This medicine will both purge him, and Å¿cowre from him much flegme and filth as well at noÅ¿e as mouth, and he will be both Å¿ounder and in better health a long time after: provided he be alÅ¿o kept to moderate exerciÅ¿e. And if after you have thus drenched and dyeted him, you doe not perceive his blowing and lifting at the ribbes and flanks to ceaÅ¿e, then be you confident your HorÅ¿e is paÅ¿t all cure, onely Å¿till moyÅ¿ten his meat as before is inculcated, and he will hold out the longer. â Another Receit I have for the Å¿ame malady, which if he be not paÅ¿t all cure, will infallibly doe him much good, which is this, viz.

Take wheate meale, the powder of Lung-wort, alias Mullet, Gentiana, AnniÅ¿eeds, Comin-Å¿eeds, of each three drammes, make them into fine powder, and make paÅ¿te with them with honey, and freÅ¿h butter, of each like quantity, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and put to it the yolkes of two new laid egges; make this paÅ¿te into pils, and every morning faÅ¿ting give him three or foure of theÅ¿e pils rowled up in the powder of Enulacampana, and the powder of Licoris, of each like much. TheÅ¿e pils preÅ¿erve the winde of the HorÅ¿e mervailouÅ¿ly, and keeps him alwaies in breath, and therefore good they be often uÅ¿ed. â

Of theÅ¿e two Receits I have had great experience, and a third I
was taught, whereof I had not oft made triall, yet with that little experience I have had of it, I doe find it to be right good, being as followeth.

Take the Excrements of a Å¿ucking child, and put unto it a pint of white wine; let it boyle till the one halfe be conÅ¿umed, and Å¿o give it him blood-warme. This will cauÅ¿e him to forÅ¿ake his blowing for 15. dayes; Å¿o as when hee beginneth againe to blow, give him the Å¿ame medicine againe, and Å¿o keep him with this from time to time Å¿o oft as you Å¿hall have cauÅ¿e, and by this meanes you Å¿hall have his wind good. â But then you muÅ¿t beware you put not into the wine too large a proportion of the Excrements, for it will make him to be very Å¿ick, and peradventure endanger him, for howÅ¿oever when at any time you doe adminiÅ¿ter it, it will make him very Å¿ick. Remember alÅ¿o to Å¿prinkle his meat, and to give him white water.

sp.speaker: Hyppoph.
sp.p: VVHat is your opinion of Botts, Trunchions, and Wormes, their Å¿everall Å¿orts, and how doe you kill them?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p:
The generall Opinion is, that there are but two Å¿orts of theÅ¿e kind of creeping Creatures, to wit, Botts, and Wormes, for they hold that trunchions and bots are both one and the Å¿ame thing, but they are much miÅ¿taken; for bots are of a different Å¿hape and colour from trunchions, and of different natures,Bots, & for bots doe breed and reÅ¿ide in the great gut adjoyning to the fundament, but trunchions doe breed and make their abode in the maw onely, and if they be Å¿uffered to remaine any time within the body of the HorÅ¿e, they will make their way through the aforeÅ¿aid great gut, and the trunchions through the maw, both which vermine doe bring death to the HorÅ¿e. Now I doe averre, that there is a third Å¿ort,Three Å¿ â¢ of verm â¢ which d â¢ engende â¢ the body the Ho â¢â¢
which have none other denomination than plaine wormes, unleÅ¿Å¿e you will adde the word maw-wormes, and Å¿o Å¿tile them maw-wormes, which name indeed is moÅ¿t proper to them, by reaÅ¿on that they Å¿elect for their reÅ¿ting place the maw onely, from which they never depart, where they doe eate Å¿mall holes quite through the maw, by meanes whereof the HorÅ¿e dyeth.

The Bots are a kinde of little wormes with great heads and Å¿mall tayles, they breed and live as I Å¿aid before in the great gut, 1 Bots. adjoyning to the fundament, and they may be taken away moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily by putting in your hand, and by picking them from the gut to which they are faÅ¿tened.

Trunchions are in Å¿hape Å¿hort and thick, and of a pretty bigneÅ¿Å¿e,2 Trunch â¢
and they have blacke and hard heads, but they muÅ¿t be Å¿ent away by medicine.

Maw-wormes are long, red, and Å¿lender,3 Worme â¢
much like unto earthwormes, moÅ¿t of them of the length of a mans finger, and Å¿ome are
longer; theÅ¿e muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be taken away by medicine. All theÅ¿e three Å¿orts doe ingender in the body of the HorÅ¿e, by meanes of evill, raw, and flegmatique meates, which have turned to bad digeÅ¿tion, whereby putrified matter hath bred in the maw, and from thence theÅ¿e three Å¿orts of evill creatures have engendred. You may very eaÅ¿ily know when your HorÅ¿e is troubled with them: for he will Å¿weat with paine, Å¿tampe with his fore-feet, and Å¿trike at his belly with his hinder-feet; he will alÅ¿o turne his head towards his belly to looke upon it, and forÅ¿ake his meat, he will alÅ¿o grone, tumble, and wallow; he will alÅ¿o rub his tayle as if it were troubled with the itch. Now how to kill theÅ¿e wormes is very difficile, for feare of endangering the life of your HorÅ¿e: onely medicines muÅ¿t be given which muÅ¿t cauÅ¿e them to diÅ¿taÅ¿t the maw, and to feed upon Å¿uch drinkes being Å¿weet, wherby he may voyd them with his dung. I will here give you many Receits, Å¿ome of which I have very much experimented; and the firÅ¿t is this, viz.

Take of Egremony one handfull, chop and Å¿tamp it Å¿mall, and put unto it a quart of new milke, with brimÅ¿tone made into very fine powder, halfe an ounce: give this to your HorÅ¿e faÅ¿ting bloud-warm, and keep him upon the trench faÅ¿ting three houres at the leaÅ¿t, and at night give him white water. â Another.

Take the guts of a well-growne chicken, (all but the gizard) and rowle it up warme in the powder of brimÅ¿tone, and bay-Å¿alt, and put it downe his throat, and trot him up and downe halfe an houre, doing as before. â Another.
Take new milke, and the powder of brimÅ¿tone, this doth the like. â Another.
Take Saven and Worme-wood chopped and Å¿tamped Å¿mall, put to it a pinte of Muskadine, and give it him warme. â Take alÅ¿o a quart of brine newly made, and give it him to drink. â Another:

Take as much Precipitate, alias Red-Mercury calcined as will lye upon a two-penny piece of Å¿ilver, and convey it into a piece of Å¿weet butter the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of an egge, in manner of a pill: give him this in a morning faÅ¿ting, the HorÅ¿e having Å¿tood all night in his MuÅ¿Å¿ell at the empty racke, unleÅ¿Å¿e extremity doe compell you, for in Å¿uch a caÅ¿e you may adminiÅ¿ter it at any other time. When you are to give it him, take forth his tongue, and make him Å¿wallow the whole pill, then ride him a while up and downe, and after Å¿et him up warme, cauÅ¿ing him to faÅ¿t three houres after: and with this medicine you may kill all manner of Bots, Trunchions, and wormes, of what kinde Å¿oever, yet at the giving, you muÅ¿t be wondrous circumÅ¿pect and carefull; for this Precipitate is a very Å¿trong poyÅ¿on, wherefore you muÅ¿t be very obÅ¿ervant of your proportion, wherein you ought not to exceed, except with good caution. Againe, if you mixe your Precipitate before hand with a little Å¿weet butter, the quantity of a haÅ¿ell-nut; and then afterwards lap it up in the greater lump of butter, it may be received by
the HorÅ¿e to his leÅ¿Å¿e danger, and it will beÅ¿ides very much allay its evill quality. But this I leave to your own diÅ¿cretion, aÅ¿Å¿uring you that there is hardly any thing comparable to this, for this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. â This Receit I have adminiÅ¿tred unto three HorÅ¿es onely, whereof the firÅ¿t and laÅ¿t I cured, but the Å¿econd dyed under my hands: but I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure you not for any want of care. â Another:

Take Sublimatum Å¿o much as can be taken upon a two penny piece of Å¿ilver, and made up in butter will kill the BotsBots. in a HorÅ¿e, if it be adminiÅ¿tred as was the former Receit. This I did never try. Another.

Take a quart of good Ale, of Rue, and Saven, of each a quarter of a pound, of Stone-Crop halfe a pound: bray all theÅ¿e in a morter, and put them to the Ale, and boyle it well, then Å¿traine it, and give it him bloud-warme, and he will voyd them. Another;

Take of new milke a quart, and a penny weight of brimÅ¿tone in fine powder, and twenty of the long haires of his tayle, cut them very Å¿hort, and put it all together into the milk, and give it him to drink, and then throw a handfull of bay Å¿alt into his mouth, and he is cured. â Another.
Take a quart of Å¿trong Wort, and give it him to drinke bloud-warme, and let him faÅ¿t eight houres after. Another;

T â¢ ke the firÅ¿t day a quart of new milke, and put to it halfe a pinte of honey, and give it him warme: this will cauÅ¿e them to give over from gnawing and feeding upon the maw for a Å¿eaÅ¿on, by reaÅ¿on they will drinke and Å¿ucke the milke and honey for a time: the next day, give him this drinke:

Take a quart of Å¿weet Wort, or of your Å¿trongeÅ¿t Ale, Å¿pecially if it be new, then take a quarter of a pound of Ferne roots, of Saven halfe a pound, of Stone-Crop halfe a pound; Å¿tampe them all together, and put to it of brimÅ¿tone and of Å¿oot, of each two Å¿poonfuls, both well powdred, and let all theÅ¿e be well Å¿teeped in Wort or Ale two hours, then Å¿train it, & give him of this two good horn-fuls, then bridle him, and let him Å¿tand upon the trench Å¿ixe houres, but this will not kill them; the third day give him theÅ¿e purging pils. Take of Lard one pound, let it be laid in water two houres, then take nothing but the pure fat thereof onely, beat it well in a Å¿tone morter, and put thereto of AnniÅ¿eeds, Licoris, and Fennugrick, all made into fine powder, of each halfe an ounce, Aloes powdred, two drams, and of Agaricke one ounce: make all theÅ¿e well mixed into one body, and divide them equally into Å¿ixe Pils or Bals, then the HorÅ¿e having faÅ¿ted over night, give him in the morning three of theÅ¿e Pils, annointed firÅ¿t with honey, then cloath him up, and litter him well, and keep the Stable warme, and at night give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, and for three dayes after, let him have none other drinke then white water. TheÅ¿e Bals will Å¿o purge the bad humours that breed and nouriÅ¿h theÅ¿e vermine, that the HorÅ¿e will be perfectly cleane and free from
them, of what kind Å¿oever they are: and you Å¿hall find them to come away in his Dounge, and the moÅ¿t of them to be living; for no Medicine (but thoÅ¿e two only of Precipitate and Sublimate before remembred, in which is Å¿o great perill) can kill them. â. This Receipt before any other I have made moÅ¿t uÅ¿e of, & I find it to be the very beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t infallible of them all; and this will hardly leave one Bot Trunchion or Worme in all his Body: I forbeare to report unto you, what quantity of theÅ¿e Vermine, a HorÅ¿e hath voyded at a time, for I love not to relate Wonders. Another Receipt I will deliver you, howbeit not equivalent to the former, which is this, viz.

Take the tender tops of greene broome, and of Saven, of each halfe a handfull, chop them very Å¿mall, and work them up into Pils with freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter; and having kept the HorÅ¿e over night faÅ¿ting, give to him three of theÅ¿e Pills in the Morning early, then Å¿et him upon the Trench, and let him faÅ¿t two houres after, but give him no Water till night, and that white Water. â. This alÅ¿o have I experienced, and have found it to be very good, for it hath cauÅ¿ed the HorÅ¿e to voyd many of theÅ¿e bad Cattle. I will conclude with this: viz.

Take a quart of Milke warme from the Cow, and put to it of Honey halfe a pint, and give it him the firÅ¿t day; the next day take Rue and RoÅ¿emary, of each halfe a handfull, Å¿tamp them well together, then let it infuÅ¿e, together with the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, and Soute, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, foure houres in Wort or Ale a quart, then Å¿traine it, and give it him bloud warme; then let him bee walked or gently ridden an houre or two, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warme, and give him Hay an houre before you give him any drinke, which let bee white Water, and you muÅ¿t not give him Hay in foure or Å¿ix houres after you have given him his foreÅ¿aid drinke. And you muÅ¿t withall remember, that in all Medicines as well for this kind of Malady, as for any other his drinke muÅ¿t be either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or elÅ¿e white Water. â. This alÅ¿o is a very good Receipt, and I have had good experience of it, and it hath evermore wrought well. â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat helpe have you for a Brittle Hoofe?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This cometh two waies, to wit, by nature, or by accident: it cometh naturally when the Stallion who begat him, or the Mare which did Fole him, was Å¿ubject to the Å¿ame infirmity; and therefore I doe adviÅ¿e all men to forbeare Breeding with Å¿uch a Stallion or Mare, for all their Colts will bee in danger to partake thereof.Brittle hoof If it come Accidentally, then muÅ¿t it fall out to come either by Å¿ome Surfet that fell downe into the Feet, which cauÅ¿ed a Å¿iccity in the Hoofes, or elÅ¿e in that he had beene formerly Foundred or heat in the Feete, and not well cured. I need not Å¿hew the Signes
whereby to know this Malady, being it is moÅ¿t apparant. As touching the Cure, I will give you but only one Receipt for the preÅ¿ent; by reaÅ¿on I Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion to handle it more largely when we come to intreate of the Hoofes. And the Cure is this: viz.

Take a Rape, or a Drawing Iron, and with eyther of theÅ¿e make the Coffin of the Hoofe fine and thin, in all Å¿uch places as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, and pare the Soles very thinne alÅ¿o; then apply to the Feete, as well Soles as Coffins this enÅ¿uing Charge. Take Ry-bran, or for default thereof, Wheate-bran, Oxen or Cowes-dunge, of theÅ¿e Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, then take Sheepes-Suet, and Hogs-greaÅ¿e tryed, Tarre, and Turpentine of each halfe a pound, mince the Sheepes Suet very Å¿mall, and melt it on the fire, then put to your Hogs-greaÅ¿e, and when theÅ¿e be molten, put in your Oxe or Cow-dung, Å¿tirring them well together, then by degrees put in your Bran, continnually Å¿tirring them, and laÅ¿tly your Tarre and Turpentine, and when you have kneaded al theÅ¿e Å¿o well together as that they are become one body and like to paÅ¿te: take them from the fire and Å¿o keepe them for your uÅ¿e, and being only warme, Å¿top his Soles therewith, but tack on his Shooes firÅ¿t: but for his Coffins make Bagges of courÅ¿e cloath, and firÅ¿t covering all his Coffins good and thick, faÅ¿ten thoÅ¿e bagges over his hoofes to his PaÅ¿terns, but take heed they be not too hard tyed, yet Å¿o as they may Å¿tay on; dreÅ¿Å¿e him thus every day once for fifteene or twenty dayes together, and let him not in all that time touch any Water with his Feete, and his Hoofes will become firme and tough againe. After if you turne him forth into moyÅ¿t ground it will be the better, if the Å¿eaÅ¿on will permit it. You muÅ¿t during the time of his cure give him continually white Water. â. This cure I have often tryed, and it is very good. â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat doe you hold good to be applyed to the Heeles and Feete of a HorÅ¿e, that is bruiÅ¿ed and beaten with travell?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I will give you only one Receipt for this cure, which I have often uÅ¿ed, and it is Å¿o truly a good one, as that it's equall can hardly be found. And thus it is.
