Take of the tender tops of the moÅ¿t angry,BruiÅ¿ed heeles ãâã feete. and Å¿tinging Nettles you can get one handfull, Å¿tamp them very well in a Morter, and when they be throughly beaten, put unto them of Turpentine and tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, to bring it to a formall Vnguent: Apply this to the Feete and Heeles of your HorÅ¿e, in bags or cloutes, and let this bee done the very next morning after you come where you may reÅ¿t him, renew this every day once, and in Å¿hort time he wilbe Å¿ound, and well againe. â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to allay burning with Shot, Gun-powder, or Wilde-fire?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: For this malady I uÅ¿e evermore to take varniÅ¿h, and to put it into faire water, and to beat the water and varniÅ¿h very well together, then I powre away the water from the varniÅ¿h, and Å¿o with a feather I annoynt the place burned,Burning with Å¿hot. and in few times dreÅ¿Å¿ing, it will kill the fire; which done, I heale the Å¿orance with carnifying and healing Å¿alves. â This is very good.
But I will now give you two or three other unguents, which are moÅ¿t precious againÅ¿t all Å¿orts of burnings, which is this.

Take Hogges greaÅ¿e as much as will Å¿uffice, Å¿et it upon the fire, and let it boyle well, and as the skimme ariÅ¿eth, take it away with a feather or Å¿uch like thing, untill no more will ariÅ¿e; that done, and that it hath boyled enough, then put it forth into an earthen veÅ¿Å¿ell, and Å¿et it forth into the open ayre foure or five nights, after which time you muÅ¿t waÅ¿h it in a great quantity of cleere running or fountaine water, to the end it may be free from Å¿alt or other filth, and waÅ¿h it Å¿o long in Å¿undry waters in Å¿ome great bowle, until it come to be very white, Then melt onely this oyntment, and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e, wherewith annoynt the places grieved, and in Å¿hort time it will cure them. â This I had of a famous French MariÅ¿hall, and I have often uÅ¿ed it, and I ever found it to be moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne for all Å¿orts of burnings. But if Hogges greaÅ¿e may not be had, then take the fat of Bacon, and waÅ¿h it well, and it is marvellous good. â Another,

Take freÅ¿h butter, and the whites of egges, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, beat them well together, till you bring them to a formall unguent, and annoint the places burned therewith, and it will Å¿peedily take away the fire and cure them Å¿oundly. â This is alÅ¿o Å¿peciall good. Another.

Take a Å¿tone of quick-lime which muÅ¿t be well burned, (that which is beÅ¿t burned, will be lighteÅ¿t) diÅ¿Å¿olve it in faire water, and when the water is Å¿ettled, Å¿o as all the Lime remaineth in the bottome, Å¿traine the cleereÅ¿t of the water thorow a fine cleane linnen cloath, then put unto this water either the oyle of Hemp-Å¿eed, or of the oyle of Olive, of like quantity with the water, and Å¿o beating them well together, you Å¿hall have an excellent unguent moÅ¿t precious for all Å¿orts of burnings. And the nature of theÅ¿e three unguents be to leave no Å¿carres. Wherefore we apply them for moÅ¿t Å¿overaign remedies as well for man as beaÅ¿t in caÅ¿es of this nature. â This alÅ¿o I have often tryed, and I have found them all to be moÅ¿t Å¿ingular.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you take away bunches, knots, warts, and wens, from a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
TheÅ¿e kindes of Å¿orances doe come to a HorÅ¿e, by meanes of much rankneÅ¿Å¿e of bad bloud, which is engendred of peccant humours, which humours doe proceed of naughty meat.Bunche â¢ Knots, ãâã
They are Å¿o apparant to the eye, that any man may point at them with his finger. The way to free your HorÅ¿e of them, is firÅ¿t: take up Å¿uch veines as you may know to feed them; then Å¿have away the hayre from about the places, and for foure dayes together, lay Aegiptiacum to them; at foure dayes end, waÅ¿h and bathe the places with Å¿trong wine vineger made hot; then take wine vineger one pinte, green coperas and Dyers gals, of each foure ounces, cantharides two ounces, bay Å¿alt one handfull, make theÅ¿e into fine powder, and let them boyle on the fire with the vineger a little, and Å¿o waÅ¿h the Å¿orances therewith Å¿calding hot, and every third day continue thus to doe till you perceive them to dry up. Let the Å¿curfe fall away of its own accord at leiÅ¿ure, if any more Å¿hall happen to grow forth afterwards, apply the Å¿ame medicine againe, albeit it was formerly cured by the Å¿ame thing: yet I have not Å¿een any HorÅ¿e to fall into the Å¿ame malady againe, and during the time you have him in cure, let him not come in any water, but keep him in the Å¿table warme. â Another cure is this: FirÅ¿t (as before) Å¿have away the hayre, and take up the veins which feed thoÅ¿e Å¿orances, then Å¿ixe dayes after, let him bloud in the heeles to draw away the humours downwards: then waÅ¿h and bathe him well with hot vineger; which done, take a quart of oyle of Nuts, and Verdegreace powdred two ounces, and a quarter of a pinte of Inke; mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and apply it cold to the places, rubbing and bathing them well therewith, and if the knots and warts doe not begin to dry up at the firÅ¿t dreÅ¿Å¿ing, then muÅ¿t you begin again every fourth day untill Å¿uch time as they be throughly cured. â Another, Take courÅ¿e honey one pound, Verdegreace in powder three ounces, mixe theÅ¿e well together with the fineÅ¿t wheat flowre, and Å¿o bring it to an oyntment, and after you have cleanÅ¿ed the Å¿orances as before is Å¿hewed you, apply this oyntment to the place with a rowler: if there be any warts among the knots, cut them away cleane before you doe apply the Å¿aid oyntment, and thus doing ten or twelve dayes every other day, he will be perfectly cured. â Another: Shave away the hayre, and take up the veins as aforeÅ¿aid, then waÅ¿h and bath the place well, then take mutton Å¿ewet, mallowes, and brimÅ¿tone, make a decoction hereof, & when you have very well bathed the Å¿orances with the Å¿aid decoction, take the Å¿ubÅ¿tance thereof, and putting it between two linnen cloaths, make it faÅ¿t to the place over night, and in the morning take it away, which done, apply unto the place this unguent, viz.

Take vineger and mutton Å¿uet, the gumme of the Pine-tree, new waxe, and roÅ¿in of each like much: melt all theÅ¿e together (but put in your Gum laÅ¿t) and Å¿o annoint the Å¿orances with a feather twice every day till they be whole. Of this Cure I never made tryall, but it Å¿eemeth to be a good one. You muÅ¿t not forget in every of theÅ¿e Cures to take up Å¿uch veines which in your judgement you may finde to feed thoÅ¿e Å¿orances, and to Å¿have away the hayre from about them cleane. Now with this other Cure, I will conclude. WaÅ¿h and bathe the places with the decoction laÅ¿t before mentioned, and lay the Å¿ubÅ¿tance to the Å¿ores. Take then new Waxe, Turpentine, and Gum Arabicke, of each like much: melt them to an unguent, and herewith annoint the Å¿orances; during which time, let him come into no water, and the Poults of Mallowes, &c. muÅ¿t be every night applyed till he be whole. Another:

Take (and to conclude) blew Å¿late and brimÅ¿tone, of each four ounces, VerdigreaÅ¿e one ounce, made into fine powder, then take freÅ¿h butter four pound, melt it in a Å¿mall kettle or PoÅ¿net, and Å¿o Å¿oon as the butter is molten, put into it all the former ingredients, and Å¿o let them boyle wel; and when you have brought it to a perfect unguent, take it off, and keep it for your uÅ¿e. And when you would uÅ¿e it, warm thereof upon a chafing diÅ¿h and coles, and annoynt your HorÅ¿e therwith upon the Å¿orance, and that but once, and it will Å¿uffice. But you muÅ¿t let him bloud the day before you doe annoint him in the necke veine. And at the end of eight dayes, take a quantity of cold Lee, and three ounces of blacke Å¿ope, and waÅ¿h the Å¿orance therewith. This quantity of oyntment will Å¿erve but onely for two HorÅ¿es. Of this Receit I never had occaÅ¿ion to make tryall; but it was taught me by a famous MariÅ¿hall of France, who commended it unto me for an extraordinary good Receit; and truely it Å¿eemes to me Å¿o to be.

sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: WHat is good to bee applyed to a HorÅ¿e, that hath caÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe in his Halter?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commonly commeth to a HorÅ¿e which being tyed down to the manger, his eare or Poule itching, with his hinder Foote Å¿cratcheth the the place that itcheth, Å¿o as when he taketh away his Foote, the Halter catcheth into the PaÅ¿terne Ioynt; which he feeling, falleth to Å¿triving, whereby he caÅ¿teth himÅ¿elfe downe, and by meanes of the hardneÅ¿Å¿e of the Cord, he is gauled even to the very bone, and many times (if he be not opportunely reÅ¿cued) the Halter doth Å¿trangle him, and he found Å¿tarck dead. But if the HorÅ¿e do eÅ¿cape with life, he will be nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e terrible gauled, which will Å¿oone rankle and Å¿well, unleÅ¿Å¿e cure be preÅ¿ently adminiÅ¿tred. The Å¿igne whereby to know it, is apparant enough. I will give you only two Receipts for this Å¿orance, whereof the firÅ¿t Å¿halbe this; viz.

Take the leafe of the hearb called SaubÅ¿ucus,CaÅ¿t in a Halter. Å¿tamp it and Å¿trayn it, and take only the juyce thereof, and apply the Å¿aid juyce to the Å¿orance by waÅ¿hing it therewith, after take a linnen cloth, white and cleane, and make it into three or foure folds, Å¿teeping the cloath in the Å¿aid juyce, and bind it on to the place grieved: but in Winter when the Å¿aid Leafe is not to be had, you muÅ¿t take the Å¿econd rinde thereof, and do therewith as before; but then note, that before you waÅ¿h and apply the Å¿aide juyce to the wound, you muÅ¿t firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the Å¿orance with warme Water, and then apply your Å¿aid juyce, and he Å¿halbe perfectly cured in Å¿hort time. This I never yet experienced, by reaÅ¿on I could never yet meete with the Hearb. This Å¿econd I have often tryed, and I have found it to bee infallible, viz. Make a Rowle of fat Wooll, and Å¿teepe the Å¿ame in Vineger and Sheepes Suet Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, boyled together till it commeth to bee very thick, and let the Rowle bee full as long, or rather Å¿omewhat longer then the place gauled: apply this to the Å¿orance PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, and bind upon it a cleane Linnen cloth, changing it twiÅ¿e a day, and in Å¿hort time it wilbe whole. This is right good. â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Cure have you for a Canker?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a very loathÅ¿ome Sorance, which if it be Å¿uffred to run long will Å¿o feÅ¿ter, and corrupt the place where it hapneth, that it will violently eate, even to the bone: if it fall upon the Tongue, it will eate the very roote in Å¿under; if in the NoÅ¿e, it will eate the very GriÅ¿tle through; You may eaÅ¿ily know this Sorance, for that the places wilbe very raw, and bleed often, and many times you Å¿hall perceive a white Scurfe to grow upon the place grieved. For it is a moÅ¿t Cankerous Vlcer, which ofttimes is engendred of a fretting humour. It commeth two waies, that is, eyther of naughty, and corrupt bloud procured by meanes of unwholeÅ¿ome meate, or by Å¿ome Bilious Humour which came to the HorÅ¿e by an extreame cold not long before taken, which will cauÅ¿e his bteath to Å¿tinke loathÅ¿omely.Canker. I will deliver unto you Å¿undry cures for this Å¿orance, which my Å¿elfe have experimented, and have found them to be very good.

Take white Wine halfe a pint, Roch Alome the quantity of a Wall-nut, Bay-Å¿alt halfe a Spoonefull, EngliÅ¿h Honey one Spoonefull, Red-Sage, Rue, Ribwort, Honey-Suckle Leaves, Yarrow, Plantine, Bramble-leaves, of each like much, but of every one a little: boyle all theÅ¿e in the white Wine Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, till a quarter be conÅ¿umed, and then firÅ¿t inject of this Water into the Å¿orance; or elÅ¿e if the Canker be in the Mouth, waÅ¿h the place with a clout faÅ¿tned to a Å¿ticks end, and Å¿o dreÅ¿Å¿e him therewith twice a day or oftner if you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, till it be whole. â. Another

Take greene Coperas, and Alome, of each one pound, white Coperas foure drammes, boyle theÅ¿e in a pottle of running Water untill almoÅ¿t the one moiety bee conÅ¿umed, then take it from the fire, and put into it of Honey half a pound, then holding up his Head with a Drenching Staffe (but yet not too high) with a Pewter or Elder Sering or Squirt, inject it into his NoÅ¿e (if the Canker be there) bloud warme; which done, give preÅ¿ently his head liberty, whereby hee may Å¿nuffle and blow forth the corruption, and faile not to inject him thus three or foure times one after the other at every dreÅ¿Å¿ing; and do thus Morning and Evening till it bee whole; which will not be long. â But if it be only a Å¿ore Mouth, and that it come to be a Canker, then.

Take of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, and make it thick with powdred Alome, and Å¿o waÅ¿h the Å¿orance therewith two or three dayes together, for this will kill and deÅ¿troy the Vlcer; then heale up the Sorance thus; viz.

Take of faire Water a quart, Alome, and Honey, of each foure ounces, Maudeline leaves, red Sage, and Columbine leaves of each
a handfull: boyle all theÅ¿e in the Water till halfe bee conÅ¿umed and every day twice, that is, Morning and Evening, waÅ¿h his Mouth therwith bloud-warme, and it will heale him. â. Another.

FirÅ¿t make this Å¿trong Alome Water, viz. Take Alome halfe a pound, Hony halfe a pint, red Sage, and Wood-bind-leaves, of each a handfull: boyle all theÅ¿e in faire water, till halfe bee conÅ¿umed: with this Water and Hearbs, waÅ¿h and rub the Sores till they become red and raw, then take white Wine Vineger halfe a pint, Alome powdred two ounces, Ginger powdred halfe an ounce, and of life Honey halfe a pint, mix all theÅ¿e well together, and therewith annoynt the Å¿ore Morning and Evening, and it will cure him. â.
All theÅ¿e Receipts I have made tryall of, and have found them to be right good. Another.

Take the juyce of the Root AÅ¿phodill Å¿even ounces, Quick-lime, & ArÅ¿nick of each two ounces, beat and incorporate all theÅ¿e together, and put them into a new pot cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and let it boyle till it come to aÅ¿hes; theÅ¿e aÅ¿hes you Å¿hall apply to the Sorance twice a day, but the Å¿ore muÅ¿t be firÅ¿t waÅ¿hed with Å¿trong Vineger, as before is taught.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw cure you that HorÅ¿e who hath caÅ¿t his Hoofe?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a troubleÅ¿ome Sorance, yet with care it may be cured: it commeth either by meanes of Å¿ome Foundring, or by an Accloy, Prick, Stub, Graveling, Quitterbone, or other hurt within the Foote, which breaking out above round about the Cronet, and in time the Hoofe breaking, it falleth from the Foote. I neede relate no Signes whereby to know the Å¿ame. The Cure is thus.

Take Aquafortis the Å¿trongeÅ¿t you can get,CaÅ¿ting the hoofe. and firÅ¿t with a Rape or Drawing Iron, file or draw away the old hoofe Å¿omewhat neere, then touch the hoofe Å¿o prepared with your Aquafortis, three or foure Å¿everall dreÅ¿Å¿ings and no more: This done, annoynt the Foote with the Vnguent we doe commonly make for HorÅ¿es Feete: viz. Take Hogs-greaÅ¿e three pound, Pach-greaÅ¿e two pound, Venice-Turpentine one pound, new Wax halfe a pound, Sallet-Oyle one pound: Melt and mix all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and herewith chafe, rub, and annoint the Coffin of the Hoofe up to the very top; and this will bring a new hoofe. â

Take alÅ¿o Turpentine halfe a pound, Tarre halfe a pint, new Wax halfe a pound, Sallet Oyle one pint: Melt all theÅ¿e except the Turpentine together till they be well mixed, and a little before you take it from the fire, put in your Turpentine, and Å¿o Å¿tirre it till it be cold; but before hand make him a Buskin of Leather, with a thick Å¿ole, made fit for his hoofe, but wide enough, that it may be tyed about his
PaÅ¿terne, and dreÅ¿Å¿e his hoofe with this medicine, laying Tow or Hurds upon it, and Å¿o put on the Å¿aid buskin, and faÅ¿ten it to the paÅ¿terne joynt, or a little above, but Å¿o as that the buskin may no way offend or trouble the foot, renewing your medicine every day once till it be whole. â

This Receit is alÅ¿o moÅ¿t Å¿overaign for a HorÅ¿e that is hoofe-bound: and as the new hoofe beginneth to come, it behoveth you carefully to obÅ¿erve where it groweth either harder or thicker in one place more than in another, or crumbleth, or goeth out of order or faÅ¿hion any where about the Hoofe, which when you Å¿hall perceive, file the place with your Rape, and Å¿o keep the hoofe in good faÅ¿hion, by which meanes there will come a very perfect hoofe againe: which being, put him out to graÅ¿Å¿e into Å¿ome moyÅ¿t PaÅ¿ture or Meadow, for that is the onely way to cauÅ¿e the hoofe to becomme tough.

p.hi: What is the reaÅ¿on that in all your medicines in which you uÅ¿e Turpentine, you put that in laÅ¿t, and not when you put in your other ingredients?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I Å¿hall give you in a word a Å¿ufficient reaÅ¿on for this demand: to wit, if the ingredients which I doe put into any medicine be to be molten upon the fire; as Gums, Pitch, Tarre, RoÅ¿in, and the like; if I Å¿hould put in my Turpentine together at once with the reÅ¿idue before it could be Å¿ufficiently molten or boyled, the Turpentine (being a drug Å¿o Å¿ubtile) would conÅ¿ume it Å¿elfe into vapour, and by that meanes leave the medicine imperfect, and that is the cauÅ¿e why I doe put in my Turpentine evermore a little before I take it from the fire.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: IN what caÅ¿es doe you Cauterize, and what be its vertues?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Cauterization or giving of fire is of two natures, viz. Actuall and Potentiall: your Cautery actuall is made by hot burning inÅ¿truments, with which you Å¿eare and burn thoÅ¿e places which be requiÅ¿ite for the perfecting of the Cure you have in hand, which cannot be peradventure otherwiÅ¿e well cured, but by giving of the fire: as in caÅ¿e of great impoÅ¿tumations, Å¿tanching of bloud in wounds, or in Å¿earing of veines, Å¿inewes, or the like: or elÅ¿e in caÅ¿e of diÅ¿membring, if other meanes be not at hand, whereby to Å¿tay the flux of bloud without danger of bleeding to death, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e in very many caÅ¿es of this nature, wherein I doe adviÅ¿e all men that are not very perfect in giving the fire, that they doe not practiÅ¿e upon HorÅ¿es of price,Cautery actuall. but firÅ¿t upon Iades, and low-prized HorÅ¿es, to the end they may the better come to know how to carry their hand, and to underÅ¿tand themÅ¿elves in this Art the better: as when they are to uÅ¿e the lighter, and when the heavier hand; as alÅ¿o that they do make their circles round, and their lines Å¿treight and even, and not crooked
or waving. For this actuall fire is a thing moÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿ary for them that doe truely know and underÅ¿tand the true uÅ¿e and vertue thereof, and therefore it ought to be very carefully, judiciouÅ¿ly, and moderately applyed, and never but upon good and very conÅ¿iderate grounds: which in Å¿o doing, you Å¿hall finde it to be a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne remedy to hinder and Å¿tay all manner of corruption whereunto any member may be enclined, provided that in the handling of your inÅ¿trument, you touch not MuÅ¿cles, Arteries, Sinewes, Ligaments, Cords, or the like, for Å¿o you may utterly lame where you would Å¿et upright, and deÅ¿troy where you would cure, excepting onely in caÅ¿es needfull. For by applying this actuall fire, you Å¿hall joyne and conglutinate parts and members Å¿evered, dry up Å¿uperfluous moyÅ¿ture, and Å¿inke members Å¿welled: you Å¿hall beÅ¿ides bring forth all evill and putrifactious matter congealed and gathered into knots, as Wens, Biles, PuÅ¿tils, Exulcerations, and the like: you Å¿hall alÅ¿o aÅ¿Å¿wage old griefes, and make perfect all Å¿uch parts of the body as be any way corrupted: neither Å¿hall you need feare the increaÅ¿e of any evill humours, by reaÅ¿on that the skin being Å¿evered by meanes of the hot iron, it doth ripen and digeÅ¿t all manner of putrifaction and matrative Å¿tuffe, whereby it venteth and paÅ¿Å¿eth away much more eaÅ¿ily, healing and qualifying all griefe and paine, cauÅ¿ing the member which before was Å¿ubject to feÅ¿tring and to gangrene, to become the Å¿ounder, and by much the Å¿tronger, Å¿o as nothing of diÅ¿advantage will be remaining, but the Å¿car onely, where the iron paÅ¿Å¿ed, and the worÅ¿t that can be made thereof, will be but a little eye-Å¿ore. But then you muÅ¿t have a very great regard unto your InÅ¿truments that they be made according to the nature and quality of the place and member which is to be Å¿eared: for one faÅ¿hion will not Å¿erve in all cauÅ¿es; for as the places which are to be cauterized are commonly different in Å¿hape and proportion, Å¿o alÅ¿o ought the Å¿hapes and faÅ¿hions of your inÅ¿truments to be made accordingly. You are alÅ¿o to have a Å¿peciall care to the heating of your inÅ¿truments, which ought to be done with a right good judgement; for as they muÅ¿t not be too cold, Å¿o ought they not to be too hot, for by that meanes you may eaÅ¿ily enflame the cauterized places too much: Againe, in giving the fire great care muÅ¿t be had to the bearing of the hand, for therein conÅ¿iÅ¿teth very great cunning, and as I have before admoniÅ¿hed you to be carefull that you touch not any Å¿inew or ligament, Å¿o no fire is to be given to the diÅ¿location or fraction of any bone. And as touching the mettle whereof your inÅ¿truments are to be made: Å¿ome commend and prefer gold, Å¿ilver, and braÅ¿Å¿e, or copper before Å¿teele or iron: but I will not controule any mans knowledge confeÅ¿Å¿ing mine own to be the leaÅ¿t; Onely thus much I may averre of that little I have (through Gods permiÅ¿Å¿ion) that having made tryall of them all, yet I have ever in all my practiÅ¿e found iron and Å¿teele to be the very beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t certaine to worke with, of all the other mettals, and my reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e Å¿teele or iron will retaine
its once received heat longer than any other mettle, whereby I cannot be Å¿o much deceived in my work; for gold, Å¿ilver, and braÅ¿Å¿e, as they be Å¿ooner made hot than iron or Å¿teele, Å¿o are they as Å¿oone cold: now Å¿teele and iron mettals are much more Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall and harder of nature then the other mettals be, and therefore as they are Å¿omewhat longer before they be hot, Å¿o they retaine their heat much longer, which during the time of their agitation, workes more Å¿urely: againe, a man cannot tell when thoÅ¿e other mettals are hot enough, as alÅ¿o when they be too hot, if you put never Å¿o little water to them whereby to allay their over-much heat, they Å¿uddenly turne and become Å¿o cold as not to be able to make them worke at all; the contrary whereof you Å¿hall finde to be in the nature of iron and Å¿teele. And let this Å¿uffice for cautery actuall. Now I will in a word handle cautery potentiall, Caute â¢ y potentiall. which as the cautery actuall burneth the fleÅ¿h by the hot inÅ¿trument; even Å¿o doth cautery potentiall burn the fleÅ¿h by medicine, of which there are three Å¿orts or degrees, namely by coraÅ¿ive, by cauÅ¿ticke, 1 C â¢ raÅ¿ive. or by putrifaction. CoraÅ¿ive is when that is applyed to the wound wherein is dead or proud fleÅ¿h to corrode or eate it away, by which meanes the wound is prepared and made the more fit for EmplaiÅ¿ters, Waters, or Vnguents which doe carnifie and make good fleÅ¿h, by which meanes the wound which before was foule, is now become cleane, healed up, and made Å¿ound, and theÅ¿e corroding things are commonly Precipitates, Sublimatum, ArÅ¿nick, ReÅ¿algar, Leads white and red, VerdigreaÅ¿e, Allome, Coperas white and green, Vitreall, Saudaraclia ChryÅ¿ocollo, Origanum, Mercury, Aconitum, Capitellum, Romane Vitriall, Shavings of Oxe or Hearts-horne, Red-corall, Spunge of the Sea Å¿omewhat burned, Vnguentum ApoÅ¿tolorum, Vnguentum Aegiptiacum, Vnguentum Caraccum, MagiÅ¿tra, Sal-niter, Cantharides, Apium, Aqua-fortis, Ciclamine, Melanacardinum, and many more, which I am enforced to leave out partly for want of memory, and partly for want of time; all which doe burne, eate, and corrode the fleÅ¿h, putting the poore beaÅ¿t to micle paine. A CauÅ¿ticke CauÅ¿tick. is a greater burner, for that being once put to the skin, will in Å¿hort time make a wound where none was before, for therewith we doe uÅ¿e to make iÅ¿Å¿ues, and where it is Å¿et to the fleÅ¿h or skin, it maketh its way in, whereby we may in Å¿horter Å¿pace adminiÅ¿ter our EmplaÅ¿trum, for CauÅ¿ticks are Å¿tronger and more violent than either Putrifactives or CoraÅ¿ives; for whereas CoraÅ¿ives doe work onely upon skin broken, and to corrode and eat out dead, proud, Å¿pungy and naughty fleÅ¿h: and Putrifactives doe ripen, mollifie, and prepare the wound for the CauÅ¿ticke; Å¿o CauÅ¿tickes do breake skin and fleÅ¿h and all; and therefore it is more violent, and burneth worÅ¿e than any of the two former. Now your Putrifactives Putrefactive. are Å¿uch medicines as we do commonly apply to Swellings, which we doe make for the moÅ¿t part of medicines compounded; as PoulteÅ¿Å¿es, roÅ¿ted-Sorrell, white Lilly roots, and the like; for Å¿uch things are drawers and ripeners,
cauÅ¿ing Å¿wellings which be hard and fleÅ¿hy, to become Å¿oft, and putrifactive, and to prepare Sorances for the CauÅ¿ticks, whoÅ¿e nature is to breake and open, what before the Putrifactive had ripened, which otherwiÅ¿e muÅ¿t have beene done by Cautery Actuall or by inciÅ¿ion. And this I doe hold Å¿ufficient to be handled upon this Å¿ubject; howÅ¿oever much more, and many other particulars may be delivered, yet in this conÅ¿iÅ¿teth the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of all, for by reaÅ¿on I aime at brevity, I refer you to MaÅ¿ter Blundeviles Offices, and to MaÅ¿ter Markhams MaÅ¿ter-peece, who have intreated hereof very accurately.

sp.speaker: Hippoph,
sp.p: VVHat good Charge have you to be applyed to the Feet, wherewith to Å¿top them, when the HorÅ¿e is eyther Surbated or in danger of Foundring?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commeth commonly to young HorÅ¿es, which are Å¿orely ridden before their Hoofes and Feete be hardned, as alÅ¿o Å¿ometimes when HorÅ¿es upon hard riding and long travell are ill Å¿hod, this doth not only cauÅ¿e them to bee Surbated, but alÅ¿o hazardeth their Foundring; which Å¿o Å¿oone as you do perceive, the firÅ¿t thing you do,Charge for Surbating. is, to cauÅ¿e his Feete to be cleane pickt, that no Gravell be remaining betwixt the Web of the Shoo and the Sole, then waÅ¿h the Feete with water and Å¿alt, and about an houre after let his feete bee throughly well Å¿topped with the Charge preÅ¿cribed you in Chapter the tenth, Â§. the Å¿ixteenth of this Booke; and hee will bee well in Å¿hort time.

sp.speaker: Hippophil.
sp.p: VVHat is the beÅ¿t way to CleanÅ¿e and Purge a HorÅ¿e from all filth, at his firÅ¿t taking up from graÅ¿Å¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This I have Å¿hewed you in the Å¿eaventh Chapter of this Booke; but yet I will once againe reiterate it unto you in few words. FirÅ¿t therefore, he having beene had into the Stable, the next day, if it be a hot Sunne-Å¿hiny-day let his Keeper take him out of the Stable into a place convenient, and there let him hanÅ¿omely trimme him (a thing which every Groome and Keeper knoweth well enough how to do;) then let him take ordinary Å¿oft waÅ¿hing Sope,CleanÅ¿e a HorÅ¿e. and annoint his Head all-over therewith, taking a great care that none of the Å¿ope or Å¿uds, get into his Eyes or Eares, then waÅ¿h him with warme Water, and Å¿o purge and waÅ¿h all manner of filth from his Head and every part thereof; that done, firÅ¿t wipe all his Head, Eares, Eyes, and Face with a warme linnen cloth; and then wipe & rub him dry with wollen clothes: then Sope his whole body all over Capapee, leaving no part thereof free, eÅ¿pecially his Maine and Taile, then waÅ¿h him very cleane with Buck-lee, with a wiÅ¿pe or wollen cloth, and when
you have Å¿ufficiently cleanÅ¿ed him, let him be wiped, rubbed, and made dry, as before you have done his Head, & when he is throughly dry, let him be led into the Stable and Å¿o clothed up with a cleane thin Å¿oft cloth, and Å¿hod up at your pleaÅ¿ure. And by this kinde of Purging, trimming, and cleanÅ¿ing of a Hoofe, I have in three or foure houres Å¿pace Å¿o altered a HorÅ¿e, as that his owner hath not on the Å¿uddaine knowne him.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Have knowne HorÅ¿es troubled with Å¿undry Å¿orts of foule or Å¿ore heeles, all which carry the name of Scratches in generall, Å¿ome whereof have Clifts croÅ¿Å¿e, and overthwart, Å¿ome Clifts with Cracks, and Å¿ome long C â¢ ifts, &c. What doe you Å¿ay to theÅ¿e Maladies?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p: I Å¿ay Sir, that every of theÅ¿e Å¿orts are very foule Sorances, yet Å¿oone cured, if the Ferrier bee Å¿o well skilled as to take up the Veines, before hee apply his Medicines and Remedies. The Maladies do come by Surfets taken by over-heats, by waÅ¿hing his HorÅ¿e when he commeth home hot, by naughty meate, or by corrupt bloud, the Peccant Humours falling downe-wards and Å¿ettling in thoÅ¿e parts where the Sorances are, whereby they prove moÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome to the creature, and no leÅ¿Å¿e noyÅ¿ome to the beholders, for the heeles be very raw, and do run with loathÅ¿ome water and matter which doth Å¿tinke very offenÅ¿ively.Clif â¢ s and â¢â¢â¢ cks in the Heeles. The Å¿ignes need no deÅ¿cription. The cure is, firÅ¿t to take up the Thigh-veines, whereby to Å¿top and hinder the falling downe of theÅ¿e bad humours which do feed them; then clip or Å¿have away the haire cloÅ¿e from about the Å¿ores, then waÅ¿h the places with broken Beere and Butter warme, and dry them againe, which done, apply this PlaiÅ¿ter to the places grieved.

Take Sheepes-Å¿uet, or Deeres-Å¿uet which is much better, and being molten upon the fire, let it coole till you may hold your finger therein; then put to it Å¿o much Ry-bran; or (for want thereof) Wheate-bran as will bring it to a Å¿alve, lay it to the place PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e upon Hurds or Tow, and binde a cleane linnen cloath over the PlaiÅ¿ter to keepe it on, and Å¿o let it remaine foure or five daies without medling with it, by which time the Sores wilbe throughly purged, and the Å¿curfe will eaÅ¿ily come off; then take old Bores greaÅ¿e well rotted, and melt it upon the fire, and when it is Å¿o cold as was the Sheepes, or Deere-Å¿ewet, put to it the yolkes of Egges Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and a little VerdegreaÅ¿e in fine powder: incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, bringing them to an Vnguent, with which annoy at the Å¿ores every day once, untill they bee throughly and perfectly whole. â. Another.

Take Oyle de Bay foure ounces, VerdegreaÅ¿e, and Litarge of Gold both in fine powder, of each two drammes, make all theÅ¿e into
an unguent, and annoynt the Å¿ores therwith morning and evening, till they be whole. In every of theÅ¿e Cures, let your HorÅ¿e come into no water. â Another:

Take Soot five ounces, VerdigreaÅ¿e in fine powder three ounces, Orpin one ounce, beat all theÅ¿e together into fine powder, and then adde thereto as much common honey as of all the reÅ¿idue; boyle all theÅ¿e together well, putting into it as it boyleth quick-lime, as much as will Å¿uffice, keeping it alwayes Å¿tirring till it be well boyled, and is become thick: with this oyntment annoynt the Sores twice every day, untill they be Å¿ufficiently cured. â Another:

Take hot wood AÅ¿hes and Quick-lime, and with common honey and white wine; make it into one body to a perfect Vnguent, and herewith annoint the Sores; and if this malady have not been long upon the HorÅ¿e, this oyntment will certainly cure him, but if they be old and have run long upon him, then give him the fire, and then dreÅ¿Å¿e the Burning with the oyntment preÅ¿cribed you in the former Cure. Another:

Take a round iron, and give the fire towards the extremities or ends of the chops, and annoynt them every day as before, and aÅ¿Å¿ure your Å¿elfe the clifts, chops, and rifts, will not increaÅ¿e but diminiÅ¿h, and Å¿o in Å¿hort time he will be whole and Å¿ound. â This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Would gladly know HippoÅ¿erus Å¿omething of CliÅ¿ters, and their true natures.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
As touching CliÅ¿ters, there be Å¿undry kindes of Purgations, and therefore to the end you Å¿hall the better underÅ¿tand them and their proper vertues; I will firÅ¿t anatomize unto you the Å¿everall degrees of Purgations: and by reaÅ¿on I have been much, and that for a long time verÅ¿ed in this Å¿ubject,Of CliÅ¿ters. I am not aÅ¿hamed to diÅ¿cover unto you from whence I had my firÅ¿t grounds and principles; for every man (as the Proverb is) muÅ¿t have a beginning; to wit, he muÅ¿t be a Å¿choller before he can be MaÅ¿ter: for as Seneca Å¿aith very well, It is great temerity in any man to take upon him to be a MaÅ¿ter, who did never know what it was to have beene a Schollar. My firÅ¿t rudiments therefore I received for MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, and after Å¿omewhat I attained unto by the help of MaÅ¿ter Markham, both very well travelled in this Art, the reÅ¿t I atchieved partly in my travels, and partly from my particular practiÅ¿e and experience. Now MaÅ¿ter Markham followeth MaÅ¿ter Blundevile in many things verbatim, in the reÅ¿t in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, wherein MaÅ¿ter Markham doth more largely dilate and deliver himÅ¿elfe, making thereby oft times many things more cleare and apparant, yet they both aÅ¿Å¿ent in what they Å¿ay;Purgation defined. viz. that Purgation is defined by the learned PhyÅ¿icians to be the emptying and voyding of Å¿uperfluous
humours, which doe cumber, peÅ¿ter, and diÅ¿turb the body with their peccant condition: affirming that Å¿uch ill humours do breed much bad nutriment, which the learned doe call Cacochymia, which when it will not be corrected or amended, either by faire meanes, or by the help of nature, then muÅ¿t it be compelled, forced, and driven away by Purgation, Vomit, CliÅ¿ter, or SuppoÅ¿itory. And whereas MaÅ¿ter Blundevile Å¿aith, that HorÅ¿es are not uÅ¿ed to be purged by Vomit, as men be; I in conference with him once asked him the reaÅ¿on thereof; he anÅ¿wered me, for that the necke of the HorÅ¿e was of that length, as not to be able to purge by vomit, which for the preÅ¿ent I tooke for Å¿atisfaction; I then imagining the thing not to be knowne, untill Å¿uch time as I travelling into remote parts, where I had frequent commerce with famous MariÅ¿hals and Ferriers, I at length faÅ¿tned upon one eminent for his faculty, who upon occaÅ¿ion offered, uÅ¿ed to adminiÅ¿ter vomit to HorÅ¿es as frequently as he did either Purgation or ClyÅ¿ter: which thing when I well obÅ¿erved, I demanded if a HorÅ¿e could vomit, and to what purpoÅ¿e he did adminiÅ¿ter in that kinde; he anÅ¿wered me that a HorÅ¿e could vomit, and that he oft times adminiÅ¿tred for the Å¿ame end, and thereupon both gave me his Receit, and did adminiÅ¿ter in my preÅ¿ence, and made me an eye-witneÅ¿Å¿e to the working, not in one HorÅ¿e alone, but in Å¿undry others. But now leaving this to its proper place, I come to aÅ¿Å¿oyle your demand as touching ClyÅ¿ters, their natures and vertues. ClyÅ¿ters Å¿ecundum vulgus are called GliÅ¿ters, but the more learned aÅ¿Å¿ume the name ClyÅ¿ter, borrowed from the latine word ClyÅ¿ter, from whence the French hath it ClyÅ¿tere. Now whereas all other kindes of PhyÅ¿ick is r â¢ ceived in at the mouth, ClyÅ¿ters and SuppoÅ¿itaries are adminiÅ¿tred per Anum, whoÅ¿e natures for the moÅ¿t part are to purge the guts, and to cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to voyd, (and to throw forth of his belly Å¿uch humours as doe offend him in matter of his health, to allay the Å¿h â¢ rpeneÅ¿Å¿e of bad humours, to cleanÅ¿e ulcers, to aÅ¿Å¿wage the griefes and paines in the belly cauÅ¿ed by winde or otherwiÅ¿e, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e in many other caÅ¿es. Now ClyÅ¿ters are not all of one and the Å¿ame nature, neither are they all laxatives (as many doe imagine) or do Å¿erve to one and the Å¿ame end: for Å¿ome muÅ¿t be made to give eaÅ¿e, Å¿ome are reÅ¿tringent, and doe binde, Å¿ome do looÅ¿en and purge, Å¿ome are to cleanÅ¿e ulcers, old and long running Å¿ores, and Å¿ome to prepare the body the better to receive its PhyÅ¿icke, whereby it may the better worke, which otherwiÅ¿e cannot be adminiÅ¿tred without much perill to the life of the Å¿icke creature. So that a ClyÅ¿ter is (I Å¿ay) commonly given for a Preparative or beginning to purgation. And a ClyÅ¿ter by cleanÅ¿ing the guts, refreÅ¿heth the vitall parts, and prepareth the way before. Wherefore I doe admoniÅ¿h every Ferrier, that when at any time they are to adminiÅ¿ter PhyÅ¿icke to a HorÅ¿e, whether Purgative or otherwiÅ¿e, if the HorÅ¿e be not at the time Å¿oluble in body, that after bloud-letting the next day he give a ClyÅ¿ter, and then may he be the
bolder to adminiÅ¿ter what he Å¿hall thinke moÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite: leÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e by giving medicine, without further preparation, he Å¿tirre and provoke the peccant humours, which by reaÅ¿on they cannot finde preÅ¿ent way forth, being hindred by oppilations in the guts, through coÅ¿tiveneÅ¿Å¿e and ventoÅ¿ity, and other impediments do attempt to make their paÅ¿Å¿age by a contrary way, which cannot be done, but with great hazard to the life of the poore beaÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: But of what ingredients doe you make your ClyÅ¿ters, HippoÅ¿erus?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: We doe uÅ¿ually make our ClyÅ¿ters of Decoctions, of Drugs, of Oyles, and Å¿ometimes we adde Å¿alt.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A decoction is a broth made of certain herbs, as Mallows,A decoction what it is. MarÅ¿h-Mallowes, Palletory, Camomile, and Å¿ometimes of white Lilly roots, and other Å¿uch like things, which we do boyle in water to a third part, and Å¿ometimes we uÅ¿e in Å¿tead of hearbs and water, to take the fat of beefe broath, or the broath of a Sheeps head, Milke, Whay, and Å¿ome Å¿uch kinde of liquor.
