sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: What time is fit for a HorÅ¿e to keepe or retaine his ClyÅ¿ter?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
When you give it him, let him be Å¿omewhat empty, but before he doe receive it, let him be raked, and then having adminiÅ¿tred it, let him keep it at leaÅ¿t halfe an houre, to the end it may work in his belly, and Å¿o do him the more good, and to cauÅ¿e him the better to keep the Å¿ame; let his Keeper (Å¿o Å¿oone as the HorÅ¿e hath received it) hold his tayle cloÅ¿e to his tuell for halfe an houres Å¿pace, or more, for the longer he keepeth it, the more effectuall it will be unto him; the beÅ¿t inÅ¿trument wherinto give it to a HorÅ¿e, is a CliÅ¿ter-pipe made of purpoÅ¿e, which ought to be 12 inches in the Å¿hanke, which muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be put home, and when the ClyÅ¿ter is aÅ¿Å¿umed, let the giver
draw away the pipe by degrees, and not all at once.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I pray Å¿et me downe Å¿ome good Receits of ClyÅ¿ters.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: That Å¿hall I Sir moÅ¿t willingly: the firÅ¿t ClyÅ¿ter that I ever gave, was to a Å¿mall Nag of a Gentlemans, which being very coÅ¿tive in his body, and refuÅ¿ing his meat, did droop, languiÅ¿h, and pine away; inÅ¿omuch as the owner fearing his HorÅ¿es life, repaired unto me for counÅ¿ell; when I had well conÅ¿idered the nature of his infirmity, together with its Å¿ymptomes, I held it moÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite to adminiÅ¿ter a ClyÅ¿ter, 1 CliÅ¿ter. which I did, and it was this: viz. Take the fat of beefe broth one pinte and an halfe, of good EngliÅ¿h honey halfe a pinte, adding thereto of white Å¿alt two drams, mixe all theÅ¿e well, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it bloud warme ClyÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, and Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath taken it, clap his tayle cloÅ¿e to his tuell, by the Å¿pace of halfe an houre together at leaÅ¿t, and if then it doe not worke, as I am confident it will, then let one take his backe, and ride him up and down a reaÅ¿onable round trot Å¿ome times, (but not Å¿o as to cauÅ¿e him to Å¿weat) for halfe an houre more, and Å¿et him up warme cloathed and littered, and Å¿o let him Å¿tand upon his trench foure or five houres; during which time he will purge kindely; then unbit him, and give him Å¿weet hay, and an houre after he hath eaten, give him white water, nor let him drink any cold water in a day or two after. And this you Å¿hall finde to be the beÅ¿t remedy for this malady. â.

This I have adminiÅ¿tred Å¿aepe et Å¿aepius, and have done great good therewith: for the nature of this ClyÅ¿ter is, to open and looÅ¿en the Body, to bring away with it all offenÅ¿ive Humours, to remoove ObÅ¿tructions engendred in the Body by meanes of exceÅ¿Å¿ive heat; it cleanÅ¿eth the Guts, and Å¿licketh away all Å¿limy Å¿ubÅ¿tance which is reÅ¿iding in the Guts

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: Why but HipoÅ¿erus I obÅ¿erve a contradiction in you, as touching the quantity of your Decoction; for where as you did before affirme that you uÅ¿e to put into your ClyÅ¿ters at the moÅ¿t but three pints, and at the leaÅ¿t but a quart; you Å¿ay that you did adminiÅ¿ter to this HorÅ¿e, but a pint and halfe only, which is under quantity of what you did before preÅ¿cribe?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Sir, in anÅ¿were hereunto you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that in caÅ¿es of this nature, PhyÅ¿ick ought with judgement to be adminiÅ¿tred, and the reaÅ¿on why I put into the ClyÅ¿ter of this broath Å¿o little; was for that the horÅ¿e was growne very weake, poore, and low of his fleÅ¿h, and in good yeeres, & was beÅ¿ides a very Å¿mall Nag, fetched out of Scotland from the mountaines of Galeway or Galwin, and therefore if I Å¿hould have made his ClyÅ¿ter Å¿o Å¿trong, and have added Å¿o great a quantity of Decoction to him, as I might peradventure have put to a ClyÅ¿ter for a great, large, fat, healthy, or corpulent HorÅ¿e, I might have repented it; and therefore I made it as I told you, whereby it wrought moÅ¿t kindly, & did him that good which I hoped, & deÅ¿ired: But paÅ¿Å¿ing from this now, let us proceed to intreate yet farther of
ClyÅ¿ters, and of their Å¿everall kinds. Another.

Take Pellitory two handfulls, 2 CliÅ¿ter Laxative. or for want thereof Melelote two handfulls, or if that may not be had, then Camomile two handfulls, but Pellitory is the beÅ¿t if it may be had; boyle it to a Decoction, and then adde to it, of Sallet-oyle, and of Veriuice of the Crab, of each halfe a pint, of Honey foure ounces, of CaÅ¿Å¿ia two ounces, mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and Å¿o apply it bloud-warme ClyÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e. â. This we do call a Clycter Laxative, for this will open the Body and Guts of the HorÅ¿e very well, it will take from him all noxious and offenÅ¿ive humours; it will carry away all Å¿pungy matter: it will allay the biliouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿harpneÅ¿Å¿e of humours; it will cleanÅ¿e old Vlcers; it will refreÅ¿h and comfort the Vitall parts, &c. But if you doe finde that by giving too great a quantity, your HorÅ¿e purgeth and Å¿cowreth longer and more violently than you would have had him to have done, or for feare it Å¿hould Å¿tir up in him upon the Å¿uddaine more bad humours than you may eaÅ¿ily know how to allay, then give him this ClyÅ¿ter, viz. Take the aforeÅ¿aid Decoction one pint, 3 CliÅ¿ter ReÅ¿tringen â¢
adding thereto as much of Cowes milke, (as it commeth warme from her) and put alÅ¿o thereto the yolkes of three new-layed Egges well beaten and well mixed with the Å¿aid liquour: and Å¿o give it your HorÅ¿e bloud warme. This is called a ClyÅ¿ter ReÅ¿tringent, for this is only to be applyed to a HorÅ¿e, that is very Laxative, or that doth empty himÅ¿elfe too much, which is occaÅ¿ioned oft times through overmuch debility, and want of Å¿trength, or when nature is very much offended: you may apply this Å¿o oft as need Å¿hall require. â Another: 4 CliÅ¿ter for fat HorÅ¿e.

Take Mallowes three handfuls, marÅ¿h mallow roots cleanÅ¿ed and bruiÅ¿ed, and Violet leaves, of each two handfuls, Flaxe Å¿eed three Å¿poonfuls, Å¿o many of the cloves of white Lilly roots as you may eaÅ¿ily hold in your hand: boyle all theÅ¿e in faire water from a gallon to a wine quart, then Å¿traine it, and put thereto of Sene one ounce, which muÅ¿t be infuÅ¿ed or Å¿teeped in the liquor three houres Å¿tanding upon the hot embers; then put thereto of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, and being bloud warme, adminiÅ¿ter it ClyÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, cauÅ¿ing him to keep it at leaÅ¿t halfe an houre or longer if you may: and the beÅ¿t time to give this is three or foure dayes before the Full and change of the Moon, howÅ¿oever it may be given to very good profit (as occaÅ¿ion may profer it Å¿elfe) at any other time. â This CliÅ¿ter is to be given to a Ketty or fat HorÅ¿e, which otherwiÅ¿e cannot be kept cleane, for it purgeth glut abundantly, and it is alÅ¿o principally to be given to a HorÅ¿e that is newly taken from graÅ¿Å¿e. Another: 5 A CliÅ¿ter for melancholy,

Take of Whey a qu â¢â¢ t, of AnniÅ¿eeds in fine powder, two penniworth, of the leaves of Mallowes one handfull; boyle theÅ¿e till the Mallowes be Å¿oft, then Å¿traine it, then put to it of Å¿weet Butter foure ounces, which when the butter is molten, adminiÅ¿ter it bloud-warm. â This purgeth melancholy, it cauÅ¿eth a good appetite which before was wanting, it refreÅ¿heth the Å¿pirits dulled, and occaÅ¿ioneth
good digeÅ¿tion if the HorÅ¿e be kept warm, and well tended. Another:

6 CliÅ¿ter in caÅ¿e of deÅ¿perate Å¿ick â¢ eÅ¿Å¿eTake of the oyle of Dill, of the oyle of Camomile, of the oyle of Violets, of CaÅ¿Å¿ia, of each halfe an ounce, and of browne Å¿ugar candy in powder, three ounces, then take of Mallow-leaves halfe a handfull: boyle the Mallowes firÅ¿t to a Decoction in faire water, then Å¿traine it, and put to the broth all the forenamed ingredients, adminiÅ¿ter this bloud-warme ClyÅ¿ter wiÅ¿e. This is a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne CliÅ¿ter to be given in caÅ¿e of deÅ¿perate Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e; it helpeth all Feavers; it is good againÅ¿t the PeÅ¿tilence, and all languiÅ¿hing diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, moÅ¿t excellent againÅ¿t Surfets, either by Provender or otherwiÅ¿e, and it will occaÅ¿ion great Å¿trength in Å¿hort time, if it be rightly made, and carefully given. â Another:

7 CliÅ¿ter for the PeÅ¿tilence.Take the pulpe of Colliquintida, halfe an ounce, (I meane the Å¿eeds and skin taken away) of Dragantium three quarters of an ounce, of Centuary, and of Wormwood, of each halfe a handfull, of CaÅ¿toreum a quarter of an ounce, boyle all theÅ¿e in three quarts of water to a quart; then Å¿traine it, and diÅ¿Å¿olve into the broth of Gerologundinum three ounces, and of white Å¿alt three drams, of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, and bloud warme adminiÅ¿ter it CliÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e. â.
This I have often proved, and doe finde it to be moÅ¿t excellent for the PeÅ¿tilence, and to helpe all Feavers. Another:

8 CliÅ¿ters Lenitive.Take the decoction of Mallowes, and put to it either of freÅ¿h Butter foure ounces, or of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, and give it him CliÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e. â This is the gentleÅ¿t CliÅ¿ter of any before preÅ¿cribed; for it is both a Lenitive, and a great cooler of the body, and doth infinitely eaÅ¿e paine. It is the beÅ¿t thing can be given to a HorÅ¿e that is taken, or againÅ¿t ConvulÅ¿ions, or Cramps, and moÅ¿t Å¿ingular againÅ¿t CoÅ¿tiveneÅ¿Å¿e proceeding from any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿urfet by Provender, foundring in the body, &c. Another:

9 CliÅ¿ter for the Collick.Take Å¿alt water or new made brine 2 pints, diÅ¿Å¿olve therein a pretty quantity of Sope, and Å¿o bloud-warm adminiÅ¿ter it CliÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e. This I never did experience, howÅ¿oever I have been oft perÅ¿waded by many able Ferriers, who have averred it to be the moÅ¿t excellent that may be had for the Collick, or any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e or gripings in the guts or belly. And let this Å¿uffice for CliÅ¿ters: onely by way of adviÅ¿e I counÅ¿ell you that before you adminiÅ¿ter any CliÅ¿ter, you firÅ¿t rake him; that you put in the Pipe (being firÅ¿t annoynted with Å¿weet Butter or oyle Olive) gently and by degrees, and that you alÅ¿o draw it forth very treatably; that you make him keep it at leaÅ¿t halfe an houre; that you doe adminiÅ¿ter it but bloud warme at moÅ¿t; that you Å¿queeze and preÅ¿Å¿e between your hands the bladder Å¿trongly; and laÅ¿tly, that you let him not drink any cold water in a day or two after, but let it be either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or elÅ¿e white water.

sp.speaker: Hyppoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to be applyed to a HorÅ¿e that is cloyed, prickt, or hath other hurt in the hoofe?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: You muÅ¿t firÅ¿t with your Butter, Drawing iron, or Paring knife, lay the wound bare as may be; then

Take waxe, Hogs greaÅ¿e, and Turpentine, of each one ounce,Cloyed. VerdigreaÅ¿e two ounces, boyle theÅ¿e upon a gentle fire, your waxe and Hogs greaÅ¿e being firÅ¿t put in and molten, then put in your Turpentine, and laÅ¿tly your VerdigreaÅ¿e in fine powder, and being indifferently warme, dip Tow or Hurds into the oyntment, and Å¿o lay it to the Sore, then Å¿top and Å¿plent it up, and dreÅ¿Å¿e him twice a day, and this will make him whole and Å¿ound in Å¿hort time. â But of this more in its due place.

p.hi: VVHat Å¿ay you to a HorÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Cods and Stones are Å¿welled?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This infirmity proceedeth from Å¿undry cauÅ¿es, as Å¿ometimes by being bitten with a Dog, or with another HorÅ¿e, or by being Å¿tung with Å¿ome venemous or evill creature: The French do call it Enflure de Coullon's: Cods Å¿welled. It commeth alÅ¿o by meanes of Å¿ome evill humours and corrupt bloud which doe fall down to the cods, Å¿ometimes after Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿ometimes of rankneÅ¿Å¿e of bloud and Å¿eed, for want of a Mare. If it come by rankneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿eed or of bloud, then let him have a Mare, and cover her two or three dayes together, and halfe an houre after, ride him into the water above the cods or Å¿tones, againÅ¿t the Å¿treame, and he will doe well. â But if this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e come by other cauÅ¿es, then

Take the Lees of Claret Wine, and Comen-Å¿eed, made into fine powder, and a little Wheat or Beane flower; boyle theÅ¿e together to an unguent, and Å¿o warme as he may well endure it, annoint the cods therewith, which done, draw forth his yard, and waÅ¿h it, and his Å¿heeth alÅ¿o with white wine vineger; and three or foure houres after, ride him into the water above the cods, and let him alÅ¿o Å¿tand in the water Å¿ome Å¿hort time, and Å¿ometimes ride him againÅ¿t the Å¿treame: doe this every day till the Å¿welling be aÅ¿Å¿waged. â This is a very good Cure. Another:
Take the roots of wild Cucumbers, and white Å¿alt, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, boyle theÅ¿e in faire water to an oyntment, and annoynt the cods therewith warme: and then apply this oyntment.

Take Goats greaÅ¿e, or for default thereof, Deeres Å¿uet, the white of an Egge, and Sallet oyle: boyle theÅ¿e over a gentle fire, and herewith annoynt the cods, but this muÅ¿t be applyed after he hath been
ridden into the water and dry againe: doe this every day once till he be well. â This I have often tryed, and have found it to be right good. Another:
FirÅ¿t, annoynt and bathe the cods in the juyce of Hemlock, and when it is dryed, then
Take Pigeons dung, and new Milke, and boyle it till it be as thick like to a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and therewith annoint the cods every day once. Another:

FirÅ¿t let him bloud in both the Å¿pur or flanck veines; Then take oyle of RoÅ¿es and vineger, of each a pinte, and of Bolearmonack in fine powder two ounces: make all theÅ¿e into one body, and being lukewarme annoynt the cods therewith, and the next day ride him into the water up to the cods againÅ¿t the Å¿treame; then bring him into the Å¿table, and when he is through dry, annoynt him againe: thus continuing to do, till he be well. But if the cods be Å¿wolne by meanes of any hurt, bite, or Å¿troke, then apply to them this following charge:

A charge for Å¿welled cods.Take Bolearmonack in powder, vineger, and the whites of Egges as much as will Å¿uffice, well beaten, and wrought together, and annoynt him therewith daily till it be abated, and if it impoÅ¿tumate, where you finde it to be Å¿oft, open it either with a hot iron, or with your inciÅ¿ion knife, if it breake not of it Å¿elfe, and Å¿o heale it up with the oyntment taught you in lib 2. cap. 10. Â§ 4. and it will Å¿oone be whole. â This is very Å¿overaigne.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Å¿ay you to the Collick?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: It is Sir, a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which commeth of winde, and therefore we generally call it the winde collicke; the French call this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e the TranchaiÅ¿ons; Collicke. it cauÅ¿eth great gripings, and extreame paine in the belly of the HorÅ¿e, Å¿o as he will oft times lye down and tumble; he will alÅ¿o Å¿trike at his belly with his hinder feet, and Å¿tamp with his fore-feet; and the paine will be Å¿o great as to cauÅ¿e him to forÅ¿ake his meat: theÅ¿e Å¿ignes I have often obÅ¿erved in HorÅ¿es perplexed with this malady; and albeit I have Å¿undry Receits for it, and all or the moÅ¿t of them by me tryed and approved good, yet one of MaÅ¿ter Blundeviles and MaÅ¿ter Markhams, I hold inferiour to none of mine, for I have often tryed it; and this is it.

Take a quart of Muskadine, or of Å¿weet Sack, of Cloves, Pepper, Cinamon, of each halfe an ounce, Sugar two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and give it him bloud warme: then annoynt his flankes with oyle de Bay; (but I often uÅ¿e to annoynt them with the oyntment of Acopum, I finding it to be much better) then bridle him up, and trot him out a good round trot, or gallop him Å¿oftly Å¿ometimes the Å¿pace of an houre untill he doe dung, but if he will not, then rake him, or elÅ¿e put an Onyon pilled and jagged into his
fundament: then for three or foure dayes, let his drinke be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white water, and keep him warme, and he will doe well againe. â Another: Keep him faÅ¿ting over night, and in the morning give him this drinke.

Take of white Wine a quart, Fenugrick foure ounces, Bay-berries, and Pepper, of each foure ounces, Graines, and Ginger, of each one ounce, Water-CreÅ¿Å¿es two handfuls, Sage one handfull, Sengrene one pound, Mints a handfull, Å¿tampe the hearbs; and pound the Å¿pices, and put them into the wine, and let it boyle a little, then Å¿traine it, and put to it of life Honey two Å¿poonfuls, and Å¿o give it him bloud-warme. â This I have alÅ¿o found to be very good: notwithÅ¿tanding if he be a Å¿toned HorÅ¿e, the beÅ¿t cure for him is to have a Mare, eÅ¿pecially if he be Å¿o troubled with the collicke, Å¿o as that he cannot piÅ¿Å¿e; beÅ¿ides it helpeth and preventeth Å¿undry Å¿orts of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿es and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, and Å¿trengtheneth nature. â Another:

Take of white Wine one pinte, and three or foure Cantharides: and make them into very fine powder, and give this to the HorÅ¿e (well brewed in wine) bloud-warme. This I never tryed, for that theÅ¿e flyes being a Å¿trong coraÅ¿ive, have deterred me, howÅ¿oever I have been often invited thereunto by many good Ferriers, who have averred unto me, that they have often uÅ¿ed it, and have found it to be right good. Another:

Take Cloves, Pepper, Cinamon, of each one ounce; all made into fine powder, and well mixed, then put it into a quart of Muskadine, and let it boyle a while; then take it off, and put to it of Honey one Å¿poonfull; give it him bloud-warme: which done, cloath him up, and litter him, and Å¿o let him Å¿tand upon his trench foure houres; then give him meat, and an houre after a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water. This was taught me by a Noble Knight, who Å¿aid he had often uÅ¿ed it. But if your HorÅ¿e hath the collicke and Å¿tone, then

Take of white wine one pinte, of Burr-Å¿eeds eight ounces,Collicke and Stone. made into fine powder, of ParÅ¿ley-Å¿eed two ounces, in powder alÅ¿o, of IÅ¿ope, unÅ¿et Leekes, and Water-CreÅ¿Å¿es, of each halfe a handfull, of black Sope halfe an ounce; Å¿tamp all the hearbs in a morter, and Å¿traine them with the Wine, then put to that liquor, your Burre and ParÅ¿ley Å¿eeds, and Å¿o give it him bloud-warme; this will breake the Å¿tone, and bring it from him with much eaÅ¿e, and cure his Collicke. â This I have often adminiÅ¿tred.

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: VVHat DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that which is called the Colt Evill?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p:
It is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e in the yard, Å¿heath, and cods of a HorÅ¿e or Gelding, and it commeth to HorÅ¿es by meanes of heat and rankneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿eed; and to a Gelding, by weakneÅ¿Å¿e and coldneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿eed, to the HorÅ¿e through too great abundance of Å¿eed, which cauÅ¿eth
a Å¿topping in the pipe or conduct of the yard, Colt-Evill. and to a gelding for want of heat and Å¿trength to Å¿end it forth, whereby the yard and Å¿heath Å¿welleth very much. The beÅ¿t way to cure a HorÅ¿e is to give him a Mare, whereby he Å¿endeth forth his Å¿eed freely, and then two or three houres after Å¿wimme him, or elÅ¿e ride him up to the flankes to and fro a pretty while againÅ¿t the Å¿treame. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is knowne by the Å¿welling of the yard and Å¿heath; I have cured many HorÅ¿es and Geldings with this enÅ¿uing Receit. FirÅ¿t Å¿wimme him, but Å¿pecially againÅ¿t the Å¿treame foure or five dayes together, then apply this PlaiÅ¿ter.

Take Beane-meale, and Mallowes, of each one handfull, Hogs greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, chop the Mallowes Å¿mall, then put to the Hogs greaÅ¿e, and Å¿o boyle it with a pinte of white Wine, and when it is boyled, put it into a cloath, and wrap his cods therein; and Å¿o order it as that it may gather like a purÅ¿e, and make it faÅ¿t Å¿o, as it may neither fall off, nor hurt him: dreÅ¿Å¿e him herewith every day till he be well. â I have had great experience of this Receit: but if you be deÅ¿irous to have variety, then looke over MaÅ¿ter Blundevile and MaÅ¿ter Markham, who are well Å¿tored.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is beÅ¿t to be given for a cold?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
There are Å¿o many and Å¿o good, as that I am to Å¿eeke almoÅ¿t to know how to begin, they be of Å¿o many, and Å¿undry Å¿orts of them,Cold. for Å¿ome are for colds newly taken, Å¿ome for old colds, Å¿ome for colds that bringeth the Glanders, &c. Wherefore for colds newly taken at firÅ¿t, you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand (Sir) that a cold newly taken (a thing not to be prevented, by reaÅ¿on it oft times commeth by meanes and wayes unknowne) you muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve firÅ¿t, that if your HorÅ¿e be propenÅ¿e to many bad humours, whereof Å¿ome HorÅ¿es are more than others, you muÅ¿t firÅ¿t then labour to expell them by purging his head, then Å¿earch betwixt his jawes, and if there you do finde any Å¿mall kernels, then be you aÅ¿Å¿ured he hath a new-taken cold, but if he have great kernels, then was not the cold Å¿o lately taken as you might have imagined; alÅ¿o if he doe rattle in the head, it is a Å¿igne his cold is newly taken, or if he doe voyd any thinne matter forth of his noÅ¿e or eyes, or if he hold his head into the manger; or if when he drinketh, the water commeth out of his noÅ¿trils, or that he cougheth oft, and Å¿ometimes perhaps cheweth mattrative Å¿tuffe betwixt his teeth, &c. TheÅ¿e and many others be certaine Å¿ignes of a PoÅ¿e, Catarre, and newly taken cold, wherein is no danger if it be taken in time, otherwiÅ¿e it will come to a worÅ¿e matter; I will now give you Å¿undry good Receits, moÅ¿t of which I have often tryed and found to be right good. FirÅ¿t, I hold moderate exerciÅ¿e, and Å¿eaÅ¿onable ayering to be marvellous good without further applying
of medicines; but if you finde that he is much Å¿topped in the head then,

Take a Å¿mall quantity of freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter, and of brimÅ¿tone made into fine powder; work them together til they be one entire body, & of a deep yellow gold colour, then take two long wing. GooÅ¿e-feathers, and annoynt them herewith to the very quils on either Å¿i â¢â¢ ; which done, rowle them in more of the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, and Å¿o put them up into either noÅ¿trill one, and at the but end of the quils, put a Å¿trong packthred, which muÅ¿t be faÅ¿tned over his pole, like to the headÅ¿tall of a Bridle: and then leap his back, and ride him moderately up and down an houre or longer, and this will provoke him to Å¿nort and Å¿nuffle forth of his noÅ¿e and head much of the congealed filth which is in his head, then tye him to the Racke for an houre after, and this will purge his head very cleane: then draw forth the feathers, and he will doe well, keeping him warme, and giving him MaÅ¿hes or white water every day for foure or five dayes after. This Receit was taught me for more than 30 yeares Å¿ince by a famous MariÅ¿hall of France, which Å¿ince I found in MaÅ¿ter Markhams MaÅ¿terpiece, but I hold it one of the beÅ¿t things can be preÅ¿cribed for this Malady. â Another very Å¿hort, but as good.

Take of Time one handfull, boyle it in a quart of Å¿trong Ale, till it come to a pinte, then Å¿traine it, and adde thereunto of ordinary Treacle two Å¿poonfuls, and give it him bloud-warme. â Another.
An excellent drinke to be given to a HorÅ¿e for a new-taken cold, provided he be young, that is, not above five yeares old.

Take of French Barly halfe a pound, put it into a poÅ¿net, and put thereto of faire water one quart, and Å¿et it upon the fire, and let it boyle a little, then take it off, and draine the water from the Barly, and caÅ¿t away the water, then adde the Å¿econd time the like quantity of water, and boyle it as much as you did the firÅ¿t t me, and then draine it from the water, & caÅ¿t away the water again, then adde once againe the like quantity of a quart of water, as you did twice before, and boyle that alÅ¿o Å¿o long a time as you did the two former waters, draine this alÅ¿o from the Barly, but caÅ¿t it not away, but keep it, and then adde to the water of AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris, of each halfe an ounce, make them into very fine powder, and Å¿earce them, and put the Å¿aid powder into the boyled water, and adde to it of white Å¿ugar-candy, foure ounces, then Å¿et it upon the fire in a cleane skillet, and Å¿o boyle it up untill a third part be conÅ¿umed, then take it off and Å¿traine it, and give it your HorÅ¿e bloud-warme; drench him thus three mornings together, and it will ripen his cold and cauÅ¿e it to come away. This is very good. â Another:

Take of white wine vineger the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t, five Å¿poonfuls, and put to it of oyle de Bay one Å¿poonfull, warme it upon the fire, Å¿tirring it well; this muÅ¿t be made and given in the morning: but when you doe adminiÅ¿ter it, you muÅ¿t firÅ¿t put your drenching horn
into faire water that is good and hot, to keep the medicine from Å¿ticking to the horne, then taking it forth out of the hot water, before the horne can be cold, and whilÅ¿t it is yet moyÅ¿t with the water, put the one halfe of your medicine into the Å¿ame, and Å¿o as Å¿peedily as may be, convey it into one of his noÅ¿trils, and after the other moity into his other noÅ¿trill; this done, ride him for halfe an houre moderately, then Å¿et him up, and cloath and litter him warme, and let him Å¿tand upon the trench three or foure houres before you give him any meat, and after doe as is accuÅ¿tomed to be done to Å¿icke HorÅ¿es in PhyÅ¿icke. â This I doe approve to be equivalent to either of the two former. Another:

T â¢ ke water and Å¿alt Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, brew them well together, it then being made bloud-warme, give it him, and doe after as is uÅ¿uall. â This for a new taken cold I have often uÅ¿ed, and I doe finde it to be Å¿ingular good to be given to a young HorÅ¿e. Another:

Take of oyle de Bay, of AnniÅ¿eeds, and of Licoris, of each one halfe penny worth, and of browne Å¿ugar-candy a penny worth, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and being well mixed, Å¿ew it up into a fine linnen rag, and Å¿o faÅ¿ten it unto the Bit or Snaffle of the HorÅ¿e, and Å¿o ride a journey, and travell him, and in Å¿hort Å¿pace he will be cured, if it be a new-taken cold onely. â This I have alÅ¿o proved, and I doe finde it good, for it will cure both cold and cough if it be rightly applyed, to wit, with riding and exerciÅ¿e. Another:

Take of white Wine one pinte, Sallet oyle a quarter of a pinte, Rubarb and Aloes, and Saffron, of each two drams, Nutmeg, Sene, Agarick, Bay-berries, Duke or Dutch powder, and of Cordiall powder, of each halfe an ounce: mixe all theÅ¿e together, and then adde to it of Honey foure ounces, warme them well in a Pipkin, and give it him to drinke bloud-warme, but let him Å¿tand upon the trench at leaÅ¿t three houres before, and three houres after, neither let him for all that day eate any Oates, but in its Å¿tead, let him have Wheate-bran, and let his drinke be that day either a warme MaÅ¿h, or white water, and no cold water, but this white water for foure or five daies after, and put into his Provender for Å¿ome time Fennugrick made into groÅ¿Å¿e powder. â This is a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne drinke to be given for a cold. But if you do finde, that his head is very much oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with a PoÅ¿e or Catar, then give him this drinke twice a day, viz. Take Fenugrick one ounce, and boyle it in a good quantity of water till it burÅ¿t, then mixe with the decoction thereof wheate meale, as much as will Å¿uffice, and give it him to drink. Another:

Take a quart of the beÅ¿t Ale, and warme it upon the fire, and put into it Å¿o much Tobacco made into fine powder, as you can take up upon a Å¿hilling at twice, and as much dryed RoÅ¿emary in fine powder as you may take up upon a Å¿hilling at once; give him this to drink bloud-warme in a morning faÅ¿ting. This drinke is called Potio-Necotiana,
but I did never make tryall thereof, for that I once Å¿aw it given by a Ferrier to a Å¿icke HorÅ¿e, which Å¿o wrought with him, as that with all his Lenitives and Cordials, the Ferrier had much labour to Å¿ave the life of the poore HorÅ¿e; this potion was Å¿o violent, which notwithÅ¿tanding drove the HorÅ¿e into a moÅ¿t dangerous Calentura. But the next is better.

Take a Hens egge, and make a hole in the top thereof, no bigger than that you may get forth the white and yolke: Then take Tarre and Å¿weet Butter, of each like much, as much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate theÅ¿e well together into one body, and Å¿o convey it into the egge Å¿hell, and give it your HorÅ¿e three or foure mornings together, and either journey him gently, or elÅ¿e ride him three or foure houres after it; which done, bring him into the Stable and cloath him up warme, and litter him well, and let him be well rubbed, and Å¿o keep him upon the trench two houres after, and then give him Hay, and an houre after give him either a warme MaÅ¿h, or white water; and this will help a cold newly taken. â This will not make him Å¿icke, for I have often made tryall of it. Another as good as this.

Take the long white moÅ¿Å¿e that groweth upon an old dry Parke pale, one handfull, chop it Å¿mall, and put it into a pottle of good Ale or Beere, till one halfe be conÅ¿umed; then take it off, and Å¿traine and preÅ¿Å¿e it hard, and put into the liquor of AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris, of each halfe a Å¿poonfull, and a piece of Å¿weet Butter, and Å¿o give it him three mornings together faÅ¿ting, and it will cure him. X Another, if he hath taken a cold or poze in the head.

Take a quart of Muskadine, or Å¿weet Sacke, of Nutmegs, Pepper, CominÅ¿eed, Graines, Bay-berries, of each three drams, all made into fine powder: boyle theÅ¿e a waume or two, then take it off, and put into it a piece of Å¿weet Butter, and give it your HorÅ¿e three mornings together bloud-warme; let him all thoÅ¿e three dayes be kept warme, neither let him drinke any cold water, but either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, yea and that three or four dayes after; and during theÅ¿e three dayes, let him faÅ¿t three houres after the receit of his Å¿aid medicine. AlÅ¿o three dayes after when you perceive the cold to begin to breake from him, and to rot, cauÅ¿e him to Å¿neeze, by blowing into either noÅ¿trils, either the powder of Tobacco, or of Pepper, or of Elebore. X Another which will cure a longer-taken cold, yea though it be accompanyed with a dry cough and Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, or purÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e, which I had of MaÅ¿ter Markham, and I have often made tryall thereof, and it hath done cures which have been held impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have been effected.

Take of the conÅ¿erve of Elecampane three quarters of an ounce, and diÅ¿Å¿olve it in a pinte and a halfe of Å¿weet Sacke, and Å¿o give it your HorÅ¿e with a horne in a morning faÅ¿ting, and ride him gently a little after: and thus doe Å¿undry times untill you doe finde the infirmity to decreaÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: But HippoÅ¿erus, this ConÅ¿erve of Elecampane I doe Å¿uppoÅ¿e is hard to come by, for Å¿urely every Countrey Apothecary hath it not; how then may a Man make this Confection you Å¿o much commend?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Sir, this ConÅ¿erve I make my Å¿elfe, and I will give you the receipt hereof. You muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that there bee two kinds thereof, the one is called particularly a PreÅ¿erve, and the other an abÅ¿olut â¢
ConÅ¿erve. The firÅ¿t is Simple, the other Compound, both very Å¿overaigne for this Infirmity, but the ConÅ¿erve is evermore to bee eÅ¿teemed the better, and I do counÅ¿ell you never to be without either of them: for they will keep the whole yeere through, if they be reÅ¿erved cloÅ¿e Å¿topped. Wherefore as touching the firÅ¿t which is the Simple, you muÅ¿t preÅ¿erve it like as you doe all other greene rootes, and Å¿o keepe them in a Gally pot or GlaÅ¿Å¿e in a good quantity of its owne Sirop, till you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e the Å¿ame; and when you are to uÅ¿e it, let it bee beaten well in a Morter together with its Sirop and refined Sugar made firÅ¿t into very fine powder. Now your Compound or ConÅ¿erve is thus made: FirÅ¿t, let your roots of Elecamp â¢ ne be neatly Candied, and made very dry and hard, and get the beÅ¿t and youngeÅ¿t Rootes can be had, which muÅ¿t be kept alÅ¿o in a Gally pot or GlaÅ¿Å¿e cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, in a dry and warme place where they may not give againe; and when you would uÅ¿e them, take Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and beat it in a Morter with the Sirop of Colts Å¿oote, and the powder of refined Sugar, Å¿till working it till you have brought it to be a perfect ConÅ¿erve, and Å¿o given to your horÅ¿e in good Å¿weet Sacke or Muskadine. The firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e two, to wit, the Simple, is of moÅ¿t excellent uÅ¿e, for it helpeth any ordinary cold or Å¿topping, it comforteth the Lunges, enlargeth his Winde, purgeth the Head from all filthy matter, and diÅ¿Å¿olveth many other obÅ¿tructions, as well in the Body, and Head. But the Compound or ConÅ¿erve worketh better effects in the Body of the HorÅ¿e, eÅ¿pecially if the Malady be old and dangerous, or if there be any taint, in the Lunges, Liver, or inward parts: This ConÅ¿erve in time, by frequent uÅ¿e thereof will cure all dry Coughs which are held to be incurable, it helpeth the heaving of the Belly and Flankes, it cauÅ¿eth the HorÅ¿e to take his Wind kindly and temperately, and freeth him of his dry Cough which before did greatly annoy him; but if you have not theÅ¿e conÅ¿erves, take this other Receipt little inferiour to the former for theÅ¿e Maladies.

Take of the Å¿irop of Colts-foote, one ounce, of Elecampane rootes dryed, AnniÅ¿eeds, and Licoris, of each halfe an ounce, all made into fine powder, browne Sugar Candy powdred one ounce, which muÅ¿t be divided into two parts, then take Å¿weete Butter Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o make this into three Pills good and Å¿tiffe; which done, rowle them in the other moyty of your powdred Sugar Candy, and Å¿o give them your HorÅ¿e faÅ¿ting, then ride him gently for halfe an houre, and after Å¿et him up warme, and let him faÅ¿t three houres after, cauÅ¿ing him to be well rubbed: let him drinke no cold
water, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be with exerciÅ¿e, and let his Hay be Å¿prinkled with water, and his Oats wet in Å¿trong Ale, or elÅ¿e with Beere. â. Another very good.

Take the cankerous MoÅ¿Å¿e of an old Pale, or of the lymbes of an old Oake two handfulls, chop and Å¿hred it Å¿mall, and boyle it in a pottle of new Milke, and with it a roote of Alecompane, let theÅ¿e boile together till halfe be conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine it, and preÅ¿Å¿e the MoÅ¿Å¿e and Roote very well; which done, put to it of Å¿weete Butter the quantity of a Ducke-Egge, and Å¿o give it him in a morning faÅ¿ting bloud warme, and ride him moderately an houre after: then Å¿et him up, cloath him and litter him warme, and order him as is accuÅ¿tomed with HorÅ¿es in PhyÅ¿icke: Let him have this drink three mornings together, and it will cure both his Cold and Cough wet or dry, or his Poze if he have it. But if you find your HorÅ¿e to be Å¿topped in the Head, and that he voydeth filth, and Å¿tinking matter out from his NoÅ¿e, then Å¿hall you every morning adminiÅ¿ter this fume.

Take of Auripigmentum and of Colts-foote made into powder, of each two drammes, then with Venice Turpentine worke them into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and make them into Å¿mall Cakes the breadth of a Å¿ixpence, and dry them a little, and then put fire into a Chafing-diÅ¿h with coales, and Å¿o put one of theÅ¿e Cakes upon the coales, covered with a Tunnell, and Å¿o fume him, and this not only during his PhyÅ¿icke, but at other times after, and let his drink be either Å¿weet maÅ¿hes or white water. â. Another, if your HorÅ¿e hath a new taken cold, then give him this Caudle, which I have often uÅ¿ed and do find it to be very good.

Take the yolkes of foure new layd Egges, and beate them well together and diÅ¿Å¿olve them with a quart of good Ale, then take three good Nutmegs with a little AnniÅ¿eeds & Licoras, made all into fine powder, and as much Pepper in fine powder as you can take up upon a Å¿ixpence; put theÅ¿e into the Ale, with a peece of Å¿weet Butter Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and two Å¿poonefulls of ordinary Treacle, and of browne Sugar Candy foure ounces, warme all theÅ¿e upon the fire till the Treacle and Butter be molten, then give it him bloud warme, foure or five mornings together; and this is an infallible cure. â. Another very good.

Take a pottle of Å¿weet Wort, three heads of Garlick pilled, of ordinary Honey halfe a pound. boyle theÅ¿e till one moiety bee conÅ¿umed, and give it your HorÅ¿e three mornings together: Then for three mornings together after, give him theÅ¿e Pills. Take Boxe leaves and Harts-tongue, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, Å¿tamp them well together, and with Å¿weet Butter make it into Pills; and Å¿o every morning give him three of theÅ¿e Pils. â. But if he hath a cold which breaketh and runneth from him, then muÅ¿t you be carefull to keepe his Head and Pole warme, by putting on a double Hood, and every
Morning faÅ¿ting, ride him with two long GooÅ¿e-feathers put up into either NoÅ¿trill, well dipped before hand in Oyle de Bay, and with a Å¿trong Packthread from the ends of the quils faÅ¿tned over his head like a HeadÅ¿tall of a Bridle, Å¿o as the feathers may not get forth, and faÅ¿ten alÅ¿o to his Bit or Snaffle one Rooteor two of Polipodium; having beene all night before laine Å¿teeped in the oyle of Spike, and every time you ride him annoint the Bit thus before hand prepared with the Å¿aid Oyle, and when he commeth home, put upon his pole his double hood, and rub him againÅ¿t the hayre all over, eÅ¿pecially his Neck and Pole, (for friction in this caÅ¿e is moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne) then whilÅ¿t he is yet warme perfume his NoÅ¿e with FrankinÅ¿ence, Storax, and Beniamin, of each like much; do this nine daies together, and let his drinke be white water: for all Rhumes having had time to worke their malice will become dangerous, yea and many times cureleÅ¿Å¿e. â. Now if your HorÅ¿e hath taken an extreame cold; then:

Take Cloves, Nutmegges, Ginger, Galls, or the fruit of the Oake and Cardimums, of each like quantity Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and of Fennell-Å¿eeds more than any one of the other Ingredients, make them into fine powder, and Å¿earce them, then put two Spoonefulls of this powder to a quart of Sack or muskadine, and Å¿traine theÅ¿e into two penny-worth of EngliÅ¿h Saffron, and the yelkes of two new laid Egges well beaten together, give this to your horÅ¿e bloud warme faÅ¿ting, and let him have none other drinke than white water for three or foure daies after, and let his Hay be Å¿prinkled with water, and every day at noone give him the blades of reed, or the leaves of Sallows to eate out of your hand, for they be very good for him, and cooling for his body: do this divers mornings together, and it will not only cleanÅ¿e his Cold, but alÅ¿o open his Pipes, and Å¿et his wind at liberty. But if your horÅ¿e have an inward cold, which lyeth lurking in his Lunges or Stomacke, then give him this Medicine.

Take Oyle de Bay and good Tar, of each the quantity of three Wallnuts, halfe as much Hony, browne Sugar-candy in fine powder halfe an ounce, mixe theÅ¿e with a quantity of powdred BrimÅ¿tone Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿ew them into a fine linnen cloth, and ty it to his Bit or Snaffle, and Å¿o ride or journey him moderately till all be diÅ¿Å¿olved into his body, then bring him into the Å¿table, and cloth and litter him warme, and three houres after give Hay, and after a warme MaÅ¿h; uÅ¿e him thus three mornings together and longer, if you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e. â. Another.

Take bloud from him, if you have ground for the Å¿ame, otherwiÅ¿e not,Bran prepared. then inÅ¿teed of giving him Oates, you Å¿hall give him bran boyled in water after this manner, viz. Set a Kettle over the fire almoÅ¿t full of water, & when it beginneth to boyle, put in your bran, and let it boyle a full quarter of an houre at leaÅ¿t, then take it off, and let it Å¿tand till it bee almoÅ¿t cold, and about foure or five a clocke in the morning, give him this Bran Å¿o hot as he can eate it; then for his
drinke, give him the Å¿ame water, and at night give him Oates and white water, and let him be covered and littered warme; if it be in Summer, let not the Stable be too hot, for that will take away his Å¿tomacke, and make him faint and Å¿weat too much; and at night give him the quantity of what you can put into an Egge-Å¿hell among his Oates of this powder following, to which you muÅ¿t keep him for eight dayes together or longer, if you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e. You muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that the boyled Branne is that which dryeth up all his groÅ¿Å¿e and corrupt humours, which was the cauÅ¿e of his cold. Now the powder is this, viz. Take of Comen-Å¿eed, Fenugrick, Silleris-Montani (alias SiÅ¿ileos) Nutmegs, Cloves, Ginger, LinÅ¿eed, of each two ounces, Quick BrimÅ¿tone Å¿ixe ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and let them be well mixed: this muÅ¿t be given with his Oates, as is before inculcated; but he muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be watered; and then preÅ¿ently let him be well rubbed, body, necke, pole, legges, breaÅ¿t and belly, and cloathed and littered warme, and an houre before you give him his Oates, put into his Rack a little Å¿weet wheat Å¿traw, and Å¿o (I Å¿ay) let him eate thereof the Å¿pace of one houre or better, and then give him his Oates mixed with this powder, which having eaten, give him Hay at your pleaÅ¿ure; and thus doing in Å¿hort time you Å¿hall perceive his Cold to be quite gone, and the Å¿ooner if he Å¿hall be moderately ayered an houre after Sun-riÅ¿ing, and an houre before SunÅ¿et, if the Sunne doe Å¿hine. Now if this Cold bring with it a violent cough, as is often Å¿een, then give him the aforeÅ¿aid Wheat Branne boyled, together with the Å¿aid powder with his Oates, but then not above three or foure dayes, for that the Å¿aid powder diÅ¿perÅ¿eth the corrupt and groÅ¿Å¿e humours that are in the body, which doe occaÅ¿ion the Å¿aid cough, and when you doe perceive that he hath purged Å¿ufficiently, keep him notwithÅ¿tanding to his white water, but an houre before you doe water him;

Take a Å¿ticke of the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of your thumb or better, of well nigh a foot long, and wrap a linnen clout about it four or five times, firÅ¿t dipped in oyle de Bay, and put it into his mouth, and with Å¿ome piece of leather thong, or other Å¿mall cord faÅ¿ten it to either end of the Å¿ticke, and Å¿o faÅ¿ten it over his eares like the HeadÅ¿tall of a Bridle, like as Smiths uÅ¿e to do when they burn a HorÅ¿e for the Lampas, and let him drinke with this Å¿ticke in his mouth; which done, let him Å¿tand with it thus in his mouth an houre after at the leaÅ¿t, to the end he may licke and Å¿ucke up the Å¿aid oyle, and when he is to eate his Oates, put among them this other powder following, viz.

Take Fennell Å¿eed four ounces, Fenugrick two ounces, Cardimums one ounce, pound theÅ¿e groÅ¿ly, otherwiÅ¿e he will blow them away in eating his Oates, and with his Oates put every night of this powder one Å¿poonefull, and keep him warme, and Å¿o uÅ¿e him as before is preÅ¿cribed. â Another.

Take Ivy-berries and dry them, and make them into powder, and
Å¿o give it to your HorÅ¿e in Ale or Beere. This I never tryed, and this is onely for a cough. Another for a cough. Take of Å¿alt one pinte, of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, oyle of AnniÅ¿eeds one ounce, browne Å¿ugar Candy, in powder three ounces, give this with your horne to your HorÅ¿e three mornings together, and it will rid him of his cough, and heale any putrifaction in his lungs, or any other inward parts whatÅ¿oever. This alÅ¿o I never tryed, but it was highly commended to me. Another Receit for a cough, which I have found to be very good.

Take two new laid Egges, and open the crownes, and get forth Å¿ome of the white, and then put into theÅ¿e Egges Å¿o much of the powder of BrimÅ¿tone as you can take up upon a Å¿hilling into either Egge: give him this every morning for Å¿ome time, or till you Å¿ee the cough to goe from him. Another:

Take three new laid egs, and put them into a pinte pot, then put Å¿o much of the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t white wine vineger into the pot as will very well cover the Egges, and let them lye in the Vineger 24 houres at leaÅ¿t, then beat the Vineger and Egges together Å¿hels and all, and Å¿o give it your HorÅ¿e cold, and then ride or walke him an houre, and againÅ¿t his comming in, have this drinke in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, and give it him, viz.

Take IÅ¿ope, AnniÅ¿eeds, Licoris, Graines, Long Pepper, Gentiana, Elecampane dried, of each three drams, make all the Å¿pices into fine powder, and Å¿tamp the IÅ¿ope well, and Å¿o put all into good Sack one pinte, and of good Ale alÅ¿o one pinte, and of Honey one Å¿poonfull, and Å¿o boyle it, and give it your HorÅ¿e bloud-warme, and Å¿et him up, and cloth him, and litter him warme, cauÅ¿ing him to faÅ¿t three houres after it, and give him no cold water, but Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water; and this will cure him, for it is an approved good receit. â Another very good.

Take Wheate meale, AnniÅ¿eeds, Licoris, Polipodium of the Oake dryed, Elecampane dryed: make all theÅ¿e into powder, and mixe them well: Take two Å¿poonfuls of this powder, with a head of Garlicke pilled and bruized, mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and with your Wheate meale and honey as much as will Å¿uffice, make pils thereof to the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a great Walnut, and give your HorÅ¿e every morning three or foure of theÅ¿e Pils, and Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath taken them, give him two new laid Egges with their Å¿hels. X Another:

Take of life hony three Å¿poonfuls, of the beÅ¿t and whiteÅ¿t refined loafe Å¿ugar one Å¿poonfull and an halfe, made into fine powder, dryed Elecampane root made alÅ¿o into fine powder one Å¿poonfull, and of Amber-greece two graines, mixe all theÅ¿e very well together, and put it into an Egge-Å¿hell, and give him hereof at night late, and in the morning faÅ¿ting, and Å¿o let him faÅ¿t for three houres after, and be the cough never Å¿o violent, it will both Å¿tay and cure the Å¿ame. X This is right good, for I have had very great proofe thereof. Another:

Take Benjamin and BrimÅ¿tone made into very fine powder, of each halfe an ounce, give this your HorÅ¿e with one pinte of Muskadine, putting into it two new laid Egges Å¿hels and all, broken and well beaten together, let it be given three mornings together. This was commended unto me for a Å¿peciall good Receit, but I never did make tryall thereof. Another:

Take Nettle-Å¿eeds, AnniÅ¿eeds, ReyÅ¿ins of the Å¿unne Å¿toned, Elecampane in fine powder, of each halfe an ounce, make all the Å¿pices and Å¿eeds into very fine powder, and cut the ReyÅ¿ins very Å¿mall, and Å¿o boyle all theÅ¿e in Muskadine or Sacke a quart, with three Å¿poonefuls of life Honey, then Å¿traine it, and give it him three mornings together bloud-warme. This I never proved. Another:

Take of Rue one handfull, chop or Å¿tampe it very Å¿mall, and put to it a penny worth of AnniÅ¿eeds in very fine powder, make it up into Pils with Å¿weet Butter, and Å¿o give it your HorÅ¿e. X This I have found to be moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne for a HorÅ¿e that hath a cold whether newly or formerly taken, either wet or dry cough; it is alÅ¿o moÅ¿t excellent for a HorÅ¿e that hath been over-ridden, or any way wronged by labour. Now if his cough be Å¿o violent as that it may endanger his winde; then,

Take Calamint, Gentiana, Comin-Å¿eed, Licoris, Elecampane, of each two drams, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and confect them with life Honey and Butter mingled together and molten; and when it is cold, make it up into Pils; then rowle them in the powder of AnniÅ¿eeds, and give him of theÅ¿e Pils three or foure every morning, for two or three mornings together faÅ¿ting, and after keep him warm, and let his drinke be MaÅ¿hes or White-water. â. But if hee hath a Cough of the Lungs, give him theÅ¿e Pills. Take the Rootes of Mallowes newly gathered, Elecampane Rootes newly alÅ¿o gathered, of each one handfull, Å¿lice them thin, and boyle them in faire water with Barly two handfuls, till the roots be Å¿oft, then Å¿traine forth the liquor, and put into it a penny diÅ¿h of Å¿weet Butter, of life Honey three Å¿poonfuls, and as much Beane meale as will make all into a paÅ¿te; then make it into Pils, and rowle them up in the powder of AnniÅ¿eeds, and give him three or foure of them every morning faÅ¿ting for three or foure mornings together, keepe him temperately warme, and during the time he taketh theÅ¿e Pils, let his drinke be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water, and every day about mid day, give him boyled Barly or Brewers graines. â Another for a HorÅ¿e that hath his winde broken.

Take the leaves of Mullet, alias Mullen, alias HorÅ¿e-Lungwort, and dry them, and make them into fine powder, and then make them up in Bals or Pils with ordinary Hony Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice: let theÅ¿e Pils be made of the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of an Egge, and give him of them three at a time, fourteen or fifteen dayes together, or longer if you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, and let him not drink any cold water, during the time,
and for a while after the giving of his Pils, and let his exerciÅ¿e be very moderate, and his Hay Å¿prinkled with water, and his Oates wet with good Ale or Beere, and in Å¿hort time he will be well and Å¿ound againe. â This is a moÅ¿t approved good Receit, with which I have done cures held impoÅ¿Å¿ible to have been effected. Another:

Take Comen halfe an ounce, AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris, of each two ounces, dryed roots of Elecampane three ounces, make them into fine powder, and then boyle them in a pottle of Ale or Beere to a quart, then Å¿traine it, and give the liquor to your HorÅ¿e in a morning faÅ¿ting bloud-warme, and ride him moderately upon it, two or three houres, then Å¿et him up warme, and uÅ¿e him ut Å¿upra. This I never tryed, but he that gave it me did highly commend the Å¿ame unto me. Thus have I given you many Receits for a cold, and Å¿uch diÅ¿eaÅ¿es which are thereof dependant, whereof many are to my knowledge right good, and by my Å¿elfe experimented, with which I have done cures which have been held very Å¿trange, and beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: Truely HippoÅ¿erus as touching theÅ¿e maladies, Å¿omething there is in them, wherein I doe earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ire to be yet better informed; and firÅ¿t I would gladly know what be the diverÅ¿ities of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es which doe proceed from Colds; and how wee may come to know one malady from another.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Sir, in anÅ¿wer hereunto you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand, that from a cold taken doth iÅ¿Å¿ue many infirmities, if the Å¿aid cold be not Å¿peedily prevented; as namely, firÅ¿t Coughs, as well wet as dry, Catars, Murs, Rhumes, PoÅ¿e, Ratlings in the head, Kernels, and inflamations under the Chaule, with Bunches, Knots, PuÅ¿tils, &c. It cauÅ¿eth alÅ¿o Hide bound, Feavers, Head-aches, Frenzy, Sleeping-Evill, weeping-Eyes, Canker in the NoÅ¿e, Strangles, QuinÅ¿ey, to have Gourded or Å¿wolne legges: It will cauÅ¿e the hayre to Å¿tare, it will in time cauÅ¿e the mourning of the Chine (if there be Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e) Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, purÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e, purtiÅ¿ick, broken winde, (alÅ¿o if there be Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e) FreliÅ¿ed, broken and rotten lungs, glanders incurable, if it be not in time prevented, griefe and paine in the breaÅ¿t, Antecor, it will alÅ¿o cauÅ¿e the evill habit of the Å¿tomacke, dropÅ¿ie, loathing of meat, foundring both in the body and feet, tyredneÅ¿Å¿e, putrifaction and inflamations in the bloud; it will alÅ¿o cauÅ¿e many diÅ¿eaÅ¿es and inflamations in the liver, together with the Å¿iccity and aridity thereof, obÅ¿tructions, opilations, coÅ¿tiveneÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿toppings both in the body and pores, a conÅ¿umption in the liver, the overflowing of the gall, the unnaturall working of the Å¿pleene, the Yellowes, Stavers, the Collick and gripings, belly bound, laxe and bloudy-fluxe. All theÅ¿e and many more diÅ¿eaÅ¿es and maladies doe depend upon this one onely infirmity we call the cold, and therefore how needfull a thing it is for a man who is the true-lover of his HorÅ¿e, to be carefull what in him lyeth both to keep his HorÅ¿e from cold taking, as alÅ¿o to know how to cure the
Å¿ame Å¿o Å¿oone as it Å¿hall appeare, in performance whereof no Å¿mall diligence and art is required.

p.hi: YOu make queÅ¿tion whether or not there bee Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which is Å¿o commonly called the Mourning of the Chine, why is there not Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: No truely, there is no Å¿uch diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, for that which is called the mourning of the Chine, is none other thing than a plain and rank Glanders, which very few of our EngliÅ¿h Ferriers doe know how to cure, which hath its firÅ¿t Å¿ource and origen from a cold which being let run long, commeth to be a Glanders, which in time doth waÅ¿te the liver of the HorÅ¿e, whereby he dyeth; for if for your better underÅ¿tanding you Å¿hall be pleaÅ¿ed to open HorÅ¿es which doe dye of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, you Å¿hall evermore finde the chine and pith of the HorÅ¿e to be Å¿ound and whole, but the liver periÅ¿hed, and his lungs putrified, by reaÅ¿on whereof the HorÅ¿e long before his death caÅ¿teth forth of his noÅ¿e much corrupt and Å¿tinking matter and filth; wherefore this malady cannot in reaÅ¿on be Å¿tiled the mourning of the Chine, but meerely the Glaunders; and for remedy thereof, you Å¿hall have Å¿undry excellent Receits when we Å¿hall come to handle this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and therfore till then I forbeare to Å¿peake any more thereof.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: You queÅ¿tion alÅ¿o another diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called a broken winde, why this is Å¿o generall a malady as that no man but giveth it that name, what doe you call it?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Sir, as touching this infirmity, I Å¿ay there is none Å¿uch, for you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e Å¿o vulgarly called a broken wind, is truely a Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, or a taint or defect in the winde, PurÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e, the Asmat or PurtiÅ¿ick, as ArtiÅ¿ts doe call it. Three cauÅ¿es there be of this infirmity, two whereof proceed from a cold formerly taken, and the third from another cauÅ¿e, as Å¿hall preÅ¿ently be demonÅ¿trated. The firÅ¿t is an exulceration of the lungs, which doth begin from a cold; the Å¿econd by clinging and growing together of the lights, whoÅ¿e origen came alÅ¿o of cold; and the third is a diÅ¿location of the lungs, and this laÅ¿t commeth by meanes of Å¿ome violent or Å¿udden act or motion of the body, or by Å¿ome fall whereby the lungs were become diÅ¿located, diÅ¿placed, or turned in the body of the HorÅ¿e, every of which doe occaÅ¿ion Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, by reaÅ¿on the lungs have not power Å¿ufficient (being the bellowes of the body) to open, Å¿hut, and play at pleaÅ¿ure; and this is the cauÅ¿e why the HorÅ¿e heaveth at the ribs and flankes, fetcheth his breath Å¿hort and hot at the noÅ¿e, wheeÅ¿eth, and oft times reeleth when he is put to little that doth Å¿traine his winde, and therefore Å¿o long as he is kept in the Å¿table at dry and hard meats, he heaveth more then when he is at graÅ¿Å¿e, for if you doe waÅ¿h his Provender in Ale or Beere, and Å¿prinkle his Hay
with water, you Å¿hall perceive him to heave the leÅ¿Å¿e: but when he runneth at graÅ¿Å¿e, he heaveth Å¿o little, as hardly to be Å¿een, and the reaÅ¿on is, for that the HorÅ¿e having naturally a very moyÅ¿t body, the cold which he hath taken doth Å¿o condenÅ¿e and make thicke thoÅ¿e humours which before were thinne, which doe (whilÅ¿t they were tenues) paÅ¿Å¿e moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily through the pores, but now they are become thick, viÅ¿cous, and Å¿limy, Å¿topping the pores in Å¿uch Å¿ort, as hardly to be able to breath, but with great labour and no leÅ¿Å¿e paine, which doth provoke him to heave and lift, by reaÅ¿on that the lungs, pores, and pipes are Å¿o Å¿topped and oppreÅ¿t, as not to be able to performe their function and naturall office, for which nature hath created them, and beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e Å¿toppings doe conÅ¿traine him to cough and labour Å¿o extreamely, as to endanger oft times the breaking of a veyne, from whence enÅ¿ue many more inconveniences then this one: nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e you may have meanes to help his winde, but to recover him perfect and Å¿ound againe, I dare not abÅ¿olutely promiÅ¿e you, and if you be Å¿olicitous to underÅ¿tand more of this Å¿ubject, to Å¿ave both your owne labour and mine, if you will be pleaÅ¿ed to peruÅ¿e MaÅ¿ter Blundevile and MaÅ¿ter Markham, they are able to give you ample Å¿atiÅ¿faction.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat meanes have you to helpe a conÅ¿umption?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
We have two kindes of conÅ¿umptions, the firÅ¿t is called the dry malady, the other the conÅ¿umption of the fleÅ¿h: as touching the firÅ¿t, which commonly commeth at the firÅ¿t of a cold taken, then it exulcerateth the lungs, which in the beginning Å¿endeth forth thinne matter from the noÅ¿e, but after when it is growne more tough and viÅ¿cous, it runneth no more, but cauÅ¿eth a maceration and leanneÅ¿Å¿e through the whole body, whereby he droopeth and pineth away, and albeit he eateth and drinketh, yet it is without appetite, his meat doing him little good. The Å¿ignes to know it are theÅ¿e; his belly will be gaunt,Dry Malady. and he will be Hide-bound, his fleÅ¿h will conÅ¿ume almoÅ¿t to skinne and bones, if you Å¿trike him on the belly, it will Å¿ound hollow, his haire will Å¿tare, neither will he caÅ¿t it in due Å¿eaÅ¿on, when other HorÅ¿es which be Å¿ound will doe, he will cough hollow and faintly: the HorÅ¿e that is troubled with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, well may he be kept for Å¿ome time alive, but long he cannot be, for the malady is incurable, if it be too long let runne, and therefore I leave him to Dogs and Crowes in his languiÅ¿hing plight. The other conÅ¿umption is that of the fleÅ¿h, which alÅ¿o beginneth of a cold formerly taken, which for want of remedy in time, occaÅ¿ioneth a generall diÅ¿like and maceration throughout the whole body: it commeth from immoderate labour or travell by violent heat and cold taken upon it: it commeth alÅ¿o by riding him into the water after a great heat given, and then
Å¿et up preÅ¿ently negligently; as once it hapned to a young Nagge of good mettell and Å¿pirit, and of very great hope, the owner of which Nagge delivered him to an Ambler to pace, who whilÅ¿t he had him in agitation, hearing Hounds abroad made in to them, who rodde him hard all day to the death of the Hare, then comming home hot and all in a Å¿weat, neere to the Amblers HouÅ¿e was a River with a Water-Mill, where he Å¿et him up to the skirts of the Saddle, & then brought him into the Stable where was neyther cloath, litter, or other thing to keepe him warme, or wherewith to rub him, at which time hee tooke Å¿o deÅ¿perate a cold as never after to be cured: for in Å¿hort time after, he brought him to the Gentleman that did owne him, when upon his comming home the Nagge drooped, forÅ¿ooke his meate, and became very Å¿ick; the Gentleman deÅ¿ired me to endeavour the beÅ¿t I might for his recovery, for that he loved the Nagge well. I ignorant of the cauÅ¿e of his Malady, went as I thought according to Art, I tooke bloud from Å¿undry veines, I gave him a SuppoÅ¿itory, and after certaine ClyÅ¿ters, which I aÅ¿Å¿ured me were moÅ¿t needfull for him,ConÅ¿um â¢â¢â¢
on. all that I did adminiÅ¿ter wrought very kindly and well, but yet nothing could provoke in him an appetite, or be the meanes of any amendment, I then Å¿ayed him then with frictions, and Cordialls, but all was caÅ¿t away, ayring or ought elÅ¿e would not prevaile; then I perÅ¿waded the Gentleman to turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e, it being in the middle of May and a very Å¿eaÅ¿onable time, for I found him to bee inwardly Å¿ound, he ran at graÅ¿Å¿e about a month, but Å¿till grew weaker, and every day more meager then other, and at length he grew to be Å¿o much enfeebled by continuall languiÅ¿hing as that being downe, he was not able to riÅ¿e, but with helpe, in fine, Å¿hortly after the Nagge died: then for my better experience I would needs have him opened, which being done; a Å¿ounder body in a HorÅ¿e could not be Å¿eene, but I diÅ¿covered the cauÅ¿e of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e and death of this Nagge in his skinne, for it being taken from him, you might moÅ¿t evidently Å¿ee the Fat which did ly next unto his belly, brisket, ribs, and Å¿ides, to be Å¿o caked and hard, as that it, not being diÅ¿Å¿olved, the Nagge could never after enjoy himÅ¿elfe, which cauÅ¿ed him to waÅ¿t and dwindle of his fleÅ¿h, and languiÅ¿hing dy, which Å¿o Å¿oone as I eÅ¿pied, I preÅ¿ently told the Gentleman the owner of the Nag, that the Ambler had given him that Infirmity (the Nagge being then very fat) and after in his heate put him into the water, which the owner examining found to bee moÅ¿t true, as well from the report of honeÅ¿t neighbours who lived adjacent to the Ambler, as (after Å¿ome Å¿mall preÅ¿Å¿ure) from the ingenuous confeÅ¿Å¿ion of the very Ambler himÅ¿elfe. And this I think fit to bring you for an inÅ¿tance, to the end you may be the more carefull in avoyding the like inconvenience, and be the better able to judge of a Malady of this nature. But now as touching the beÅ¿t cure for a ConÅ¿umption of the fleÅ¿h (albeit there be many) yet I can recommend but only this one, which both MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, and MaÅ¿ter Markham
have recorded, which is this, viz.

ConÅ¿umption of the fleÅ¿h.Take a SheepÅ¿head with the wooll on, cleave it, waÅ¿h it, very cleane, and boyle it in a gallon of faire water, untill the fleÅ¿h come from the bones, then Å¿trayne the liquor from the fleÅ¿h, and put into the broath of refined loafe-Sugar halfe a pound, of Cinamon, conÅ¿erve of RoÅ¿es, conÅ¿erve of Barberies, conÅ¿erve of Cherries, of each three ounces, and give your HorÅ¿e of this broath a quart, every morning faÅ¿ting bloud warme, uÅ¿e this till foure or more SheepÅ¿heads be Å¿pent, and after every of theÅ¿e drinks let him be walked abroad, (if the weather be warme and not windy) otherwiÅ¿e walke him in Å¿ome barne, or warme place, and let him faÅ¿t two or three houres after, & let him not drinke any cold water in fifteene daies after at the leaÅ¿t, but let his drink be eyther Å¿weet maÅ¿hes, or white water, and for his Diet let that be what himÅ¿elfe beÅ¿t liketh, and that given by little at once and often: and by this meanes he may recover both FleÅ¿h and Å¿trength againe in reaÅ¿onable time, â. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e when he hath gotten FleÅ¿h, depart with him Å¿o Å¿oone as may be, leaÅ¿t upon any hard travell he happen to relaps, as is moÅ¿t probable he may. With this Receipt I have recovered three HorÅ¿es, whereof one was a HorÅ¿e of a high price.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: But tell me I pray you, were it amiÅ¿Å¿e (for this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e) to take bloud from him before you drench him?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea, that it were Sir very much amiÅ¿Å¿e, for Å¿o to do, were certaine death, for in caÅ¿es of ConÅ¿umptions you muÅ¿t take no bloud at all, but rather labour to cheriÅ¿h the bloud he hath, for his debility and feebleneÅ¿Å¿e wilbe Å¿uch, as that he conÅ¿uming Å¿o much in his FleÅ¿h, you muÅ¿t rather endeavour to procure his Å¿trength then any way to hinder the Å¿ame, which the loÅ¿Å¿e of bloud may moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily do. Neither muÅ¿t you be too buÅ¿ie in adminiÅ¿tring unto him Purges, but Cordialls, as Diapente, DiateÅ¿Å¿eron, Duke powder, Cordiall powder and Å¿uch like reÅ¿toratives, alÅ¿o by giving him good meat, as good Å¿trengthning bread and hartning, well made and of purpoÅ¿e for him, if he will eate bread, Å¿ometimes boyled Barley, and Oates, alÅ¿o boyled Beanes, and Å¿uch like hearty meat, as will reÅ¿tore him, and to give him Å¿ometimes about midday a quart of Å¿trong Ale or Beere, is very good, and will greatly comfort him. And thus keeping him warme, feeding him, and ordering him well, you may in time recover him againe. â. And this is the beÅ¿t CounÅ¿ell I can give you for this Infirmity.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: Now what Å¿ay you to a ConvulÅ¿ion? How doe you cure that?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
A Crampe and ConvulÅ¿ion is one and the Å¿ame Malady, which is a violent contracting or drawing together of the Sinewes,
and Veines, and Muskles, as well through the whole Body, as in any one member of the Å¿ame: yet doth it not alwaies apprehend or Å¿e â¢ ze the whole body, but takes one member or other as, Å¿ometimes it laieth hold upon the Eye, Å¿ometimes upon the Tongue, the Iawes, Lips, Legs, &c. which albeit it commeth by Å¿everall meanes, yet principally it comes eyther through cold in the body, or elÅ¿e for want of bloud, or laÅ¿tly by over much purging. The Å¿ignes to know this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e are moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ie, for that horÅ¿e that is therewith troubled, will have that member (for the time the fit is upon it) Å¿o Å¿tiffe, that a man with the utmoÅ¿t of his Å¿trength is not able to Å¿tirre the Å¿ame, by reaÅ¿on that the Sinewes and Muskles wilbe Å¿o much contracted as not poÅ¿Å¿ibly to bring the limb to its priÅ¿tine Å¿tate but only by rubbing and chafing, the limbe or member with warme cloths, and after the fit is over, it were very requiÅ¿ite to Å¿weate him in the Stable in his cloaths, for two or three houres together, and if the Malady bee in the lower parts, as in the Legges, ConvulÅ¿i â¢
then let that member which is taken be wiÅ¿ped up with thumb-bands of Hay made wet firÅ¿t, and after when the member is thus wiÅ¿ped, to caÅ¿t thereon cold water, and after this his Å¿weating, let his whole body (but eÅ¿pecially the member taken) be annoynted with the oyntment of Acopum before mentioned in the Å¿econd booke cap. 14 Â§. 1. A. and to give him Å¿ome of it inwardly with Å¿weet Sack, or Muskadine: and thus have I recovered Å¿undry horÅ¿es perplexed with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, giving him two or three drinks after of Diapente & then to keepe him warme, and to continue him for Å¿ome time with Å¿weet maÅ¿hes or white water, but when you come to give him cold water againe, let it be with exerciÅ¿e and ayrings after Sun riÅ¿ing, and before Sunne Å¿et, the Sunne Å¿hining, and when there is no wind, or other cold nipping weather. But if you have not of this Acopum in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, then apply this bathe or oyntment to the greived place or member, viz.

Take Pinpernell a good armefull, PrimroÅ¿e leaves, Camomile, Crow-foot, Mallowes, Fennell, RoÅ¿emary, of each Å¿ix handfuls, & fine up-land Hay, cut & made about MidÅ¿omer, when the Å¿trength and heart of graÅ¿Å¿e is at the beÅ¿t, a good quantity, put all theÅ¿e into a Lead or Chalderon, and fill up the Chalderon with faire water, and Å¿o let it Å¿teepe eight and forty houres, then boyle it untill the hearbs be Å¿oft, and bathe the the greived member therewith foure daies together, morning and evening warmed, which done, apply Å¿ome of theÅ¿e hearbs to the places or limbs greived and keep them on with a thumb-band of Hay, wet in the Å¿aid decoction, and every day about noone anoynt the Å¿aid viÅ¿ited member with Petroleum, and Nervall, and Oyle of Spike, mixed together, and keep him warme, give him good meat and maÅ¿hes or white water, not only during the time of his cure, but a good time after, and let his ayrings be temperate, and his exerciÅ¿e moderate, and take heed of waÅ¿hing him after labour, for that probably was the cauÅ¿e of his ConvulÅ¿ion. â. Another.

Take Å¿trong white Wine vineger, and Patch-greaÅ¿e, alias Peece-greaÅ¿e, of each like much, melt them upon a gentle fire, then with Wheat-flowre make it into a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and apply it to the grieved member good and warme, renewing it morning and evening, but before you doe adminiÅ¿ter this charge (by holding a barre of iron, or a chafing diÅ¿h of coales neere) let him be annoynted with Petroleum, Nervall, and Patch-greaÅ¿e, and oyle of Spike, of each like much) very well, and after binde on the charge all over the grieved place, dreÅ¿Å¿e him thus morning and evening, and give him moderate exerciÅ¿e and ayrings, and let him have MaÅ¿hes and white water to drinke, and keep him warm. This is very good â Another:

FirÅ¿t rake him, then give him the CliÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed in booke 2. chap. 11. Â§ 8. CliÅ¿ter 4. then let two men (on either Å¿ide of the horÅ¿e one) rub him well with Å¿oft cloaths all his body and limbs over, eÅ¿pecially the diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed limb, then cloath him up warme, and let him Å¿tand upon the trench foure or five hours, to the end the CliÅ¿ter may work the more kindly, after give him meat and white water, and Å¿o feed him for that day. But I muÅ¿t tell you, that Å¿o Å¿oon as you have given him this CliÅ¿ter, and before his friction, give him this drink whereby to cleanÅ¿e his body, viz.

Take of white wine one pinte, Aloes halfe an ounce, Agarick half an ounce, all beaten very Å¿mall, and infuÅ¿ed in the Wine, putting thereto of the pureÅ¿t clarified Hogs-greaÅ¿e one Å¿poonfull, or for want thereof (and which is much better) of Å¿weet Butter Å¿ixe ounces, and give him this bloud warme. The next day prepare in a readineÅ¿Å¿e this unguent.

Take of Å¿trong Ale two quarts, and of black Sope two pound, boyle them together till they look black like Tarre, and herewith annoynt, rub, and chafe him all over that the unguent may Å¿inke in: that done, cloath him up, and Å¿tuffe him warme that he may Å¿weat well, but Å¿tuffe head, necke, and breÅ¿t well, let him Å¿weat thus two hours, then coole him by degrees, taking now a little from him, then a little, till he be brought to a good temper againe, then keep him Å¿o, and about one of the clock at afternoon, give him a warm MaÅ¿h, or white water, and then Å¿ome Hay, and an houre after that Provender. Let not this drink be given him above once during his whole Cure, but his CliÅ¿ters, Sweats, and Frictions till he be well; yet the CliÅ¿ters not every day neither, and let his drinke be white water, wherein Mallowes have been boyled, unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ometimes you give him wherewith to comfort him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, but if he will not drink his white water boyled with Mallowes, then let him have it without, and let his food be that which is Å¿weet and very good. This did I never try, but two Å¿everall Ferriers who lived more then 100 miles diÅ¿tant the one from the other, gave me this Receit verbatim without Å¿carÅ¿e altring one word, and they both proteÅ¿ted unto me they have cured Å¿undry HorÅ¿es which have been forely perplexed with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: What meane you by moderate and temperate ayering of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I doe meane by moderate ayering,Ayering. that he be not forth in ayering too long, and by temperate ayering, that a Å¿icke HorÅ¿e if there be cauÅ¿e why he Å¿hould be ayered, it be not done too late in the evening, nor too early in the morning, for that Å¿uch kinde of ayerings will take too much from a HorÅ¿e that is feeble or Å¿ick, but in Å¿uch caÅ¿es, let him be walked to his ayerings in a warme evening, an houre before Å¿unne-Å¿et at leaÅ¿t, and in a morning an houre after the Å¿unne is up, eÅ¿pecially if the winde be not too high, or blow too cold, and that the Å¿unne Å¿hine warme: for by ayering before Å¿unne riÅ¿ing, and after Å¿unne Å¿et (like as is to be uÅ¿ed with Running and Hunting HorÅ¿es) will make a fat Å¿trong HorÅ¿e both Å¿o poor and leane, as not to have a Crow of fleÅ¿h on his back, as the proverb is, and Å¿o feeble as not to be able to ariÅ¿e being layed, and therefore give not Å¿uch kinde of ayerings to a HorÅ¿e that is infirme; but thoÅ¿e which I do tearme the temperate ayerings, will greatly comfort the Å¿pirits of your HorÅ¿e, give him a very good appetite to his meat, and encreaÅ¿e his fleÅ¿h and good liking, whereas the late ayerings will be (as I Å¿aid before) very noxious to Å¿icke, diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed, or leane HorÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you helpe a HorÅ¿e that groweth coÅ¿tive or belly-bound?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: The nature of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is Å¿uch, as that the HorÅ¿e that is therewith troubled, cannot diÅ¿charge himÅ¿elfe but with great paine and trouble, his ordure comming from him both very dry and hard. sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: WEll now that we have made an end of this Chapter, let us proceede on to another: Tell me I pray, how may a Dangerous SickneÅ¿Å¿e come to a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, that which you call Dangerous SickneÅ¿Å¿e is of divers natures, proceeding from Å¿undry cauÅ¿es,Dangerous Å¿icknes how it commeth. having everyone its diÅ¿tinct Å¿ymptoms, and therefore do require Å¿everall remedies; wherefore that you may the better know how and when any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e commeth, obÅ¿erve I pray, but theÅ¿e foure principles following, and you Å¿hall never erre. viz.

FirÅ¿t, that all Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e commeth either by heates in over violent exerciÅ¿e, as when the HorÅ¿e (v. g.) hath his greaÅ¿e molten, the heart overchaged, the vitall bloud forced from the inward parts, and the large Pores and Orifices of the heart Å¿o obÅ¿tructed, and Å¿topped, that the Å¿pirits cannot returne backe to their proper places, Å¿o as the Organs of the Body cannot rejoyce, but by this meanes the body muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity languiÅ¿h, founder, and mortifie.

Secondly, dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e commeth alÅ¿o by colds, as by indiÅ¿creete or negligent keeping, as well before as after long and violent exerciÅ¿e, and then is the head perplexed, the eyes dulled, and pained, the rootes of the tongue inflamed and Å¿welled, the lunges with rhumes tickled and offended, occaÅ¿ioning Å¿trong, and laborious coughing, and the NoÅ¿thrills often diÅ¿tilling and powring forth filthy and corrupt matter.

Thirdly, dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e commeth alÅ¿o by Å¿urfet of foode, either by eating too much, or too little of what is good, or alÅ¿o of that which is not wholeÅ¿ome, Å¿o as the firÅ¿t killeth, or at leaÅ¿t debilitateth the Stomacke, oppreÅ¿Å¿eth the Heart, and Å¿endeth up thoÅ¿e evill fumes into the Head by which are ingendred the Stavars, Frenzies, and other mortall diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, the Å¿econd putrifies the bloud, and converts all its nutriment into corruption, from whence proceedes the Yellows, Farcin, Feavers, Mainges, and other Å¿uch like peÅ¿tilent, leprous and loathÅ¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which Å¿uffocating the heart, and clogging the Stomacke, dilates and Å¿preads it Å¿elfe univerÅ¿ally over the whole body, leaving no member free, and confoundeth every faculty, and member thereof.

Fourthly, and laÅ¿tly, dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e comes alÅ¿o by accident,
as when a HorÅ¿e (v. g) receiveth Å¿ome deep or perilous wound or hurt, either in his body or elÅ¿ewhere in Å¿ome vitall or dangerous part, by meanes whereof nature is Å¿o farre offended, as that incontinently a general Å¿icknes Å¿eazeth upoÌ the HorÅ¿e, which (not in opportune time prevented) death Å¿uddenly enÅ¿ueth; and theÅ¿e infirmities are called by the more expert Ferriers, Accidentall feavers: for if you be pleaÅ¿ed to obÅ¿erve well, you Å¿hall finde the HorÅ¿e Å¿ometimes trembling, Å¿ometimes Å¿weating, Å¿ometimes cold, Å¿ometimes burning, but never in good temper. And thus much briefly of theÅ¿e foure points or grounds, which be the occaÅ¿ion of moÅ¿t dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e Accidentall.

p.hi: What meanes hath a man to know the Å¿ignes, whereby to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h theÅ¿e Å¿everall Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e the one from the other?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Very eaÅ¿ily Sir, for if Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e doth proceed from the firÅ¿t of theÅ¿e foure principles, to wit from heats, then are the Å¿ignes theÅ¿e, viz. The heavineÅ¿Å¿e of his countenance, Å¿welling of his limbs, eÅ¿pecially of his hinder legges, Å¿cowring and looÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e of his body, in the beginning of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hort, and hot breath, a loathing and forÅ¿aking of meat, &c.

If from the Å¿econd, viz. cold, then the Å¿ignes are, a dejected countenance, dulneÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿leepineÅ¿Å¿e of the eyes, Dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e how to know PuÅ¿tils or hard knots under the Chaule, yea and many times inflamed kernels and Å¿wellings Å¿o high as to the very roots of the eares, a rotten or moyÅ¿t inward hollow cough, he many times chewing betwivt his teeth, Å¿ome looÅ¿e, filthy, and flegmaticke matter, immediately after his coughing, which in Å¿ome caÅ¿es is not an evill Å¿igne by reaÅ¿on that thereby the cold rotteth and goeth away; whereas on the contrary Å¿ide for a HorÅ¿e to cough cleare and dry, doth demonÅ¿trate a dry cough, which hath long time lurked in his body, Å¿orely feÅ¿tring and tormenting him inwardly, which is very difficile to cure, but at length diÅ¿covers it Å¿elfe by reaÅ¿on the creatures languiÅ¿hing, and generall falling away of his fleÅ¿h, for his belly will be Å¿hrunke up, and when he drinketh much of the Å¿ame, water will iÅ¿Å¿ue forth of his noÅ¿e, his eyes will be either watry, or materative, and runne continually through paine which he hath in his head, procured by meanes of this cold, and his hayre will be rough and Å¿taring, &c.

From the third, to wit from Å¿urfet by meate, either naturall or unnaturall; the Å¿ignes be theÅ¿e, a dulneÅ¿Å¿e of the head, eyes, and countenance, yea and that in Å¿uch a violent manner, Å¿o as the HorÅ¿e will be hardly able to lift up his head from the manger, a dull and dead eye, and Å¿unk into his head, his eares prickt upright, and the tops of them cold, as alÅ¿o his upper lips and Å¿heath, his pace reeling and Å¿taggering, and (if the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e be farre gone) he will be of a frenetike and mad comportment, as by biting and gnawing the Racke and Manger, or whomÅ¿oever Å¿hall come within his reach, and Å¿ometimes by biting of himÅ¿elfe, and by beating his head againÅ¿t the wall and floore, and
