The fourth and laÅ¿t ground or principle is, that if his infirmity and Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e doe proceed from accidentall meanes, then are the Å¿ignes, a perplexed and troubled body, Å¿ometimes Å¿weating at the roots of his eares, in the flankes, and behinde the Å¿houlders, againÅ¿t the heart, Å¿ometimes he will be taken with a trembling all his body over, and Å¿ometimes with a glowing and burning in his vitall parts, as in the temples of his head againÅ¿t his heart, on the inÅ¿ide of his fore-legs next to the body, and on the inÅ¿ide of the hinder-legs, alÅ¿o his mouth will be dry and hot, his tongue will be Å¿ubject to be enflamed and furred; in fine he will have a loathing and averÅ¿ion from meat; but onely that he muÅ¿t eate, and a great draught and thirÅ¿t, and a great longing to drink cold water, and when he hath drunke what him liketh, yet will he nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e deÅ¿ire to keep his mouth continually in the water. Many other Å¿ignes there be, whereby a man who is any thing at all skilfull and cautelous, may by obÅ¿erving, diÅ¿cover when his HorÅ¿e falleth into any infirmity and Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, as when you doe perceive that his countenance and poÅ¿tures do alter from their uÅ¿uall cuÅ¿tomes, then be you well aÅ¿Å¿ured, your HorÅ¿e doth alter and decay in his health. AlÅ¿o you muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve his feeding, and how he doth eate, as whether with a good appetite, or with a weake Å¿tomacke, the firÅ¿t being good, the Å¿econd unkindely and unhealthy, as alÅ¿o how he doth diÅ¿charge or empty himÅ¿elfe, and how his urine and the colour of his doung or ordure doe alter, which if his doung or excrements be pale, and full of graines, then is it good, but if blacklÅ¿h and dusky (according as I have before in its due place handled) then be you confident, he hath much heate and dryneÅ¿Å¿e in his body, by which meanes probably enÅ¿ueth great and dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e: very many other Å¿igns of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e
there are, as the not caÅ¿ting or Å¿hedding of his hayre, in its due and proper Å¿eaÅ¿on, hide bound, coÅ¿tiveneÅ¿Å¿e, laxativeneÅ¿Å¿e, the clinging up of his belly to the flankes, continuall diÅ¿like, drowÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, dulneÅ¿Å¿e and heavineÅ¿Å¿e, when he hath wanted due ordering and feeding, &c. all which Å¿ymptomes are Å¿o well known to every man, as that they need not be handled further in this place.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: But now HippoÅ¿erus, Å¿ithence you have thus farre diÅ¿courÅ¿ed, what are the cauÅ¿es and Å¿ignes of dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, I would gladly you would Å¿hew me how I may either prevent Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e before it commeth, or cure the Å¿ame at firÅ¿t appearance?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, in this caÅ¿e two things are principally and diligently to be conÅ¿idered. The firÅ¿t is to prevent Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e before it Å¿hall approach, whereby it Å¿hall not offend at all, and the Å¿econd is, to take it at the firÅ¿t appearance, and Å¿o to prevent and hinder it, whereby to prevent the danger thereof. As touching the firÅ¿t,Dangerou â¢ Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e how to prevent. the beÅ¿t way will be three or foure dayes before you put forth your HorÅ¿e to graÅ¿Å¿e, to take bloud from him, and the next day to give him the drinke of Diapente halfe an ounce, with a pinte and a halfe of Å¿weet Sacke, which you Å¿hall finde mentioned in lib. 2. Â§ Å¿equent, and Å¿o by degrees to abate his clothes if he have had any, and it is alÅ¿o very good that when you doe take bloud from him, you doe receive it in a baÅ¿on or bowle, and therewith annoint his backe, loynes, fillets, breaÅ¿t, and all Å¿uch like places about him with the Å¿aid bloud, for it is moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome, and doth comfort the body very much, cleanÅ¿eth the skinne, and begetteth a generall rejoycing throughout all the vitall parts of the HorÅ¿e. To take Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e at its firÅ¿t appearance, whereby to Å¿end it packing before it hath taken deep root in the body of the HorÅ¿e, Dangerou â¢ Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e how to cu â¢â¢
Å¿o that it Å¿hall never come to danger of life or limb, then thus in a few words.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea Sir, if neither of theÅ¿e may be gotten, and that you are fearefull of the life of your HorÅ¿e, then doe I counÅ¿ell you thus.

Take of the beÅ¿t Tarre two ounces, of honey one ounce,DeÅ¿perate and dangerous Å¿ickneÅ¿ â¢
blacke Å¿ope two drams, and bay Å¿alt a handfull, incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, then fill two egge Å¿hels, the crownes onely being broken, Å¿o as you may get forth the meat, and fill them up againe with this medicine, and put them downe his throat, and walke or ride him gently up and down a quarter of an houre or more warme cloathed, that done, Å¿et him up warme, and litter him well, and let his drinke be either MaÅ¿hes or white water for foure or five dayes after, but let him faÅ¿t three houres after his medicine, and let his Hay and Provender
bee Å¿weete and good, â. This I have often experimented.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Should thinke HippoÅ¿erus, that for change, Bread were good to be given Å¿ometimes to a HorÅ¿e; I pray you what is your opinion thereof?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If you meane Å¿uch ordinary HorÅ¿e-bread, which our common Bakers uÅ¿ed to make for HorÅ¿es, (which is now long Å¿ince out of date and uÅ¿e) I Å¿ay it cannot be good for a HorÅ¿e, by reaÅ¿on it was ill made, and the Materialls whereof it was compounded, nouriÅ¿h very little, nay it hurteth a HorÅ¿e much more than it can do him good, for it breedeth evill humours, and worÅ¿e bloud in his body, it being made of bran and chiÅ¿ell for the moÅ¿t part with a little courÅ¿e Rye meale, to make it Å¿tick together, and Å¿o made up and kneaded with cold water, and after the outÅ¿ide of the loaves or roules are rowled in ground or rather bruiÅ¿ed peaÅ¿e, which can in no caÅ¿e bee good or wholeÅ¿ome. But if you have a deÅ¿ire to give your horÅ¿e bread, whereby hee may the better endure labour, eyther in his travell or long journeys, or in Tilting, Hunting, or otherwiÅ¿e, then if you pleaÅ¿e to give him this bread which I do heere preÅ¿cribe you, it will give him Å¿trength of body, be very much helpfull to his winde, keep him from fainting in his labour and exerciÅ¿e, be it never Å¿o Å¿ore.

HorÅ¿e breadTake Wheate meale, Oate meale, and Beanes, all ground very Å¿mall, of each one peck, AnniÅ¿eeds foure ounces, Gentiana, and Fenugrick, of each one ounce, Licoris two ounces, let all theÅ¿e be finely powdred and Å¿earced, and ad the whites and yelkes of twenty new layd Eggs, well beaten together, and put to the other ingredients, and Å¿o much Å¿trong Ale, as will knead it up, then make your loaves like to horÅ¿e-bread, but not too thick, and let them be well baked, but not burned, let not this bread bee given to your HorÅ¿e too new, and when you doe give it too him, let it be five or Å¿ix mornings together without other provender; and thus you Å¿hall have him well winded, luÅ¿ty, Å¿trong, hardy, and healthy, whereby to be able to hold out and retaine his mettle to the laÅ¿t. AlÅ¿o when he is to bee uÅ¿ed or employed:

Take a thinne linen cloath, and put therein of white Sugar candy, one ounce, and as much powder of AnniÅ¿eeds, Å¿ew up this to the Bit or Snaffle in a fine linnen cloath, when you are to take his backe, firÅ¿t dipped in White or Claret Wine, and Å¿o let him bee exerciÅ¿ed, or travelled with this in his mouth: this giveth moyÅ¿ture to his mouth, and Å¿tomacke, it expelleth inward heat, and faintneÅ¿Å¿e from his body and heart, and cauÅ¿eth him to forget his labour and travell, for it doth revive his vitall Å¿pirits â. Another kind of bread I will give
you not much unlike the former, but Å¿omewhat better and a greater cooler.

Take Wheate-meale one peck, Rie-meale, Beanes, and Oate meale, both ground very Å¿mall, of each halfe a peck, AnniÅ¿eeds, Lycoris, of each one ounce, and white Sugar candy foure ounces, all in fine powder, the yelkes and whites of twenty Egges well beaten, and Å¿o much white Wine as will knead it into a paÅ¿t, make this into great loaves, bake them well, and after they be two or three dayes old, let him eate of this bread, but chip away the outÅ¿ide. â.

p.hi: What is the reaÅ¿on you chooÅ¿e of theÅ¿e graines, meale rather then flower, wherewith you doe make your bread?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I preferre Meale far before Flower, by reaÅ¿on Flower is much more hot, and binding, and therefore the courÅ¿er the bread is, the better it is for the HorÅ¿e, and the more wholeÅ¿ome; and the reaÅ¿on, why I doe put Rie into my latter bread, is, becauÅ¿e Rie is a looÅ¿ener, and a cooler, and therefore it will make him the more Å¿oluble.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to diÅ¿Å¿olve and mollifie Tumors and hard Å¿wellings in the Legges, or other parts and members of the HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Tumors and Å¿wellings Å¿ometimes comes by heats gotten with over hard riding, whereby the creature being over much heat, the greaÅ¿e falleth downe, and Å¿etling in the Legges and other parts, doe grow dry and hard, this breedeth Splents, Spavens, Curbes, Ring-bones and the like Sorances, which in trueth are none other things then proper Tumors, beÅ¿ides it doth occaÅ¿ion other knots and Å¿wellings, which are to be cured after this manner, viz.

Take of the roots of Mallowes, or of Holliocks of each two ounces,DiÅ¿Å¿olve Tumors. of LinÅ¿eed, and of Fenugrick, of each Å¿ix ounces, of the fat or greaÅ¿e of Hennes or Capons, or for want thereof, of Neats foote oyle, a Wine quart, of Waxe Å¿ix ounces, Å¿teepe the rootes and Å¿eedes being bruiÅ¿ed, in a pottle of white Wine, when it is Å¿calding hoat, for three dayes and three nights, and the fourth day boyle them in the Å¿ame liquor, and adde thereto when you beginne to Å¿et it upon the fire, your greaÅ¿e and waxe, putting alÅ¿o thereunto of RoÅ¿in three ounces, then let all theÅ¿e boyle together a good while, and at the taking it from the fire, put thereinto of Venice Turpentine two ounces, and Å¿o Å¿tirre them together, and thus it is made fitting for your uÅ¿e, which being well reÅ¿erved, will diÅ¿Å¿olve all hard Å¿wellings and Tumors, the Sorances being dayly anoynted therewith, â. This I have by much practiÅ¿e found to be very good. Another.

Take white Lilly roots, Hemlock, Mallowes, Beares-foote, Scabeous, Cuccoe-pits, of each one handfull, chop them Å¿mall, and infuÅ¿e
them for twelve daies together in white Wine, and Sallet Oyle, of each one pint, then take wax foure ounces, and Beane Flower, twelve Spoonefuls, and Å¿o boyle it, and after Å¿traine it, and bring it to an Vnguent, and therewith anoynt the Tumors and Å¿welled parts, which being done, apply this PlaiÅ¿ter to the places. Another.

Take Darnell and red Docks, of each two handfuls, bruiÅ¿e them, and then boyle them in wine, and Salet Oyle, of each one pint, and Beane Flower foure Spoonefuls, and put thereto of AÅ¿Å¿es or Oxes dung, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, when it is boyled to a pultis, apply it PlayÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e and uÅ¿e this every day once, till it be well, â. This is alÅ¿o very good. Another.

Take LinÅ¿eed and pound it in a Morter, and of Fenugrick in powder, of each foure ounces, Pitch, and RoÅ¿in, of each three ounces, Damaske RoÅ¿e leaves dryed, two ounces, Pitch of Greece Å¿ix ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e together, and when you are ready to take it from the fire, adde thereto of Turpentine two ounces, Honey Å¿ix ounces, and Sallet Oyle, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and thus applying this Salve PlaiÅ¿ter wiÅ¿e to the place, it will mollifie any hard Å¿ubÅ¿tance. â. This I have often tryed and have found it to bee very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt HippoÅ¿erus, is there any cure for a Å¿ick HorÅ¿e? whoÅ¿e infirmity is Å¿o deÅ¿perate, and he Å¿o farre Å¿pent, as to bee generally judged to be almoÅ¿t at the poynt of death?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Truely Sir, both my MaÅ¿ter and my Å¿elfe have done Å¿uch cures upon HorÅ¿es, which have beene Å¿o deÅ¿perately Å¿ick as you Å¿peak of; inÅ¿omuch as the beholders have pronounced Å¿entence of death upon them, and the owners would have beene well content to have beene Å¿atisfied, and well appayed with their skinnes and Å¿hooes, and I will Å¿hew you what our cure is.
FirÅ¿t open the neck veine, and let him bleed well, then two houres after his bleeding,

Take of DiateÅ¿Å¿eron halfe an ounce, and give it him bloud warme in Muskadine a pint,DeÅ¿perate Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e. or Sack, for want thereof, or elÅ¿e if theÅ¿e be not on the Å¿uddaine to be gotten, then take good Ale or Beere, with the like quantity of DiateÅ¿Å¿eron, then having given it, walke him halfe an houre (if he be able) in the warme Sunne, or if there be not SunneÅ¿hine, then in Å¿ome warme Stable, or Barne, then Å¿et him up warme cloathed, and littered, and let him be rubbed all over, as Head, Pole, Neck, and Legges, and eÅ¿pecially twixt the Eares, for that greatly eaÅ¿eth the payne in the head, by reaÅ¿on it diÅ¿Å¿olveth and diÅ¿perÅ¿eth the humors: at noone unbridle him, and offer him a little Å¿weet Hay, Å¿prinkled with water, which if he Å¿hall refuÅ¿e to eate, (as tis likely he
will) then offer him Å¿o much bread as the quantity of a penny loafe, and let him eate it all if he will, but if he do refuÅ¿e to eate thereof alÅ¿o, then give him one gallon of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Ale-wort you can get of the firÅ¿t runnings Å¿o Å¿oon as it is maÅ¿hed, but let it not be over-hot, and before barme be put unto it, give him this I Å¿ay bloud warm, but if that cannot be gotten, then provide him in a readineÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t the Å¿ame houre, a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, which when he hath taken, fume his head with Olibanum, Storax, and Benjamin, and then let him be rubbed againe as before, and Å¿ee him warme kept as is uÅ¿uall for Å¿icke HorÅ¿es in phyÅ¿icke: and thus doe for three dayes together in all poynts (bloudletting excepted) for that muÅ¿t be once onely (unleÅ¿Å¿e extraordinary cauÅ¿e doe require the Å¿ame) and aÅ¿Å¿ure your Å¿elfe your HorÅ¿e will mend daily, and recover his health and Å¿trength in Å¿hort time, and at three dayes end, give him no more MaÅ¿hes, but in their Å¿tead, let him have white water onely: if by meanes of this Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e he hath any PuÅ¿tils or inflamations riÅ¿en under his chaule, then clip away the hayre, and apply Å¿uch things thereunto, as may ripen them and bring them to a head; and after breake them with Shoomakers waxe, or other Å¿uch like good things, and Å¿o let them runne and heale at pleaÅ¿ure. AlÅ¿o if you doe finde your HorÅ¿e to be coÅ¿tive by meanes of his Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, as commonly horÅ¿es will be after PhyÅ¿icke, then firÅ¿t rake him, and finding his doung to be hot, dry, and hard, give him the Å¿uppoÅ¿itory of a candle, Å¿hewed you in chap. 18. Â§ 27. SuppoÅ¿. 1. of this Å¿econd Booke. And this is the beÅ¿t SuppoÅ¿itory can be given him in a caÅ¿e of this nature. â But if contrariwiÅ¿e you finde him to have a Å¿trong and violent laxe, or Å¿cowring upon him, whereby he purgeth overmuch, and Å¿o continueth, then be you aÅ¿Å¿ured that hee hath Å¿omething in his body wherewith nature is offended, which you muÅ¿t labour to remove, and for remedy thereof,

Take of new milke one quart, and put to it of Beane flower two Å¿poonfuls, and as much of the powder of Bolearmonack Å¿earÅ¿ed, boyle theÅ¿e untill the milke thicken, and Å¿o bloud warme give it your HorÅ¿e, and in a morning or two faÅ¿ting with a horne, and it will Å¿tay his looÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e: â but if this doe it not, then Å¿hall you

Take of red Wine one pinte, or Tinto the like quantity, and put into it of BurÅ¿a-PaÅ¿toris, one handfull, and of Tanners Bark in fine powder, half a handful, the outÅ¿ide being firÅ¿t taken away, then boyle it till the hearb do begin to be Å¿oft, then Å¿traine it, and put thereto of Cinamon powdred two Å¿poonfuls, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme, one or two mornings, and this will infallibly Å¿tay his fluxe: and if you cannot get Diapente or DiateÅ¿Å¿eron, then give him this drinke.

Take of Dragon-water one pinte, London Treacle one ounce, warme it till the Treacle be diÅ¿Å¿olved, and Å¿o give it him bloud warm; give him this drinke three mornings together, and for his drink otherwiÅ¿e, let him have Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes three mornings onely, and after till he be well recovered, let him have no cold water by any meanes, but
onely white water, and through Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance he will be Å¿oone reÅ¿tored to his former health. â TheÅ¿e things I have often practiÅ¿ed to good purpoÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: VVHat is to be done to a HorÅ¿e that droopeth, pineth, or languiÅ¿heth?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth by a cold taken, or by Å¿ome unnaturall Å¿urfet, by reaÅ¿on of over-hard riding, or by being waÅ¿hed after an extreame heate; the fignes to know it, is, he will feed, but with no appetite, neither will the meate he eateth, diÅ¿geÅ¿t well with him, for, give him Oates and you Å¿hall finde many of them come forth whole in his ordure, beÅ¿ides, he will be lanke in the belly and flankes, and his fleÅ¿h will fall away. The cure for Å¿uch a malady, is firÅ¿t to

Drooping.Take bloud from him as well in the necke as Å¿purre veines, for that the bloud is moÅ¿t corrupt, and naught, the next day rake him, and adminiÅ¿ter unto him the CliÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. chap. 6. and Â§ 7. CliÅ¿t. 3. C. the next day after he hath taken his CliÅ¿ter, give him this drinke.

Take of new milke warmed as much as will Å¿uffice, the yelkes of three new laid Egges, of pepper, made into very fine powder, a halfe penny worth of AnniÅ¿eeds, Myrra, Bay-berries, Turmaricke powdred alÅ¿o, of each halfe a dram, of ordinary Treacle one penny worth and a little Å¿affron powdred, pound all the Å¿imples that are to be pounded, every one by it Å¿elfe, and mixe them well with the reÅ¿idue, and let them infuÅ¿e in the milke a whole night, and the next morning give it to the HorÅ¿e bloud warme, and after order him as you are accuÅ¿tomed to doe to Å¿icke HorÅ¿es in PhyÅ¿icke, but let him have this drink five mornings together, and keep him to MaÅ¿hes or white water, and if during that time you doe not finde his appetite to come unto him better then before, then let him reÅ¿t foure dayes, and at foure dayes end give him this drinke, viz.

Take Bay-berries, Iuniper-berries, AriÅ¿toloch. rot. Ivory, Myrra, of each two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and Å¿earÅ¿e them, and let them be well mixed, boyle of this powder two Å¿poonfuls in Å¿trong Ale one quart, or Muskadine or Sacke one pinte, which is much better, adding thereto when you take it from the fire, Å¿o much Pepper finely beaten, as will lye on a Å¿ixe pence, and Å¿o much grated Ginger as will lye upon a Å¿hilling, and Å¿o bloud warme adminiÅ¿ter it to your HorÅ¿e, then Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath taken this drinke, trot him gently a mile or two upon faire ground, and then Å¿et him up warme, and cauÅ¿e him to Å¿weate in the Stable an houre, but not too violently, and after coole him diÅ¿creetly, and by degrees, and give him this drinke and Å¿weats three times, to wit, every other day, and after the taking of theÅ¿e three drinkes, Take of burnt Sack one
pinte, and put to it of Arement two good lumps made firÅ¿t into fine powder, and give it your HorÅ¿e two mornings, that is to Å¿ay, having given it him once, let him reÅ¿t, and then give it him for the Å¿eco â¢ d drinke foure dayes after. â And thus have I cured Å¿undry horÅ¿es of this infirmity.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a DropÅ¿ie?

sp.speaker: HyppoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e hath an apparant ground more then conjecturall, for it never commeth to be knowne by any Å¿ymptomes, but onely when the horÅ¿e falleth into diÅ¿like, and loÅ¿eth the true and perfect colour of his hayre and skinne, and when he loÅ¿eth his Å¿pirit, mettle, Å¿trength, cheerefulneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿tomacke, and therefore we Å¿ee it commeth principally for want of good nouriÅ¿hment and digeÅ¿ture, which paÅ¿Å¿eth into melancholy, it proceeding either from the Å¿pleene, or from the liver, or both, the bloud being corrupted, and converted into a thin and watry Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and Å¿ometimes it commeth of over-much reÅ¿t, for want of moderate exerciÅ¿e, which I doe judge to be the more probable. Some Ferriers doe affirme that there be three kindes of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, but I could never obÅ¿erve more then one only, which hath its origen either of melancholy bloud water, or winde, but chiefly of water, by reaÅ¿on that the belly & legs of a horÅ¿e will Å¿well, and that a watry humour runnes 'twixt the skin and the fleÅ¿h, and if you lay your finger hard upon the Å¿wolne places, when you Å¿hall take it away, there will be in the place a pit for a Å¿mall time after. The Å¿ignes to know it are, that he will be Å¿welled both body and legges, he will be alÅ¿o Å¿hort-breathed, loÅ¿e his Å¿tomacke, have in his body a continuall drought, but yet when he commeth to drinke, he will not drinke much, but pudder long with his noÅ¿e in the water, he will be as if he had a generall conÅ¿umption over all his body, and in time he will pine and fall away to the very bones, and his flankes and buttockes will be dry, and his hayre will Å¿hed and pill off with every rubbing, &c. The cure is, firÅ¿t let him bloud, to take away the cold,DropÅ¿ie. thin watriÅ¿h or wheyiÅ¿h bloud, that better may come in its place, then cover him warme, and give him a Å¿weat in the Stable, but if he will not be brought to Å¿weat in the Stable (as many times it Å¿o falleth out) then exerciÅ¿e him abroad till he Å¿weat, and bring him into the Stable againe, and cloath and litter him warm, and let him be well rubbed, and give him Sallow leaves, or the leaves of the Elme tree greene, Rye blades, Sedge, or GraÅ¿Å¿e, to keep his body open, and when you doe give him Hay, let it be Å¿princkled with water; then give him this drinke:

Take of Ale one gallon, Å¿et it upon the fire, and Å¿cum off the froth as it riÅ¿eth, then put into it of Worm-wood, and of Rue the tender tops and leaves without Å¿talkes carefully picked, of each a handfull,
and Å¿o boyle the Ale to a quart, then take it off, and Å¿traine it well, and diÅ¿Å¿olve into it of the beÅ¿t London Treacle three ounces, and put alÅ¿o unto it of long-Pepper and Grains both made into fine powder, of each one ounce, then brew all theÅ¿e well together till it be but bloud warme, and Å¿o give it him to drinke, then bathe and annoynt the legs that be Å¿welled with Trayne-oyle twice a day, till the Å¿welling goe away; and give him MaÅ¿hes or white water, and feed him with Å¿uch meate as he will beÅ¿t eate, changing his dyet daily, and give it him by little at once, and after Å¿ome Å¿mall time thus Å¿pent with him, if the weather be Å¿eaÅ¿onable, turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e, and he Å¿hall doe well and become Å¿ound againe. â This is all the DropÅ¿ie I doe know, howÅ¿oever many Ferriers doe talke much of another kinde which they doe call the Feltrick, which is not truely a DropÅ¿ie, but a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e diÅ¿tinct from the DropÅ¿ie, unto which young HorÅ¿es are inclinable, that from Foles and Colts are bred in Fennes, Moores, MarÅ¿hes, moyÅ¿t and wet grounds, and Commons, by meanes whereof they will Å¿well exceedingly under the belly, and Å¿o Å¿oone as they doe come to be handled and backed, whereby they may be provoked to Å¿weate, they will preÅ¿ently have inflamations under the Chaule, runne at noÅ¿e, fall into an incurable Glanders, and in a word become inwardly rotten, The cure is,

Feltrick.FirÅ¿t with your fleame Å¿trike him in Å¿undry places under the belly, where the Å¿welling is moÅ¿t ranke, and Å¿o let the corrupt bloud and filth iÅ¿Å¿ue forth, by the Å¿pace of an houre or two, then wipe the places cleane and dry, and then

Take of Buck-lye made very Å¿trong with chamber-lye, and the aÅ¿hes of AÅ¿hen wood, and diÅ¿Å¿olve into the lye of Vnguentum Populeon, and Dialthea, of each one ounce, or as much as will Å¿uffice, according to the Lye you have, and being made good and hot, waÅ¿h, bathe, and annoynt the Å¿welling therewith morning and evening till the Å¿welling be quite gone, and after every dreÅ¿Å¿ing, trot him up and downe by the Å¿pace of a quarter of an houre, which will be a very good meanes to cauÅ¿e the humour to diÅ¿Å¿olve, and Å¿o to depart the Å¿ooner and the better, and for two or three dayes, give him faÅ¿ting a quart of good Ale, and of Diapente two Å¿poonfuls, which muÅ¿t be immediately before his trotting forth, after his dreÅ¿Å¿ing, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warme, and give him white water. â And thus have I cured many HorÅ¿es of the Feltrick.

p.hi: VVHat is good to take dead fleÅ¿h out of a Å¿ore?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
We uÅ¿e Å¿undry Å¿orts of corroÅ¿ives wherwith to cleanÅ¿e foule wounds, and to eate away dead, proud, and naughty fleÅ¿h out of Å¿ores to the end they may heale and carnifie the better and more kindely: but yet omitting all Å¿orts of powders
and other corroÅ¿ives to corrode and eate away dead fleÅ¿h, I will teach you a moÅ¿t precious Vnguent, which will take off any dead, proud, Å¿pungy, or bad fleÅ¿h, in the foote or any other part of the Body, be the wound never Å¿o deep or ulcerated, and it will not only take away all proud, dead, and naughty fleÅ¿h, but it will alÅ¿o clenÅ¿e, and heale up the Å¿ame very Å¿oundly in Å¿hort Å¿pace, And this Vnguent is thus made and compounded.

Take of common Hony two ounces, Roach-alume, Verde-greaÅ¿e and Vinegar, of each one ounce, Å¿ublimat two drammes,Dead fleÅ¿h let all bee made into fine powder, and boyle it a few waumes, keeping it Å¿till Å¿tirring, and then take it from the fire, and keep it in a gally pot Å¿topped, for your uÅ¿e. Apply this Vnguent upon lint or fine hurds, to the Sorance once a day, and it cureth Å¿peedily, and Å¿oundly, but then obÅ¿erve that every day before you dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ore, you cleanÅ¿e, waÅ¿h, & inject into the wound the water taught you in the next Â§. which I will Å¿hew you for a Puncture or deepe wound, â. And this is an approved cure, and beyond all peradventure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVEll Å¿hew mee then, what is good for a Puncture or deepe wound?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If it be in the foote, or any other part of the Body, if you can come well unto it, or if it be an ImpoÅ¿tumation unbroken, Å¿cald it firÅ¿t with the medicine of red-Tarre, Hogs-greaÅ¿e, Bay-Å¿alt, and greene Copporas, deÅ¿cribed in lib. 2. cap. 16. Â§. 10. for the Poll. evill, then waÅ¿h the wound with this water.

Take red-Sage, Plantane, Ribwort, Yarrow, Bramble-leaves,Deepe wounds. RoÅ¿emary, IÅ¿ope, and Honey-Å¿uckle-leaves, of each one half a handfull, boyle them in white Wine one pint, and as much of Smithes, or coletrough-water, then adde thereunto in the boyling, of common Honey one Spoonefull, and as much Alume, as a wall-nut, and a bright black peece of Sea-cole, the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of an Egge unbroken, then let this boyle till the one moiety bee conÅ¿umed, then Å¿trayne it hard, and waÅ¿h the Sorance therewith, and if the wound bee deepe, inject of this water with a Å¿iring or Å¿quirt every day: when you dreÅ¿Å¿e him, and by thus doing you Å¿hall cleanÅ¿e the wound, take away all dead and bad fleÅ¿h, and heale up the wound, both Å¿oundly and Å¿peedily. â. This is a moÅ¿t approved Receipt.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is beÅ¿t to be applyed to a deÅ¿perate Straine?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If it bee Å¿o deÅ¿perate an old Straine as that it be holden incurable, if it lyeth in the Shoulder, or other hidden
and fleÅ¿hy part of the Body, or that the HorÅ¿e have a FiÅ¿tula, Poll-evill or other inflamation, or Å¿welling, then uÅ¿e but this one Medicine, and it will cure the Å¿ame. viz.

DeÅ¿perate Å¿traine.Take a large earthen veÅ¿Å¿ell, or crock of one, two, or three gallons or more, and fill it almoÅ¿t to the top, with AÅ¿mart and Brookelime, of each like much, and mix them well, then fill it up to the top with old chamber-lye as can be gotten, Å¿o that all the herbs be quite covered and more, then Å¿top it cloÅ¿e with a board or Å¿ome Å¿uch like thing, and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e, for it never can bee too old; now when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e this Medicine for any griefe aforeÅ¿aid, then take an earthen Pipkin, and put thereinto aÅ¿well of the liquor, as of the hearbs Å¿o much as Å¿hall Å¿uffice, for your preÅ¿ent uÅ¿e, and boyle it well upon the fire. Then if it be for a Å¿trayne in the Å¿houlder, you Å¿hall take an old boote, and cut of the foote, Å¿o as you may draw it over the HorÅ¿e-foote and bring it up above the knee, almoÅ¿t to the Elbow of the Shoulder, keeping the neather part of the boote as cloÅ¿e and Å¿traight to the legge as may be, but the upper part which is to cover the Å¿houlder muÅ¿t be wide and Å¿patious; then into this boote thruÅ¿t all this mixture, Å¿o hot as the HorÅ¿e can Å¿uffer it, and lay it faÅ¿t, and cloÅ¿e about the Å¿houlder, eÅ¿pecially before and behind; then drawing up the upper part of the boote, Å¿o faÅ¿ten it to the Mane, and about his Neck, as that it may not by any meanes Å¿lip downe, but keep conÅ¿tant and firme; and thus you muÅ¿t apply this Medicine to the place, till the griefe depart; this is the moÅ¿t violent of all medicines, and fit for no creature but a horÅ¿e to endure, yet in Å¿hort time it will bring forth whatÅ¿oever evill matter lyeth in the Ioints; and if you have occaÅ¿ion to apply this to a FiÅ¿tula, Poll evill, or any ImpoÅ¿tumation, or Å¿welling, then may you Å¿pare the boote, and only lay on the medicine in manner of a Pultis, and it will be Å¿ufficient. â. This is a very approved Receipt.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat meanes have you to diÅ¿Å¿olve GreaÅ¿e or Glut in a fat or ketty HorÅ¿e, after a Å¿trong heate or violent exerciÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: For a thing of this nature, I have Å¿eene this Å¿cowring adminiÅ¿tred, viz.

DiÅ¿Å¿olve greaÅ¿e.Take of Å¿weet Sack one quart, and Å¿et it upon the fire, eyther in a BaÅ¿in, or open Skillet, and when it is Å¿calding hot, put into it of RoÅ¿in one ounce, made into very fine powder, then by degrees a little after a little, convey it into the Sacke, continually Å¿tirring it as you put it in, for feare of clotting, and when the Sack and it is very well incorporate, take it from the fire, and put into it of Sallet oyle halfe a pint, and Å¿o Å¿tirre them well together, and as it cooleth, put alÅ¿o into it of browne Sugar-candy, made into fine powder one ounce, and
when it is only bloud warme, give it to your HorÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿oone as hee commeth from his exerciÅ¿e, and then being Å¿et up, let him bee well rubbed, and cloathed warme and well littered, and let him faÅ¿t three houres after it, and let the Groome remaine continually with him during theÅ¿e three houres, till you do give him meate, yea and an houre after, neyther let your horÅ¿e all that time Å¿tand Å¿till long, nor Å¿leepe, but be kept Å¿tirring, and mooving, for that the medicine will by that meanes worke the more kindly, and when you Å¿hall give this or any other Å¿cowring, be you Å¿ure that neyther the Å¿ame day, nor the next, you give him any cold water, but eyther a Å¿weet maÅ¿h or white water. This Å¿cowring I once did Å¿ee made, and given by a Iocky to a Å¿trong, luÅ¿ty, able hunting HorÅ¿e, which he had in agitation for a hunting match, but it wrought Å¿o violently, and made him Å¿o extreame Å¿ick for more then twenty foure houres after the taking thereof, as that I never durÅ¿t be Å¿o hardy, as to put the Å¿ame in ure, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the Creature did very well recover againe, and wonne his match.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw may a man come to know, what are the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the Liver?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
AÅ¿Å¿uredly Sir the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the Liver are many, but yet the true and certaine grounds, how to diÅ¿cover them is beyond every Ferriers skill to compaÅ¿Å¿e; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e that there be many, and thoÅ¿e Å¿everall and diÅ¿tinct Infirmities in the Liver, no man needes make doubt: for if the Liver be eyther too hot, or too dry, too moiÅ¿t, or too cold, may eaÅ¿ily be diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed, which muÅ¿t needs occurre to the HorÅ¿e, eyther by intemperate riding or labour, or by evill foode, or by meanes of evill and corrupt humors, which do gather to the place, or by the overflowing of the Gall, or when Choler is predominate, it being cheifly ingendred through heat, like as cold begetteth Flegme, which cauÅ¿eth the Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e and ill diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the Liver, together with its payne and anguiÅ¿h, whence proceede inflamations, and ImpoÅ¿tumations, Å¿toppings, obÅ¿tructions, knobs, yea and very pernicious Vlcers, every of which do cauÅ¿e the generall ConÅ¿umption and diÅ¿eaÅ¿e thereof. If the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the Liver do proceed from any hot cauÅ¿e, it is more eaÅ¿ie to bee diÅ¿covered, then if it came from any cold cauÅ¿e, for that it doth diÅ¿cover it Å¿elfe by theÅ¿e apparant Å¿ignes viz. He will bee leane and fall away of his fleÅ¿h, hee will loath his meate, and that which he eateth doth him little or no good, for want of ready digeÅ¿tion, his ordure wilbe very offenÅ¿ive, his thirÅ¿t great, and he will be verv much Å¿ubject to a looÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e: whereas on the other Å¿ide, if the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e ariÅ¿eth from any cold cauÅ¿e, you cannot diÅ¿cerne it bv any of theÅ¿e Å¿ignes, for that he will be in very good liking & Å¿tate of body, eate his meat with a good appetite, his excrements will
have no evill Å¿avour when he diÅ¿chargeth himÅ¿elfe, he will drinke orderly and temperately, neither will he be looÅ¿e or coÅ¿tive; wherefore if it come of any cold cauÅ¿e, we muÅ¿t then endeavour to finde out its Å¿ymptomes. Now if a HorÅ¿e be diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed in his liver, the infirmity muÅ¿t (I Å¿ay) proceed from an inflamation and impoÅ¿tumation, or from an ulcer. If it come from a cold cauÅ¿e, it cannot be an inflamation, nor an impoÅ¿tumation, for that theÅ¿e two doe both come from a hot cauÅ¿e, as all the learned doe know full well, and therefore of neceÅ¿Å¿ity it muÅ¿t be an ulcer which proceedeth from a cold cauÅ¿e, and the Å¿ignes to know it is, continuall coldneÅ¿Å¿e of his body, his hayre will Å¿tare, and he will be Å¿ubject to great feebleneÅ¿Å¿e, faintneÅ¿Å¿e and debility of body, and the reaÅ¿on is, for that the exulcerated matter doth diffuÅ¿e throughout the whole body its evill vapours, which corrupteth and very much offendeth the heart in Å¿uch wiÅ¿e, whereby to occaÅ¿ion and haÅ¿ten the death of the poore beaÅ¿t: if in time the malady be not diÅ¿covered, and skilfully and by Art cured. I have intreated Å¿ufficiently upon this Å¿ubject, to wit, of the nature of this infirmity, and the Å¿ignes how to know the Å¿ame. And therefore I thinke it time we doe goe to the Cure.

DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the Liver.So Å¿oone as you have diÅ¿covered this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: firÅ¿t let him bloud on both Å¿ides the necke the firÅ¿t day, and the next day let him bloud in both the Å¿purre veynes, then give him this drink, viz.

Take IÅ¿ope, Cowes-lip-leaves, Liver-wort, Lung-wort, alias Molin or Molet-leaves, Harts-tongue, of each a handfull, then take Gentiana, AriÅ¿tolochia rotunda, Fenugrick, Enulacampana dried, and long-Pepper, of each like much, Å¿o as when they be pounded and Å¿earÅ¿ed, you may have of each a Å¿poonfull; chop the hearbs, and then mingle them with this powder, and put to it of life honey one Å¿poonfull, then boyle all theÅ¿e ingredients in a quart of Å¿trong Ale, untill a moyety be conÅ¿umed, and Å¿traine it well, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme, and keep him warm, and having made him faÅ¿t three or foure houres after this drinke, give him Barly boyled, but if he Å¿hall refuÅ¿e to eate thereof, by reaÅ¿on the drinke hath made him dry and thirÅ¿ty, then give him a warme MaÅ¿h, and after the boyled Barly againe; but let him not have this drink, but the day after he hath been let bloud in the Å¿purre veynes, give him this drinke three times, but let him alwayes reÅ¿t three dayes betwixt every drench, and give him white water for fifteen dayes after his laÅ¿t drinke, and let him every day be well rubbed, and this will cure him. â I have often made tryall of this cure, and I have found it to be very good, and it is alÅ¿o Å¿ingular for the lungs; but if you doe Å¿uÅ¿pect the liver to be waÅ¿ted, then give him this drinke, viz.

Take of Å¿trong wort, either of Ale or Beere, and give it him to drinke in a morning, having faÅ¿ted all night from meate and drinke, and three houres after he hath drunke his Wort, give him Oates baked in the Oven, and doe thus for three or foure dayes together or
longer, as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, and he will be Å¿ound againe. â But if you doe Å¿uÅ¿pect his liver not to be very Å¿ound, then

Take a good root or two of Polipodium of the Oake, made very cleane, and of Liverwort, alias Mullet one handfull, cut them very Å¿mall, then take of Rubarb Å¿craped or grated into fine powder, Å¿ixe penny weight, and three or foure dayes in a moneth give it him in his provender early in the morning two or three houres before hee drinketh, and let his drinke be white water during his cure, and once in Å¿ixe moneths make tryall of his bloud by opening a veyne, whether it be pure or corrupt, Å¿o as you take it from him accordingly, that is, the greater quantity if the Å¿ame be bad, and the leÅ¿Å¿e if it be good, and adminiÅ¿ter helpe as cauÅ¿e Å¿hall require it. â This is alÅ¿o a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne receit.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: YOu have formerly delivered me many good Receits for colds, but yet would I gladly have Å¿omething which Å¿hould be good for a HorÅ¿e that runneth at the noÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Very well Sir, I will therefore give you that which Å¿hall be very good, and which I have often my Å¿elfe proved. FirÅ¿t then if you Å¿hall finde your HorÅ¿e to have taken a cold, and therewith he runneth at the noÅ¿e, whereby he may be in danger of a Glanders, let him bleed at the necke veine well, then

Take of AÅ¿Å¿efetida, the quantity of a haÅ¿le nut,Cold or running at the noÅ¿e. and diÅ¿Å¿olve it in a Å¿aucer full of white Wine vineger, then take Lint or fine Hurds, and dip it into the medicine, and Å¿o Å¿top it into the eares of the HorÅ¿e, and with a needle and threed Å¿titch up his eares, Å¿o as the medicine get not forth: the next day, take the dry moÅ¿Å¿e which groweth upon an old pale of a Parke, or other pale, or upon the limbs of an old Oke, one handfull or better, chop it Å¿mall, and boyle it in a pottle of new milke, together with a green root of Elecampane cut into thin and Å¿mall Å¿lices, and Å¿o let it boyle till halfe the milke be conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine it and preÅ¿Å¿e it throughly, and before it be cold, put into the milke a good piece of Å¿weet Butter, and of ordinary Treacle Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme. â This is alÅ¿o good for the head-ach, Frenzy, Stavers, PoÅ¿e, Cold, Cough, wet or dry, Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, rotten lungs, Glaunders, mourning of the Chine, Laxe, LooÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e, Bloudy-fluxe, of the like diÅ¿eaÅ¿es.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat may a man apply to a HorÅ¿e to cauÅ¿e him to draw up his yard?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which commeth of weakeneÅ¿Å¿e in the backe, Draw his yard. or kidneyes, either through over-riding, or Å¿ome leap or Å¿train; or by meanes of a cold; and Å¿ometimes it commeth by a terrible Å¿tripe given him upon the loynes againÅ¿t the kidneyes, or upon the yard it Å¿elfe, or by wearineÅ¿Å¿e or tyredneÅ¿Å¿e; the Å¿ignes to know it, is by the unÅ¿eemely hanging of the member, and the cure is thus:

FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and bathe all the yard and Å¿heath with white Wine made warme, and after that annoynt it with oyle of RoÅ¿es, and life honey mingled together, and Å¿o put up the yard into the Å¿heath, and with a Å¿oft boulÅ¿ter of Canvas, keep it from falling downe, and dreÅ¿Å¿e him thus every day once till hee we well, and let his backe and fillets be kept warme, and annoynted with Acopum, or if you have not Acopum, then apply this charge unto his backe and fillets.

Take Bolearmonacke, the whites of Egges, Wheate meale, Sanguis Draconis, Venis Turpentine, and Å¿trong white Wine vineger, of each of theÅ¿e as much as will Å¿uffice, mixe them well, and charge his backe therewith, his Å¿heath and his Å¿tones, and he Å¿hall be well. Another:

Take the aÅ¿hes of AÅ¿hen wood, the whiteÅ¿t, fineÅ¿t, and beÅ¿t burned, and Å¿earÅ¿e them, one pound, or red-clay dryed, and made into fine powder, halfe a pound, Bolearmonacke halfe an ounce powdred, boyle all theÅ¿e in as much Verjuyce of the crab, as will make it liquid like pap, and with it, annoynt his yard, Å¿heath, and Å¿tones morning and evening, and he Å¿hall be preÅ¿ently cured. â This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to draw a thorne, Å¿tub, iron, Å¿plinter, naile, or what elÅ¿e out of the fleÅ¿h of the horÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If the Å¿tub, thorne, or whatÅ¿oever elÅ¿e it be, that is gotten into the fleÅ¿h be Å¿o deep as that you cannot come to it to plucke it forth with your fingers or plyers, then lay to the place a good quantity of blacke Å¿ope,Draw a thorne. and Å¿o let it lye all night, and in the morning it will make it to appeare, Å¿o as you may come to take hold of it with your InÅ¿trument: but if it be gotten into the fleÅ¿h Å¿o deep, as that the Å¿ope cannot doe it, then muÅ¿t you open the fleÅ¿h by the way of inciÅ¿ion, Å¿o deep till you may come to take hold thereof with your InÅ¿trument, and Å¿o plucke it forth, which done, heale up the wound with the oyntment taught you in lib. 2. cap. 10. Â§ 4. G. and Å¿o heale it up, but be you certaine that you doe heale it from the bottome, leÅ¿t
it breake out againe. â This is the moÅ¿t certaine way for this cure that I doe know.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good drinke is to be given, whereby to preÅ¿erve the lungs?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If you have no great occaÅ¿ion to feare your horÅ¿es lungs, then you may adminiÅ¿ter to him in his Provender onely Å¿uch powders as you Å¿hall finde preÅ¿cribed you already in lib. 2. cap. 2. Â§ 43. but if you have juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to Å¿uÅ¿pect that his lungs may be rotten, fretized or broken, then to heale or make them Å¿ound againe, or at leaÅ¿t to give him great eaÅ¿e, for you may know it by theÅ¿e Å¿ignes,Drinke to preÅ¿erve lungs. viz. his flankes will beat when he cougheth, which he will often do, but principally when you give him riding or exerciÅ¿e, and the Å¿lower they beat, the older and more dangerous the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is; he will alÅ¿o draw his winde Å¿hort, he will grone oft, but moÅ¿t in lying downe, and riÅ¿ing up, and be very fearefull and loth to cough. The cure is,

Take Tartar made of white Wine Lees, which you may have of the Apothecaries, or if you pleaÅ¿e you may make it your Å¿elfe, (for it is none other thing then the thickeÅ¿t of the Lees of white Wine well dryed and made into powder.) Take (I Å¿ay) of this one ounce and a halfe, of IÅ¿ope and of Colts foot, of each halfe a handfull, of Hore-hound one handfull, of Elecampane in fine powder, AnniÅ¿eeds, and Licoris of each one ounce, of browne Å¿ugar candy foure ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e together in good Ale one quart, and when it is halfe boyled, put into it of IÅ¿ope water, and of Colts-foot water, both twice diÅ¿tilled, to take off their crudities, of each one pinte, and Å¿o boyle all againe together, and then Å¿traine it, and give it your HorÅ¿e bloud warme. â If your HorÅ¿e have been exerciÅ¿ed, being foule, or having been in dyet, then he hath been over-much uÅ¿ed to CliÅ¿ters, Drinkes, Rakings, Purgations, Sweats, Vomits, and the like; give him this drinke then, and you Å¿hall finde it to be moÅ¿t Å¿overaign for him, and the cleaner he is within, the better is its operation, and will worke more kindely in his body; and at what times you are to Tilt, Hunt, Travell, or exerciÅ¿e him, give him but one pinte of this drinke in the morning faÅ¿ting before his going forth, for it will Å¿o helpe his breath, whereby (through moderate exerciÅ¿e) he will be much the better able to goe through with his worke, then otherwiÅ¿e he could have done. â And this drinke I have often proved. AlÅ¿o if you doe finde him to be either diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed, or Å¿icke in his lungs, or that they be any way fretized, then give him this drinke.

Take of tryed Hogges-greaÅ¿e two ounces, and of Diapente three Å¿poonfuls, put theÅ¿e into a quart of water, wherein Barly hath been boyled till it burÅ¿t, and warme it in the fire till the Hog-greaÅ¿e be diÅ¿Å¿olved, and Å¿o bloud warme give it your Å¿icke HorÅ¿e, and three
houres after, give him of the Barley warme to eate, and either Å¿weet maÅ¿hes, or white water to drinke, â. This was taught mee by an Italian Rider in Paris, and I have often made uÅ¿e thereof, and have found it to be Å¿peciall good, howbeit for the time it will cauÅ¿e him to bee very Å¿ick, but have no feare, for it is right good for this Malady. Another.

Take Muskadine or Å¿weet Sack one pint, life-honey th â¢â¢ e Spoonfuls, Myhrre, Saffaron, CaÅ¿cia, and Cinamon, of each like much, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and mixe two Spoonefuls of this powder with your Muskadine and Hony, and give it him warme with a Horne, give him this drinke fifteene daies together, continuing to give him maÅ¿hes and white water, and this is a moÅ¿t certaine Cure, â. But if you do find that his Lungs be rotten and impoÅ¿tumated, then

Take of the juyce of PurÅ¿laine halfe a pint, and mix therwith of the Oyle of RoÅ¿es Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and put thereto a little Tragantum Å¿teeped before in Goates, Ewes, or Cowes milke, and give him thereof to drinke Å¿even mornings together: but this drinke will but only ripen and breake the ImpoÅ¿tume, which you Å¿hall know to be done, by his exceeding Å¿tincking breath, then Å¿hall you give him in fine powder CaÅ¿Å¿ia three ounces, and Å¿eaven RaiÅ¿ins of the Sunne Å¿toned, boyle theÅ¿e in Muskadine one pint, and bloud warme give it him, and it will heale up his Lungs againe. â. This is very good

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: IS there no good thing to be given to a HorÅ¿e, wherewith to prevent diÅ¿eaÅ¿es all the whole yeare?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: As touching the prevention of all diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, I have Å¿poken before, I thinke, Å¿ufficiently, but yet I will teach you one thing, (for that you are deÅ¿irous to learne, and learning is no burthen) which may bee worthy your notice, for I will keepe no Å¿ecret from you; Sithence it is my MaÅ¿ters pleaÅ¿ure, I Å¿hould dilate the utmoÅ¿t of my skill and Art.

FirÅ¿t, therefore the Å¿pring of the yeare comming on, a time when new bloud beginneth to come, and that ere long graÅ¿Å¿e wilbe able to take heart, whereby the better to give nutriment to a HorÅ¿e; The firÅ¿t day of April open a veine in the Neck, to Å¿ee the better how the bloud is: if good, take the leÅ¿Å¿e, if bad then the more: then from that day untill the firÅ¿t of May, give him this which I Å¿hall preÅ¿cribe you, and let him have it every day without fayle, Morning and Evening during the whole month of April, from the firÅ¿t day to the laÅ¿t, which is before his turning out to graÅ¿Å¿e, or Å¿oyling, which Å¿hould be about the middle of May, and let him have the Å¿ame alÅ¿o all the whole
month of October (like as you muÅ¿t do in April after you have taken him from graÅ¿Å¿e, about Bartholmewtide, and do as you before have bin taught in all poynts. That which I preÅ¿cribe is this.

Take a BuÅ¿hell of old Rie, Å¿weet and cleane, well purged,DiÅ¿eaÅ¿es ãâã prevent. or Å¿ifted, from duÅ¿t, Å¿tones, lome, feathers, cobwebs, or any Å¿uch like filth, and put it into a cleane iron pot, dry, and without water, I meane Å¿uch an iron pot, in which uÅ¿ually fleÅ¿h meat is boyled, for Å¿uch a like veÅ¿Å¿ell, is beÅ¿t for this our purpoÅ¿e, it taketh leaÅ¿t harme, and is much more wholeÅ¿ome then BraÅ¿Å¿e, Copper, or any other mettall: Å¿et this pot thus dry, and without water over the fire, and put into it your BuÅ¿hell of Rie (for a leÅ¿Å¿e quantity you cannot well have) and as it beginneth to wax hot, keepe the Rie with continuall Å¿tirring, even from the bottome, without any intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, untill you have Å¿o parched the Rie, that it becommeth black and hard, which to be Å¿o, will aske good heat, and no leÅ¿Å¿e labour to Å¿tirre it up and downe in the pot, when you do find that the Rie is Å¿ufficiently parched, which you Å¿hall know by its blackneÅ¿Å¿e, dryneÅ¿Å¿e, and hardnes, take it from the fire, and put it into Å¿ome other cleane, and dry veÅ¿Å¿ell, which Å¿o Å¿oon as it is cold, let the veÅ¿Å¿ell be kept cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and Å¿o kept for your uÅ¿e. Now when you are to uÅ¿e of this Rie, take two or three good handfuls of it, and let it bee beaten to fine powder and given to your HorÅ¿e mingled with his Provender, at every watring, morning and evening, or other times when you uÅ¿ually give him Oates; doe this theÅ¿e two entire months of April and October, for that all men doe hold, that in theÅ¿e two months the bloud turneth and altereth, as wee alter his diet from hard and dry meate, to graÅ¿Å¿e; and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e from graÅ¿Å¿e to dry meate, for this Rie thus parched and ordred, doth refine the Bloud, coole the Liver, and purgeth the Spleene, Å¿o as the whol Å¿tructure of the body is thereby the better eaÅ¿ed and freed, from all Å¿uch bad and unnaturall humors, which would otherwiÅ¿e make the body inclinable to Å¿undry Maladies and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which this Rie preventeth, and therefore if you bee willing to keepe your HorÅ¿e Å¿ound, and free from diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, order him in theÅ¿e two months according as I have preÅ¿cribed you, and you Å¿halbe Å¿ecure, â. This I have oft made uÅ¿e of, and it is good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HAve you any comfortable drinke to adminiÅ¿ter to a HorÅ¿e that is very Å¿icke?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have heretofore Å¿hewed you divers, but yet I will give you one more.

Take of good white Wine one pinte, of white Sugar Candy,Drink comfortable. and of Cinamon, of each one ounce, of Cloves halfe an ounce, Saffron three drammes, of Sugar refined three ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, then take Mithridate two ounces, Honey of RoÅ¿es
foure ounces, mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and put it to the Wine, and make it bloud warme over the fire, and Å¿o give it him, and now and then as he Å¿tandeth upon the trench, let him chew upon the end of a Buls pizell, Å¿ome Arman, let him be cloathed and littered warm, and remaine faÅ¿ting upon the trench three houres, and after give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, and after order him as is uÅ¿uall for a Å¿icke horÅ¿e. â This is one of the beÅ¿t preÅ¿ervative drinkes that I know, and I have had great proofe thereof.

p.hi: VVHat remedy have you for a diÅ¿located joynt?
