sp.p: WHat diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that is called TranchaiÅ¿ons?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This tearme we have from the French, which is onely a paine or griping in the belly, cauÅ¿ed partly of winde, and partly of cold, and eftÅ¿oones of both, and our EngliÅ¿h tearme is, the Chollicke, which is a moÅ¿t grievous paine, ingendring many infirmities, as I have before declared in its due place: notwithÅ¿tanding becauÅ¿e you have given me the French tearme, I will give you two or three French Receits for the Å¿ame diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, albeit I did never experiment any of them, yet I doe hold them to be good.

DiÅ¿eaÅ¿e of TranchaiÅ¿ons or the chollicke.Take of Arquequamis one ounce, make it into juyce, and put to it of white wine one pinte, and Å¿o give it to the HorÅ¿e, which done, annoynt his privy members with this unguent, Take of Garlicke unpilled, as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿tampe it well, and mixe with it of Sallet oyle as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o bring it to an unguent, and therewith annoynt the yard, Å¿heath, and cods, and it will both give him eaÅ¿e, and cauÅ¿e him to Å¿tale Å¿uddenly, by which meanes he will amend. Another:
Take Cinque-foyle halfe an handfull or Pantaphillon, beat and Å¿tampe it well, and moyÅ¿ten it with warme water, and Å¿o give it him to drinke. Another:

Take of the powder of Siliris Montani, D'quare, and of Comin, of each an ounce, and put them into white Wine one pinte, and Å¿o give it him, then Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath taken this drinke, trot him out for halfe an houre, a good round trot, eÅ¿pecially up the hill, and after bring him into the Stable, and cloathe and litter him warme. Another:
Take of Fenugricke and of Comin, of each one ounce, make them into fine powder, and with white Wine a pinte, give it him bloud warme, and trot him out as before.

p.hi: HAve you no way to dry Å¿oares?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea Sir, and I will give you Å¿ome receits for that purpoÅ¿e. â¢ ake egge Å¿hels and burne them almoÅ¿t blacke:Dry up Å¿oares. take alÅ¿o the upper leather of old Å¿hoes, and burne them to a cole: take alÅ¿o a Char-cole, quick lime, and greene coperas, burned in a well nealed earthen pot, untill it be red: Take of each of theÅ¿e a like quantity, and beate them together to fine powder, and Å¿trew this powder upon the Å¿oare or galled place, and every time you dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿oare herewith, waÅ¿h it well with Å¿trong vineger or chamber-lye warmed. â But if it be an old ulcer, or cankerous Å¿oare, then take MaÅ¿ticke, FrankincenÅ¿e, Cloves, greene Coperas, BrimÅ¿tone, of each like much, Myrra double as much as any of the former ingredients, beate all theÅ¿e by themÅ¿elves to fine powder, and mixe them well, then take of this powder and burne it upon a chafing-diÅ¿h and coles,Lint whe â¢ with to he â¢ ulcers or o â¢ Å¿oares. but be carefull it flame not, then as the Å¿moake or fume thereof ariÅ¿eth, take of fine lint a good handfull or two, and hold it over the Å¿aid Å¿moake or Å¿teame, Å¿o as it may receive all the Å¿aid Å¿teame into the Å¿aid lint, then when it is throughly well perfumed, put the lint into a box, pot, or glaÅ¿Å¿e, and be Å¿ure to Å¿top it up Å¿o cloÅ¿e, as that none the leaÅ¿t ayre can poÅ¿Å¿ibly come into it (for the leaÅ¿t ayre will deprive the lint of its vertue) and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e; and when you have occaÅ¿ion to make uÅ¿e thereof, firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the Å¿oare with new made chamber-lye warme, either as it commeth from the man, or elÅ¿e warmed upon the fire, then dry the Å¿oare againe, and laÅ¿tly lay Å¿ome of this lint to the Å¿oare, and Å¿o make it up, and doe this twice every day, and you Å¿hall finde it to be a Å¿peedy and perfect cure. â But if you would dry up the Å¿cratches in the heeles of your HorÅ¿e,

Take then chamber-lye which is old made, or Å¿tale, and rock or roch-Allum as much as will Å¿uffice, boyle them together, and reÅ¿erve it thus well boyled in a glaÅ¿Å¿e, or other cleane veÅ¿Å¿ell well Å¿topped, then take of greene nettles the Å¿trongeÅ¿t, moÅ¿t angry and keene, two handfuls, and lay them thin upon Å¿ome plate, or other broad thing, and Å¿o dry them either before the fire, or in an Oven, after houÅ¿holdbread is drawne, then make it into powder very fine, this done, take of Pepper, and make it alÅ¿o into very fine powder, being finely Å¿earÅ¿ed, Å¿o as it may be of like quantity with the powder of nettles, and Å¿o mixe them well together, then keep this powder in a dry glaÅ¿Å¿e, cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and when you may have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e this powder, firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the Å¿oare with the Å¿aid liquor of Allome and Chamber-lye made bloud warme, and Å¿o having purged, cleanÅ¿ed, and dryed the
Å¿orance well with a cleane linnen cloth, Å¿trew and lay on your powder, and thus doe after travell or exerciÅ¿e every day once during the time of his reÅ¿t, and this will cure him throughly. â This cure I have often practiÅ¿ed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that which is called the ArraiÅ¿tes, and how is it cured?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: ArraiÅ¿tes or Rats-tayles.This is alÅ¿o a French Epitheton, which we call the Rats-tayles, being a kinde of Å¿cratches: of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e I have Å¿poken before in the letter A. and therefore I will now leave entreating further thereof.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is to be given to a HorÅ¿e that hath eaten a Taynt?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A Taynt is a kinde of red worm which many Ferriers will Å¿ay can doe a HorÅ¿e no harm, but they are much miÅ¿taken, for I have knowne HorÅ¿es to dye with eating it; but if he have eaten a Taynt, the Å¿ignes will be, that he will be Å¿icke, and forÅ¿ake his meat, and he will Å¿well in all his body, alÅ¿o his eyes will Å¿o Å¿well that you would thinke they would fall out of his head, he will draw in and out his breath very Å¿hort, and his tongue and mouth will be very dry and hot, and peradventure bliÅ¿tred, but he will be eaÅ¿ily cured, for Å¿o Å¿oone as you Å¿hall perceive him to forÅ¿ake his meate, and that he doth begin to Å¿well, then be you confident that he hath eaten Å¿ome unwholeÅ¿ome thing, for this inconvenience Å¿eldome commeth to any HorÅ¿e but at graÅ¿Å¿e onely. The cure is,

Eate a Taynt.Take of the urine of man as it commeth warme from him, one pinte, and of bay-Å¿alt one handfull, Å¿tirre theÅ¿e well together, and give it him with a horne, and after walke him up and downe halfe an houre, and he is cured. â This I have Å¿undry times tryed, and it is a certaine cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a HorÅ¿e that hath eaten a Feather?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This may be gotten aÅ¿well in the Stable, as abroad at graÅ¿Å¿e: in the Stable through the negligence of the Keeper or Groome, in not duÅ¿ting, Å¿haking, or picking, and Å¿earching his Hay and Provender well, and by not looking narrowly, that no Feathers bee among his Hay, Oates or Provender, when he giveth him his meate, eyther in the Rack or Manger, he may alÅ¿o get a Feather at GraÅ¿Å¿e, as hee feedeth in a Meadow or PaÅ¿ture, where Swannes, GeeÅ¿e, Ducks, Turkies, or other Poultry or Foules doe lye and feed, they in the Summer Å¿eaÅ¿on, mowting, and mewing their Feathers, whereby the HorÅ¿e grafing and feeding in thoÅ¿e places, may eaÅ¿ily and unwares eate a Feather, which being taken into the WeÅ¿and, will Å¿tick faÅ¿t there, which will Å¿o Å¿uffocate him, as that it will provoke him to cough Å¿o vehemently, as if his Heart would breake, for it will Å¿ticke Å¿o faÅ¿t in his Throte or WeÅ¿and, as that he can neither Å¿wallow it downe into his Body nor caÅ¿t it up at his Mouth. The cure is.

Put the cord of your Drenching Staffe into his teeth, Eate a fe â¢
therâª and hold his head up on high, then take of Verjuyce of the crab one pint, and two new laid Egges, and beate them together, Å¿hels and all, with the Verjuice, and Å¿o give it him with a Horne, and Å¿o Å¿oone as hee hath Å¿wallowed the Å¿ame, give him a few Å¿mall branches of Savine, and this will carry away the feather into his Å¿tomacke, â. This I have very ofttentimes done, and made him well againe.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt then what Cure have you for a HorÅ¿e that hath eaten a Spider? which I take to be much more perillous to the life of the HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: The Å¿ignes to know this, is like to that of the Taint, but only that he will Å¿well much more, and this may befall him rather in Winter then in Summer: for which give him this drinke.

Take Vrine of a Man newly made one quart, of Rue, Bittony,Eate a Spider. Scabious, Pimpernell, Dragons, of each a like much, but in Å¿uch a quantity, as in the whole, all will amount but only to one handfull, chop theÅ¿e hearbs together Å¿mall, and let them boyle together in the Vrine a little, adding thereto of Bay-Å¿alt, and Sallet-oyle of each one Spoonefull, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme, â. Now if it be in Winter,

Take of Vrine one quart, Arement one lumpe, AriÅ¿tolochia rotunda, Mithridate, of each one dramme, EngliÅ¿h Saffaron, one Å¿cruple, Sallet-oyle one Spoonefull, Bezar-Å¿tone three graines, let theÅ¿e bee
Å¿et on the fire and given him bloud warme, if it be in Summer, turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e, and if need be rake him, and then convey into his Tuell a ball of freÅ¿h Butter. But if it be in Winter let him be alÅ¿o raked, and give him of the blades of Greene Rie, to a good quantity, and for his Provender, let it be for two or three meales, of Å¿calded bran and HempÅ¿eed, and let his drinke for three or foure dayes bee white water. â. TheÅ¿e are all approved medicines.

sp.speaker: Hippophyl.
sp.p: VVHat is good for a blow on the Eye, whereby aÅ¿well to Å¿ave the Eye, as to aÅ¿Å¿wage the Å¿welling thereof?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This needes no Å¿tudy as well to find out the meanes how it commeth, as the Å¿ignes how to know it, for both are apparant enough, there only remayneth to treate of the Cure.
Shave off the hayre from off and about the place Å¿welled, having firÅ¿t well bathed it in warme water. then

Eye a Å¿troakTake the tenderÅ¿t tops of wormwood, Pellitory, and Branca-VrÅ¿ina, of each halfe a handfull, chop the hearbs very Å¿mall, and then beate them to an oyntment with old Boares-greaÅ¿e Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, then put to it of life hony, and Wheate flower, of each one Spoonefull, and of LynÅ¿eed-oyle three Spoonefull, boyle theÅ¿e over the fire very well, keeping it with continuall Å¿tirring, and when it is Å¿ufficiently well boyled, Å¿traine it into a gally pot, and keepe it Å¿topped, and as occaÅ¿ion is offered, anoynt the place Å¿welled herewith â.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat remedy is to bee had for the Eye that is charged with a Filme, Pinne and Webbe, or with Dragons, &c?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: TheÅ¿e diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the Eye, do come Å¿ometimes by meanes of Å¿ome payne in the head, which cauÅ¿eth a Rheume to fall into the Eyes, and Å¿ometimes by meanes of Rheumes themÅ¿elves, which cauÅ¿ing the Eyes to water, do ingender theÅ¿e diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, and Å¿ometimes againe it is occaÅ¿ioned by meanes of a Å¿trip or hay-duÅ¿t, or Å¿ome hame which may be gotten into the Eye. I need not deliver you the Å¿ignes whereby to know them, they are viÅ¿ible to your Å¿ight. The cure therefore is thus.Eye Filme, Pin and web Dragons.

Take Camfire or Sol-Armoniacum, or for want of eyther of theÅ¿e, white-Sugar-Candy: any of theÅ¿e three being made into very fine powder, and blowne into the Eye, three times a day, are moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne to cure theÅ¿e diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the Eyes of a HorÅ¿e, but Sol-Armoniacum is the very beÅ¿t of them all. â. But if a Filme or Pearle, without
a Pin and Web, do grow in the Eye, then, take up both the two weeping-veines firÅ¿t, which are under the Eyes, and then give a Cauterize to eyther place, viz. to open the skinne all along to the very Eyes, and put in to each of them, a quill cut in the middle, then oft-times cleanÅ¿e them, and comfort the places Cauterized or roweled with unguentum-Populeum, and waÅ¿h the Eyes every day three times with Eye-bright water, mingled with the juyce of Smallage, and about fifteene dayes after, take away the quils, and after waÅ¿h the Eyes with cold Fountaine-water. Another. But if it be a Pin and Web, then

Take Cuttle bone, Tartar, Salt-Gemme, of each like much,Pin an â¢
make them all into pure fine powder, and with a quill blow of this fine powder well mixed, into his Eye two or three times a day or oftner. â. This have I tryed, and have found it to be Å¿peciall good. But if be a Pearle, that the horÅ¿e hath in his Eye, then

Take the angrieÅ¿t tops of red-Nettles, and Å¿tamp them well,Pearl â¢ Filme. and put them into a fine cleane linnen Rag, then dip the Nettles as they be in the Rag, into Beere, but yet very Å¿lightly, and Å¿o wring forth the juyce of the Å¿aid Nettles, into Å¿ome cleane thing, which done, put to it a little Å¿alt Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, made firÅ¿t into fine powder, and when the Å¿alt is diÅ¿Å¿olved, convey one drop of the medicine into the grieved Eye, morning and evening, and this will take away the Pearle, and the Eye will become as cleare as the other, â. This I have often tryed, and found it to do rare cures in this kinde. Now for a Pin and web, any of theÅ¿e enÅ¿uing will cure it.

Take the Å¿word of a Gammon of Bacon and dry it,Pin an â¢
and make it into powder, & blow thereof into the grieved Eye. â. This is good. Another.

Take the juyce of ground-Ivy, alias Ale-hoofe, Selendine, life-hony, and womans milke, of each of theÅ¿e Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, mixe all theÅ¿e well, and put it into the Eye of the HorÅ¿e, â Another.
Take the powder of the bottome of a BraÅ¿Å¿e pot, the outermoÅ¿t black being firÅ¿t taken off, & the next powder let it be blown into the Eye of the HorÅ¿e, and it will helpe him. Another.
Take the powder of burnt Alume, or of a black-flint, or the powder of Ginger, eyther of theÅ¿e made into fine powder and blowne into the Eye of the HorÅ¿e, will helpe a Pinne and webbe. Another.

Take â¢â¢ lt Arment, and make it into very fine powder, and put thereto of life-honey and freÅ¿h butter, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, and Å¿o convey of this medicine into the Eye of the HorÅ¿e, and this will cure a Pin and web. â. But if there be a Hawe Hawe. in the Eye, this every Smith can take away; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e whereas all other Ferriers, that ever I Å¿aw worke upon this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, do uÅ¿e to take it away from the out-Å¿ide of the Eye, I doe
take it away from that part which lyeth next of all to the eye, and I doe finde my way to be much better, and a Å¿afer way, as well whereby to preÅ¿erve the Å¿ight of the eye, as alÅ¿o the waÅ¿h, and Å¿o Å¿oone as I have cut out the Haw, I doe uÅ¿e to waÅ¿h the eye with white Wine, and the juyce of Å¿elendine mingled together, of each a like much, for this healeth the Å¿orance, and keepeth the eye from rankling. Now I have oft times Å¿eene the French MariÅ¿hals take up the waÅ¿h of the eye with a SpaniÅ¿h needle, threeded with a double brown threed, and to pluck forth the Haw Å¿o farre as he well can, then with a payre of Å¿izers to clip off the Haw Å¿o cloÅ¿e as he can: but I cannot commend this manner of curing the Haw, for by that meanes he cutteth away the waÅ¿h of the eye, which indeed is the beauty of the eye, whereby the HorÅ¿e becommeth bleare-eyed, which is in him a very great eye-Å¿ore, he being thereby very much disfigured. â But if your HorÅ¿e have gotten a canker in his eye, then

Eye a Canker.Take Ale-hoofe (which is indeed your true ground Ivy) and Å¿tamp it well in a morter, and if it be very dry, then moyÅ¿ten it with a little white RoÅ¿e-water, or the water of Eye-bright diÅ¿tilled, as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o Å¿traine it into a cleane glaÅ¿Å¿e, and therewith waÅ¿h, bathe, annoynt, and taint the Å¿orance therewith, and in Å¿hort time it will cure it. â This is very good to cure a Canker, a Pin and Web, bloud Å¿hotten eyes, or any Å¿uch griefe in or about the eyes; and I have often made uÅ¿e of this medicine. Another much better.

Take of Å¿tone Coperas (a thing knowne to few, and therefore very hard to get) but in the Å¿tead thereof you may uÅ¿e ordinary white Coperas, make it into fine powder, as much as will Å¿uffice, (for I muÅ¿t leave the quantity to your owne diÅ¿cretion) and put it into a Å¿mall Pipkin, and put thereto Å¿o much very faire, cleare running, or Well water as will fill up the Pipkin to the very top, then Å¿et the Pipkin upon a few coales, and cauÅ¿e the water to boyle, but Å¿o treatibly, as it may but onely Å¿imper, and as the Å¿cum doth ariÅ¿e, take it away with a feather, continuing Å¿o to doe, till the Å¿cum doe leave to ariÅ¿e any more, and when you have Å¿ufficiently well boyled it, take it off, and let it Å¿tand till it be through cold, then poure away the cleare from the bottome, which muÅ¿t be caÅ¿t away, and the cleare kept in a glaÅ¿Å¿e viall, very cloÅ¿e Å¿topped and bound up for your uÅ¿e, which being thus carefully kept, the water will remaine in its perfection long, yea a whole yeare together or longer. This water cureth almoÅ¿t all diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the eyes, as Filmes, Pearles, weeping eyes, Pin and Web, Dragons, Cataracts, dimneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ight, BlindeneÅ¿Å¿e, Rheuma â¢ icke, watry, Å¿troake, blow, or Å¿tripe of or in the eye, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently in many other caÅ¿es of the like nature. â And of this water I have had great experience. Another:

Take Sal-Armoniack, Lapis-Tulia prepared, Sagina, called in Latine Panicum-Indicum, and of Ginger, of each halfe an ounce, and of white Å¿ugar-candy two ounces, powder all theÅ¿e and Å¿earÅ¿e them,
and being well mixed, put this powder into a cleane and dry boxe very cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and Å¿o keep it that no ayre come to it for your uÅ¿e, and when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e of this powder, take a little thereof, and mixe with it of the juyce of ground Ivy, alias Ale-hoofe, as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o twice a day convey thereof into his eye with a feather, till it be throughly whole. â This is a principall good receit; I will give you another Å¿peciall good receit, which will cure all manner of Å¿ore eyes.

Take the leaves and roots of Vervine, ordinary honey, and Roman Vitrioll, of each like much, beat, bruiÅ¿e, and mixe theÅ¿e together, and put it into a Å¿tillitory glaÅ¿Å¿e, and diÅ¿till it by Balnea-Maria, with a gentle fire, and the water you take into your Receptacle, put into a viall glaÅ¿Å¿e, and keepe it very cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, that no ayre get into it, and when you are to uÅ¿e of the Å¿ame water, poure of it a little into a Å¿ilver Å¿poone, and mixe with it of the fat of a Henne or Capon, a Å¿mall quantity, and therewith annoynt the Å¿ore eye twice a day, and it will cure the Å¿ame perfectly. â I will give you another receit which will take the filme from off the eye albeit there be a very great and thicke skin growne.

Take the gall of a Hare, and life honey, of each like much, put them together into a Å¿poon, and hold the Å¿poone over the fire, till the medicine be bloud warme, and with a feather convey part of this medicine into the eye of the HorÅ¿e, and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e him morning and evening, and in Å¿hort time it will take it quite away, Å¿o as the eye will become as bright and cleare againe as ever it was before. â This receit I doe hold no whit inferiour to any of the former, for I have often made uÅ¿e thereof. But if your HorÅ¿e have gotten a Å¿tripe in the eye, then let him bloud in the necke, and in the weeping veyne, on the Å¿ame Å¿ide where the Å¿tripe is, then

Take white RoÅ¿e-water, and the white of a new laid egge, beat them very well together, then waÅ¿h and bathe the eye well therwith, and lay round about it with your Å¿platter this charge reÅ¿tringent.

Take MaÅ¿ticke, Bolearmonacke, Sanguis Draconis, the white of a new laid egge, and white wine vineger of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t,Eye a charge. beat firÅ¿t the hard Å¿imples to very fine powder, and then Å¿earÅ¿e them, and they muÅ¿t be beaten Å¿everally, then mixe them all together with the white of the egge, and the vineger Å¿o well wrought, as that the medicine come to a thicke oyntment, and with this charge the Å¿orance round about the eye, and this will keepe off the humour, and when that you finde that the eye doth begin to amend, then waÅ¿h and bathe the eye twice or thrice a day, or oftner, with cold fountaine or Well water, Å¿o freÅ¿h as it is taken or drawne out of the Well or Fountaine, and if after you Å¿hall perceive that there doth grow a filme or skin over the eye, then take it away by blowing, or putting the powder of Camphire, or Sol Armoniacum, or white Å¿ugar-Candy in fine powder, according as I have before preÅ¿cribed you. â This is a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne
receit. AlÅ¿o if your HorÅ¿e in his eye have gotten a Å¿tripe,
Take of freÅ¿h Butter wherein never came Å¿alt, the quantity of a Walnut, and put it into his eare on that Å¿ide where the Å¿tripe is, and it will helpe him. Another:

Take Lentels or Gray-PeaÅ¿e, and champe or chew them in your mouth, and then whilÅ¿t they be in your mouth, blow and breath into your HorÅ¿es eye, but not any of the PeaÅ¿e by any meanes, doe this every day often, and a little after waÅ¿h the Å¿ore eye with cold Fountaine water till it be whole. â But yet I will teach you another receit which will take off a Pin and Web, Filme, ThickneÅ¿Å¿e, or any other fouleneÅ¿Å¿e which may be in the eye whatÅ¿oever, whereof I have had great experience, and have done many rare cures in this kinde, viz.

Take the Å¿hels of Å¿even or eight egges, cleanÅ¿e them from all manner of inward Å¿lime, and dry them well within, then lay thoÅ¿e Å¿hels betweene two new Tyles, or old, Å¿o they be made very cleane and free from Morter, and then lay them in the glowing embers, and cover them all over, and on every Å¿ide with burning hot embers, and Å¿o let them ly a good Å¿pace, untill the moyÅ¿t Å¿ubÅ¿tance be quite taken from them, then take them up, and beat the Å¿hels to very fine powder, and Å¿earÅ¿e the powder, then with a gooÅ¿e quill blow of this powder into your HorÅ¿es eye, doe this twice every day, and it is a certaine cure. â But if you doe finde the eye to be fed with any Rhumaticke humour, or that it be inflamed, or that it hath go â¢ ten a bruiÅ¿e, Å¿tripe, or the like, then

Take of the pureÅ¿t and whiteÅ¿t refined loafe Å¿ugar, one Å¿poonfull and a halfe, let it be made into fine powder and Å¿earÅ¿ed, or elÅ¿e of the beÅ¿t white Å¿ugar-Candy (which is much better) the like quantity, let it be finely powdred and Å¿earÅ¿ed, and mixe with it Å¿o much May or Å¿weet butter (wherein never came Å¿alt) as a Walnut, and adde alÅ¿o to it Å¿o much of the former powder of Egge Å¿hels, as of Å¿ugar-Candy, make theÅ¿e into one body, and bring it to a Å¿alve, and put thereof into the HorÅ¿es eye, morning, evening, and noone, and this will make the eye to be cleare, Å¿ound, and whole againe. â This unguent doth purge, cleanÅ¿e, coole, and comfort the eye of the HorÅ¿e, and helpeth greatly his Å¿ight; make uÅ¿e of this, for it is very good. But if the eyes be inflamed, which you may eaÅ¿ily know by the red Å¿trakes which will be in them, then

Take Thuris MaÅ¿culi, the marrow of a Lamb, Saffaron, Cuttle-bone, of each one ounce, of the oyle of RoÅ¿es one ounce, and the whites of ten new laid egges, beat and incorporate all theÅ¿e very well together, and then with a feather put Å¿ome of this medicine into his eyes once every day. â This receit is very good, for I have had great triall thereof. Another:

Take of white Starch made of wheate, FrankincenÅ¿e, life-honey, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, make all theÅ¿e into one body, and with
a feather apply it to the grieved eye. â Another:

If the inflamation be great, let him bloud in both the temple veynes, and in the weeping veynes, and then waÅ¿h his eyes with womans milke and life honey mingled together. â Another for a wart or Å¿pungy excretion growing neere to to the eye of the HorÅ¿e, which commonly doth proceed from a condenÅ¿ed flegme that deÅ¿cendeth to the eye, which in time will cauÅ¿e the eye either to conÅ¿ume, or to grow little, if it be not prevented, which muÅ¿t be done thus.

Take Roch Allum and burne it,Eye a W and then adde unto it Å¿o much white Coperas unburnt, grinde them together to very fine powder, then lay a little of this powder juÅ¿t upon the top of the wart, but take heed none get into the eye, for it is a Å¿trong corraÅ¿ive, and will corrode; let the Wart be thus dreÅ¿Å¿ed once every day, and in Å¿hort time it will conÅ¿ume and eate it quite away never to come more. â But as touching Lunaticke eyes,Lunatic â¢ eyes. this word Lunaticke is derived from the Latine word Luna, which Å¿ignifieth the Moone, and the reaÅ¿on why this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e takes its denomination from thence, is, for that at certain times of the Moone he will Å¿ee well, and at other times a little, but then at other times no whit at all; and therefore this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is called lunaticke, and this kinde of blindeneÅ¿Å¿e we do hold to be the very worÅ¿t of all other, but when he doth Å¿ee, you may know it by the colour of his eyes, for then they will be dimme and yellowiÅ¿h, but when he Å¿eeth nothing; then will they looke fiery and red. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth Å¿ometimes naturally, taking it hereditary, either from the Stallion his Sire, or from the Mare his Damme, by whom he was begotten and foled: it commeth alÅ¿o Å¿ometimes by meanes of evill humours which deÅ¿cending from the head, make their reÅ¿idence in and about the eyes, and theÅ¿e naughty humours are occaÅ¿ioned by the meanes of intemperate riding, drawing, or other laborious exerciÅ¿e, in which the poore creature hath bin put to doe more then nature was well able to performe; wherefore by one of theÅ¿e wayes, this malady commeth; the cure is thus.

Take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, and MaÅ¿ticke, of each like much, melt them together, and having before hand provided in a readineÅ¿Å¿e two round plaiÅ¿ters of leather, the breadth of a 20 Å¿hilling piece of gold, lay and Å¿pread the medicine hot upon theÅ¿e two plaiÅ¿ters, and Å¿o hot as the HorÅ¿e can Å¿uffer them, apply them to his temples, cauÅ¿ing them to Å¿tick faÅ¿t to the skinne, and let them there remaine, untill they Å¿hall fall off of themÅ¿elves, then rowell him on the face juÅ¿t under his eyes with a very Å¿mall French Rowell the bredth of a three pence at the moÅ¿t, and let it be turned every day once, the Å¿pace of 12 or 15 dayes, then take forth the Rowell, and heale up the orifice with the greene oyntment preÅ¿cribed you in lil. 2. cap. 10. Â§ 4. G. and this will undoubtedly very much help his Å¿ight. â Another:
Shave away the hayre the breadth of a Å¿hilling on either Å¿ide of the head upon the temple veines, and after apply to the place this charge.

Take Taca-Mahaca, and lay it upon thoÅ¿e places which were Å¿haven, and clap upon them flocks of the Å¿ame colour, then make inciÅ¿ion and put in two French Rowels, as is Å¿hewed in the cure going before, to bring downe the peccant humours, and let the eyes be waÅ¿hed twice every day with the medicine before taught you, made of ground Ivy, Honey, Selendine, and womans milke. X This is very good for this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and this I can boldly commend unto you to be a very good medicine, for I have often uÅ¿ed. Now as touching Å¿ore eyes which muÅ¿t be cured by medicine, you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that the eye is the moÅ¿t delicate part of any one member in all the whole body, it is the Torch or Candle which doth give light to the whole body, it is the guide which doth uÅ¿her the body, and to carry it from danger, Å¿o as it Å¿hall not at any time either Å¿tumble upon rockes, or blockes, or fall into any precipice; wherefore great regard ought to be had, how you doe at any time tamper or meddle with this Å¿o choyce a member, leÅ¿t in Å¿tead of endeavouring to cure one Å¿ore eye, you put out both, a thing often Å¿eene and knowne, and therefore the medicines which you apply to the eyes ought evermore to be new made, yea in a manner every day, for that when once they begin to grow Å¿tale, they become Å¿harp and aÅ¿per, perplexing the poore beaÅ¿t, much more then otherwiÅ¿e, neither are they Å¿o wholeÅ¿ome, nor Å¿o powerfull whereby to performe their office for which they were made and compounded. If you have a HorÅ¿e which is but weake of Å¿ight, the â¢ eÅ¿Å¿e bloud you take from him, the better it will be for the continuance of his Å¿ight, for by taking much bloud from a HorÅ¿e weakely Å¿ighted, will on a Å¿udden cauÅ¿e him to become Å¿tone blinde, like as by experience I have often knowne and obÅ¿erved. But now to conclude this Paragraph, becauÅ¿e I have not yet handled one part appertaining to a Å¿ore eye, viz. for an eye which by an unlucky Å¿troke or Å¿tripe is broken and beaten out of the head of the HorÅ¿e. I will give you one onely receit, which can never be parallelled: to wit,

Eye broken.Take Allum, and firÅ¿t burne it in a fire-pan, and after when it is burned Å¿o,â put it upon the hot coales, and let it burne there till all the moyÅ¿ture be quite conÅ¿umed, that it becommeth as light as a feather, and as white as Å¿now, and Å¿o brittle as that it will breake with every touch, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be very carefully handled, when it is Å¿o brittle as that it will runne to aÅ¿hes with every Å¿mall preÅ¿Å¿ure, and that the taÅ¿t of Allum remaineth little in the Å¿aid Allum, then is it Å¿ufficiently burned, then take of this powder as much as will Å¿uffice, and mixe it with life-honey, and Å¿tirre them well together, as that you do bring it to an unguent; put of this every day morning and evening into his eye with a feather, and Å¿o hold your hand upon the eye a pretty while, that the medicine cannot Å¿uddenly get forth, and by thus doing, in few dayes it will be throughly cured, though the eye be utterly loÅ¿t.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to take away a bony excretion, or a fleÅ¿hy?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This malady of a bony excretion commeth moÅ¿t commonly by the meanes of cauÅ¿ticks and burning corroÅ¿ives, which be laid to wounds that are neere to the bone, as when the wound is either in the legge, or about the paÅ¿terne, for that the fleÅ¿h being extreamely burned and mortified by Å¿uch cauÅ¿ticks and corroÅ¿ives, it doth cauÅ¿e an excretion to grow upon the bone, which through the unskilfulneÅ¿Å¿e of the Ferrier, the wound is healed up, but the excretion doth remaine Å¿till upon the bone, which becommeth an eye-Å¿ore, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be afterwards taken off, which occaÅ¿ioneth a new cure, and over and above it enforceth oft times the HorÅ¿e to hault: Å¿ometimes againe an excretion commeth by the HorÅ¿e being galled with a locke or fetters, having beene long continued upon the Å¿ame foot, without changing or removing in time convenient. But howÅ¿oever it commeth, the cure is,

Take Elecampane root newly gathered, and cleanÅ¿e it from its earth,Excreti â¢â¢
and wrap it up in a brown paper, then wet the paper, and Å¿o heale it in the hot embers, and Å¿o roft it as you would doe a Warden, when it is throughly well roÅ¿ted, that it be like to pap, Å¿o hot as your HorÅ¿e can Å¿uffer it, (for it muÅ¿t not Å¿cald him) after you have with a Å¿ticke, (like as you doe a Å¿plent) rubbed, knocked, and chafed the excretion, binde this roÅ¿ted root cloÅ¿e unto the place, and Å¿o let it remaine on 24 houres before you doe remove it, and in two or three times thus dreÅ¿Å¿ing it, the excretion will rot and conÅ¿ume to nothing, and this will alÅ¿o take away a Å¿plent. â This is very good. Another:

Take the oyle of Origanum, and every morning and evening, or oftner, take a little upon the brawne of your thumb, and rubbe the place, and it will therewith in time conÅ¿ume, and quite take it away. â And this will alÅ¿o take away a Å¿plent.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat will cure an ImpoÅ¿tume in the eares of a horÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e proceeds from Å¿undry cauÅ¿es, as by means of Å¿ome blow with Å¿ome Å¿taffe or other Å¿uch like thing, which he receiveth about the eares, or poll, or elÅ¿e by meanes of Å¿ome hurt he may get, by being wrung or galled with a new or hard hempen halter, Å¿pecially if a knot be neer or upon the place; Å¿ometimes it comes alÅ¿o of a cold taken in the head, and Å¿ometimes againe by meanes of bad and peccant humours, which reÅ¿iding in the head, doe make its paÅ¿Å¿age by the eares; it is eaÅ¿ily known by its much burning, glowing, and Å¿welling, and by the HorÅ¿es unwillingneÅ¿Å¿e to be touched and handled about that place; if it be an impoÅ¿tumation, then thus it muÅ¿t be cured.

Take LinÅ¿eed and make it into fine powder, and Wheate-flower, of each halfe a pint,Eares impoÅ¿tumated. ordinary honey one pint, tryedâ Hogs-greaÅ¿e one pound, mixe all theÅ¿e well, and warme them upon a fire, keeping them continually Å¿tirring: then take of this oyntment and Å¿pread it upon a linnen cloath, or upon a plaiÅ¿ter of leather, the breadth of the Å¿welling only, and apply it warme to the place, and renew it once every foure and twenty houres, till it eyther do breake or be Å¿o ripe, as that it may be opened; which muÅ¿t be Å¿o done downewards, that the corruption may eaÅ¿ily iÅ¿Å¿ue away, then heale it up with this Å¿alve.

Take Mel-RoÅ¿atum, Sallet-oyle, and ordinary Turpentine of each two ounces, incorporate them well together, and make for the HorÅ¿e a biggen, or night-cap to keepe on the medicine, taint the Å¿ore to the bottome dipped in this oyntment, and apply alÅ¿o a plaiÅ¿ter of the Å¿aid Å¿tuffe upon the Å¿ore, renewing it every day till it be whole and Å¿ound. â. But if the ImpoÅ¿tumation be broken of its own accord before you do perceave it, then

Take oyle of RoÅ¿es, Venice Turpentine, and common Honey of each like much, mixe them well together, and Å¿o making it bloud warme upon a few embers or coales, dip Å¿ome black wooll in the medicine, & Å¿o Å¿top up that Eare therewith, which is grieved, renewing it once a day till it be whole. â. But if the Eares be only inflamed, then Å¿top of this foreÅ¿aid medicine into them, and it will both eaÅ¿e him and take away the inflamation, â. Another.

Take of pepper made into fine powder diÅ¿t. tryed Hogges-greaÅ¿Å¿e one Å¿poonefull, the Iuyce of Rue one handfull, the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vinegar two Å¿poonefull, beate all theÅ¿e very well together, and if the Å¿welling, ImpoÅ¿tumation, or Inflamation, be eyther in the Eares, Face, Head or Throte of the HorÅ¿e, if you take eyther black-wooll, fine lint, Flax, or Hurds, and dip it into this medicine, and Å¿o Å¿top both his Eares therewith, and then Å¿titch them up, that it get not forth, renewing it once in two dayes, till the Å¿welling bee cleane gone, your HarÅ¿e will be certainely cured â. But if the griefe be in any other part of the Body, then with this Vnguent, you Å¿hall anoint the grieved or Å¿wolne place, once or twice a day, till it depart. â. But if the Å¿welling be neere or about the Cods, or privy parts, then

FirÅ¿t Bathe the place well with cold water, and after being made dry againe with a cloath, anoynt it with the Å¿aid oyntment, every day once or twice, and you Å¿hall find it to be a preÅ¿ent cure â. This alÅ¿o cureth the Vlcer and Canker in the NoÅ¿e, and it is a Å¿ure Cure for the Vives â. I have often cured all theÅ¿e maladies with this Receipt.

sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: WHat cure have you for the Farcin?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Of all the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es whereunto HorÅ¿es are inclinable, this of the Farcin is the moÅ¿t loathÅ¿ome, the moÅ¿t Å¿tinking, and the moÅ¿t filthy, wherefore for the Å¿ame I Å¿hall Å¿et you downe many cures, but firÅ¿t I intend to diÅ¿courÅ¿e Å¿omewhat of it's Nature, and how it comes to a HorÅ¿e; This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e we here in England do for the moÅ¿t part call the Farcy, and (Secundum Vulgus) it is called the FaÅ¿hions, for Å¿o MaÅ¿ter Markham doth Å¿tile it; But MaÅ¿ter Blundevile, the Italians, and the French do give it the name of Farcin, to which denomination I doe the rather incline, by reaÅ¿on we take the Å¿aid name from the Italians and the French, for that truely I do find that to be the proper name of the Å¿aid Infirmity, derived from the word Farcina, which is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e moÅ¿t infectious, poyÅ¿nous, and dangerous, being never Å¿o little let alone, or neglected: It is a kind of creeping Vlcer beginning with hard knots, and PuÅ¿tils, and after dilating and Å¿preading it Å¿elfe into branches (like to a Vine or Ivy) doth not ceaÅ¿e from running, untill Å¿uch time as it hath viÅ¿ited every part and member of the Body, for QuaÅ¿i Cancer Å¿erpit, it commonly beginning either in a veine, or neere to Å¿ome MaÅ¿ter veine, which feedeth and nouriÅ¿heth the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, that is the cauÅ¿e of it's diffuÅ¿ion. It is ingendred Å¿ometimes of corrupt bloud, which heats and Å¿urfets have occaÅ¿ioned in the Body, Å¿ometimes by hurts and wounds received, as alÅ¿o by Å¿ome Cankerous & poyÅ¿nous thing, as ruÅ¿ty Å¿purres, Å¿naffles, bits, or the like, it is alÅ¿o taken from another horÅ¿e, which is faln into the Å¿ame diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, alÅ¿o by hewing one legge againÅ¿t another, and being Å¿mitten with Å¿ome Å¿taffe, whereon are hard knots, and Å¿undry Å¿uch like meanes and wayes; it comes alÅ¿o to a HorÅ¿e by Å¿urfets given him, which finding no other way of avoidance, lais hold of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, wherby the bloud, being over much heat, his greaÅ¿e molten, and his taking a Å¿uddaine cold, which is moÅ¿t frequent after great heates, then growing in the body, and eÅ¿pecially in the bloud, Å¿uch obÅ¿tructions, corruption, and putrefaction, not having any meanes to vent it Å¿elfe, or to voyde, or evacuate, but by this way only, by growing into knots, PuÅ¿tils, Vlcers, or the like, which be Å¿o contagious and infectious, Å¿o as if but any other horÅ¿e, doe but gnaw or lick with his teeth or tongue, upon the place infected, hee
will be aÅ¿Å¿uredly within a Å¿hort time after himÅ¿elfe infected alÅ¿o, and when once a horÅ¿e is Å¿trucken or infected with this leprous malady, if he be not preÅ¿ently and skilfully cured, it is as infallible death to him, as if he had eyther his throate cut, or his braines beaten out, with a Butchers Axe; Farcin, wherefore if in this caÅ¿e, your horÅ¿e be viÅ¿ited with this Å¿iniÅ¿trous diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, I could wiÅ¿h you would carefully obÅ¿erve two things: the firÅ¿t is, that Å¿o Å¿oone as you doe perceive this Malady to appeare upon him, that you preÅ¿ently Å¿equeÅ¿ter him from his fellowes, into Å¿ome other Stable or Å¿tall by himÅ¿elfe alone, for feare he might infect them, for that it is catching; And Å¿econdly, to be very diligent in omitting no time or opportunity, in getting him adminiÅ¿tr â¢ d unto for his Cure: The Å¿ignes of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e are Å¿o plaine and familiar, as that it needeth no deÅ¿cription. I will paÅ¿Å¿e to the cure. To the end therfore you may go the more Å¿ecurely to work, wherby you may make it an able and perfect cure, eÅ¿pecially if you do finde the PuÅ¿tils to be malevolent, and greatly inflamed, then the firÅ¿t day let him bloud in or neere to that MaÅ¿ter veine, which doth moÅ¿t feed and nouriÅ¿h the Farcin, then Å¿o Å¿oone as you have well bloudied him, give him this purge, viz.

Take of Aloes, made into fine power one ounce, and a quantity of London Triacle Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and of life hony Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, mixe theÅ¿e well together, and give it him in a morning faÅ¿ting, and Å¿ix houres after, give him white water, neyther needeth this bloudying him, or Purgation, any way hinder him from being dreÅ¿Å¿ed for his diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, for that bloud-letting doth but only hinder it from running any farther for that time, and the Purge Å¿endeth the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e from the heart, to the end it may no way annoy that place, wherefore for the perfecting of the cure.

Take of oyle de-Bay two ounces of Euforbium made into fine powder one ounce, incorporate both theÅ¿e Å¿o well together, that they may become but one body, then fearch for the firÅ¿t origin, or Å¿pring, where the firÅ¿t knots did begin, and Å¿o continue Å¿earching till you find out the laÅ¿t, clip away the hayre from off, and about all theÅ¿e knots, and annoynt them very well with this oyntment once every three dayes; and after you have thus dreÅ¿Å¿ed him three times, if you do not find the Farcins to be killed, and that the knots do not dry up, then bathe the places three dayes together with the Å¿tale or vrine of a Cowe, or Oxe, and with the hearbe called Lions foote, in latine, Leontipodium, both boyled together, and this will cure him. â. This medicine I never made uÅ¿e of but once only, and it cured the horÅ¿e unto which I did adminiÅ¿ter the Å¿ame. â. Another.

Take nine leaves of the pot herbe called Beetes, of the Å¿malleÅ¿t but Å¿oundeÅ¿t leaves, and nine grains of Bay-Å¿alt, beat theÅ¿e very well together to Å¿alve, and in a morning before Sun-riÅ¿ing, put this medicine into both his Eares by equall portions, and put into them after it, a little wooll, to keepe in the medicine, and Å¿o Å¿titch up his
eares, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o with meate and white water 24 houres at the leaÅ¿t, then take forth the wooll and Å¿tuffe, and he is cured. â With this receit I have cured Å¿undry horÅ¿es. Another. If your HorÅ¿e have a farcin in any of the foure quarters of his body, let him bleed well in the necke veyne faÅ¿ting, then

Take of ArÅ¿enick two ounces, and put it into a piece of new cloth, and binde it up with a piece of new Pack-threed, and faÅ¿ten it unto the mayne of the HorÅ¿e, this is to be thus adminiÅ¿tred, if the farcin be onely in the foreparts, but if the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e be as well in the hinder-parts, as in the fore-parts, then hang alÅ¿o the like quantity of ArÅ¿nick, made up in a cloth like as was the former, and hang that alÅ¿o upon his tayle, and the more you ride, work, or travell, and exerciÅ¿e him, the better it will be for his diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, to qualifie and rid the Å¿ame, and the more Å¿pare his dyet be, the Å¿ooner is he cured, provided you keep him warm in the Å¿table, and for Å¿ome time you muÅ¿t give him white water. This cure I did never try, but it was taught me by a great MariÅ¿hall of Paris, one who had the repute of a very honeÅ¿t man, and a moÅ¿t skilfull Ferrier, who proteÅ¿ted unto me that he had perfectly cured many HorÅ¿es with this receit. Another:

Take white Bran prepared, like as you Å¿hall finde preÅ¿cribed you, lib. 2. cap. 2. Â§ 4. F. how to make fat a HorÅ¿e, and give it him a day before he is to be dreÅ¿Å¿ed, and let him eate it Å¿o hot as well he may: continue him to this dyet three mornings together, then let him bleede well in the necke-veyne, but give him no Hay that day he bleedeth, but Å¿weet wheat Å¿traw onely, neither let him either eate or drink in four houres after, and then let his drink be white water. And two dayes after his bleeding, you Å¿hall begin to give him again his wheat bran prepared as before, which Å¿hall continue for Å¿ixe dayes together, during which time you Å¿hall give him every evening with his Oats, this powder and theÅ¿e roots following, viz.

Take of Comin, of LinÅ¿eed, of Fenugrick, Sileris. Montani, of each two ounces, quick BrimÅ¿tone, foure ounces, let all theÅ¿e be powdred, and mixe them well, and give it at one time with his Oates, Å¿o much as you may put into an egge Å¿hell, the meat being firÅ¿t taken out; let him be thus uÅ¿ed daily, by the Å¿pace of Å¿ixe dayes. ThoÅ¿e dayes being ended,

Take the root of Salerick, the root of TaÅ¿Å¿us-Barbatus, the root of Valerion, and the root of Lappaizon, of each like much, chop them all very Å¿mall, as hearbs to the pot, which being thus well mixed, give them to the HorÅ¿e without Oates if he will eate them, if not, then otherwiÅ¿e in Pils; and when you give him the roots, do not give him the aforeÅ¿aid powder, and Å¿o continue him with theÅ¿e roots Å¿ixe dayes together, which Å¿ixe dayes ended, cauÅ¿e him to be bloudied againe on the other Å¿ide of the necke, but then let him not bleed Å¿o much as before, and order him as before after the firÅ¿t bleeding: nor Å¿hall you give him either powder or roots, but let him be Å¿till kept warm,
and have his ordinary allowance of meate, as well of Hay as of Oats, and then for Å¿ixe dayes after, every evening after he hath drunke white water, give him one evening of this powder with his Oates, and the next evening of theÅ¿e rootes, and if you finde not the Farcin to dry up to your minde, continue then this powder and theÅ¿e roots for Å¿ixe dayes more, and thoÅ¿e dayes being paÅ¿t, give him good Hay and good Oates, and not any longer the powder, or the rootes: and thus following theÅ¿e directions punctually, your HorÅ¿e Å¿hall be perfectly cured, and be brought into good Å¿tate and health again, neither Å¿hall the relicks of the farcin remaine in any part of his body, and if there be any knots remaining, they Å¿hall breake, purge, cleanÅ¿e, heale, and dry up, the maine cauÅ¿e being taken and purged away. Of this my Å¿elfe had never tryall by reaÅ¿on that many of the ingredients were not eaÅ¿ily to be had. Another:

Take blacke Elebore, and adde to the hearb Å¿ome of its juyce, put unto it old Boares-greaÅ¿e, and boyle it untill the juyce be quite boyled into it, whereby to bring it to a perfect unguent, with which you Å¿hall annoynt and rub the knots, or buttons of the farcin, but before you doe apply this unguent, let the hayre be Å¿haven or clipped away from and about the knots. â With this receit I have cured onely one HorÅ¿e. Another:

Take five or Å¿ixe handfuls of four-leaved Plantane, with the roots, of Bay Å¿alt one handfull, and Å¿o much Comin as you may well take up, with your thumb and two fingers, beate the Comin to fine powder, and then Å¿tamp the Plantane and Salt well together with the Comin, and after they be well incorporate, let it Å¿teepe and infuÅ¿e 24 hou â¢ es, then Å¿traine and wring it hard, and give the liquor thereof to your HorÅ¿e in a morning faÅ¿ting, but you muÅ¿t take bloud from him the day before, and he muÅ¿t Å¿tand upon the Trench Å¿ixe hours before you give him the Å¿aid drinke, and you muÅ¿t alÅ¿o put into his eares the juyce of Rue, and then Å¿titch up his eares, and Å¿o let them remaine 24 hours, but if the malady Å¿hall continue (which I think it will not doe) then muÅ¿t you let him bloud againe, and give him the aforeÅ¿aid drink. This I never tryed, but he that taught me this, did aÅ¿Å¿ure me that there is no kinde of farcin, but this receit will cure. Another:

Albeit that all theÅ¿e receits be very good for the farcin, yet are not all HorÅ¿es cured with one and the Å¿ame medicine; and moÅ¿t certain it is, that the moÅ¿t infallible way to cure the farcin, is to give him the fire: in the practiÅ¿e not onely of this cure, but of many others alÅ¿o, which are to be adminiÅ¿tred inwardly, it is greatly behoofefull that the Ferrier be mindfull to obÅ¿erve the Å¿trength, age, quality, and ability of the HorÅ¿e, to which he is to adminiÅ¿ter, and accordingly to mixe and apply his ingredients. Another:

FirÅ¿t let him bloud on both Å¿ides the necke and Å¿purre-veynes, and let him bleed a good quantity, then take Hemlocke, Cinque-foyle, or five leaved graÅ¿Å¿e, and Rue, of each like much, Å¿tamp them and Å¿train them, and put the juyce thereof into his eares, and then Å¿titch them up 24 houres, and it is a certain cure. â For with this I have cured Å¿undry HorÅ¿es. Another:

FirÅ¿t let him bleed well at the necke veyne, then take Trifora-Magna, and Aloes Platice, of each two ounces, and as much Barly bran, mixe all theÅ¿e, and diÅ¿Å¿olve it in oyle-olive one pinte, and put thereto of white wine one pinte, and then divide it into two parts or moyities, and Å¿o give it two mornings together to your HorÅ¿e faÅ¿ting with a Horne, that is to Å¿ay, either morning the one moyity: this done, take as much black Å¿ope as a Walnut, halfe as much ArÅ¿nick in fine powder, and work them into one body to a Å¿alve, then with the poynt of a knife Å¿lit or open all the hard knots or puÅ¿tils, and Å¿o put into every of them the quantity of two Barly cornes of this Å¿alve, which will eate forth the cores, and kill the poyÅ¿onous humours, then where you Å¿ee the wounds, and places red and faire, heale them up by annoynting them with freÅ¿h Butter molten and made hot, and then Å¿trew upon them the powder of Bolearmonack. â This is a moÅ¿t approved good receit, and by my Å¿elfe often practiÅ¿ed. Another:

Take the juyce of Rue, and of Aqua-vitae, of each one Å¿poonfull and a halfe, beat them well together, and by equall portions convey it into both his eares, then Å¿titch them up for 24 houres Å¿pace, and he is infallibly cured. â This is an excellent cure, and by me often uÅ¿ed. Another:

FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h all the places that be raw or Å¿welled, with Chamberly, or white Wine Vineger warmed, take then of Salt one handfull, of white Wine Vineger one pottle, of Allum diÅ¿Å¿olved in the Vineger,
one ounce, of Verde-greaÅ¿e and greene Copperas, both made into fine powder, of each one pound, melt all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and every day waÅ¿h the Å¿ores, and places Å¿welled therewith warme, twice a day, morning and evening. sp.speaker: Hippophyl.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir over much riding and exerciÅ¿e, will bring the fatteÅ¿t HorÅ¿e that ever trode upon the Earth, to become poore, bare, and leane, and Å¿o will too early, and too late ayerings, bad dyet, evill keeping, lingring after Mares, and Å¿pending upon them, lingring after graÅ¿Å¿e, and the like: But if your horÅ¿e be poore, bare, leane,Fat horÅ¿e. and feeble, Å¿o that his Å¿tomack be good to meate, I will give you a Receit, which (if you doe duly obÅ¿erve my rules, juÅ¿tly as I Å¿hall deliver them) you Å¿hall get him up into fleÅ¿h in twelve or foureteene dayes.

FirÅ¿t therefore take bloud from him, if you do find it groÅ¿Å¿e, or Fl â¢ gmatick, for otherwiÅ¿e he cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly mend, then inÅ¿teade of Oates in the morning, you Å¿hall give him Wheate branne,Bran prepared. prepared after this manner. You muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that this branne thus prepared, is the only thing which dryeth up his naughty, groÅ¿Å¿e, and corrupt humours, and doth the better prepare the body to aÅ¿Å¿ume luÅ¿t, courage, Å¿trength, and fleÅ¿h, together with the helpe of the powder, which is this.

Take of Commin, Fenugrick, Sileris-Montani, Nutmegs, Cloves, Ginger, LinÅ¿eed, of each two ounce, Quick-BrimÅ¿tone Å¿ix ounce,Fat a lean â¢ horÅ¿e. make all theÅ¿e into powder, of this powder give him every night, the quantity of an Eg-Å¿hell full, with his Oates, as I have before preÅ¿cribed, but he muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be watred, with white water, which Å¿o Å¿oone as hee hath drunke, let his whole body be rubbed, then cloathed, & littered,

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

Falling of the fundament.Take white-Salt made into very fine powder, Å¿trew a little upon the gut, then take a piece of Lard, and firÅ¿t having boyled Mallow-leaves till they be Å¿oft, take of theÅ¿e leaves and beat them well with the Lard, and when it is Å¿ufficiently beaten, make it up like to a Å¿uppoÅ¿itory, and apply it to the place every day once, till it be whole. â This I have often tryed,

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Should be very glad to know what you can Å¿ay of Feavers?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, as touching feavers in HorÅ¿es, I Å¿ay that they be as Å¿ubject to them, as man is, as alÅ¿o that theÅ¿e feavers are of Å¿everall natures, which cannot be denied, which may moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed and knowne, if you pleaÅ¿e diligently to obÅ¿erve. A feaver commeth many times, either by intemperate riding or travell, or elÅ¿e through bad and unwholeÅ¿ome dyet: and all feavers for the moÅ¿t part have their Å¿ourÅ¿e from theÅ¿e effects, if you adde thereunto evill ayre.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHy HippoÅ¿erus, how doe you define a Feaver?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
I define it thus.
ã1 paragraphã
A Feaver is an unnaturall and intemperate heat which beginneth at the heart, dilateth it Å¿elf through all the arteries and veynes of the whole body of the HorÅ¿e, hindring all his naturall motions: howÅ¿oever Å¿ome Ferriers are pleaÅ¿ed to make of them more Å¿orts, then I will queÅ¿tion their phyÅ¿icall and learned diÅ¿tinctions, for I could never conclude them but in a few, as quotidian, tertian, quartan, and peÅ¿tilent, and yet all theÅ¿e be of one nature, albeit Å¿ome more malignant then others be, onely a Hectique feaver is of a different nature from the former, and Å¿o alÅ¿o a peÅ¿tilent feaver may be. Now as touching feavers which come in the Spring, Summer, Autumne, or Winter, I cannot Å¿ee why they Å¿hould be feavers different in nature from theÅ¿e other, for there are not any of theÅ¿e, but may come to a HorÅ¿e in any of theÅ¿e Å¿eaÅ¿ons.

p.hi: FRom whence doe Feavers proceed then?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
FirÅ¿t Sir you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that Feavers are of two Å¿orts, that is to Å¿ay, Ordinary and Accidentall, the ordinary feavers are thoÅ¿e that come of Å¿urfets, over-riding, and labour, unwholeÅ¿ome meat, as moyÅ¿t, raw, mouldy, and muÅ¿ty bread, corne, provender and hay, of what nature, Å¿ort, or condition Å¿oever; but your feavers Accidentall come of Å¿ome ter â¢ ible Å¿troke or deep wound, bringing therewith inÅ¿ufferable paine, dolour, and griefe to the poor beaÅ¿t, again, your ordinary Feavers come oft times by the extreame violent Å¿corching of the Sunne, but moÅ¿t commonly in the canicular dayes, as when your HorÅ¿e is abroad at graÅ¿Å¿e, where is either want of water, or having Å¿uch as is neither good or wholeÅ¿ome, or elÅ¿e where is want of houÅ¿ing, Å¿helter to goe into, or Å¿hady trees to be under, and Å¿uch kinde of Agues doe prove for the moÅ¿t part either Hectike, or PeÅ¿tilent feavers, for by that meanes his bloud becommeth inflamed, whereby the humour of choller is predominate. Now Sir, if you be pleaÅ¿ed to obÅ¿erve Å¿trictly and carefully, you Å¿hall alÅ¿o finde that feavers doe come many times alÅ¿o from a quite contrary cauÅ¿e; as from cold taken upon hard riding, or great labour, and by having at Å¿uch times cold water given him to drink, or by waÅ¿hing, or walking having Å¿weat much, or by being out too late in the gripÅ¿e or Å¿hutting in of the evening, or upon day breaking, eÅ¿pecially neere or among fenny, mooriÅ¿h, or mariÅ¿h grounds, by reaÅ¿on that naughty vapours do ariÅ¿e from Å¿uch kinde of places: Feavers alÅ¿o do accrew to HorÅ¿es when upon hard riding, and great toyle, you give your HorÅ¿e cold water drawn out of a Well, which being much colder
then either River, or Pond water, doth more chill the HorÅ¿e inwardly, whereby he is much more diÅ¿tempered, cauÅ¿ing him to quake, and to Å¿hake exceedingly after his drinke, which occaÅ¿ioneth crudities, and an evill habit in the Å¿tomacke, which doth beget and ingender an ague or feaver, wherefore after Å¿weating and great labour, I doe adviÅ¿e you that whatÅ¿oever is given him, be firÅ¿t Å¿et over the fire to take away the chilneÅ¿Å¿e, whereby your HorÅ¿e may take the leÅ¿Å¿e damage, for that feavers taken of this nature, doe commonly prove peÅ¿tilent feavers, whoÅ¿e nature is to infect all his fellowes which are in the Å¿ame Å¿table or roome with him, if he be not either Å¿peedily removed from his conÅ¿orts, or elÅ¿e Å¿uddenly cured; and the reaÅ¿on hereof is moÅ¿t evident, for that when as a HorÅ¿e hath been al the whole day travelled (eÅ¿pecially in the winter) and brought into the Å¿table all hot and Å¿weating, when in Å¿hort time after his bloud and pores begin to be Å¿etled, and to return to his heart again, and to his intrals, then if you give him cold water, you may inÅ¿tantly perceive him to fall into a formall quivering and Å¿haking for a time, which being once paÅ¿Å¿ed over, you Å¿hall Å¿ee him moÅ¿t palpably aÅ¿Å¿ume a moÅ¿t extreame and violent burning, and peradventure after fals into a moÅ¿t deÅ¿perate Å¿weating, whereby is moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ie to be found in him a generall diÅ¿temperature throughout his whole body, together with a formall and dangerous feaver, wherefore if the Ferrier be not the more expert, it may Å¿tick cloÅ¿er unto him, and remain longer by him then a buÅ¿hell of Oats will do. But a feaver which doth proceed elther from the corruption of the bloud, or from the contagion of the ayre, (according as I have before intimated) that I Å¿ay is moÅ¿t frequent, albeit not Å¿o well known to all Ferriers, and I am able to affirme thus much of theÅ¿e kinde of feavers out of mine own long experience, that they are of that extreame violence, and Å¿o malignant, and their poyÅ¿on of that infinite force, as that if through their own violence, they be not able of themÅ¿elves to bring the creature viÅ¿ited therewith to his end, yet will theÅ¿e convert their malice into other mortall maladies and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which will in time prove as noxious, to wit, into the Yellowes, Stavers, Glanders, DropÅ¿ie, ConÅ¿umption, Farcin, &c. unto which a peÅ¿tilent feaver is evermore the precurÅ¿or: inÅ¿omuch as if the Ferrier be not very skilfull and cautelous in obÅ¿erving and knowing the true Å¿ymptomes of theÅ¿e kinde of diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, he may eaÅ¿ily in Å¿tead of labouring to effect a Cure, through his miÅ¿priÅ¿ion, miÅ¿carry therein.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat be the true Å¿ymptomes or Å¿ignes whereby to know a Feaver?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If you doe obÅ¿erve him well,Feave â¢ to kno â¢
you Å¿hall perceive him Å¿o Å¿oon as he beginneth to be feaveriÅ¿h, and when the fit firÅ¿t commeth upon him to hang or hold down his head, and if at firÅ¿t comming, it beginneth with a cold fit, then will he quake and tremble, and when his cold fit is over, then will he glow and burn throughout his whole body, his breath will be very hot, and he will fetch his winde thicke, and his noÅ¿trils will be very open, and his flankes will beat thick, he will forÅ¿ake his meat, and reele oft times as he goeth, his eyes will be Å¿welled, they will water and be matterative, he will fall away and conÅ¿ume in his fleÅ¿h, his Å¿tones will hang low, he will deÅ¿ire and offer oft to lye down, and yet being laid he will riÅ¿e Å¿uddenly againe, he will have great deÅ¿ire to drinke, neither will he drink much, and yet you would thinke that all the water in the Thames would not be Å¿ufficient to quench his thirÅ¿t, for he will covet evermore to keep his mouth in the water, albeit he will drinke very little, and his Å¿leepe will goe from him. p.hi: VVHat are the beÅ¿t cures for theÅ¿e ordinary Feavers?

sp.p:
If the feaver be quotidian and daily,Feaver Ordinar â¢
then

Take the yolkes of three new laid egges, and beat them well with Å¿even Å¿poonfuls of the beÅ¿t Aqua vitae, and put unto it of ordinary Treacle, a Å¿poonfull, and Å¿o making it bloud warme over a few hot embers, give it him, and then take his backe and ride him, untill hee doe begin to Å¿weat, and then bring him into the Å¿table, and cloath, wiÅ¿pe, and litter him warme, Å¿o as he may Å¿weat an houre in the Å¿table, but then coole him by degrees, and let him faÅ¿t three houres after, but let him bloud before you drench him, in the necke and mouth, and give him white water or MaÅ¿hes. warme, but not to Å¿weate any more, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench three houres after his Å¿weating, then unbit him, and waÅ¿h his tongue and mouth, with Alume, Vineger, Sage, and water boyled togather, that done give him a little Wheate Å¿traw to eate, and an houre after a gallon of Å¿weet, dry, and cleane Oats, well dreÅ¿Å¿ed and Å¿ifted, but lay not all at once before him, but three or foure handfuls at a time continuing thus to feed him, till hee hath eaten up his whole gallon, and at night, give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h. â¢ ake of Å¿trong Ale one quart, and of Wormewood halfe a handfull, long-Pepper, Graynes, and the powder of dryed Rue of each one ounce, London Triacle two ounces, boyle them to a third part, then take it off, and Å¿trayne it, that done, put into it of browne-Å¿ugar-Candy in powder halfe an ounce, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme. â. Take Stone-Crop, of the iuice thereof foure Spoonefull, put this iuice into Å¿trong-Ale one quart, and Å¿o give it your horÅ¿e, then let him be walked, (if the winde be not too cold and Å¿harpe) an houre, then Å¿et him up and cover him Å¿o as he may Å¿weate an houre, then coole him by degrees, and let him drinke no cold water by any meanes, & let his provender bee good, old, dry, and well Å¿ifted Oates, but againÅ¿t the fit commeth (whether the Feaver be Quotidian, Tertian, or Quartan) let him be kept faÅ¿ting, for the longer hee is faÅ¿ting, and

This is a well approved receipt, and let this Å¿uffice for ordinary Feavers, provided that when his fits be gone from him, and that he appeareth more lightÅ¿ome, and well, it will be very good and wholeÅ¿ome for him if you cauÅ¿e him to bee had abroad, and walked warme covered, and Å¿o ayred in due time, in the warme Sun, and that will greatly comfort him, and revive his Å¿pirits.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Å¿ay you now to the Feaver Hectique?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I Å¿ay Sir, it is a moÅ¿t dangerous and mortall Feaver, and Å¿o malignant, as that if a skilfull Ferrier bee not with him in time, it is certaine death, and firÅ¿t it beginneth with a ConÅ¿umption in the fleÅ¿h; it proceedeth of a hot humour ingendred firÅ¿t in the Å¿tomacke, which too much PhyÅ¿icke hath occaÅ¿ioned, and by taking away of too much bloud from him, in his youth without neceÅ¿Å¿ity, wherefore it is a thing moÅ¿t perillous to take bloud from young horÅ¿es upon very Å¿light cauÅ¿e, & not to be over ready with PhyÅ¿ick, but only in caÅ¿e of great neceÅ¿Å¿ity. The Å¿ignes to know this Feaver from any other, are to looke into his mouth, and to draw forth his tongue, and you Å¿hall finde both his mouth and tongue raw, and mervailous hot, and having little appetite to meate, his fleÅ¿h will conÅ¿ume, and waÅ¿te, and Å¿eene looÅ¿e, if you Å¿trike him with your hand upon the buttocks, the fleÅ¿h thereof will quiver and quake, and he will be continually Å¿ubject to quaking and Å¿haking all his whole body over: beÅ¿ides he will be very much inclined to Å¿weate as hee Å¿tandeth in the Å¿table. The cure is. FirÅ¿t to make this lotion for his mouth.

Take of running water or Well water two quarts, and put thereto of Sage, of Yarrow, of Ribwort, of Plantane, of Bramble-leaves,Feaver Hectique. and of Hony-Å¿uckle-leaves of each one handfull, with common Hony one Å¿poonefull, boyle all theÅ¿e to the conÅ¿umption of one moyety, and a little before you take it from the fire, put to it the quantity of a wal-nut of Alume, and two Å¿poonefull, of Vineger, when that is diÅ¿Å¿olved take it off, and drayne the water from the hearbs, or elÅ¿e Å¿lightly Å¿trayn it, which water you Å¿hall keepe for your uÅ¿e, and when you would waÅ¿h his mouth therewith, faÅ¿ten to a Å¿tick a ragge, and Å¿o waÅ¿h his mouth and tongue twice or thrice a day, and this will make his mouth well againe; or elÅ¿e if you do waÅ¿h his mouth with the Å¿urrop of Mulberries, it is very wholeÅ¿ome and good. â. and Å¿o give it your horÅ¿e, then let him bee ridden a little, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warme, and let him bee Å¿et upon the Trench three houres before, and three houres after, and then eyther give him Å¿weete Hay, or greene Corne, or the leaves of Sallowes, and towards night give him a Å¿weete M â¢ Å¿h, and give him this drinke every other day, for three mornings, continuing him with MaÅ¿hes or white water, and let his Oates bee very well Å¿ifted, and in Å¿hort time, he will doe well againe. â. With this receipt I have cured Å¿undry horÅ¿es, but then forget not to waÅ¿h his mouth dayly with the aforeÅ¿aid lotion. But if in all theÅ¿e Å¿everall Feavers, you do find him eyther to be coÅ¿tiue, or very hot in his bodyâª then you may do well to adminiÅ¿ter that ClyÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed you, in lib. 2. chap. 6. Â§. 2. ClyÅ¿ter 2. letter C.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p:
VVHat Å¿ay you now ãâã
Feaver PeÅ¿tilent?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: It is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e moÅ¿t contagious, for it is Å¿o malignant as that it will infect Å¿o many horÅ¿es as be in the Å¿table wher he Å¿tandeth, and it proceedeth from one of theÅ¿e two cauÅ¿es, viz. eyther from an infectious ayre, or from the corruption of the bloud, inflamed by meanes of intemperate riding, and exerciÅ¿e. The Å¿ignes are theÅ¿e, the horÅ¿e will hang downe his head in the Manger, as if hee Å¿lept, his eyes will water very much, and Inflamations will ariÅ¿e at the roots of the Eares, as if he had the Vives.

The beÅ¿t cure I ever knew was this, with which I have cured many HorÅ¿es viÅ¿ited with a PeÅ¿tilent Feaver, Feaver PeÅ¿tilent. firÅ¿t let him bleed well in the Neck veine, reÅ¿erving the bloud in a cleane baÅ¿in, which when it is cold will be very bad, and ill coloured, then waÅ¿h his mouth with the lotion, Å¿pecified in the precedent Â§. Å¿econdly apply to the Temples this PlayÅ¿ter.

Take of Camamile, of Goates-milke, of the Iuyce of Sage, of Sallet-oyle, of white Wine-vineger of each foure Å¿poonfull, of red-roÅ¿e-leaves dryed one handfull, which muÅ¿t be eyther of a red-roÅ¿e cake, or otherwiÅ¿e red-roÅ¿e leaves dryed, beat them all in a Morter, till they become of one body; and Å¿o thick, as that you may Å¿pread it playÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, upon a linnen cloath, then Å¿trew upon the PlaiÅ¿ter two or three Nut-megges made into fine powder, then make it good and hot, putting the backÅ¿ide of the PlaiÅ¿ter, into a Pewter diÅ¿h, over a chaffing diÅ¿h â¢ nd coales, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it warme to the HorÅ¿e, and for his drinke, let it bee Å¿uch water wherein have bin boyled violet leaves, Mallowes, and Sorrell, but if the fit doe hold him violently, then.

Take of London Triacle three ounces, and diÅ¿Å¿olve it in Muskadine one pint, and Å¿queeze into it the iuyce of two or three good Lemons, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it with a horne: and this will preÅ¿ently put the fit from him, for the preÅ¿ â¢ nt. The nature of this Feaver is Å¿o malignant,
and Å¿o contagiouÅ¿ly hot, as that it will furre the mouth exceedingly, and cauÅ¿e ulcers and Å¿ores to breed in the mouth and throat: wherefore you Å¿hall doe the more carefully, if every day you doe look into his mouth, and if you can perceive it to be furred, and clammy, then faile you not to waÅ¿h his mouth and tongue, either with the Å¿yrope of Mulberries, or the lotion water taught you in the precedent Section: and if through his too great heat, you doe finde your horÅ¿es body to be coÅ¿tive, then Å¿hall you adminiÅ¿ter this CliÅ¿ter.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that which of Å¿ome is called the Flying-Worme?

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to keep a HorÅ¿e that he be not tormented with Flyes?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
TheÅ¿e Flyes are a vermine which are more bold then welcome to a HorÅ¿e, for what by their buzzing, their biting, and Å¿tinging, they do infinitely annoy and afflict the poore beaÅ¿t, cauÅ¿ing him many times to falter in his travell, and loÅ¿e his pace, and moÅ¿t commonly through his nodding and other evill poÅ¿tures and geÅ¿tures, provoked by theÅ¿e flyes, they cauÅ¿e him Å¿o to fret, as to looÅ¿e his rain and comely carriage of hi â¢
body, whereby he hath bin much undervalued; beÅ¿ides in his travell theÅ¿e Flyes doe Å¿o cauÅ¿e him to fret and fume, that he both overtoyleth himÅ¿elfe in his way, cauÅ¿ing him to Å¿weat Å¿o much, as that he loÅ¿ing his mettle, hath many times thereby inflamed his bloud, and brought upon himÅ¿elf Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, together with a ciÅ¿temperature throughout his whole body. So likewiÅ¿e being at graÅ¿Å¿e, at what time the flye is too buÅ¿ie, they do provoke him to run, and to Å¿cope about, by which meanes he being many times very full, it cauÅ¿eth crudities and raw digeÅ¿tions to ariÅ¿e in his Å¿tomacke, which breedeth Å¿urfets, or other maladies, wherefore for prevention thereof,

Take the leaves of Gourdes, Pumpions, or wilde, or garden Cowcumbers, Å¿tamp them, and Å¿train them, and with the juyce thereof waÅ¿h your horÅ¿e all over, and the flyes will not come nigh him. â Of this I have made often tryall. Another:

Take Mallowes, Å¿tamp and Å¿train them, and with the juyce thereof waÅ¿h your horÅ¿e, and it will keep away the flyes. â This is an approved
good thing alÅ¿o. Another:

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is good to mollifie the foot of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If your horÅ¿e hath bin foundred, and that after being cured, his Å¿oles and hoofes doe waxe dry and hard, they be either Å¿hrunk or in perill of Å¿hrinking, then firÅ¿t take off his Å¿hoes, and let him be pared Å¿omewhat cloÅ¿e, but not too neere, which done, with Bee-waxe molten annoynt the Å¿oles with the Å¿aid molten waxe, with a GooÅ¿e-feather, and Å¿o Å¿et on his Å¿hooes againe, then three daies after

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is Å¿o called by reaÅ¿on of that naughty fleÅ¿h which groweth upon the fruÅ¿h or heele, which is in likeneÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿hape of a figge, from whence this malady and Å¿orance taketh its denomination, and the French alÅ¿o give it the very Å¿ame Epitheton, viz. la Figne, which Å¿ignifieth a figge. It commeth by means of Å¿ome hurt which the HorÅ¿e hath formerly received in his foot (which was not well healed) by Å¿ome nail, Å¿tub, thorn, bone, or Å¿tone, & oft times by Å¿ome over-reach, upon the heele or fruÅ¿h. Cut away the hoofe Å¿o as there may be a convenient Å¿pace betwixt the Å¿ole and the hoofe, Figge in t â¢ foot. to the end the figge may the more eaÅ¿ily be cured, then put to the Å¿orance a piece of Å¿punge which you muÅ¿t binde cloÅ¿e upon the figge, which will eate it off to the very root, then heale up the Å¿ore with the green oyntment taught you in lib. 2 chap. 10. Â§ 4. G. â This I have found good. Another.

Cut away the figge cloÅ¿e, either with your inciÅ¿ion knife, or elÅ¿e burne it off with a hot iron (which is the better way) and Å¿o lay unto it for two dayes after tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e to take away the fire.

Take then the tops of the moÅ¿t angry yong nettles you can finde, pound them very Å¿mall, and Å¿o lay them upon a linnen clothâª juÅ¿t the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of the figge, then take the powder of Verdegreece, and Å¿trew
it upon the chopped nettles, (which muÅ¿t be done before you lay it to the Å¿orance) and Å¿o binde it upon the Å¿orance, renewing it every day once till the hoofe have covered the Å¿ore. â This I doe know to be a moÅ¿t certain cure, for it never did faile me.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt now what Å¿ay you to a FiÅ¿tula? how doe you cure that?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A FiÅ¿tula is a hollow ulcer which maketh its way crooked, proceeding oft times from naughty and malignant humours; Å¿ometimes it is ingendred from Å¿ome wound which hath not bin well healed; Å¿ometimes it commeth by meanes of a Å¿tripe, which having been Å¿o Å¿trongly laid on, that it hath bruiÅ¿ed the fleÅ¿h to the bone, whereby it hath putrified inwardly, and either brake forth of it Å¿elfe, or was opened by the Ferrier, and thus it commeth to be a FiÅ¿tula: Å¿ometimes it commeth by a wrench or pinch, with a Collar in drawing, or by being wrung by the tree of a bad Å¿addle; and Å¿ometimes it ingendreth of its own accord by the meanes of peccant and bilious humours, which hath long lyen lurking in the body of the HorÅ¿e. The Å¿ignes how to know it are Å¿o manifeÅ¿t, as that it needeth not an Ecce. The way how to cure it, is to Å¿earch to the bottome either with a probe of lead, or elÅ¿e with Å¿ome other thing which will bend and yeeld which way Å¿oever the concavity of the Å¿orance leadeth it: and when you have found the bottome thereof, let it be opened downwards, if it may poÅ¿Å¿ibly be done, to the end the corruption may the better iÅ¿Å¿ue from the place, then taint it for two or three dayes with tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e, thereby to cauÅ¿e the hole to be the wider, and then inject this water following:

Take of Sublimate, and of Precipi â¢ at, of each Å¿o much as will lye upon a three pence, of Alume, and of white Coperas, of each three ounces, burn all theÅ¿e in an earthen pot, but firÅ¿t rub the bottom with a little oyle, that it may not burn there; this done, burne them all together, then take of faire cleare water, two quarts, boyle this water firÅ¿t by it Å¿elfe, and Å¿cum it in the boyling, then take it from the fire, and put in as much of this powder as will lye upon a Å¿hilling at twice, and thus it is made. But if you be deÅ¿irous to make this water of more Å¿trength and efficacy, take then faire water, and Coltrough or Smiths water, of each like much, and of white Wine Vineger a third part, and with the aÅ¿hes of AÅ¿hen wood, make lye of them, with the water and Vineger, and Å¿o make your water with this powder and lye, and the former ingredients, according as before is taught you. Inject this water with a Syringe into the Å¿orance, and in Å¿hort time it will both kill the fiÅ¿tula, FiÅ¿tula. and heale it up. â This is a moÅ¿t approved and infallible cure. Another:

Take of the beÅ¿t honey one pinte, of Verdigreece one ounce, make it into fine powder, and Å¿o boyle them together upon a Å¿oft fire three
quarters of an houre, that done, Å¿train it into a gally pot, and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e. â This is a moÅ¿t pretious unguent wherewith to taint a fiÅ¿tula or poll evill, for it goeth down to the bottome, it eateth away all dead and evill fleÅ¿h, whereby to cauÅ¿e that the carnifying fleÅ¿h may heale the better. â This I have often tryed. I have alÅ¿o another Aegiptiacum, which I make thus.

Take honey one pinte, white Wine Vineger, halfe a pinte, Allum three ounces, and Verdigreece finely powdered, one ounce and a halfe; boyle all theÅ¿e together, till it be thicke: this is a good Aegyptiacum. But if you deÅ¿ire to make it yet Å¿tronger, then put to theÅ¿e ingredients of Mercury Å¿ublimate in fine powder one ounce, and of ArÅ¿nick three Å¿cruples powdred alÅ¿o, and Å¿o boyle them with the former ingredients. This laÅ¿t will kill any fiÅ¿tula or old ulcer whatÅ¿oever being dreÅ¿Å¿ed therewith: but the other which is made onely of Vineger, Allum, and Verdigreece, may be applyed to a fiÅ¿tula in the mouth without prejudice to the HorÅ¿e. â Of both theÅ¿e I have made often tryall.

p.hi: HAve you not Å¿ome good water beÅ¿ide, wherewith to waÅ¿h a FiÅ¿tula or old Å¿ore?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I can give you a moÅ¿t excellent water which is this:

Take white Wine Vineger four pints,FiÅ¿tula water. of Camphire and of Mercury-Precipitate, of each halfe an ounce, greene Treacle three ounces, red Sage, Yarrow, and Rib wort, of each one handfull, of Honey, and of Hogs-greaÅ¿e, of each halfe a pound, boyle all theÅ¿e together untill the one halfe be conÅ¿umed, and then Å¿train it, and Å¿o waÅ¿h and cleanÅ¿e the wound with the liquor. X This is Å¿peciall good. Another no whit inferiour to the former.

Take of Coltrough water, four quarts, firÅ¿t boyle it by it Å¿elfe a good while, and Å¿cumme it Å¿o long as any Å¿cumme doth ariÅ¿e, then Å¿traine it through a fine cloth into a cleane pot, and throw away the grounds, which will be black and naught, then waÅ¿h the PoÅ¿tnet cleane wherein it was boyled, and put in your water againe. Then take of white Coperas, of Allum and of Verdegreece, of each one pound, beat them all into fine powder, and put them into the water, and boyle them all together, and when it is boyled as much as will Å¿uffice, which will Å¿oon be done, let it Å¿tand to Å¿ettle a while, then poure the cleare into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, being firÅ¿t cold enough, and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e. But the powder which remaineth in the bottome, you may dry and keep in a boxe by it Å¿elfe, for it will heale, and dry up any Å¿ore or ulcer. This water being injected with a Å¿yringe of wood or pewter, will cure any fiÅ¿tula whatÅ¿oever, if it may come to the bottome thereof. â Of this water I have had great experience. But you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that theÅ¿e Å¿everall waters will onely kill the
cankerous humour of the fiÅ¿tula, and therefore after the malice thereof is quelled, you muÅ¿t heale up the Å¿orance with the green oyntment preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2âª chap. 10. Â§ 4. G. or elÅ¿e with Å¿ome carnifying Å¿alve or unguent. Another:

But if you cannot come to taint it to the bottome of the fiÅ¿tula, then take Å¿trong Lye, Honey, Roch-Allum, white Mercury, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and boyle them together, and inject it to the very bottome of the fiÅ¿tula, and it will kill it. â But if the fiÅ¿tula be in the head, then

Take the juyce of HouÅ¿eleeke, and dip a locke of blacke Wooll into it, and put the Å¿ame into his eares, and Å¿o Å¿titch them up, renewing it every day till it be whole. This cure hath been highly recommended unto me, but I never had opportunity to make proofe thereof. Another:

Take Roman Vitreall, Roch-Allum, and RoÅ¿e-water, of each two ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e on a quicke fire, till they come to be as hard as a Å¿tone, then beat it to fine powder, and when you dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ore, make a taint, which being dipped in unguentum Aegyptiacum, rowle then in this powder, and Å¿o convey the end of your taint down to the very bottome of the fiÅ¿tula. This is the beÅ¿t way alÅ¿o to cure a poll-evill, and this powder being laid upon an old Å¿ore, will both heale and dry it up. â This I onely made twice proofe of, the firÅ¿t time to a fiÅ¿tula, and the Å¿econd time to a poll-evill, both which cures I perfected. But now you would gladly know how to ripen and breake a fiÅ¿tula, wherefore

Take Brooke-lime, Mallowes, AÅ¿Å¿mart, of each, like much, boyle them in old Chamberlye, till the hearbs be very Å¿oft, and apply theÅ¿e hearbs to the Å¿welling, neither doe you renew it in two or three dayes, and then it will both ripen and breake any impoÅ¿tume. â This I have often uÅ¿ed, and found very good. And let this Å¿uffice for this malady.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: NOw let us come to the Feete, how doe you cure the Fetlock being hurt?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If this Å¿orance commeth by any wound, by the biting of a Dogge, or by being caÅ¿t in a Halter, then the beÅ¿t way to cure the Å¿ame, is.

Take unÅ¿laked lime, and the yelke of an Egge of each like much,Fetlock hurt. beat them together to a Å¿alve, or unguent, then mixe therewith the juyce of one head of Garlick, and a little Å¿oot, and with this annoint the Å¿ore till it be almoÅ¿t whole, then to skinne the Å¿ame,
