This is a very well approved Receipt. But if your horÅ¿e have gotten a Å¿ore foot by meanes of any cannell-nayle, or bruiÅ¿e, by treading upon a Å¿tone, which after rankleth inwardly, or by other accident; then firÅ¿t rayle the skinne with your Cornet, and lay upon Å¿orance, Wheate-flower and Bores-greaÅ¿e well incorporate together, and dreÅ¿Å¿e him therewith twice a day, for two daies together, and at the Å¿econd dayes end,

Take the powder of Quick lime, Sope, and Tallow, and mixe them well together & for three dayes or more, apply it to the place, dreÅ¿Å¿ing it alÅ¿o twice a day, then waÅ¿h the wound with hot Vineger, and put upon it Caprinell, till it be whole. This I nev â¢ r tryed.Froathy o â¢ weeping hoofe. But if the hoofe doe weepe, or froath by Å¿ending forth thinne, watry, or froathy Å¿tuffe, then open the toppe thereof with your Cornet, Å¿o as the wound may become hollow round about the extreamities thereof Å¿o farre forth as that you may come to the MaÅ¿ter Keine to breake it in Å¿under, which done, let it bleed at pleaÅ¿ure, what it will, and when the Veine hath Å¿tanched, fill up the wound with Salt finely powdred, then take Hurds, and Å¿teepe them in Vineger, and Å¿o Å¿top the wound therewith, and bind thereto a cloath to keepe the Å¿ame from falling away, and it will cure it. â. But if the Å¿ole be hoofe, and in danger to fall away, draw it round twixt the Å¿ole and the hoofe with your drawing Iron, and Å¿o take out the Å¿o â¢ e quite, and then Å¿uffer his foot to bleed well, then apply to it this PlaiÅ¿ter.

Take the whites of Egges, and beate them a little, and Å¿o laying them upon Hurds, apply it to the foot, and bind it on that it fall not off, and let it remaine on Å¿o by the Å¿pace of two dayes, which ended open it, and waÅ¿h the foote with Å¿trong Vineger warmed, and then fill the Å¿ole with the powder of Salt and Tartar mixed together, and Å¿o bind it up with Hurds, Å¿teeped in Å¿trong Vineger, and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e it till it be whole. TheÅ¿e two Receipts were taught me by a famous
Ferrier of Paris in France, but I never had occaÅ¿ion to make uÅ¿e of it, howbeit I eÅ¿teeme them to be very good. But if your horÅ¿e be foundred in the feet, and that he hath not bin foundred above foure daies, then with this enÅ¿uing Receipt you may eaÅ¿ily Å¿et him upright, and make him Å¿ound againe in foure dayes more. The Cure is this.

Foundring in the feet.FirÅ¿t, let him bloud in the Neck, BreaÅ¿t, and Spurre veines, and take from him of bloud two quarts, which you muÅ¿t receive in a BaÅ¿in, or other cleane veÅ¿Å¿ell, with which make this Charge as followeth.

Take the bloud, and put into it eight new laid Egges Å¿hels and all, beat them well with the bloud, put to it of Bole-armonacke in fine powder halfe a pound, Å¿trong white Wine-Vineger one pinte, Sanguis Draconis three ounces, in fine powder, make this up with Wheate meale good and thicke Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, with this, charge his Back, Reines, BreaÅ¿t Thighes, Fetlockes, and Soles, & Å¿pread two cloathes PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, good and thick, and apply them to the Coffin of his Hoofes, and bind the fore-legges above the knees good and Å¿treight, with broad Filletting, or LiÅ¿tes, then Ride him two houres upon a hard way, which if it bee paved or pitched is the better, his feete having beene pared reaÅ¿onable neere before hand, and when you doe bring him into the Å¿table, let his feet be Å¿topped with this Charge.

Take Rie, or Wheate-branne, Oxe or Cow-dunge, Sheepes-Å¿uet, Turpentine (which muÅ¿t be put in laÅ¿t) let your Sheepes-Suet, be of the fat of the loyne of Mutton, and minced very Å¿mall, melt and heat all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and mixe them very well in the heating, and then put in your branne to make it into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, all which being through hot, then laÅ¿t of all put in your Turpentine, and Å¿o incorporate all very well together, with this Å¿top your horÅ¿e, who being thus three or foure dayes charged, and Å¿topped, ridden and kept warme, and not Å¿uffered to drinke cold water, but eyther MaÅ¿hes, or white water, he will be Å¿ound in foure or Å¿ix dayes â. This is a moÅ¿t excellent Receipt, for with it I have recovered many foundred horÅ¿es. If it be a dry Foundring, eÅ¿pecially with too long Å¿tanding in the Stable, then firÅ¿t pare him Å¿omewhat neere, and let him bleed well in the Toe-veines, then.

Take Egges and roÅ¿t them blew hard, raked up in the hot embers, and together with the powder of Comin, Å¿top his feete therewith Å¿o hot as they may be taken out of the embers, and put ouer the Å¿ole a peece of leather, with Å¿plents cloÅ¿e, to keepe the Egs that they come not forth.

Take then a great Onion, pill and Å¿tampe it, and let it infuÅ¿e or Å¿teepe foure and twenty houres together before, in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine-Vineger, you can get, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, Å¿o that it may bee in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, againÅ¿t you have Å¿topped your horÅ¿e, which
muÅ¿t be given him to drinke with a horne faÅ¿ting, and after let him bee warme covered, littered, let him Å¿tand upon the Trench three houres, and after that you may give him meate, and white water. â. This is a moÅ¿t approved good cure. If your horÅ¿e have beene long foundred, as a month or better, to make a perfect cure, and to Å¿et him up Å¿ound againe, it is needfull the Å¿oles of his feet be taken out, by which meanes new and better will come in their roome, wherefore when you do intend to take them off, have in a readineÅ¿Å¿e theÅ¿e things, viz.
Take the tender tops of IÅ¿ope three handfuls,Foundre â¢ long. pound them to maÅ¿h in a Morter, wherewith to Å¿tanch his bleeding, then have alÅ¿o further in a readineÅ¿Å¿e this receipt.

Take Snayles in the Å¿hels and breake the Å¿hels, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and take forth the Snayles, and reÅ¿erve them, then take Bay-Å¿alt one handfull, and of the tendreÅ¿t tops of the angrieÅ¿t red-nettles you can find, two or three good handfull, beat them with your Å¿nailes and Å¿alt in a Morter to a very Å¿alve, then take out the Å¿ole, then preÅ¿ently Å¿tanch the bleeding with your IÅ¿ope, and Å¿o Å¿oone as the foote leaveth bleeding, apply to the foote your other Medicine, of Snayles, Salt and Nettles, and Å¿o bind up the foot with cloathes, and Å¿o let it remaine foure and twenty houres, then open it, and heale up the Å¿orance with your greene oyntment taught you in lib 2. chap. 10. Â§. 4. and within two dayes you Å¿hall Å¿ee a new Å¿ole comming, â. This is right good.

But if hee bee foundred both in feete and body at once,Foundred the feet a â¢ body. and the Å¿ame time, as falleth out oftimes, through indiÅ¿creete and immoderate Riding, by a moÅ¿t violent heat giuen him, whereby the bloud is become inflamed, and his greaÅ¿e molten, then firÅ¿t rake him, and give him the CliÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. chap. 11. Â§. 8. C. CliÅ¿ter 8. and the next day let him bloud in the neck veine to a good quantity, reÅ¿erving the bloud, and keeping it from clotting, by continuall Å¿tirring, till it be cold; reÅ¿erve I Å¿ay of this bloud halfe a pint, by it Å¿elfe, to put into his drinke, and the reÅ¿idue keepe wherewith to make a charge; Now for his drinke let it be thus made.

Take of good Sack one pint, of the bloud you Å¿aved for his drinke halfe a pint, of London Triacle, and of Diapente, of each one Å¿poonfull, and of mans-ordure warme as it commeth froÌ him, the quantity of a wall-nut, brew and mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and give it him to drinke bloud warme. This drinke thus given, Charge him with this Charge.

Take the reÅ¿idue of the bloud you kept, and put unto it twelve new-laid Egges with their Å¿hels, and beat them together, then put thereunto of Bole-armoniack in powder foure ounces, Vineger halfe a pint, Sanguis Draconis in powder three ounces, and with Wheate meale, thicken it to a convenient Charge. Charge his Backe, BreaÅ¿t, Loynes, Legges, and Feete herewith, both above and beneath
the knees, laying it on againÅ¿t the hayre. This done, then

Take unÅ¿laked-lime, & Orpiment, of each like much, q.s. & diÅ¿Å¿olve them in running water, and let it Å¿tand two good houres, and after it is thus prepared, take as much MatroÅ¿etum as will bring it to a thicke Å¿ubÅ¿tance, which being made good and hot, annoynt the coffins of his hoofes therewith, eÅ¿pecially about the cronets, and Å¿top alÅ¿o the Å¿oles of his feet with the Å¿ame medicine, and if you let him bloud in the toe-veynes well, it will be the better, and he will be the Å¿ooner, better, and Å¿ounder cured. â This way I have cured two HorÅ¿es foundred in the body and feet, never having applyed it but unto thoÅ¿e two onely. But if your horÅ¿e be hoofe-bound, then

Hoofe bounden.Take Turpentine and Å¿heeps-Å¿uet, of each halfe a pound, Waxe a little, as much as will Å¿uffice, Sallet-oyle halfe a pinte, boyle all theÅ¿e together, but put in your Turpentine laÅ¿t, and as theÅ¿e boyle, keepe them with continuall Å¿tirring, and herewith annoynt his hoofes once a day well, or once in two dayes, and he will doe well. â But if it be but an ordinary heat in the feet newly taken, then

Take Wheate bran and Hogs greaÅ¿e, and make them to a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and apply it as well to the coffins, as the Å¿oles, and he will be well again. TheÅ¿e two latter receits a worty Knight taught me, but as yet I never made uÅ¿e, but of the former, which I have found to be very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph
sp.p: BVt yet HippoÅ¿erus, you have not Å¿hewed me how this malady commeth.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
That was but forgotten Sir, I will now therefore doe it. A foundring in the feet commeth evermore after great and over-violent labour, whereby the whole body is become diÅ¿tempered, the peccant and malignant humours Å¿tirred, the bloud inflamed, and the greaÅ¿e molten, which falling down into his feet, there Å¿etleth, and in Å¿hort time after, to wit, in 24 houres, the poor creature is hardly able to Å¿tand, or if he do, it is after a very feeble manner, holding his four feet together, Å¿o as you may eaÅ¿ily with your hand throw him to the ground, beÅ¿ides he will Å¿tand trembling, quaking, and Å¿haking, as if he had a Å¿haking ague, nor would he Å¿tand at all, unleÅ¿Å¿e he be enforced, for the Å¿oles and coffins of his feet will be Å¿o Å¿ore, his joynts and Å¿inewes Å¿o Å¿tiffe and benummed, that he cannot Å¿tand but with very much anguiÅ¿h and paine: wherefore if he may have his minde, he would alwayes be lying, and his whole body will be diÅ¿tempered, and Å¿o much abound with heat, as rather to deÅ¿ire cold water, rather then meat, which if it be given him, then will he quake and quiver anew, and be in Å¿uch pangs for the time, as that you would thinke he would aÅ¿Å¿uredly dye. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth alÅ¿o to a HorÅ¿e by being watered when he is very fat, and ridden till he do Å¿weat, cauÅ¿ing him
to take Å¿udden cold therewith: alÅ¿o after a great heat taken, to be Å¿et up without exerciÅ¿e upon the cold Planks, without litter, or to be waÅ¿hed, or walked after great labour, the HorÅ¿e being very hot and ketty, (for this infirmity falleth moÅ¿t commonly upon fat HorÅ¿es, but very Å¿eldome upon leane) alÅ¿o to water your HorÅ¿e in Å¿hallow places, or waters where the water aÅ¿cends not higher then his paÅ¿ternes, by which meanes through the Å¿udden coldneÅ¿Å¿e of the water at his feet, cauÅ¿eth the molten greaÅ¿e deÅ¿cending unto the feet, to cake and congeale, which is the prime ground of this malady. And this not onely my Å¿elfe, but all the moÅ¿t perite Ferriers doe with an unanimous aÅ¿Å¿ent acknowledge. And therefore I doe admoniÅ¿h you and every man, who is the HorÅ¿es friend,
FirÅ¿t, to be very carefull not to exerciÅ¿e his HorÅ¿e too Å¿oon after his taking up from graÅ¿Å¿e.
Secondly, whilÅ¿t he is very fat; that he doe not over-travaile, over-labour, or over-toyle him.
Thirdly, that having travelled hard, and to prevent his foundring, let him be more gently ridden an houre before he commeth to his lodging, to the end he may be choole, and the more free from danger.

Fourthly, if one houre before you get to your lodging, you ride him into Å¿ome River, or other watring place up to the belly, (but not deeper) then water him by degrees, Å¿till betwixt every draught, Å¿tirring and removing him a little, it would not be amiÅ¿Å¿e; but then Å¿o Å¿oon as you be come forth of the water, it were very good you did continue him in the Å¿ame pace, going neither faÅ¿ter or Å¿lower, (like as I have before inculcated) it will be the better alÅ¿o, and your HorÅ¿e out of danger of foundring.
Fifthly, forbeare evermore (eÅ¿pecially if your HorÅ¿e be heated) to water him in any Å¿hallow place.

Sixthly, beÅ¿ides his being warme Å¿et up with litter enough, let him have Å¿tore of rubbing, as well of his legges as body, for it is a moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome thing, it diÅ¿Å¿olveth molten greaÅ¿e very much, and it doth diÅ¿Å¿iipate and Å¿end away bad humours.

LaÅ¿tly, picking and Å¿topping of his feet in time of journeying, and after is very good and profitable. And thus have I Å¿hewed by what meanes this malady commeth to the HorÅ¿e, howÅ¿oever many other wayes there are, which I have touched, by reaÅ¿on they are Å¿o vulgarly known to every man, and therefore your Å¿elfe cannot be ignorant of them.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you helpe the foundring in the body?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commeth oft times by eating too much Provender whilÅ¿t the HorÅ¿e is yet very hot, Å¿uddenly given him after great labour, whereby his meate not being well digeÅ¿ted, (from whence) doth occaÅ¿ion crudities, raw digeÅ¿tion, and the evill habit in and about the Å¿tomacke, whereby many ill humours are ingendred, which will Å¿oon be diffuÅ¿ed throughout the whole body, by which meanes the very vigor and Å¿trength of the HorÅ¿e becommeth to be much decayed, and in a manner quite loÅ¿t, enfeebling every joynt and member in Å¿uch wiÅ¿e, as to loÅ¿e almoÅ¿t the uÅ¿e of going, and being once layd not able to riÅ¿e again without helpe: nor can he either dung or Å¿tale, but with mickle paine; foundring in the body commeth alÅ¿o Å¿ometimes, when by travelling and the horÅ¿e very hot, you Å¿uffer him then to drink his fill of cold water, and after doe not give him exerciÅ¿e enough, which might warm the Å¿ame in his belly, wherfore it is moÅ¿t certain that the greaÅ¿e being molten, and the bloud inflamed, the humours being Å¿tirred and diÅ¿Å¿olved, will preÅ¿ently reÅ¿ort to its center, which if they once Å¿ettle in the body, it muÅ¿t be in and about the heart, if not, they then muÅ¿t down lower; to wit, either to the legges or feet, and there reÅ¿iding, ingender theÅ¿e and Å¿uch like maladies, whereof we have entreated, wherefore by eating and drinking out of its due Å¿eaÅ¿on, begetteth an evill habit of the Å¿tomacke, Å¿o as if often times preÅ¿ent cure be not had, the HorÅ¿e becommeth deÅ¿perate Å¿icke, which Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e will mathematically uÅ¿her in his death. Now the Å¿ignes whereby to know when a HorÅ¿e is foundred in his body, be theÅ¿e; the hayre will Å¿tare, and he will be very chill, he will Å¿hiver and Å¿hake after cold water, and whilÅ¿t he is in drinking, the water Å¿ome of it will iÅ¿Å¿ue out of his noÅ¿e, and after two or three dayes, his legs will Å¿well, eÅ¿pecially his hinder legges, and after a while they will begin to pill, he will begin to have a dry cough at firÅ¿t, but after it will be more moyÅ¿t, and then his eyes will water, and his noÅ¿e runne with white flegmaticke Å¿tuffe, and he will forÅ¿ake his meat, and his head will Å¿o much paine him, as that he will not be able to hold it out of the manger, and Å¿eeme as if he were alwayes Å¿leeping, &c.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: FRom whence proceedeth this word foundring?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
From the French word Fundu, which is melting, which word we many times uÅ¿e in our language, and therefore when through extream toyle and labour of riding or other exerciÅ¿e, the greaÅ¿e is diÅ¿Å¿olved, and fals to running, we Å¿ay then that the horÅ¿es
greaÅ¿e is molten, and that he is foundred, for whereas the French calleth foundring in the body, Morfundu, it is none other thing with us, then plaine foundring, or a Å¿urfet given in the body of a HorÅ¿e. As for the Cure, the beÅ¿t way is and moÅ¿t agreeable to Art to purge him, but not in that violent manner, as we uÅ¿e in caÅ¿e of other diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, but firÅ¿t to rake him, then to adminiÅ¿ter to him this CliÅ¿ter.

Take of Mallowes three handfuls, and boyle them in faire water tvvo quarts, to one quart, then Å¿traine it, and put to it of freÅ¿h or Å¿vveet butter, Å¿ixe ounces, and of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it to him CliÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e bloud warm, that done, vvalk him up and dovvn in the vvarm Å¿unne, or in Å¿ome vvarm houÅ¿e, untill he doe begin to empty himÅ¿elfe, then keep him faÅ¿ting three or four hours, keeping him vvarm, and to a Å¿tomacke for three or foure dayes, but let him have but that one CliÅ¿ter onely, and let all his Hay be Å¿princkled with water, and let his drink be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water, which when he hath drunk, give him the Malt or Bran to eate, and let his Provender be very little for fourteen dayes after, eÅ¿pecially if his diÅ¿eaÅ¿e came through glut of Provender: NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e the day after his CliÅ¿ter, give him this cordiall drinke.

Take of Muskadine one quart, of Sugar two ounces, of life honey foure ounces, of Cinamon halfe an ounce, Licoris and AnniÅ¿eeds, of each one Å¿poonfull; all theÅ¿e made into fine powder, put them into the Muskadine, and warme them on the fire till they be diÅ¿Å¿olved, and then give it him bloud warme, then walke him in the Sunne, or warm houÅ¿e an houre, then Å¿et him upon the trench warm cloathed and littered, and Å¿o let him Å¿tand three houres faÅ¿ting, unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ometimes you put a little Armen into his mouth, then give him Hay Å¿princkled with water, and after an houre a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, and then a few Oates well Å¿ifted and duÅ¿ted, and this by a little at once, remembring to take bloud from the necke veyne, the Å¿ame morning you give him this drinke, and that a little before he taketh it, and pricke him alÅ¿o in the mouth, and the next day after this drink, perfume his head with Storax, Benjamin, and FrankincenÅ¿e, and Å¿o order him according as you in your diÅ¿cretion Å¿hall think to be moÅ¿t meet, onely remember to ayre him every day abroad, if there be no winde, (for winde is hurtfull to him) and thus doing you may recover him, and make him a Å¿ound HorÅ¿e againe. â This is Å¿ingular good. Another:

FirÅ¿t give him this CliÅ¿ter, take the flowers of Melelote, AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris, LinÅ¿eeds, Silleris-Montani, of each halfe an ounce, Polipodium of the Oake, two ounces and a halfe, Agnus-CaÅ¿tus one handfull, the hearb Mercury, Mallowes, Pellitory of the Well, Branca-urÅ¿ina, of each three handfuls, make a decoction of al theÅ¿e, lettiog it boyle to a quart, then put to it of red waxe one ounce and a halfe, of CaÅ¿Å¿ia newly drawn, three ounces, of Diafennicon, two ounces of Benedicta, one ounce of oyle of nuts, as much as will Å¿uffice,
and of all theÅ¿e make your CliÅ¿ter according to Art, which you Å¿hall give to your horÅ¿e Å¿o Å¿oon as you doe Å¿uppoÅ¿e or Å¿uÅ¿pect him to droope, and after this CliÅ¿ter hath done working, give him the drink preÅ¿cribed in lib. 2. chap. 9. Â§ 10. F. which is very proper and good, provided that you doe adminiÅ¿ter it Å¿o Å¿oon as you doe perceive your horÅ¿e to be foundred in the body, and withall adding to the drinke the juyce of three great Onions, well beaten and Å¿trained into the white Wine, and that he be dreÅ¿Å¿ed, ayered, ridden, and ordered as is fitting and uÅ¿uall for horÅ¿es in phyÅ¿icke. â Of this I have made tryall, and doe finde it to be good. Another:

Take a head of Garlicke, of Pepper, of Ginger, and of Graines, of each two penny worth, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and put them into Å¿trong Ale one quart, and Å¿o give it him to drink bloud-warm: give him this drink two or three mornings, and order him as is before preÅ¿cribed. And when you doe finde that he hath gotten Å¿trength, let him bloud in the necke and Å¿purre-veynes. â This is very good. All cordiall drinkes are good for this infirmity.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is your beÅ¿t cure for a falÅ¿e Quarter?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A falÅ¿e Quarter is a very evill Å¿orance, it is a rift, cracke, or chinke, which is moÅ¿t commonly upon the inÅ¿ide of the hoofe, yet Å¿ometimes (though rarely) it happeneth upon the out Å¿ide, it is occaÅ¿ioned Å¿ometimes by evill Å¿hooing, by evill paring, and Å¿ometimes by gravelling, or a prick with a nayle or Å¿tub: nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e which way Å¿oever it commeth, it will cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to halt, and watriÅ¿h bloud will many times iÅ¿Å¿ue out of the rift or chinke; the Å¿ignes are needleÅ¿Å¿e to recite, they be Å¿o manifeÅ¿t: the onely way to cure this malady and Å¿orance is, firÅ¿t to take off the Å¿hooe, and to cut away Å¿o much of the Å¿hooe on that Å¿ide where the griefe is, as that the Å¿hooe being immediately Å¿et on again, the chinke may be wholy uncovered,FalÅ¿e quarter. then open the chink to the quick with your drawing yron, and then fill up the rift with a rowle of hurds dipped in this unguent.

Take Turpentine, Waxe, and Sheepes-Å¿uet, of each like much, melt them together, and your rowle of hurds being dipped therein, Å¿top the rift therewith, renewing it once a day till it be whole, and thus the rift or chinke being with this oyntment cloÅ¿ed in the top, draw the place betwixt the hoofe and the hayre with a hot yron overthwart that place, which will cauÅ¿e the hoofe to grow, and Å¿hoot all vvhole dovvnvvards, and vvhen your HorÅ¿e goeth upright and Å¿ound again, let him not be ridden vvith any other Å¿hooe untill the hoofe be throughout hardened, neither let him be ridden upon any hard ground, till his hoofe is become very Å¿ound and perfect. â Another.
For a falÅ¿e Quarter, and to cauÅ¿e the hoofe to grow:

FirÅ¿t prepare a flat piece of wood, making it an inch broad at the leaÅ¿t, and Å¿o Å¿lender, as that it will bend like to a hoop, which muÅ¿t be alÅ¿o Å¿o long, as that it may come well nigh twice about the cronet of the hoofe: then when you are to bring it about the hoofe, have in a readineÅ¿Å¿e a piece of filliting, which muÅ¿t be long enough, which you muÅ¿t cut into two pieces, then having brought the hoope about the cronet, with one piece of the filliting, binde faÅ¿t the top of the hoope, which faÅ¿tning muÅ¿t be behinde againÅ¿t the heele, and bound very Å¿traight and hard, and then the filliting Å¿o bound, muÅ¿t be twiÅ¿ted three or foure times, and Å¿o brought about upon the hoope, and the ends made faÅ¿t before upon the hoop: then take the other piece of filliting, and few it upon the top of the firÅ¿t filliting, which you bound about the hoofe, and then let it be Å¿ewed as well upon the one Å¿ide of the hoofe as the other, Å¿o faÅ¿t Å¿ewed on, as that it cannot get off. Now you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that before you doe binde the foot of the HorÅ¿e with the wooden hoop, and filliting, you muÅ¿t prepare the Å¿orance of the Å¿aid falÅ¿e quarter, by drawing the place with yowr drawing yron, Å¿o cloÅ¿e & neer, till you come almoÅ¿t to the very quick, and then will iÅ¿Å¿ue out a kinde of Å¿weaty or deawy moyÅ¿ture, which you Å¿hall perceive, then is it time to binde on the hoop and filliting, according as I have before preÅ¿cribed you: but yet before you doe any thing at all unto the foot, or falÅ¿e quarter, have your Å¿alve in a readineÅ¿Å¿e which is to be applyed unto the chinkes of the falÅ¿e quarter, viz.

Take of the roots of Lingua-Bovis, green, and newly gathered, of the roots of ConÅ¿olida-Major, and the root of Mallowes, all newly gathered, of each halfe a pound, theÅ¿e muÅ¿t be waÅ¿hed and Å¿craped very cleane, and cut into Å¿mall pieces; let theÅ¿e roots be boyled in Aligant two quarts, untill the â¢ ine be boyled quite away, and that the roots become very Å¿oft, then pound them very well, and Å¿traine them through a fine Å¿earÅ¿er, and that it may Å¿traine the better, reÅ¿erve a little of the Wine as it boyleth, wherewith to moyÅ¿ten it in the Å¿trayning.

Take then of Venice Turpentine, of new Waxe, and of Burgundy Pitch, of each halfe a pound, of blacke Pitch foure ounces, of the oldeÅ¿t oyle Olive one quart, put theÅ¿e things with the former ingredients into a cleane kettle or PoÅ¿net, but yet after this manner, viz.

FirÅ¿t the roots, then all the other things by themÅ¿elves, the one after the other, the Turpentine onely excepted, which muÅ¿t be put in when all the other ingredients be molten, you muÅ¿t let all theÅ¿e boyle, untill all the Wine be conÅ¿umed, and the ingredients be very well incorporate, and then put in the Turpentine, and then when it hath boyled one waume or two, take it from the fire, & keep it with continuall Å¿tirring, till it be cold, and Å¿o keep it in Å¿ome cleane veÅ¿Å¿ell for your uÅ¿e; you muÅ¿t alÅ¿o adde unto theÅ¿e things (which I had almoÅ¿t
forgotten) of FrankincenÅ¿e foure ounces, made into fine powder.

This Å¿alve is to Å¿often and mollifie the hoofe whereby to make it to grow; having thus prepared your Å¿alve, before you bind the hoofe, with the hoope, and Filleting as before is Å¿hewed, annoynt and rub very well, where the hoope and filletting is to bee placed, with the Å¿alve, & then bind on the hoope with the Å¿aid filletting, that don take hurds & rowle it up into a rowle, the full length of the chinke of the quarter, & having firÅ¿t annoynted the hurds very wel with the Å¿alve, lay it upon the chinke of the falÅ¿e quarter, and Å¿o bind the hoofe up with the two long peeces of the aforeÅ¿aid Filletting, which were Å¿ewed unto the other peece of the Filletting, which bound and made faÅ¿t the hoope: and let him not be dreÅ¿Å¿ed but once every three daies, untying all, aÅ¿well the hoope as filletting; Continue him to this kind of dreÅ¿Å¿ing, fiveteene or twenty dayes, or otherwiÅ¿e according as your diÅ¿cretion Å¿hall thinke to be requiÅ¿ite.

Now when you Å¿hall find that the Å¿alve hath brought up the hoofe, and that now you know not how to harden it, and make it Å¿olide and Å¿ound, to make an able cure thereof, apply this enÅ¿uing Å¿alve.

Take of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine-Vineger one quart, Diers-gals, of greene-Coperas both bruiÅ¿ed, of each foure ounce, boyle theÅ¿e in the Vineger to the conÅ¿umption of a moyity, then Å¿traine it, and put unto it of old Sallet-oyle one pinte, and Å¿o boyle it againe, untill the Vineger be all conÅ¿umed, which you Å¿hall know by Å¿tirring it with a little Å¿tick, and drawing the Å¿ticke forth let it drop into the fire, and if that which droppeth from the Å¿tick into the fire, do not crackle, theÌ let it boyle yet longer, for then it is not enough, but when it is Å¿ufficiently boyled, by dropping in a little of the medicine, it will burne without crackling, then take lyturgy of Gold, and lyturgy of Silver, of each halfe a pound, make th â¢ m into very fine powder and Å¿earÅ¿e them. Take then the Skillet from the fire, and let the medicine Å¿tand till it be almoÅ¿t cold, then mixe well the lyturgys and put them in, for if they Å¿hould bee put in whileÅ¿t the liquour is hot, they would fly forth of the Skillet againe: t â¢ en Å¿et the Skillet upon the coales againe, and Å¿o let it boyle upon a gentle fire, otherwiÅ¿e you Å¿hall not now bee able to keepe in the medicine, and Å¿o boyle it up, keeping it continually Å¿tirring untill it become to be of a deepe or darke gray, and do cleave unto the thing with which it is Å¿tirred, and that it doth rope like unto glew, then adde unto it of new Bee-waxe three ounces, which muÅ¿t bee firÅ¿t molten by it Å¿elfe, and then put alÅ¿o into the medicine of foote made into very fine powder, and which is made of wood, and alÅ¿o of white leade in powder, of each three ounces, theÅ¿e I Å¿ay being made into very fine powder, muÅ¿t bee put into the medicine, after it is taken from the fire, and by continuall Å¿tirring made halfe cold, and Å¿o Å¿et upon the fire againe, and kept by continuall Å¿tirring untill it bee throughly incorporate, and thus it is

And when you are to uÅ¿e the Å¿alve, take away the hoope Fillitting and all, and all annoynt the hoofe with the Å¿alve, and Å¿o bind upon the hoofe a linnen cloath to cauÅ¿e that the medicine may remayne on, and let him bee annoynted therewith, every day once till the hoofe bee Å¿o hard as that he may be able to travell. â. sp.speaker: â¢â¢ ppoph.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called the Flankes is different from the former, neyther have we no proper name for it, unleÅ¿Å¿e wee will name the Å¿ame the PluriÅ¿ie, for the Epithete wee have from the French, who Å¿tile the Å¿ame Mal-de-Flankes, it is when your horÅ¿e is troubled with over much abundance of bloud, whereby he eyther ingendreth a Mainge, or elÅ¿e falleth dangerouÅ¿ly Å¿ick thereby, who by reaÅ¿on he hath beene oft-times let bloud before, his body now will looke for it, whereof he miÅ¿Å¿ing, falleth eyther into very dangerous, or no leÅ¿Å¿e loathÅ¿ome Maladies, the cure is.

and three dayes after in both the Å¿purre veynes, in the Mouth, and in the Temple-veines; then give him a drinke of Diapente and Å¿weete Sack, and he will do well. â. This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good Charge have you wherewith to Å¿top the Feet?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I think I have Å¿ufficiently Å¿hewed you already, notwithÅ¿tanding for the reÅ¿idue, I do remit you to its proper place, when and where I will give you Å¿tore of good Receipts, and therfore I leave it for the preÅ¿ent.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to Å¿tay a Flux.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This commeth of cold taken, Å¿ometimes by reaÅ¿on nature is offended with Å¿ome cholerick humour proceeding from the Liver or Gall, into the Guts: it commeth eftÅ¿oones, when a horÅ¿e drinketh too much, preÅ¿ently after the eating a great
quantity of Provender, for by that meanes the water comming to the Provender, cauÅ¿eth the Provender to Å¿well, whereby crudities are bred in the Å¿tomack, and Å¿o conveyed down into the Guts, which occaÅ¿ioneth his Flux, alÅ¿o it commeth by travelling too Å¿oone after provender, it not being well digeÅ¿ted before: and it will come alÅ¿o to a HorÅ¿e by drinking cold water when he is very hot, and after (the water not being preÅ¿ently warmed in his belly) is the cauÅ¿e of a Lax or Flux. It will alÅ¿o come by eating of a Feather, Hen-dung, Spider, Å¿ome venemous worme, or other troubleÅ¿ome creature; and therefore my counÅ¿ell is, not to Å¿top a Flux too haÅ¿tily, unleÅ¿Å¿e you do finde that your horÅ¿e do purge too too violently, and then be you well aÅ¿Å¿ured, that nature is not a little offended, for it will bring him in Å¿hort time to great weakneÅ¿Å¿e, and debility of body, give him therefore firÅ¿t the ClyÅ¿ter Laxative, Flux. which you have taught you in lib. 2. chap. 6 Â§. 8. ClyÅ¿ter 21. letter C. and that will carry away from him all that may any way offend him, and a day after give him t â¢â¢â¢ drink.

Beane flower, and Bole-Armoniack powdred of each three ounces, mix them with red Wine or Tinte one quart, give it him bloud warme, and after keep him warme in the Å¿table, and let him have Hay and Oates, by a little at a time, and that often, and eyther Å¿weete MaÅ¿hes or white water, â. This is very good. Another.

p.hi: VVHat good Receipt have you to Mundifie, cleanÅ¿e, and heale foule and old Sores?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
I had thought Sir, you would not have fallen upon this till it had come to its proper place, when and where we Å¿hould have the particular matters of Sores by themÅ¿elves, together with their cures: but Å¿ithence you are pleaÅ¿ed to touch them in this place, I will

Take of green Coperas, and of Salt-Peter, of each halfe a pound,Foule an old Å¿ores â¢ mundifie. bay Salt, and Salt-Gemma, of each three ounces, ArÅ¿nick one ounce, put all theÅ¿e finely powdred into a Å¿tillitory glaÅ¿Å¿e, the pot or bottome thereof well nealed, and put alÅ¿o thereunto of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger one pinte, Å¿et the pot on the fire, and put on the head, cloÅ¿ing it with Cute of Hermes, and being thus placed in the furnace, make under it a Å¿trong fire, by the Å¿pace of five or Å¿ixe hours, and with your Receptory take the firÅ¿t water that commeth, for that is the very Å¿trongeÅ¿t and beÅ¿t, and after an houre the fire will be out of the warer, then Å¿top up the glaÅ¿Å¿e very cloÅ¿e, and Å¿o keep the water for your uÅ¿e. The next water is alÅ¿o good, but not Å¿o Å¿trong as the firÅ¿t, but reÅ¿erve it alÅ¿o by it Å¿elfe, as you do the firÅ¿t. And when you are to waÅ¿h any Å¿ores therewith, be very carefull that you lay none of this water upon either Å¿inewes or veynes, for that it will burn them in Å¿under, but where Vlcers and fouler old Å¿ores be in the fleÅ¿hy parts, this water will work wonders if wounds be waÅ¿hed with it, and you carefull in the application thereof. â Of this I have had great experience. Another I have taught me by an expert MariÅ¿hall of France, but by reaÅ¿on of the extreame violence thereof I never durÅ¿t uÅ¿e it, which is called the Å¿pirit of Tinne, which will alÅ¿o mundifie all Å¿orts of old Å¿ores, and the French MariÅ¿hals do uÅ¿e it much. And this is the Receit, viz.

Take Mercury one ounce,Spirit of Tinne. and put into an old cleane pewter pottinger, and fill up the pottinger with Plantane water, and with your finger Å¿tirre the Mercury about the pottinger till it be quite diÅ¿Å¿olved, and then the water will become white, then let it Å¿tand an hour in the pottinger, then poure forth the water into a cleane glaÅ¿Å¿e-viall, and then you Å¿hall Å¿ee in the bottome of your pottenger, the Tinne runne liquid like unto Quick-Å¿ilver, or life as if it were melted, for that is your Å¿pirit of Tinne, and thus is it made.

p.hi: WHat is to be adminiÅ¿tred to a HorÅ¿e that forÅ¿aketh his meate?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
There be many cauÅ¿es that may make a HorÅ¿e to forÅ¿ake his meate, and yet not be Å¿icke at all, and Å¿o alÅ¿o by occaÅ¿ion of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e that either comming upon him, or elÅ¿e which hath already Å¿eized him. And firÅ¿t a HorÅ¿e may forÅ¿ake his meate, and forbeare to eate for Å¿ome time, no whit Å¿icke, as when he Å¿hall eyther linger after Mares, or after graÅ¿Å¿e being weary of dry meate: againe, he may forbeare his meate, and yet not be Å¿icke by meanes of Å¿ome accident or inconvenience bred in him, or befalne unto him, as by having the Lampes, Barbs, Giggs, BliÅ¿ters, bloudy-rifts, tongue hurt, paine in the teeth, or Å¿ome Å¿uch like infirmity in or about his mouth,, theÅ¿e
may be cauÅ¿es that may induce him to forbeare to eate, and yet the creature not Å¿icke, but otherwiÅ¿e healthy and hungry, and faine would feed, but eyther cannot or dare not. AlÅ¿o a HorÅ¿e may forÅ¿ake his meate, being through the inconÅ¿iderateneÅ¿Å¿e of his keeper cloyed, whereby he doth loath his meat, Å¿ometimes through over-ayerings morning and evening, Å¿ometimes againe by Å¿uffering him to eate being very hot after great Å¿wearing, upon immoderate riding and toyle, or after water or waÅ¿hing being alÅ¿o very hot. TheÅ¿e and many more may be the cauÅ¿es why a HorÅ¿e may forÅ¿ake his meat, and yet not be Å¿icke. And he may alÅ¿o forÅ¿ake his meat by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e enÅ¿uing, as upon Colds, Rhumes, and Catarres newly taken, and beginning to be felt upon him: Å¿o alÅ¿o he may forÅ¿ake his meat, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e which hath already Å¿eized him, as in caÅ¿es of Glanders, Feavers, Morfounding, ConÅ¿umption, DropÅ¿ie, and the like, whereby it is made moÅ¿t apparant that he feedeth not becauÅ¿e he is already Å¿icke. As touching the firÅ¿t poynt, if you doe perceive him to forÅ¿ake his meate, and that you cannot eaÅ¿ily finde the reaÅ¿on thereof, then the firÅ¿t thing you doe, Å¿earch his mouth, lips, and tongue, and if you finde any thing there amiÅ¿Å¿e, let it be preÅ¿ently amended, but if you cannot finde any thing there amiÅ¿Å¿e, then examine his keeper, and if you may perceive that it came through his default or negligence, either by the cloying him with Provender, or otherwiÅ¿e according as I have heretofore touched, then give him a few branches of Savin, and let him be ayered abroad, keeping him upon the Trench faÅ¿ting to procure him a Å¿tomack, and then feed him by degrees, and that by a little at once, Å¿o he will fall to his meat againe with good appetite, feed heartily, and doe well againe. â But if you doe finde that his forÅ¿aking of meat commeth by meanes of any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e which hath already Å¿eized him, then give him this drink, viz.

ForÅ¿aking meat.Take of white Wine one quart, Polipodium of Oake, a red Cole-wort-leafe, Hore-hound, Mints, Å¿he-Holly, Iuniper-berries, Ginger, ParÅ¿ley-Å¿eeds, Fennell-Å¿eeds, of each three ounces, beate into fine powder what is to be powdred, and chop and Å¿tamp the hearbs Å¿mall, and Å¿o put all into the Wine, and boyle them a pretty while, then Å¿train it, and give it your horÅ¿e bloud warme, then leap his back, and trot him Å¿oftly upon faire ground an houre, but not to Å¿weat by any means, then Å¿o Å¿oon as he commeth into the Å¿table, cloath, and litter him warm, and waÅ¿h his mouth with water and Å¿alt, and Å¿et him upon the Trench, and put over his noÅ¿trils a fine linnen ragge Å¿teeped in Å¿owre leven, infuÅ¿ed firÅ¿t in the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, and the juyce of Sorrell, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o three houres at the leaÅ¿t, then unbit him, and bring him meat, but by little at once, for feare of cloying his weake Å¿tomacke, neither let him have any MaÅ¿hes, or cold water, but white water onely, untill Å¿uch time as he hath found his Å¿tomack againe. â This I have often made tryall
of, and have found it to be right good. Another:

Take Rue and Pepper, of each like much, Å¿tamp them together to a thick Å¿alve, then take a good lump thereof, and put it up a good way into his mouth, and let him champ and chew it a good while, and Å¿o Å¿oon as you doe Å¿uffer him to open his mouth, he will put it out, and fall to feeding heartily. â This is not inferiour to the former. Another:

Take the leaves of Briony, and give him them to eate, and it will bring him to a good Å¿tomack Å¿uddenly. This was taught me by a very good Ferrier, who avowed it to me to be Å¿peciall good, but I never made triall thereof.

p.hi: HOw doe you cure a running FruÅ¿h?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a naughty Å¿orance, which I have heard rurall Smiths to call the Frog, by reaÅ¿on that it breedeth in that Å¿pungy part of the heele, which they call the Frog. This Å¿orance comes Å¿ometimes when the Smith inconÅ¿iderately as he pareth that part, doth goe to the quicke, whereby it bleedeth, which after becommeth Å¿ore, and commeth to the running FruÅ¿h, for that the horÅ¿e being travelled, whilÅ¿t it is raw, and Å¿o the gravell getting into it, doth cauÅ¿e the place to rankle and impoÅ¿tumate, and it will come in Å¿hort time to be a running Å¿ore, which will Å¿o Å¿tinke, as not well to be endured: Å¿ometimes again it commeth by reaÅ¿on of evill humours which do fall down into the legges, and makes its way out at the FruÅ¿h, it being the Å¿ofteÅ¿t and tendreÅ¿t part of all the foot. And Å¿ometimes it commeth by a bruiÅ¿e which the horÅ¿e may eaÅ¿ily take by treading upon Å¿ome Å¿tone, which inwardly corrupting, putrifieth, and Å¿o is engendred a running FruÅ¿h. The Å¿ignes to know it is, the horÅ¿e will goe lame, either upon hard or durty wayes, whereby the gravell doth get in, and fret and paine him at the quick, and you Å¿hall perceive that when he reÅ¿teth, the FruÅ¿h will weep, Å¿ending forth watery Å¿tuffe from the FruÅ¿h. The way to cure it is,

Take Å¿tale Chamberlye,FruÅ¿h ru â¢
ning. and boyle it with a good quantity of Allum, and keep it in a glaÅ¿Å¿e cloÅ¿e Å¿topped by it Å¿elfe for your uÅ¿e. Then take of red Nettles two handfuls, the Å¿trongeÅ¿t and keeneÅ¿t, dry them that they may be made into fine powder, then look what quantity of this powder you have, adde alÅ¿o unto it the like quantity of Pepper, made alÅ¿o into very fine powder, and mixe them very well together, and keep it either in Å¿ome dry bladder, or boxe for your uÅ¿e alÅ¿o: and when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e this water, and powder for this Å¿orance, firÅ¿t take off the Å¿hooe, and open the FruÅ¿h, Å¿o that you may come unto the very bottome, then waÅ¿h the Å¿orance very cleane and well with this water made warme, then put on the Å¿hooe again, but firÅ¿t let it be hollowed, that it hurt not the FruÅ¿h, and
let the heeles of the Å¿hooe be wide enough, then the Å¿orance being thus cleane waÅ¿hed and purged from all gravell and mattrative Å¿tuffe, and the Å¿hooe Å¿et on as aforeÅ¿aid, fill the wound full with this powder, and Å¿top it with Hurds, and Å¿plent it that the Hurds may keep in the powder, and that nothing get to the Å¿ore, and thus waÅ¿h and renew the powder to the place grieved every day once, and in a weeke or little more it will be perfectly Å¿ound and whole againe, provided you Å¿uffer not any dung to come to the griefe, and that he tread not in any wet during the time of the Cure, neither Å¿hould he goe forth of the Stable. â And thus have I cured many horÅ¿es of this malady. Another,

Take of Soot and bay-Salt, of each one handfull, and pound them very well together, (having opened and waÅ¿hed the Å¿orance as before is Å¿hewed) and put unto your Soot and Salt, the whites of three new laid Egges, and Å¿o temper and beat all well together, till you bring it to one entire body, then dip Å¿ome hurds therein, and Å¿o Å¿top not onely the place it Å¿elfe, being opened and made raw, but all the Å¿ole beÅ¿ides, and Å¿o Å¿top up the FruÅ¿h, Å¿plenting it in Å¿uch Å¿ort, whereby the medicine may be kept in, and thus let him be dreÅ¿Å¿ed once a day, and ordered as before is premoniÅ¿hed, and he Å¿oone will be whole and Å¿ound. â This I have often proved, and cured many Å¿orances of this nature.

p.hi: VVHat is beÅ¿t to cure a Fret?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e you call the Fret, is onely gripings and pain in the belly, which commeth of Å¿undry cauÅ¿es. The French doe call it TranchaiÅ¿ons, which doe Å¿ignifie gripings, it is the plaine Collicke, cauÅ¿ed of winde, Å¿ometimes of bilious and Å¿harp humours, which deÅ¿cending from the Å¿tomacke, goe down into the guts, and there torment him, and Å¿ometimes it commeth by reaÅ¿on of Wormes, Bots, or Truncheons, which doe engender in the Å¿tomacke or guts of the HorÅ¿e, which do feed and gnaw upon the paunch and guts, putting him to mickle pain and perplexity. The Å¿ignes are, he will forÅ¿ake his meat, lye down oft, and tumble, and when he Å¿tandeth, he will eft Å¿oones Å¿trike at his belly with his hinder legs, he will alÅ¿o Å¿tampe with his fore-feet, and turn his head towards his belly, and looke upon it, and he will many times Å¿weat at the flankes, and Å¿eldome any where elÅ¿e, and if the malady be of winde, then Å¿hall you perceive his belly to Å¿well, eÅ¿pecially towards the flanks: the cure is,

Fret.Take of good Ale two quarts, of Fenugrick foure ounces, of Bay-berries Å¿even ounces, of long Pepper foure ounces, of Ginger one
one ounce, Water-CreÅ¿Å¿es two handfuls, Sage and Nettles, of each one handfull, beat to powder the Spices, and chop the hearbs Å¿mall, and boyle them in the Ale till one moyity be conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine it, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme, and then cover and litter him warme, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench Å¿ixe houres after. But yet Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath his drinke, rope up all his legges to the body, not Å¿uffering him to lye down, and cover him Å¿o as that he may Å¿weat for one houre onely, and then coole him by degrees, and let his drink be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water, and he being thus ordered two or three dayes he will be well. â This I have often uÅ¿ed. Another:

Take the entrals of a great Chicken, caÅ¿ting away the gizzard, rowle them up in bay-Salt and the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, and Å¿o give it him down his throat, then preÅ¿ently let him be gently ridden, or walked, till he doth dung, and at night give him a MaÅ¿h, or white water, and he is cured. This is alÅ¿o very good. But if you have cauÅ¿e to Å¿uÅ¿pect that he hath the Bots, then rake him, and in his raking Å¿earch for Bots, which if you doe finde any Å¿ticking upon the great gut, pluck them all (or Å¿o many as you can finde) away, whereby you may be confident that the Bots is cauÅ¿e of his griefe, wherefore apply Å¿uch remedies and medicines which I have formerly preÅ¿cribed you for Bots, Truncheons, and Wormes, in lib. 2. cap. 5. Â§ 15. where you Å¿hall finde Å¿uch receits as will cure him. â But if you doe perceive this griefe of his commeth of winde, then make uÅ¿e of Å¿uch receits which you Å¿hall finde by me before inculcated for the Collicke, in lib. 2. cap. 6. p.hi: WHat is beÅ¿t to be done to cure a galled backe?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: There be Å¿o many wayes which doth occaÅ¿ion it, as that it would be an endleÅ¿Å¿e labour to deliver every particular thereof. But becauÅ¿e you doe motion the galled backe onely, I will firÅ¿t Å¿peake Å¿omething thereof. A galled backe commeth commonly either with the Saddle, the Pannell, Pack-Saddle or Male-pillion, which through evill Å¿topping, or defect of Å¿topping, may very eaÅ¿ily gall the HorÅ¿e, Å¿o alÅ¿o may the fault be in the tree, which may be Å¿o badly made, Å¿o as that let the Saddler be never Å¿o Å¿ufficient, skilfull, or carefull, yet Å¿hall it both gall and hurt him; Å¿o alÅ¿o may the tree of the Saddle be either broken or crackt, if it at any time happen, be you then confident, that it can never be Å¿o amended or repaired, but that doe what you can it Å¿hall hurt the back of the HorÅ¿e, and theÅ¿e be the moÅ¿t frequent and ordinary wayes, whereby to gall the back of your horÅ¿e, howbeit I paÅ¿Å¿e over Male-pillions, Cloake-bags, Port-mantues, TruÅ¿Å¿es, and the like. The Å¿ignes to know a galled back are eaÅ¿ie, for either the backe will be apparantly Å¿welled, or the hayre fretted off, the skinne either broken or raw, or the backe either inflamed or impoÅ¿tumated, every of which is eaÅ¿ily to be determined by the eye, or if his backe be wrung with the Saddle, and yet not come to be viÅ¿ible to the eye, yet may you come to the knowledge therof, if taking off the Saddle, Å¿troking your hand all along the back, you Å¿hall perceive him either to Å¿hake his head, or to winch with his tayle, to rouze, or Å¿hake, to Å¿tamp or Å¿trike with his feet, to offer to bite, or the like, whereby you may come to know it, and very eaÅ¿ily to finde out the place grieved. Now if the back be Å¿welled, and before it be impoÅ¿tumated, Å¿o Å¿oon as you Å¿hall take off the Saddle, and finde the Å¿ame, clap upon the Å¿welling a little of his wet litter, and Å¿o Å¿et on the Saddle againe, and let him remain with his Saddle on all night, and in the morning the Å¿welling will be abated, and the place it Å¿elfe become whole and Å¿ound again. Now if the hayre be but galled off, Å¿o that it doth not impoÅ¿tumate, annoynt the place but with a little Butter and Salt melted together, and in twice dreÅ¿Å¿ing the place will be whole; but if the backe be Å¿o galled, as that it is become raw, then the cure is thus, viz.

Take three parts of Å¿heepes-dunge newly made,Gaelled ãâã
and one part of Rie, or Wheate flower, and dry the flower, and then mixe it well with the Å¿heepes-dung, kneading it as into paÅ¿te, and making it into the faÅ¿hion of a Cake, and after bake it a little, and apply the powder thereof warme unto the place, â. This will heale him very well. But I may very well Å¿pare the labour, in reciting any more receipts for this matter, conÅ¿idering, I have Å¿ufficiently already handled them in lib. 2. chap. 5. Â§. 1. letter, B.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Å¿ay you to a Galde that commeth by the Shackell?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: T â¢ a â¢ kind of Gallings being Å¿o frequent, as to be knowne to every one both in the manner how it commeth, and in the Å¿ignes how to know them, needeth not much diÅ¿Å¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will give you an experiment or two of mine owne, and Å¿o leave it to its more proper place.

Take new milke three quarts, Plantane one handfull,Galled wi â¢ the Shack â¢
boyle theÅ¿e together till one part of the milke be conÅ¿umed, then take of Allum Å¿ix ounces, and of white Å¿ugar-Candy one ounce, beat them both to fine powder, and Å¿o put it to the milke, and adde alÅ¿o unto it of white Wine-Vineger Å¿ix Å¿poonfuls, then boyle it a little till there do come upon the top a tough curd, then Å¿trayne it, and keep the whay,A whay. caÅ¿ting away the curd, and with this whay firÅ¿t made warme bathe, and waÅ¿h the Å¿ore, the hayre being firÅ¿t clipped cloÅ¿e away, and having thus waÅ¿hed the Å¿orance, and wiped it dry then apply your greene oyntment mentioned in the fourth Â§. of this Chapter, but in caÅ¿e where the Galde is not yet broken, yet likely to breake, there you Å¿hall only apply the medicine taught you in lib 2. chap. 16. Â§. 10. L. for the Poll-evill, â. This whay is alÅ¿o good to cure the bloudy Riftes, Bladders, Canker in the mouth, Barbs, Pappes, and all Feavers, and Maladies in the Mouth. Another.

Take life-hony Å¿even Å¿poonfuls, and Verde-greaÅ¿e halfe an ounce, and boyle them till the hony bee halfe conÅ¿umed, and that it is become red, then put it into Å¿ome cleane pot, and annoynt the Å¿orance therewith, made warme, twice every day, and when you have thus annoynted it, caÅ¿t upon the place Hurds cut very Å¿hort to keep on the oyntment, and this will in Å¿hort time heale it up very Å¿ound. â. This is moÅ¿t Å¿overaign for any Å¿hackle-galde, which commeth eyther by lock, cord, or Å¿hackle, but if your HorÅ¿e be deÅ¿perately galled in any part of his body, as by the girt or otherwiÅ¿e, then.

Take of Verjuyce of the Crab two quarts, of greene Copperas, two penny-worth, and boyle them together to one pint and a halfe: and waÅ¿h the Å¿orance therewith very well, and after fill up the hole (if any be) with the powder of red-leade, and Å¿o let it remaine three
dayes untoucht, then waÅ¿h it as before, and fill it with your red ointment againe, and thus in two or three times dreÅ¿Å¿ing, it will heale up, bee the galling never Å¿o dangerous, â. This have I often uÅ¿ed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is beÅ¿t to bee done to a HorÅ¿e that is Gravelled?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This malady commeth when a horÅ¿e in his travell hath gotten gravell betwixt the Å¿ole and the hoofe which Å¿etleth at the quicke, and there fretteth and feÅ¿treth, you Å¿hall Å¿oone know it by his halting, and complayning upon the Å¿ame foot, which Å¿o Å¿oone as you do perceive, take up the foote and you Å¿hall feele it warm â¢ t in that place, then in any other part of the foote, and if you make tryall with your PinÅ¿ors,Gravelling. you Å¿hall perceive him to Å¿hrinke, and to yeeld when you nip him againÅ¿t that place: Take off the Å¿hooe and with your drawing iron draw the place, till you come unto the quick, picke forth all the gravell, and cruÅ¿h forth the matter and bloud cleane, then waÅ¿h the Å¿ore cleane with your Copperas water, taught you in the next enÅ¿uing Paragraph, then poure upon the Å¿ore Å¿heeps-Tallow, and Bay-Å¿alt molten together, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and let it bee poured into the wound Å¿calding hot, then Å¿top up the hole with hurds, and Å¿et on the Å¿hooe againe, and at two or three times dresÅ¿ing it will be whole, but till he be through well do not travell him, neyther let his foote come into any wet â. This is a certaine cure. Another.

Search and draw the place as before, and get forth all the gravell, then Å¿top the place with Hogs-greaÅ¿e, and Turpentine molten together, pouring it into the wound Å¿calding hot, and Å¿top it up with hurds, and tack on the Å¿hooe, and keepe his foote from wet, and hee will Å¿oone bee whole; This is alÅ¿o very good. Another.
Be you certaine that you have gotten forth all the gravell and corruption, then.

Take Virgin-waxe one ounce, RoÅ¿in, and Deeres-Å¿uet, of each two ounces, Bores-greaÅ¿e halfe an ounce, and of Sea-greene, alias HouÅ¿e-leeke, one head, incorporate all theÅ¿e together in a Morter, then melt them over a very gentle fire, and Å¿o apply it hot to the Å¿orance, and Å¿top it up with hurds and tack on the Å¿hooe, and in few dreÅ¿Å¿ings it will cure it, â. This is a Å¿peciall good cure.

p.hi: HOw doe you make your greene oyntment, you doe Å¿o much commend?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, this Vnguent which I doe Å¿o much commend unto you, is the moÅ¿t rare, and Å¿overaigne thing that I ever yet Å¿aw, or knew, for the cure of any Å¿ores, whether old or greene, Vlcers, FiÅ¿tulas, Poll euills, or what elÅ¿e, for where this oyntment commeth, no proud or dead fleÅ¿h will grow, no flies will adventure neere the place where this oyntment is laid, and for a HorÅ¿e or Mare-Filly that is cut, gelt, or Å¿pla, annnoynt but the place, and they will neyther Å¿well or feÅ¿ter, whereby the creature is the further of from danger, for this Vnguent doth not only heale Å¿oundly and well, but Å¿peedily alÅ¿o; provided you lay nothing upon the wound or Å¿orance, where the oyntment is adminiÅ¿tred, as neyther hurds, lint, plaiÅ¿ters, or the like, unleÅ¿Å¿e you may have occaÅ¿ion to Taint a wound which is extraordinary deepe, neither that for any long time, or too often, and beÅ¿ides the Å¿eldomer the wound is dreÅ¿Å¿ed, as once a day, or once in two daies, it will heale the better and faÅ¿ter, eÅ¿pecially if it be brought into good forwardneÅ¿Å¿e of healing. And together with this Vnguent, you may do well to waÅ¿h the Å¿orance, with the water I call the Copperas water, which by reaÅ¿on it is alwaies firÅ¿t to be uÅ¿ed, I will Å¿et it downe firÅ¿t, and the Greene-oyntment Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿ume the Å¿econd place.

Take faire water two quarts, and put it into a cleane PoÅ¿tnet, and put thereto of greene Copperas halfe a pound,Copperas â¢
ter. and of Å¿alt one handfull, and of ordinary Honey one Å¿poonefull, and a branch or two of RoÅ¿emary, boyle all theÅ¿e till one halfe of the water bee conÅ¿umed, and a little before you take it from the fire, put to it the quantity of a Doves egge of Alume, then take it from the fire, and when it is cold put the water into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿top it up cloÅ¿e, and keepe it for your uÅ¿e; and when you are to dreÅ¿Å¿e any Å¿ore, firÅ¿t waÅ¿h it cleane with this water, and if the wound be deepe, iniect it with a Å¿eringe. â. This water of it Å¿elfe will cure any reaÅ¿onable Å¿ore, or wound (but the greene oyntment being applyed after it is waÅ¿hed) will heale any old Vlcer, or FiÅ¿tula whatÅ¿oever, if they come to the bottome of them, and for greene wounds, they have not their fellow; the Greene-oyntment is thus made.

Take a cleane Skillet or PoÅ¿tnet,Greene-oy â¢
ment. and firÅ¿t put into it of RoÅ¿in the quantity of a wall-nut, which being molten, put to it the like quantity of wax, and when that is alÅ¿o molten, put to them of tryed-Hogs-greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, and Å¿o Å¿oone as that is molten, put into the reÅ¿t of common EngliÅ¿h Hony one Å¿poonfull, when all theÅ¿e are molten and well Å¿tirred together, then put in of ordinary Turpentine halfe a pound, and Å¿o Å¿oone as it is diÅ¿Å¿olved, take it from the fire, and put into the Skillet of VerdegreaÅ¿e made into very fine powder one ounce,
and Å¿o Å¿tirre it well al together, but be carefull it runne not over, for that the Verde-greaÅ¿e will cauÅ¿e it to ariÅ¿e, then Å¿et it againe upon the fire, till it do beginne a little to Å¿imper, then take it off, for if you Å¿uffer it to boyle it will turne red, and loÅ¿e its vertue of healing, and become a CoraÅ¿ive, then Å¿traine it through a cloth into Å¿ome earthen Pot, or Pipken, and keepe it for your uÅ¿e, laying Å¿omething upon the mouth of the veÅ¿Å¿ell, that duÅ¿t get not into it, and if it be not Å¿trained, then the grounds in the bottome will coraÅ¿ive a Å¿ore, and not heale it. â. This is the moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne Oyntment that I could ever know, for with it I have done Å¿o many great cures, as have made me admired by Ferriers themÅ¿elves, who have courted mee not a little for this Receipt, yea they have profered mee ten pounds to teach it them; This cleanÅ¿eth a wound, bee it never Å¿o foule, or infected with dead, proud, Å¿pungy or naughty fleÅ¿h, it carnifieth, and healeth abundantly, and with all Å¿o Å¿oundly, and firmely, as that it doth never more breake forth, it draweth forth thornes, Å¿plinters, nayles, and all Å¿uch things in the fleÅ¿h, and in a word it cureth al Å¿orts of Å¿ores and wounds.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is good to bee adminiÅ¿tred to a HorÅ¿e whoÅ¿e greaÅ¿e is molten?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: As touching this infirmity I have Å¿ufficiently Å¿hewed you before how it commeth, the Å¿ignes how to know it, and how to cure the Å¿ame, and therefore I may now forbeare to Å¿pend any more time in the declaration thereof, only I will give you one Å¿ingular Receipt more, and this it is.

GreaÅ¿e molten.FirÅ¿t, take bloud from the neck-veine, to a reaÅ¿onable good proportion, to the end all his inflamed bloud may be let forth, then give him to eate eyther branne prepared as you are Å¿hewed in lib. 2. chap. 9. Â§. 4. F. or dry branne whether he will eate beÅ¿t, but if he will eate neyther, and that he doth empty himÅ¿elfe over much, then give him the ClyÅ¿ter ReÅ¿tringent preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. chap. 6. Â§. 8. ClyÅ¿ter 3. letter C. or elÅ¿e if you pleaÅ¿e, you may give him the 8. ClyÅ¿ter in the Å¿ame Â§. eyther of theÅ¿e two Å¿o often as neede Å¿hall require you may give. And if his appetite be not good, give him Arman preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. chap. 2. Â§. 2. letter A. and two dayes after let him bloud in both the Flank-veines, and if you cannot eaÅ¿ily finde them, then in the Å¿purre-veines, and the next day after that give him to drinke, two quarts of water warmed, and put into it of white-Wine-Vineger one pint, for this will very much refreÅ¿h his body, and then the next day give him this drinke.

Take of TiÅ¿an three pints, of lofe Sugar finely powdred thre ounces, of Cordiall powder one ounce, of life honey foure ounces, give him this to drink bloud warme. In maladies of this nature you
muÅ¿t forbeare to adminiÅ¿ter Å¿uch drugs as be hot, for by Å¿uch meanes more horÅ¿es dye then doe recover and live: for Å¿uch kinde of drinks as this is being wholly cordiall, are beÅ¿t for this infirmity. â This cure I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure you I have often adminiÅ¿tred, and have done very much good, and made many great and deÅ¿perate cures therwith.

p.hi: VVEll now let us come to the Glanders.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
With all my heart Sir. As touching this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which we doe call the Glanders, it is of all others the worÅ¿t, noyÅ¿ome, and moÅ¿t infectious, inÅ¿omuch as that horÅ¿e that hath it, if he be not removed and Å¿eparated from his fellowes, will infect Å¿o many as Å¿hall be with him in the Å¿ame Stable and roome. To finde out the depth, root, and true nature of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, I have greatly laboured, as alÅ¿o how to cure the Å¿ame. I have alÅ¿o had much conference with many the moÅ¿t famous and exquiÅ¿ite MariÅ¿hals and Ferriers abroad, and I have Å¿een very much of their practiÅ¿e therein, Å¿o alÅ¿o have I had very Å¿erious diÅ¿courÅ¿es with a number of our beÅ¿t Ferriers and Smiths at home, but I finde not one in twenty can Å¿peake truely to any purpoÅ¿e of the nature of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and therefore I do not wonder that they cannot cure a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e whereof they are Å¿o much to Å¿eek. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e what I do underÅ¿tand of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, I will ingenuouÅ¿ly deliver unto you. The Glanders is an infirmity which proceedeth firÅ¿t of cold taken, which being neglected, will in time come to be the Glanders; you Å¿hall firÅ¿t perceive it by the inflamed kernels and knots which may be felt under the chaule of the horÅ¿e, and as they doe grow in bigneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o do the Glanders grow and increaÅ¿e within the body of the HorÅ¿e, which firÅ¿t beginning with a thin Rhume, aÅ¿cendeth up to the head, and Å¿ettleth neer to the brain, and Å¿o venteth it Å¿elfe at the noÅ¿e, which yet may be eaÅ¿ily cured, as I have before inculcated, where I entreated of Colds, afterwards it growes thicker, and then it is worÅ¿e to cure, but yet faiÅ¿able enough, in longer time it commeth yet to a thicker Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and its colour is yellowiÅ¿h, much like unto Butter, and then it is more hard to cure, but yet curable, albeit that now it is come to be a perfect Glanders: but when it commeth to be of a viÅ¿cous, and of a tough and Å¿limy Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and of a green colour, and to Å¿tink terribly, and that it hath now runne Å¿ome moneths, or peradventure halfe a yeer or better, as alÅ¿o having Å¿ome Å¿mall Å¿pecks of a reddiÅ¿h colour in it, then is not every Ferriers work or Art to cure the Å¿ame, for in a caÅ¿e of this nature, the ableÅ¿t Ferrier may receive the foyle, and the HorÅ¿e dye under his hands and cure, as I have often by experience been an eye witneÅ¿Å¿e, albeit there hath been no defect in the Ferrier, either in Art, induÅ¿try, care or diligence. I doe therefore averre that I would not have any man (be he never Å¿o expert an ArtiÅ¿t) to promiÅ¿e to himÅ¿elfe
the cure of every HorÅ¿e he Å¿hall take in hand, by the reaÅ¿on that the Glanders it Å¿elfe is the thing he muÅ¿t cure, but in taking upon him o cure that malady, he muÅ¿t before he can have perfected his cure, cure him alÅ¿o of many other diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which the Glanders will bring along with it, as (v. g.) the conÅ¿umption of the fleÅ¿h and lungs, griefes and aches in the head and braine, inflamations under the chaule, diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the liver, purÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e, hide-bound, dropÅ¿ie, Å¿welled legges, and many other infirmities too prolixe to repeat, all which (I Å¿ay) are inherent to the Glanders, and its origine that it is of cold paÅ¿t all peradventure, howÅ¿oever it Å¿ometimes commeth of Surfets, Å¿ometimes of Morfounding, Å¿ometimes by infection, all which (the laÅ¿t only excepted) taketh its firÅ¿t Å¿ource from cold, and when it runneth (as before I Å¿aid) greeniÅ¿h with reddiÅ¿h Å¿pecks, accompanied alÅ¿o with an offenÅ¿ive or Å¿tinking breath, then are his lungs ulcerated, by meanes whereof the cure is the more deÅ¿perate and difficile. I do therefore adviÅ¿e all Ferriers my brethren, who Å¿hall at any time take upon them this cure, that they doe firÅ¿t prepare the body of the HorÅ¿e with Å¿uch preparatives and PhyÅ¿icke, as are meet to expell his peccant humours, which muÅ¿t be alÅ¿o very carefully adminiÅ¿tred, yea and that according to the Å¿trength and ability of the HorÅ¿e: for the HorÅ¿e cannot chooÅ¿e but be feeble and weake, having of a long time before viÅ¿ited with a Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e of this nature, yea peradventure a whole yeere or two before together, during which time he hath continually waÅ¿ted and languiÅ¿hed, wherefore he cannot be Å¿trong, but a very weake HorÅ¿e, and therefore his phyÅ¿icke muÅ¿t be very gentle, yet Å¿uch alÅ¿o which may have operation whereby to work, otherwiÅ¿e phyÅ¿icke is but caÅ¿t away. The Å¿ignes how to know this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e need no further deÅ¿cription, and therefore I will proceed to the cure, for the which I will deliver you many receits, Å¿ome whereof I have well experienced, to which I will give my particular marke, like as I have formerly done. And I do the rather inÅ¿ert the more receits, becauÅ¿e (as I have before remembred) that receit which will not cure one, will cure another.

Glanders.The firÅ¿t therefore that is to be done in this caÅ¿e, is, to prepare his body by giving him for four or five dayes together, in Å¿tead of his Oates and Provender, wheat Bran prepared, like as I have before Å¿hewed you in the caÅ¿es of Å¿ick HorÅ¿es, eÅ¿pecially in lib. 2. cap. 9. Â§ 4. F. to qualifie and dry up his moyÅ¿t and bad humours abounding in him, then let him bloud in the neck, and the next day rake him, and give him this CliÅ¿ter. Make a decoction of Mallowes one pinte and a halfe, and put unto it of freÅ¿h Butter, foure ounces, and of Sallet oyle a quarter of a pinte, and adminiÅ¿ter it bloud warme, and then with a Å¿trappe of leather tye it to his tayle, and then faÅ¿ten the other end of the Å¿aid Å¿trap to his SurÅ¿ingle, Å¿o Å¿traight, that his tayle muÅ¿t be cloÅ¿e to his tuell, that he cannot purge till it be looÅ¿ened, then mount his back, and let him be gently ridden, Å¿ometimes a foot pace, and Å¿ometimes
an eaÅ¿ie trot for halfe an hour, then Å¿et him up warm clothed and littered, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench three hours, during which time he will purge kindely, then give him white water and Hay, and at night a few Oats, for he muÅ¿t be kept to a Å¿pare dyet. The next day annoynt two long GooÅ¿e-feathers with the powder of BrimÅ¿tone and freÅ¿h Butter, being firÅ¿t well wrought together, till it be brought to the colour of gold, put them into either noÅ¿trill, and faÅ¿ten them to his headÅ¿tall, as is before taught you, and Å¿o ride him an houre or two, for this will purge his head, and cauÅ¿e him to Å¿end forth mattrative Å¿tuffe which abideth in his head and lungs, then bring him in and take them forth, and an houre after give him Hay and white water, and Bran prepared, which alÅ¿o he Å¿hould have given him before his riding abroad. The next day give him his CliÅ¿ter againe, and Å¿o let him reÅ¿t for that day, but ordered in all things as before. The next day give him his GooÅ¿e feathers again, annoynted as before, and ordered in the like manner as you did before, and all this is, but to prepare him for his after drinke, but remember to keep him alwaies warme, and let him bee evermore faÅ¿ting and empty, when he is to have any kind of PhyÅ¿icke adminiÅ¿tred unto him, and let him be ayered morning and evening, if the Å¿unne Å¿hine, or that it be otherwiÅ¿e warm and calm weather. And having thus begun with him, three dayes after give him this drink.

Take of Aqua vitae halfe a pinte, and of white wine one pinte, AriÅ¿tolochia-Rotunda, Agarick, Gentian, Bay-berries, Myrrha, Ivory, Aloes, of each three drams, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder each one by it Å¿elfe, then mixe them very well, and put them into a clean PoÅ¿net with the Wine and Aqua vitae, and Å¿o warm it upon the fire, then being well brewed, give it him bloud warm. This drink muÅ¿t be given thrice, to wit, every third day, and he made to faÅ¿t three houres after, and after ordered as is accuÅ¿tomed with horÅ¿es in PhyÅ¿icke, during which time, and Å¿ome time after, let him drink no cold water, but moÅ¿t commonly white water, which once or twice in a week may be changed into a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, and let him eate the Bran and Malt, and dyet and feed him Å¿o, as that he may be kept to a Å¿tomack, but be carefull you neither cloy, nor pine him. InÅ¿tead of the Oats which you Å¿hould give him, let them Å¿ometimes be changed into bread if he will eat it: and Å¿ometimes you may give him in Å¿tead of Oats, Å¿ome Wheat either in the eares, which is beÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e Wheat threÅ¿hed and cleared ready for the Mill. â Truely with this cure as I have Å¿et it you down, I have recovered many horÅ¿es. But you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that this malady as it hath runne along upon the horÅ¿e, before it come to that height, as to be Å¿o rank a Glanders, to be termed the mourning of the chine, Å¿o will it aske a long time to cure, and therfore you muÅ¿t not think that it can be cured with this one only courÅ¿e of PhyÅ¿ick, but you muÅ¿t let him reÅ¿t a few dayes, whereby he may the better gather Å¿trength, and then to him again and again, but take
no more bloud from him, and as you doe perceive him to gather fleÅ¿h, and get Å¿trength, Å¿o let his exerciÅ¿e be increaÅ¿ed, but withall, Å¿o as not to over-labour him, or to cauÅ¿e him to Å¿weat violently, nor yet Å¿traine his winde too much. Another:

If you do finde that together with his Glanders, he hath the Strangles, that is that he be oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with inflamations under the chaule, clip away the hayre from about the place, and clap a piece of Å¿heeps skin newly killed, over all the place, which muÅ¿t be daily renewed, and you muÅ¿t keep warme, not only that place, but his Poll alÅ¿o, then,

Take BaÅ¿ilicon, old Bores greaÅ¿e and Dialthea, of each four ounces, and of oyle de Bay one ounce, beat all theÅ¿e very well together, then annoynt the place enflamed, once every day at the leaÅ¿t, and then put to the Å¿heeps skin, and Å¿o keep it on till it be ripe enough, then open it, and put into the orifice a taint of BaÅ¿ilicon for three or four dayes, then heale up the wound with taints of Aegyptiacum, preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. cap. 4. Â§ 4. lit. A. and during the time of his cure, give him Wheat Bran, as well dry as prepared, and for his drink, let it be white water, unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ometimes a MaÅ¿h; keep him warm, and after five or Å¿ixe dayes, ride him abroad with the GooÅ¿e feather in his noÅ¿e, annoynted as is before adviÅ¿ed you, and if he do runne at noÅ¿e very much, then take a Å¿tick, and wrap a fine linnen rag about it, and annoynt it very well with black Å¿ope, and put it into his noÅ¿trils a good way, but not Å¿o as to cauÅ¿e him to bleed, and doe this three or four times a day: or elÅ¿e
Take the Å¿eed of Pordo accenta, and bruiÅ¿e itâª made up in Å¿weet Butter, Å¿o much of the Å¿eed as you may take up betwixt your thumb and two fingers at a time. â This is very good. Another:

Take the oyntment of the oyle de Bay, and unguentum Agrippa, of each like much, rub the inflamation places every night with this unguent well mixed, then apply unto the place a piece of a Å¿heeps skin with the wooll on: but this medicine is much better in Winter then in Summer, by reaÅ¿on that this unguent of it Å¿elfe is very hot, wherefore in the Summer Å¿eaÅ¿on, in Å¿tead of Å¿uch hot unguents, take two ounces of thoÅ¿e that be cooler, with three roots of white Lillies roÅ¿ted or boyled, or Rie-leaven Å¿ixe ounces, of old Hogs-greaÅ¿e as much as will Å¿uffice, and of the tender tops of IÅ¿ope halfe an ounce, mixe all theÅ¿e together, and make thereof an unguent, with which rub and annoynt the place well, and after apply it to the place plaiÅ¿ter wiÅ¿e, this done, cover the place with a piece of Å¿heeps skin the wooll being on, and continue to do this till it be ripe and ready to be opened, blow alÅ¿o into his noÅ¿e of Euforbium, and black Elebore pulverized, of each like much, to the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a haÅ¿le nut of either, then put into each noÅ¿trill a long GooÅ¿e feather, firÅ¿t dipped in oyle de Bay, which powder and oyle will cauÅ¿e him to caÅ¿t forth much of his Glanders, and of his bad humours which do feed them. â
This medicine if it be rightly applyed, will cure him. Another:
If your horÅ¿e together with his Glanders be troubled with inflamed kernels under his chaule, then give him this drink.

Take of Elecampane dryed, AnniÅ¿eeds, Fennell Å¿eeds, Commen, Pepper, Grains, Licoris, of each three drams, all pulverized, and adde thereto two heads of Garlick pilled and bruiÅ¿ed, boyle all theÅ¿e in Å¿trong Ale two quarts, to a moyity, then Å¿train it and Å¿et it over the fire again, and put unto this liquor the quantity of a Tennis ball of tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, and let it remain no longer over the fire, but untill the Hogs greaÅ¿e be molten, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it bloud warm with a horn, this done, leap his back, and trot him gently a mile upon faire ground, and Å¿o home again, then Å¿et him up warm clothed and littered, cauÅ¿ing him to Å¿weat in his clothes two hours, then by little and little, Å¿lake his clothes, cooling him by degrees, till you have brought him to his former cooleneÅ¿Å¿e, and as he doth begin to leave off Å¿weating, let him be well rubbed till he be dry, then two hours after this, give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, and uÅ¿e this drink and Å¿weating Å¿undry times, every Å¿econd day for a week.
