This done lay about two or three of them on a Chafing-diÅ¿h of coles, and cover them with a Funnell, Å¿o that the Å¿moake may come out onely at the end thereof, and Å¿o without any loÅ¿Å¿e aÅ¿cend up into the HorÅ¿es head through his noÅ¿trils, then ride the HorÅ¿e till he begin to Å¿weate; this doe once every morning, before water till the running be Å¿topped, which will be in very Å¿hort Å¿pace, conÅ¿idering the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e.

TheÅ¿e be MaÅ¿ter Markhams two great cures, which by reaÅ¿on hee hath Å¿o great Eecomions of their vertues, and alÅ¿o what great cures he hath wrought and perfected with them, I thinke it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to inÅ¿ert them in this place. Thus I have delivered unto you a great number of Receipts for this one diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, many of which I have tried, and have found them very good, Å¿ome I could never have meanes or occaÅ¿ion to prove, and therefore I muÅ¿t expect prompt opportunities, in the interim I do remit them to my brethren to practiÅ¿e. But I will now conclude this Chapter, with one only Receipt more, which I do eÅ¿teeme my MaÅ¿ter-peece for this Malady, having had much experience thereof, nor did it ever faile mee upon often tryall made. This cure is called, The black drinke for the Glanders. The Cure. FirÅ¿t prepare his body with branne prepared, and after with a ClyÅ¿ter, and your GooÅ¿e-feathers, as before hath bin taught you. This done,

The black drinke for the glanders.Take new made Chamberly, and of the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t white-Wine-Vineger, of each halfe a pint, then take of MuÅ¿tardÅ¿eede, two or three Å¿poonfuls, and make MuÅ¿tard thereof with Vineger, and let it be very well ground, that done, put your Vineger and Chamberly to the MuÅ¿tard, and Å¿o Å¿tirre them well together. Then take of Tarre and bay Salt, of each like much, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate them well together, and convey Å¿o much thereof, as three Egges-Å¿hels will hold, the meate firÅ¿t taken forth, and having firÅ¿t prepared theÅ¿e things, let the HorÅ¿e be taken forth of the Å¿table (being kept that night to a very Å¿pare dyet) and ride him firÅ¿t till he begin to Å¿weate, then give him the three Egges-Å¿hels filled with the Å¿aid Tarre and Salt, and Å¿o Å¿oone as hee hath taken that, give him with a horne the fore-named-drinke made of Chamberly, Vineger, and MuÅ¿tard, all at the mouth, excepting only two Å¿mall or halfe hornefuls, which let be conveyed into his NoÅ¿thrils, which Å¿o Å¿oone as he hath taken, let him bee ridden againe, Å¿o much as before you did, then bring him into the Stable, cloath him up warme and litter him well, and Å¿o let him Å¿tand upon the Trench untill three or foure of the clocke, then unbit him and give him a warme MaÅ¿h, and order him in all things as is uÅ¿uall for HorÅ¿es in PhyÅ¿ick. Give him this Medicine or drinke every
other or third day, three or foure times, and it is an infallible cure. â. This cure I gat from a Noble Knight, who had done many great Cures therewith, who was very preciÅ¿e in teaching it, and Å¿ince I came to know thereof, I have perfected many great Cures therwith, upon horÅ¿es far Å¿pent with the Glanders, inÅ¿omuch as if it be rightly and carefully adminiÅ¿tred, it will cure the rankeÅ¿t Glanders that is. And with this Cure I conclude this Chapter.

sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: WEll HippoÅ¿erus, Å¿ithence we have finiÅ¿hed this Chapter, let us goe to the next; and tell me, what meanes have you to helpe the falling away of the hayre from the Mayne and Tayle of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth Å¿ometimes by a heat which the horÅ¿e hath taken, which hath engendred a dry Mainge in the mayne and tayle, which is the occaÅ¿ion of the Å¿hedding of the hayre from thoÅ¿e parts, and Å¿ometimes it commeth by a Å¿urfet, cauÅ¿ing evill humours to reÅ¿ort to thoÅ¿e parts, which is the cauÅ¿e of the falling away of the hayre & I have alÅ¿o known a HorÅ¿e to Å¿hed the hayre, both of mayne and tayle after hee hath beene violently and dangerouÅ¿ly viÅ¿ited with the Stavers: The Å¿ignes are evident. And the Cure is.

FirÅ¿t take bloud from the necke veine if it be onely in the mayne, Hayre fr â¢ the May â¢ and Tayl â¢ falling a â¢
but if in both mayne and tayle, and then after you have opened the necke veyne, and taken from thence a reaÅ¿onable quantity of bloud, then Å¿lit the skin of the inward part of the taile, next to the tuell from the buttocks to the fourth joynt, and there with your Cornet you Å¿hall finde a hard griÅ¿tle which the French MariÅ¿hals do call Barivole, raiÅ¿e it up with your Cornet and take it forth: that done, fill up the clift with Å¿alt finely beaten, and then with a hot iron Å¿teep it in Buck-lye; burn the tayle in Å¿undry places, and then annoynt the places Å¿o burned with Hogs greaÅ¿e, till it be whole. â This cure I gat in France among the MariÅ¿hals there, whom I Å¿aw cure Å¿undry HorÅ¿es of this malady, and I my Å¿elfe have cured four or five after the Å¿ame method. If it be both in the mayne & tayl, and that you be feareful to experiment this cure by reaÅ¿on you never Å¿aw the manner of it, then
Å¿earch both mayne and tayle well with your finger as aforeÅ¿aid, and annoynt the places with this unguent. Take Quick-Å¿ilver, and tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e (the Quick-Å¿ilver being firÅ¿t mortified with faÅ¿ting Å¿pittle) incorporate them very well together till the Hogs greaÅ¿e be of a perfect AÅ¿h-colour, and annoynt the Å¿orance therewith every day once, holding a hot bar of iron neer, to cauÅ¿e the oyntment to Å¿inke in, and in three or four dayes thus dreÅ¿Å¿ing him, he will be well, â This is a very good receit, and I have often uÅ¿ed it.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt then what is good to cauÅ¿e the hayre to grow againe?

sp.speaker: HipoÅ¿p.
sp.p: Take the dung of a Goat newly made, ordinary Honey,Hayre to grow. Allum, and the bloud of a Hog, the Allum being firÅ¿t made into fine powder: boyle all theÅ¿e together, and rub and annoynt the places therewith every day, and it will cauÅ¿e the hayre to come again apace. â This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: What is good for the Head-ach?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: FirÅ¿t let him bloud in the mouth, and rub it with Salt to cauÅ¿e it to bleed the more, then take two long feathers of a GooÅ¿e wing well annoynted in oyle de Bay, thruÅ¿t them up and down his noÅ¿trils, whereby to open and purge his head, and then perfume his head with the Å¿talks of Garlick broken into Å¿mall pieces, as is before Å¿hewed, keeping him to a Å¿pare dyet, and moderate exerciÅ¿e, the better to cleanÅ¿e his head and Å¿tomack, and to empty himÅ¿elfe, by meanes whereof the head and braine will be the better quieted.Head-ach. It were very good alÅ¿o to perfume him with FrankincenÅ¿e, Storax, and Benjamin, groÅ¿ly beaten and well mixed, of each like much as will Å¿uffice, but two or three dayes after, let him bloud, and give him white water for eight dayes after, during which time, you may do well to give him Å¿ometimes a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h. â This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to helpe the heels that be Å¿cabbed?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: You Å¿hall many times have Å¿mall dry Scabs upon your HorÅ¿e heeles, which will not be greatly noxious to him, & therupon the beÅ¿t cure for his Keeper daily to annoynt them throughly with the oyntment made of Elbow greaÅ¿e. But if there be any running humour iÅ¿Å¿uing from the heeles of the HorÅ¿e, Heeles Å¿cabbed. then let him Å¿tand every day morning and evening up to the belly in water, till the Å¿cabs do dontract, then make a convenient Cautherize neer to the joynts as well croÅ¿Å¿e as thwart wiÅ¿e, then heale it up as you uÅ¿e to do kibed heeles. â This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is good for heels that be kibed?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e the French do call Iavarrs, which is a kinde of Scratches, and the cure is to Cautherize the middle of the Å¿welling along, both long and croÅ¿Å¿e-wiÅ¿e; that done,Heeles kibed. take Oxe dung reeking hot, mixe it upon the fire with Sallet oyle, and apply it to the Å¿orance, once and no more, then do afterwards as is preÅ¿cribed you in a cure for a Splent, in lib. 2. cap. 18. Â§ 17. S. This I never tryed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat cure have you for heels that are troubled with the Mellet?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This Å¿orance we call the mellet, is a dry Å¿cab that groweth upon the heele, Å¿ometimes on the one, and Å¿ometimes on the other heele; Å¿ometimes it commeth of corrupt bloud, Å¿ometimes of a blow given by the toe with the hinder foot, for the mellet growes commonly upon the heele of the fore-foot) and Å¿ometimes for want of good rubbing and dreÅ¿Å¿ing after travell; it will alÅ¿o have a dry chop without any moyÅ¿ture at all. The Å¿ignes to know it, is eaÅ¿ie, to wit, it will Å¿oon be felt with your hand.Heele Mellet. To cure it I have before Å¿hewed you in Â§ precedenti. But yet I will give you one receit more for the Å¿ame cure, whereof I have made often tryall, and it is very good.

Take of ordinary Honey halfe a pinte, black Sope a quarter of a pound, mixe theÅ¿e together, and put thereto four or five Å¿poonfuls of Vineger, and as much Allum finely beaten as a Hens egge unburned, and of Rye-flowre two Å¿poonfuls, mixe and incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, and having firÅ¿t clipped or Å¿haven away the hayre, apply this medicine plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e to the Å¿orance, juÅ¿t Å¿o farre as the Å¿orance goeth, and let it Å¿o remain five dayes, and then take it away, and waÅ¿h all the legge, foot, and Å¿orance with powdred beefe broth, & after rope up his legs with thumbands of Å¿oft Hay wet, and he wil be Å¿ound. But then you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand, that when at any time you do dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿orance, you do not faile to take off the dry Å¿cab, or whatever cruÅ¿ty thing Å¿hall be upon or about the place, and by waÅ¿hing and cleanÅ¿ing the Å¿ore that you do make it marvellous clean. â This is a very good receit.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to helpe a HorÅ¿e that is Hide-bound?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This malady is when the skin of the horÅ¿e doth cleave to the fleÅ¿h, as you cannot with your hand pull up the skin from the ribs; Å¿ometimes it commeth through extreame poverty and maceration; and Å¿ometimes through the indiÅ¿cretion of the Groome for want of good tending; Å¿ometimes of a Å¿urfet taken by over-riding, and violent heats given him, and then waÅ¿hed, or negligently Å¿uffered to Å¿tand long in the cold, or in the raine; and Å¿ometimes again it commeth of corrupt cholericke bloud Å¿iccicating the fleÅ¿h, which wanting its naturall courÅ¿e, cauÅ¿eth the skin to Å¿hrink and cling together, and to cleave to the bones and fleÅ¿h; it alÅ¿o maketh him Å¿ick, and to have a gaunt belly Å¿hrunk up to his flankes, and his hayre will Å¿tare, and his legges will Å¿well: and by theÅ¿e Å¿ignes you may know the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e it is Å¿o conÅ¿picuous. It cauÅ¿eth alÅ¿o Å¿iccity and aridity in the liver and lungs, cauÅ¿ing great torment throughout all the whole body, and his dung will be very hard and dry, and of a naughty Å¿avour, for his body will be very coÅ¿tive, and if he have not help in reaÅ¿onable time, if death it Å¿elfe enÅ¿ue not, yet will at the laÅ¿t other deÅ¿perate maladies attach him, whereof the leaÅ¿t will be the mainge, which will not eaÅ¿ily or Å¿uddenly be cured. The cure is to let him bloud either on both Å¿ides the necke, or on both the Å¿pur-veines, then cloth and litter him warm, and do no more unto him that day, more then to give him good meat and white water, for cold water he muÅ¿t not drink till he be throughly well againe. The next day give him this drink.

Hide-bound.Take of white wine one pinte, of Sallet oyle one pound, of Venice Turpentine one ounce, of Methridate, of loafe Sugar, and of CaÅ¿Å¿ia prepared, of each two ounces, of the milk of Å¿weet Almonds halfe a pinte, and of Verjuyce of the Crab one penny worth, mixe all theÅ¿e well together, and warming it upon the fire, give it to the Å¿ick horÅ¿e, let him have this drink Å¿ixe or Å¿even mornings together, alwayes having a Å¿peciall care to the Å¿trength of the HorÅ¿e, as well in this, as in all other your cures. â This is a cure I have uÅ¿ed very often, and haue found it to be Å¿peciall good. Another Å¿ingular good receit. FirÅ¿t, annoynt his body all over with Acopum and Sacke warmed together, or elÅ¿e with this Bath.

Take faire water, Mallowes, Smalage, RoÅ¿emary, and Bay leaves; boyle all theÅ¿e in the water till they Å¿hall become Å¿oft, and Å¿o bath his whole body therewith warm, and when you have dryed him again, annoint him with this unguent.

Take of Hogs greaÅ¿e tryed one pound, Camomile, Mallowes, GrunÅ¿ell, Smallage, of each one handfull, chop the hearbs very Å¿mall, and boyle them with the Hogs greaÅ¿e a good while with a Å¿oft
fire, then Å¿train it and wring forth the oyle that commeth of the hearbs, and with this Vnguent annoynt his body all over, for it will both Å¿upple and looÅ¿en his skin: the next day give him this drink.

Take of Muskadine and of Å¿trong Ale, of each one pinte, GrunÅ¿ell, Rue, Smalage, RoÅ¿emary, and Betony, of each like much: all together amounting to a handfull. Then take Gum-Dragamant one ounce, two heads of Garlick pilled and bruiÅ¿ed: let all theÅ¿e boyle in the Muskadine and Ale, to the conÅ¿ummation of one pint, then put to it of Å¿weet Butter, a penny worth, and when it is molten, take it from the fire, and Å¿traine it very hard, and Å¿o give it him bloud warm. Let this drink be divided into three parts, whereof give him one part the firÅ¿t morning, the other Å¿econd parts, the Å¿econd and third mornings following, for you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that when I Å¿aid that this drink muÅ¿t be boyled to the conÅ¿ummation of one pinte; my meaning is, that it muÅ¿t boyle till one part be conÅ¿umed, and not otherwiÅ¿e; and in the interim you muÅ¿t keep your HorÅ¿e very warm, and let his drink be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water, and four dayes after he hath been thrice thus drenched, give him this other drink. Take AnniÅ¿eeds, Licoris, Fennel-Å¿eeds, Bay-berries, Elecampane dryed, Fenugrick, Turmerick, of each like much, all made into very fine powder, and Å¿earÅ¿ed; let two Å¿poonfuls of this powder (being well mixed) be infuÅ¿ed in good Ale one quart, with Sallet oyle two Å¿poonfuls, give him this drink four mornings together, wherein you are to obÅ¿erve that the firÅ¿t time you are to adminiÅ¿ter this drink to your horÅ¿e, you are to put into the Ale two Å¿poonfuls of this powder, and the other three mornings, but one Å¿poonfull: keep him warme, and order him as is behoovefull for a Å¿icke HorÅ¿e that is in phyÅ¿icke, and he is certainely cured. â This is a Å¿peciall good Receit. Another:

Let him bloud in both the flanke veines, then take of good white Wine one quart, and put thereto of Sallet oyle, three ounces, of Comin one dram, AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris, of each two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into very fine powder, and Å¿earÅ¿e them, and give it him bloud warm, then Å¿et him up, and let him be throughly rubbed againÅ¿t the hayre, and along the back and ribs, and nape of the necke, halfe an houre together, then cover all his backe with a Sacke made throughly well Å¿oaked in a tub of water, and when it hath drained a while, lay it upon him, and upon that, two houÅ¿ing clothes at the leaÅ¿t, and gird them cloÅ¿e unto him well wipÅ¿ed, which will bring him into a Å¿weat, which truely will be the prime cauÅ¿e whereby to reÅ¿tore him to his priÅ¿tine Å¿anity, but let him not Å¿weat above one houre at moÅ¿t, and coole him by degrees, taking away the Sack firÅ¿t, and keep him to Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes or white water during the time of his phyÅ¿icke, and longer; let him be thus drenched, Å¿weated, and ordered, Å¿even dayes together, and give him in Å¿tead of his Oates, Barly boyled, and dry Beanes bruiÅ¿ed in a Mill, and good old Å¿weet
Hay, well Å¿haken and duÅ¿ted, and Å¿ometimes green Mault from off the floore; and after eight dayes let him bloud in both the breÅ¿t veines, but take not above a pinte of bloud from him in all, and that day you bloudy him, give him of good Sacke one pinte, and put to it of Sallet oyle a quarter of a pinte, and of London Treacle one ounce, warm this upon the fire, and brew them well together, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it bloud warm, then leap his backe, and ride him till he Å¿weat, then Å¿et him up warm clothed and littered, and at night give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, putting into it the powder of BrimÅ¿tone two Å¿poonfuls, and he will be well again. â This is very good. Another:

Take Hogs greaÅ¿e two drams, and of the juyce of Dragon-wort one ounce, of IncenÅ¿e halfe a dram, of Sirrop of RoÅ¿es three ounces, diÅ¿Å¿olve all theÅ¿e in TiÅ¿on one pinte and a halfe, Å¿et it upon the fire till all be diÅ¿Å¿olved, and Å¿o give it him bloud warme, and exerciÅ¿e him moderately upon it till he do begin to Å¿weat, then Å¿et him up warme, and let him faÅ¿t three houres after, and this will Å¿cowre from him all his infection, looÅ¿en his skin, and procure a good appetite to meat, provided you take bloud from him the day before, and (if as well in this receit as in all the former) you doe give your HorÅ¿e a Å¿uppoÅ¿itory the day before you drench him, you will much better and Å¿ooner perfect your cure, eÅ¿pecially if you finde him coÅ¿tive, otherwiÅ¿e a gentle CliÅ¿ter will not be amiÅ¿Å¿e. â This is a well approved cure, and I have often uÅ¿ed it.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure a HorÅ¿e that is Hip-Å¿hot?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, this commeth Å¿undry wayes, that is to Å¿ay, either by a Å¿troke with another HorÅ¿e, or by a wrench, by which meanes the bone may be Å¿lipped out, and then it muÅ¿t be put in again, or by a Å¿traine, which may cauÅ¿e him to halt, or by meanes of Å¿ome thorne which he may get by leaping or running among buÅ¿hes, which muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be gotten out, otherwiÅ¿e the place will feÅ¿ter, and he goe lame. The cure is, firÅ¿t let him bloud in the thigh veine, on that Å¿ide whereon the griefe is, then charge him with the charge we call a honey-charge, preÅ¿cribed you in the next Â§. and Å¿o put upon the other foot a Pattent-Å¿hooe, and let him not lye down in ten dayes (if that the bone have been out) after bathe the place well with that bath which is already taught you in lib. 2. cap. 5. lit. B. and the receit beginneth thus, (take Smalage, Oxe-eye, and Sheeps Å¿uet, &c.) and put into the Bath Å¿ome of the Å¿aid honey charge, and if this doe not cure him (as it is moÅ¿t probable it will) then apply to the place this Ceroene (as the French doe terme it) which is a Searcloth very hot, and this Ceroene is thus made.

Take of blacke Pitch halfe a pound, of MaÅ¿ticke two ounces, of Galbanum four ounces, of fat Pitch and of Turpentine, of each
halfe a pound: melt theÅ¿e in a pot together, and when it is halfe cold, charge the place up to the hanch, and Å¿o overthwart the reynes of the backe, and if he be not cured at the end of eight or tenne dayes more with this Ceroene, or Searcloth, then take it off and apply to the place grieved this unguent.

Take of oyle de Bay, Althea, tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, of each halfe a pound, incorporate all theÅ¿e together to an unguent, and therewith annoint, rub, and chafe the place grieved, and he Å¿hall doe well. â This is a very good receit, and I have made great uÅ¿e thereof.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you make this Honey-Charge HippoÅ¿erus?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I will Å¿hew you Sir, Take of Wheat meale two pound, and put a little Wine to it, as much as will Å¿uffice, put it into a kettle, as if you were to make a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, & when it is wel mixed adde to it of Bolearmoniack in fine powder, half a pound, of common EngliÅ¿h Honey, one pound, then Å¿et it upon the fire,Honey-charge. and boyle it, keeping it continually Å¿tirring, and put to it in the boyling, of blacke Pitch, halfe a pound, Å¿till Å¿tirring it till it be boyled, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, & when it is almoÅ¿t enough, put to it of ordinary Turpentine halfe a pound, of oyle de Bay, Comin, Althea, Sanguis Draconis, Bay berries, Fenugrick, and of LinÅ¿eed-meale, of each two drams, boyle all theÅ¿e together againe, Å¿till Å¿tirring them till they be well incorporate, and herewith charge the grieved members of the horÅ¿e. â This is the very beÅ¿t charge that I doe know for ordinary griefes of this nature; but if you be to apply this to many horÅ¿es, then muÅ¿t you double your ingredients according to the number of your horÅ¿es. This charge is Å¿ingular good for any Å¿lip or wrench in the Å¿holder, hip, or other member, for all Å¿orts of Å¿cratches, and for Å¿tifneÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿inewes, or for Å¿inewes hurt or any way offended, as alÅ¿o for a hip-Å¿hot or diÅ¿location, or for a horÅ¿e that is over-wearied with travell, as alÅ¿o to draw away all bad humours to aÅ¿Å¿wage Å¿wellings and tumours, and it will Å¿erve in the place of a white plaiÅ¿ter. And this I have often tryed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVEll now let us come to treat of the hoofe; what have you good to mollifie, the hoofe, and to cauÅ¿e it to grow?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
I gave you a very good receit in lib. 2. cap. 6. Â§ 3. lit. C. but now I will give you more which Å¿hall be very good. Take of Elder leaves, and of Wal-wort, of each like much; Å¿tampe and Å¿traine them till you have gotten of the juyce one quart, or better,Hoofe to grow. then take of Mutton or Deers Å¿uet clarified, three pound, Turpentine, Honey,
and Sallet oyle, of each one pound: boyle theÅ¿e till all the juyce be conÅ¿umed into the other ingredients; then when it is cold, reÅ¿erve it, and when you have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e it, annoynt the hoofe therewith. â This is very pretious. Another as good to cauÅ¿e the hoofe to grow. You muÅ¿t obÅ¿erve this rule, viz. you muÅ¿t at what time you would have him Å¿hod, cauÅ¿e his hoofe to be pared well and even, and to open the heeles and fruÅ¿h well, and Å¿o let him be Å¿hod up; which muÅ¿t be done when the Moone is three dayes in the increaÅ¿e after the change, by which meanes the hoofe will grow more in eight daies then (if he had been pared and Å¿hod in any other time of the Moone) in fifteen dayes, both faÅ¿ter and better, then to Å¿upple the hoofe, and to cauÅ¿e it to grow the more, Take Goats greaÅ¿e, Turpentine, Sallet oyle, and new waxe, of each two ounces, melt them together, then whilÅ¿t they be hot, adde to it of ordinary Honey three ounces, of Sanguis-Draconis one dram, in fine powder: incorporate all theÅ¿e together, and bring them to an unguent, with which annoynt and rubbe the hoofes of the horÅ¿e daily, which may well be done by uÅ¿ing to each the quantity of a haÅ¿le nut of this oyntment, which will cauÅ¿e the hoofe to grow more in fifteen dayes, then without it in three moneths, and if you adde to the former ingredients, of the juyce of the hearb called Hepatica, Å¿ixe ounces, and of the root called HoÅ¿manderigalis two ounces, it will be much better. For if you doe finde that the aforeÅ¿aid Unguent doe not make the hoofe to come away to your minde, then will this addition aÅ¿Å¿uredly doe it. â This is a very good receit. Another:

Take Salet oyle foure ounces, new Waxe and Turpentine, of each one ounce, Goats greaÅ¿e three ounces, melt all theÅ¿e together, and being all molten, take it from the fire, and put into it of HorÅ¿e-greaÅ¿e, Agrippa, and of Morciaton, of each one ounce, beat and incorporate all theÅ¿e together with the other ingredients, till it be through cold; with this oyntment, rub and annoynt the coffins of the hoofes eÅ¿pecially about the cronet at the hayre, every day once, and it will grow very much. â This is Å¿ingular good. Another very good.

Take of Hogges-greaÅ¿e three pound, of patch or peece-greaÅ¿e two pound, Turpentine one pound, new Wax halfe a pound, and of Sallet-oyle one pound, melt, and mixe all theÅ¿e together, bringing it to an Oyntment, and herewith rub and annoynt the Coffins of the HorÅ¿e, eÅ¿pecially about the Cronets, neere to the hayre. â. tle to m â¢ tough. Wax and Turpentine of each halfe a pound, melt firÅ¿t the Waxe, then put to it your Butter, and when that is molten put in your Turpentine, and Å¿o Å¿tirring them well together, reÅ¿erve it to your uÅ¿e, and when you do uÅ¿e it, apply it thus:

ved. therewith. And if it come of cold, it will at foure or five times thus doing, cure it. â. This is Å¿ingular good. Another.

Take Aqua-vitae, and warme it upon the fire, and therewith bathe and rub the greived Member therewith very well, and hold a hot bar of iron before it, to cauÅ¿e it to Å¿inke in the better; take then a rag, and wet it in the Å¿ame Aqua-vitae, and laÅ¿tly, take Pepper finely powdred and Å¿earced, an â¢ Å¿trew it good and thick upon the Å¿aid wet rag, and Å¿o bind it to the place greived; take then a dry Rowler of linnen, and Å¿wathe the place therewith, and Å¿o let them remaine, and thus do every day once, and in Å¿hort time it will recover him. â. Of this I have made often tryall.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to encreaÅ¿e the Hoofe of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have given you Å¿undry good Receipts before, but I will adde one more, which the moÅ¿t Famous MariÅ¿hall of all Paris gave me, which he recommended unto me for tresbonne, but I never had yet a good occaÅ¿ion to make tryall thereof. The receipt is this.

Take of the Oyle of Hempe-Å¿eed, of Waxe, of Venice Turpentine,IncreaÅ¿ â¢ Hoofe. RoÅ¿in, Pitch, Bay-Å¿eeds dryed and powdred of each halfe a pound, Roch Allume two ounces, mixe all theÅ¿e together, and let them boyl Å¿oftly upon a gentle fire, then Å¿traine it through a hayre-cloath, and keepe it for your uÅ¿e. With this annoynt every day the hoofes of your HorÅ¿e, and this will cauÅ¿e them to grow very much. This is probably a good Receipt.

sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure the Lampas HippoÅ¿erus?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a Malady that every common Smith can eaÅ¿ily cure, by putting into the Mouth of the HorÅ¿e a good big Bat of wood, where unto two long peeces of the Head-Å¿tall of an old bridle is nayled at either end, which will cauÅ¿e him to keepe open his Mouth, and then holding up his Lip with your left hand, burne away the ranke fleÅ¿h, with a hot Iron made of purpoÅ¿e, and after rubbing the place with Salt, and giving him Bran for Oats three or foure daies at the moÅ¿t, he will bee whole. â. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is a Swelling proceeding from rankneÅ¿Å¿e of bloud, which groweth in the Mouth adioyning to the fore teeth, which Å¿aid Swelling is an impediment to his feeding; it is apparant enough to be Å¿eene, and therefore needs no further remonÅ¿trance. â. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will Å¿hew you how the MariÅ¿hals in France do uÅ¿e to cure the Lampas, from whom I had the Cure, and wherewith I my Å¿elfe have cured many horÅ¿es.

Take a roÅ¿ted Onion, and very hot put it upon a clout, or upon hurds, and with it rub the Lampas Lampas. very hard, and do this two or three times a day till it be whole. â. But many times they burne away the Lampas, like as do our Smithes with an iron inÅ¿trument, which they do call a BiÅ¿tory, which is the very Å¿ame that our Smithes uÅ¿e here in England.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw do you Å¿top a Lax or LooÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e, when it commeth to be violent?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Very eaÅ¿ily Sir, but I had thought I had handled that point Å¿ufficiently before, in letter F. where you made your demand touching the Flux in a HorÅ¿e, notwithÅ¿tanding I will give you other very good Receipts by me almoÅ¿t forgotten. To illuÅ¿trate the manner of it's comming,Laxe to Å¿top and the Å¿ignes how to know the Å¿ame, I hold unfitting for this place, by reaÅ¿on I have Å¿ufficiently already performed it. Take of Allome one penny-worth powdred, Bole-Armoniack poudred, one ounce, put theÅ¿e into Milke one quart, continually Å¿tirring it till the Milke doth become all of a Curd, give him this
with a horne, and it will Å¿tay his Laxe bee it never Å¿o violent. â. This I have uÅ¿ed. Another.

Take Beane flower, and Bole-Armoniack in fine powder, of each foure ounces, put them into red Wine one quart, and give him this with a horne bloud warme. Let his drinke be white water, only inÅ¿teed of Wheate-bran, put in Bean-flower, and that for three or foure daies after; then let him bloud in the Temple veines, and give him warme MaÅ¿hs, made of ground Malt and Beane-flower, and having drunke up the Wort, let him eate up the reÅ¿idue, but if this doe not Å¿tay him within two daies, then put in each NoÅ¿thrill, Sallet-oyle, and that will do it. â. This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat meanes have you to raiÅ¿e a leane HorÅ¿e, and to cauÅ¿e him in Å¿hort time to hecome very fat?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have Å¿hewd you this before, but yet I will give you Rereipt which you yet have not.

Take Elecampane dryed, Comin, Turmerick, AnniÅ¿eeds,Lean â¢ to ma â¢
of each two ounces, GrunÅ¿ell halfe a handfull boyle all theÅ¿e very well with three heads of Garlick picked, a little bruiÅ¿ed in Å¿trong Ale foure quarts, then Å¿traine it well, and give unto your HorÅ¿e of this drinke one quart, in a morning faÅ¿ting bloud warme, and then ride him upon it till he do begin to be warme, but not to Å¿weate, and thus do for foure mornings together, and within Å¿ome Å¿hort time after, turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e if the time of the yeare be Å¿eaÅ¿onable, and he will feed wonderfully and fatten Å¿odainely: but if the time of the yeare doe not Å¿erve for graÅ¿Å¿e, then Å¿hall you keep him in the Stable, and beÅ¿ides his former drinke, you Å¿hall give him in his Oates, this powder, viz. Take the powder of Elecampane dry, and of Comin, both pulverized and Å¿earced of each like much: mix them wel together, and every time you give your HorÅ¿e this Provender, take of this powder half an ounce, and Å¿trew it by little and little among his Provender for feare of offending him, till he hath eaten up all cleane, and doe thus but foureteene daies together, and you Å¿hall perceive your HorÅ¿e to thrive, mend, and proÅ¿per after a Å¿trange manner: provided that you do give him Å¿eaÅ¿onable ayring, moderate exerciÅ¿e, and MaÅ¿hes or white water. â. This is marvelous good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to bee done to a HorÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Legges doe Å¿well?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If this Swelling be only in his fore Legges and not behind, then it is a Å¿igne that this his Swelling came by over-violent labour, when the HorÅ¿e was very fat, (eÅ¿pecially inwardly) by reaÅ¿on that
the greaÅ¿e that was molten fell downe into his fore-Legges, which if it had Å¿taid in his Body, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity have engendred either an Anticor, Feaver, or a Surfet to the great perill of his life; The Å¿ignes are knowne by the Å¿welling,L â¢ gs Å¿welled and therefore to annoynt them with Acopum were very good. But the beÅ¿t cure is, firÅ¿t to take up the thigh veines, then with your Fleame to prick the places moÅ¿t Å¿welled, and hotteÅ¿t, in Å¿undry places, eÅ¿pecially be low, to the end that the corrupt bloud may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth; then

Take of white Wine-lees one pint, of Comin bruiÅ¿ed one ounce, boyle then together to a pultis with Wheate flower, three handfuls; then with a cloth apply it to the place good and warme, renewing it every day once, & if in two or three daies it doth draw it to a head (as it is very probable it will do) then lanch it and heale it up either with Shooe-makers waxe, laid on upon a PlayÅ¿ter of leather, or alÅ¿o with a Å¿alve made of the yolke of an Egge, Whete flower, and common honey well wrought together to a Å¿alve, which you muÅ¿t alÅ¿o apply PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e â. But if it do not come to a head, and yet the Å¿welling continue; then

Take of Pitch, and of Virgin-wax, of each three ounces, RoÅ¿in half a pound, of the iuyce of IÅ¿op, and of Galbanum, of each half an ounce and of Mirrah-Å¿econdary half a pound, of Bdellium-Arabicum, Populeon, and of the drops of Storax, of each halfe an ounce, and of Deeres-Å¿uet halfe a pound; boyle all theÅ¿e together in an earthen Pot, and when it is cold; take of Bitumen halfe a pound, Bole-Armoniack, and of CoÅ¿tus, of each one ounce and halfe: make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and then incorporate them well with the other, and Å¿o boyle them all over againe very well; that done, poure this whole mixture or Medicine into cold water, and Å¿o make it up into rowles like a Å¿alve for PlayÅ¿ters: and when you are to uÅ¿e it, Å¿pread thereof upon PlayÅ¿ters of Leather, which muÅ¿t bee Å¿o large as to cover the Legges full Å¿o far as the Å¿wellings are, which (if any thing can do it) this will aÅ¿Å¿wage the Å¿welling, and give very much Å¿trength and comfort the Sinewes and Nerves: neyther is this PlayÅ¿ter to be removed Å¿o long as it will remaine on. â. This I have applyed to many HorÅ¿es very much annoyed with Å¿wolne-Legges, and brought them to their former Å¿mallneÅ¿Å¿e, when as Ferriers have Å¿pent much time upon the Cure, and given it over at laÅ¿t. But if the Swelling do fall into the hinder-Legs, or into all foure-Legs together (being but a bad Sorance) cauÅ¿ing them to burne and Å¿well exceedingly, and the hayre to Å¿tare, the cauÅ¿e whereof coming, (as I have before Å¿aid) from immoderate Riding, heat, and labour, whereby the greaÅ¿e melting falleth downe into the Legges, by reaÅ¿on the HorÅ¿e cannot voyd it in his Excrements, or elÅ¿e being over-hot, he is waÅ¿hed or negligently, Å¿et up without Å¿ufficient Å¿tore of litter and rubbing, Å¿o as the taking cold, the bloud with the greaÅ¿e Å¿etleth in the Legges, and there congealeth, and Å¿o cauÅ¿eth them to Å¿well. This Å¿orance alÅ¿o commeth by having
his feet beaten (eÅ¿pecially in the Summer) with being ridden and galloped upon hard ground, which firÅ¿t occaÅ¿ioneth wind-gals, and thoÅ¿e alÅ¿o cauÅ¿eth the legs to Å¿well, which truely is the worÅ¿t kinde of Å¿welling of all other, by reaÅ¿on that lameneÅ¿Å¿e doth immediately follow it, unleÅ¿Å¿e great Art and diligence be Å¿peedily applyed for prevention thereof. Wherefore the Å¿ignes being Å¿o apparant, needs no remonÅ¿trance, and therefore I will paÅ¿Å¿e on to the Cure, which is thus.

Take Populeum, Nervell, Hogs greaÅ¿e, of each one ounce,Legs â¢
led. incorporate them very well together cold, and annoynt the Å¿orance therwith morning and evening foure dayes together, and at foure dayes end, take of Claret Wine lees one quart, boyle it upon the fire with Å¿o much Bran as will bring it to a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, apply this to the place grieved plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e with a cloth good and hot for foure or five daies more, renewing it every day once, and in Å¿hort time he will be Å¿ound again. â This is a moÅ¿t excellent receit which I have often experimented. Another. The Å¿welling of the legges may be eaÅ¿ily cured, if in the beginning, they be often times in the day laved and bathed in cold water, unleÅ¿Å¿e the malady come of too great a Å¿urfet, wherefore if this of cold water will not doe it, then

Take of common honey one pound, Turpentine, common Gum, meale of LinÅ¿eed, meale of Fenugrick, of each foure ounces, Bay berries made into very fine powder, and Å¿eraced, three ounces, mixe and boyle all theÅ¿e together well, and when you take it from the fire, put unto it of white Wine one pinte, and then boyle it over againe till it doe become thicke, Å¿preade this upon a cloath reaÅ¿onable hot, and wrap it about the members Å¿welled, and doe not renew it above once in a weeke, and it will cure them. â This is a certaine and moÅ¿t approved Cure. Another. If you take up the veines, and make them to bleed below and not above, and then rope up the legges with thumbands of Å¿oft Hay wet in cold water, and then caÅ¿t more water upon them, in Å¿hort time he will be Å¿ound and well againe. â This is alÅ¿o very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to cure the LeproÅ¿ie?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a moyÅ¿t mainge, very infectious, which commeth by meanes of great Å¿urfets, taken by over-riding, which is very eaÅ¿ie to be Å¿een and known, and therefore needs no further deÅ¿cription. The cure therefore is: firÅ¿t, let him bleed well in the necke, then Å¿crape away the Å¿curfe with an old Curry-combe, OyÅ¿ter-Å¿hell, Hayre-cloth, or Å¿ome Å¿uch like thing, till the Å¿orance doe looke raw, and that it be ready to bleed, then annoynt the raw places with this oyntment.LeproÅ¿ â¢ elepha â¢ malady

Take ArÅ¿nick, or ReÅ¿algar, and tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, (the ArÅ¿nick
or ReÅ¿algar being firÅ¿t beaten unto very fine powder) incorporate theÅ¿e well together to make them into a perfect oyntment; then tye up the head of your HorÅ¿e Å¿o high to the Rack, as that he may not be able to bite, rub, or lick himÅ¿elfe, and Å¿o annoynt the places therewith, and cauÅ¿e the oyntment to Å¿inke the better in by himÅ¿elfe, and Å¿o annoynt the places therewith, and cauÅ¿e the oyntment to Å¿inke the better in by holding a hot bar of iron neere to the place as you annoint him, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o tyed three houres, and then waÅ¿h away the Vnguent with the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Chamber-lye you can get, and waÅ¿h him Å¿o throughly, that you may be aÅ¿Å¿ured you leave none of the oyntment upon the HorÅ¿e, and then untye him, and give him meat: and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e him once every day till the Å¿ores be quite dryed up. â This is alÅ¿o good for Scratches, and Kibed-heeles.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to kill Lice in a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Lice commonly commeth to a horÅ¿e when he is very poore, eÅ¿pecially when he runneth abroad in the Winter time in Å¿ome Wood, Coppice, or places where are many high trees, for that the dropping of the trees falling upon the HorÅ¿e, together with his poverty, doth cauÅ¿e them to engender, and albeit they may be at firÅ¿t but a few, yet will they in Å¿hort time multiply abundantly: Å¿ometimes alÅ¿o a HorÅ¿e will catch them by Å¿tanding neer to another horÅ¿e that be lowÅ¿ie, and Å¿o long as he be viÅ¿ited with them, he can never proÅ¿per, but remaine very meager and leane. You may eaÅ¿ily know when he is annoyed with this kinde of vermine, for that he will often Å¿crub and rub himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t Wals, PoÅ¿ts, and Doores, with his mouth and hinder feet. The way to deÅ¿troy them is,
Lice.Take Staves-Acre, and boyle it in running water, and waÅ¿h him all over with that water warme, and it will kill them. â Another,

Take Quick-Å¿ilver two ounces, and firÅ¿t kill it with faÅ¿ting Spittle, and when it is throughly mortified, take Hogs greaÅ¿e tryed, and Å¿o work them together till it become of an AÅ¿h-colour, and annoynt him therewith, and it will in twice or thrice dreÅ¿Å¿ing, kill them all. â Another:

Take Tobacco as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿hred it very Å¿mall, and put it into Å¿mall Beere, and put to it of Allum powdred, as much as will Å¿uffice, and when the Allum is diÅ¿Å¿olved, waÅ¿h him therewith, and it will kill them. X All theÅ¿e I have often tryed, and have found them to be very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p:
HOw doe you make your powder of Lime and Honey,Lime ãâã Hone â¢
with which you doe heale and dry up Sores?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿,
sp.p: Take of EngliÅ¿h Honey, and of quick-lime newly taken from the Kill, unÅ¿laked, of each like much as will Å¿uffice, beat your Lime into fine powder, and with your Honey and your Lime knead it to a paÅ¿te, and when it is throughly wrought, make it into a thin Cake, then lay it upon a cleane fire-pan, and Å¿et it upon the fire, and Å¿o let it bake, and as it is baking, take the Å¿oles of two old Å¿hooes and caÅ¿t them into the fire, and let them burn untill they have done flaming, and that they do come to be fire coale; then take them forth, and when the Cake is baked Å¿ufficiently and cold, beat the Cake together with the burnt Å¿hooes Å¿oles to very fine powder, and Å¿o keep this powder in a bladder or dry boxe for your uÅ¿e. X This will heale and dry up any wound or old Å¿ore, and I have often and long uÅ¿ed this powder.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is that we call the Low-worme?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is that diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which I cannot diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h from Saint Anthonies fire, or the Shingles, for that it hath the Å¿elfe Å¿ame Å¿ymptomes, and this I have cured. This is a Worme that breedeth in the back, betwixt the skin and the bone, and runneth along the breaÅ¿t to the braine, and when it commeth to touch the pannicle of the braine, it maketh the HorÅ¿e Å¿tarke mad. You Å¿hall firÅ¿t diÅ¿cover it by theÅ¿e Å¿ignes, viz. preÅ¿ently after a long and tedious journey, the HorÅ¿e will be Å¿ick and forÅ¿ake his meat, and Å¿tand out of length with his feet, bending down his backe, and he will often make offer to piÅ¿Å¿e, but cannot, and if he doe, yet will it be but very little at a time, and that in the Å¿heath, and in time he will fall mad, gnaw the Wals, RackÅ¿taves, and Manger, and bite and Å¿trike at every man that commeth within his reach or danger: and theÅ¿e be the moÅ¿t pregnant and apparant Å¿ignes: and this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e doth deceive many a good Ferrier. For albeit that this infirmity may be many times among horÅ¿es, yet Ferriers being ignorant thereof by miÅ¿taking it meerely for the Stavers, and applying remedies onely for that cure, doe thereby loÅ¿e many a good horÅ¿e through their miÅ¿priÅ¿ion. But now to come unto the Cure it Å¿elfe, I will give you two receits; the former of which I learned of a Farmer in Buffolke, who was cryed up for a very expert man in this faculty, (as indeed he was) and hath perfected in my preÅ¿ence many a great cure. Then thus,

Take of Acrement a quarter of a pound,Loe- â¢â¢
Å¿ixe heads of Garlicke cleane pilled, of Rue and Turmentile that beareth the yellow flower,
of each one pound, Å¿tamp all theÅ¿e in a Å¿tone morter, and put to it Å¿o much white Wine, as that when it is Å¿trained, there may be of the juyce and Wine two quarts, when you have of this liquor in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, let your horÅ¿e bloud under the tayle a good quantity, then Å¿tanch him, and dividing this pottle of liquor into Å¿ixe parts, give it him Å¿ixe mornings together, that is to Å¿ay, every morning one part or portion, till he hath taken it all, and by that time he will he perfectly cured. â

The Å¿econd receit was taught me in France by a famous MariÅ¿hall of Burbon, who hath cured very many horÅ¿es of the Å¿elfe Å¿ame malady, but in a quite contrary way. For whereas the firÅ¿t Cure was wrought by medicine, this Å¿econd is perfected by giving of fire. Take an iron with a Button at one end, and make it red hot, then burn him therwith upon the top of his forehead, and a little under his foretop, and another in the fore-top, and foure other in the necke, cleane through upon the creÅ¿t, whereof two of the holes muÅ¿t be upon the one Å¿ide of the creÅ¿t, and two on the other Å¿ide, and to take away and kill the fire, put into every hole Vnguentum RoÅ¿arum, and then let him bloud in the necke veine, and he is cured. â This is alÅ¿o an approved Cure. The French do call this malady ver-coquin, and the Italians doe name Vermiforme, but they both have but one manner of Cure for the fame. This Ver-coquin, or Low-worme is a living worm which breedeth upon the back bone running along the necke, and Å¿o by degrees commeth to the head of the horÅ¿e, where with its hard beake, it firÅ¿t pierceth the panicle, and then worketh it Å¿elfe to the very brain of the creature, where it lyeth biting, gnawing, and feeding, cauÅ¿eth the horÅ¿e to become enraged, and to dye mad, if otherwiÅ¿e he be not cured in time, and therefore the French MariÅ¿hals doe affirme, that the prime remedy wherewith to kill and deÅ¿troy this Worme, is, by fire, and they hold that it cannot be deÅ¿troyed any other way.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat remedy have you to helpe the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the Lungs?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the Lungs is a malady which is firÅ¿t engendred of cold taken, and let runne till the horÅ¿e be either frettized or putrified in the lungs, at what time they become infl â¢ med, and to come at laÅ¿t to rottenneÅ¿Å¿e and corruption: the means how to come to the knowledge of this infirmity is, that by carefull obÅ¿ervance you may perceive his flankes to beat, and his ribbes to work, but moÅ¿t chiefly when he cougheth, and then the more Å¿lowly they doe beat and heave, the more old and dangerous is the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e; he will alÅ¿o draw his breath at his noÅ¿e Å¿hort, and yet weakely, and he will grone often, and principally when he lyeth down and riÅ¿eth up, and when at any time he cougheth, he will Å¿eeme to chew Å¿ome thing
betwixt his teeth, and from his noÅ¿e will iÅ¿Å¿ue much corruption. The Cure is,

Take of horÅ¿e Lung-wort, alias Mullet, it groweth in every place with broad hoary Å¿oft leaves which doe feele like velvet; Å¿hred it,Lungs ãâã diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. Å¿tamp it and Å¿traine it, then take of Fenugricke a good Å¿poonfull, and of Madder as much, make them into fine powder, and give this to your horÅ¿e in Muskadine one pinte, or elÅ¿e in good Ale one quart, and adminiÅ¿ter this unto him every other day for twelve or fourteen dayes, and Å¿princkle his Hay with water, and let his Oates be waÅ¿hed in good Ale, and let his drink be white water, and Å¿ometimes Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes. â This is very good. Another:

Take a Snake, and cut off the head and tayle, and flea it, and after cut the Å¿ame into pieces the length of your finger, and roÅ¿t it as you would an Eele upon a Spit, but do not baÅ¿te it with any thing, for it will baÅ¿te it Å¿elfe, reÅ¿erve carefully the oyle that drippeth from it, and herewith annoynt the breaÅ¿t and the fore-Å¿hort ribbes of the HorÅ¿e which be againÅ¿t the Lungs, but clip away the hayre firÅ¿t from about the place where you are to annoynt him, otherwiÅ¿e the hayre will take up much of the Å¿aid Oyle; and thus doing often for Å¿ome time you Å¿hall recover his lungs againe, and make him perfectly Å¿ound. This was taught me by a great MariÅ¿hall of Tours, but I never could come to make tryall thereof.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: NOw HippoÅ¿erus that we have ended this Chapter, let us proceed to another; and tell me what is good to cure a Malander?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a noyÅ¿ome Å¿orance which groweth upon the inward part of the fore-legs in the bending of the legge over againÅ¿t the knee: it is a Scab hard and dry, which hath a chop or chink upon it, and it hath hard and Å¿tubborn Å¿taring hayres growing in and about it, not much unlike to Hogs briÅ¿tles, by which meanes it cankereth & corrupteth the fleÅ¿h, which will cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to go Å¿tiffe, and to halt at firÅ¿t Å¿etting forth till he be warm, like as doth the Scratches. It commeth either through the negligence of the Groome for default of rubbing, and due and orderly dreÅ¿Å¿ing, or elÅ¿e from the corruption of the bloud through hard and immoderate riding; and thoÅ¿e horÅ¿es are moÅ¿t eÅ¿pecially Å¿ubject thereunto, which have long hayre growing all along the legges from the paÅ¿terne up to the top of the thigh as moÅ¿t commonly have your Flanders and Freeze-land horÅ¿es, by reaÅ¿on that the hayre in that place, being thick, long, and Å¿haggy, doth gather Å¿and, durt, and other filth, which not being continually taken off by the induÅ¿try of his Keeper, will Å¿cald, burne, and fret into the joynt, and Å¿o breed this kinde of Å¿orance. I have already Å¿hewed you the Å¿ignes how to know it, now I will alÅ¿o give you very many receits wherewith to cure it, many of which are Å¿peciall good. FirÅ¿t therefore (whatÅ¿oever you have to apply unto this Å¿orance) faile not to waÅ¿h and Å¿have away the hayre from off and about the Å¿orances; firÅ¿t then

Malender.Take blacke Sope, Vnguentum Populeon, and freÅ¿h Butter, of each like much as will Å¿uffice: mixe them well together, and Å¿o bring them to a formall Vnguent, and apply it to the Å¿orance every other day till it be whole. â But you muÅ¿t withall underÅ¿tand that unleÅ¿Å¿e you doe picke away and rubbe off the dry cruÅ¿t or Å¿curfe, as well as waÅ¿h and Å¿have away the hayre which doth annoy the Å¿orance, you doe nothing in the perfecting of the Cure, for be you confident unleÅ¿Å¿e you doe this, the Malender will not be taken away, nor any medicine that you Å¿hall apply to it, be able to heale it up. Another:

Take blacke Å¿ope, and allay it with Buck-lye, and waÅ¿h the place
well therewith: this done, apply unto the Å¿orance a plaiÅ¿ter of GooÅ¿e-dung, and renew it twice a day till it be whole. â Another:

Take quick-Å¿ilver, and kill it in Orpiment, then take Buck-lye, and mixe ordinary durt which lyeth in the Å¿treet (wherein muÅ¿t be neither Å¿tones nor gravell) with the Buck-lye, Quick-Å¿ilver, and Orpiment, and herewith annoynt the Å¿orance twice a day if need be, and when the oyntment is well rubbed in, then clap a plaiÅ¿ter of the Å¿ame medicine to the griefe every time you do annoynt it. â This is very good. Another:

Take of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, and boyle it, and Å¿o boyling hot, rub the Malender therewith twice every day till it doe bleed, that done, put upon it the powder of Verdigrece good and thicke, and Å¿o binde it on with a clout, and let it Å¿o remaine till a cruÅ¿t come thereon, and when you Å¿hall finde the cruÅ¿t to be dry, and withall to chop, annoynt the grieved place with tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, and that will cauÅ¿e the cruÅ¿t to fall off, and the Å¿ore to heale up. â This is is a moÅ¿t excellent Cure, and it did never faile me. Another:

Rub the Å¿ore with the oyle of Hemp-Å¿eed, or with the oyle of Nuts, or with Å¿harp MuÅ¿tard, but the oyle of Hemp-Å¿eed is the very beÅ¿t if it may be had. This was taught me by a French MariÅ¿hall, but I never made tryall thereof. Another:

FirÅ¿t rub off the outward Å¿curfe till it bleed, then binde upon the place this medicine; take of blacke Sope, and of Quick-Å¿ilver mortified with faÅ¿ting Å¿pittle as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o worke them to a Å¿alve, and plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e binde it to the Å¿orance, renewing it every day once till it be killed, and after heale up the Å¿ore with freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter. Another:

Take Glovers Å¿hreds which he cutteth from his white leather, and hoyle them in Vineger of the beÅ¿t and Å¿trongeÅ¿t till they be Å¿oft, binde this to the malender very hot, and it will perfectly cure the Å¿ame. I did never make tryall thereof, but it was given me for very good. Another:

Take the fat or lard of Bacon one pound, red Lead, Verdegrece and Lethurge of gold, of each two ounces, make them all into fine powder, and boyle them well together with the Å¿aid fat of Bacon, keeping them in the boyling continually Å¿tirring; then having very well cleanÅ¿ed the Å¿ore, and made it raw, annoynt it with this medicine morning and evening till it be cleane dryed up. â This is very good. Another which is onely to annoynt the Å¿orance with the oyle of Turpentine, and it will heale it up, and make it marvellous Å¿ound. â And this will likewiÅ¿e cure Scratches, Sores, Hurts, or the like maladies in a horÅ¿e. Another:

Take a Å¿alt barrelled Herring out of the pickle, which hath a Å¿oft row, and cut off the head and tayle, and caÅ¿t them away, then mince all the Herring very Å¿mall, and put it in a Å¿tone morter, and put thereto of blacke Sope two Å¿poonfuls, and of Allum powdred halfe
an ounce, Å¿tampe all theÅ¿e things together till you have made them to be of one body, and plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e apply it to the Malender, renewing it once a day for three daies: And this will kill the humour that feedeth it; which once done, annoynt the place with the oyle of RoÅ¿es, and that will cauÅ¿e the CruÅ¿t to fall away, then waÅ¿h it once every day with Chamber-ly, and Å¿trew upon it the powder of OyÅ¿ter-Å¿hels, and it is made whole and Å¿ound againe. â. This I dare promiÅ¿e to be a very good Receipt.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVEll what Å¿aey you now to the Mainge?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This of all other is the worÅ¿t, vildeÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t filthy, and it will cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to be ever more rubbing, Å¿crubbing, and Å¿cratching. It is a formall LeproÅ¿ie, and the French doe call it the Elephantick Malady, by reaÅ¿on that Elephants are very much Å¿ubject thereunto. The hayre will Å¿tare and in many places pill and fall away, and a lothÅ¿ome Scurfe will be upon the places touched therewith, and he will infect all other horÅ¿es which reÅ¿ide in the Å¿ame Å¿table, with him: Wherefore Å¿o Å¿oone as the Malady may be eÅ¿pyed, let him be Å¿eperated from his fellowes whether in the Stable, or abroad at GraÅ¿Å¿e. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth of corrupt and melancholy bloud, by meanes of it's over-heating, and Å¿ometimes by feeding upon naughty and unwholeÅ¿ome meate. It is Å¿o eaÅ¿ie to be diÅ¿covered, as that it needs no other deÅ¿cription, then what hath beene already Å¿hewed: and I will give you many good Receipts for this Malady.

Mainge.Take Spurge, Selendine, BrimÅ¿tone, all in fine powder, of each three ounces, Hogge-greaÅ¿e tryed, new-Wax, Sheeps-Å¿uet, & quick-Silver well mortified with faÅ¿ting-Å¿pitle, of each two ounces, melt and incorporate all theÅ¿e together, and Å¿o bring them to an oyntment, then firÅ¿t waÅ¿h and make raw the places infected with Å¿tale Vrine and greene Copperas boyled together, the infected places being Å¿craped, and made raw with a Curry-combe or Å¿ome Å¿uch like thing, and then annoynt him with this Vnguent, but firÅ¿t of all you muÅ¿t take bloud from the Neck-veine, the day before you dreÅ¿Å¿e him with this Vnguent. â. This is one of the beÅ¿t Recepts for a Mainge that I have, and with it I have done very many rare Cures.

Take the rootes of Elecampane newly gathered, and the rootes of red Dockes, of each like much, Å¿lice and cut them thin, and put unto unto them of Chamber-ly three quarts, and of Bay-Å¿alt, one handfull: boyle theÅ¿e till one quart be comÅ¿umed, then take it off, and with a rag faÅ¿tned to the end of a Å¿tick, waÅ¿h the places infected very hot, you having firÅ¿t made the places raw, with an old Curry-combe, OyÅ¿ter-Å¿hell, &c. VÅ¿e this foure or five mornings together, then
Å¿ome three mornings after annoynt the places greived with this Oyntment.

Take quick-Silver one ounce, let it bee well mortified in faÅ¿ting Å¿pittle, and mix with it Å¿o much Hogs-greaÅ¿e as a Hens Eg, or better: then take powder of BrimÅ¿tone, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and incorporate all theÅ¿e very well together, and annoynt all the Maingy places therewith till they bee perfectly whole. â. This is very good. Another.

Take of the Oyle of Pilchards, and of Chamber-ly of each one quart, Guinny powder, and the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, of each three ounces, white Wine-Vinegar one pint, boyle all theÅ¿e together till they bee thicke, make the places raw, and annoynt them therewith three times in nine dayes, that is to Å¿ay, every three daies once, and this will cure him. â. This is very good, but you muÅ¿t not forget evermore for this Malady, to take Å¿tore af bloud from your HorÅ¿e a day or two before you do adminiÅ¿ter any thing unto him, for untill Å¿uch time as the Melancholy & corrupt-bloud be firÅ¿t let out, he will not eaÅ¿ily be cured. Another for a Mainge, Itch, or Running Scab, &c.

Take as much Auripigmentum finely powdred, and mixed with Hogges-greaÅ¿e as will bring it to be yellowiÅ¿h, but not too yellow a colour, annoynt the places infected therewith, and it will kill it in three or foure dreÅ¿Å¿ings: This Vuguent will take away both the Scab and hayre together: but have you no feare, for it will not be long ere new hayre will come in it's place. â. With this receipt I have cured very many horÅ¿es, who have not beene a little over-run with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. Another,

The firÅ¿t day let him bloud on the left Å¿ide of the Neck, then two daies after open the other Veine, and three daies after that let him bloud on both the Spurre-Veines, and laÅ¿tly, two daies after that under the Tayle, and let him bleed in every of theÅ¿e Veines, then Å¿carrifie all the places and waÅ¿h them with new Brine made very Å¿alt: that done annoynt the places with this Vuguent.

Take of quick-Silver one ounce, tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e one pound, BrimÅ¿tone made into fine powder foure ounces, Rape-oyle one pint. FirÅ¿t kill the quick-Å¿ilver with faÅ¿ting-Å¿pittle, and then incorporate them together throughly with all the other Ingredients, and having annoynted all the raw places with this Oyntment, cauÅ¿e it the better to Å¿inke in by holding a barre of hot iron neere to the places, and then touch him no more in three daies after, and evermore when you dreÅ¿Å¿e him, forget not firÅ¿t to rub and Å¿carrifie the places infected till they do begin to bleed; but if all this will not avayle, then burne the rankeÅ¿t places of the Mainge with an iron, having a button on the end thereof, but then take heed you enter not the fleÅ¿h, but beare your hand light upon the skin only, and let each hole be well-nigh a Å¿pan from the other. â This I have often uÅ¿ed. Another.

Take of Chamber-ly foure quarts, Bay-Å¿alt foure handfuls, boyle them well together, and waÅ¿h the HorÅ¿e therewith, Å¿o hot as hee can well Å¿uffer it, and when he is well waÅ¿hed; take Neats-foote oyle and put it into water, and beate them well together, and therewith annoynt the raw places, and in foure or five times thus doing, he will be well. This Å¿eemes to a good cure, but I do not remember that I ever did uÅ¿e it. Another.

Take Mother of Salt-Peter, the beÅ¿t & Å¿trongeÅ¿t, and waÅ¿h the Å¿ores therewith Å¿o hot as the HorÅ¿e is able to Å¿uffer it, and in three or foure times dreÅ¿Å¿ing it, will cure him. This I never tryed, but the party that taught it me, averred that it would not only kill any Mainge, but all Scratches, Paines, Rats-tayles, &c. Another.

Take Sopers-lees, and firÅ¿t make the Maingy places raw, and after waÅ¿h them with the Å¿aid Sopers-le â¢ s, and in once or twice dreÅ¿Å¿ing, he will be well. â. This was taught me by the moÅ¿t able Ferrier, I do now know living in England and I have often uÅ¿ed it, and I have done with it very many great Cures. It cureth the Mainge both in HorÅ¿es and Dogges, provided they get not to it with their mouth and teeth. Another.

Take Hogges-greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, Oyle de Bay one ounce and halfe, Crude-Mercury, and white Elebore, of each one ounce, incorporate theÅ¿e well together, and firÅ¿t make the places raw, & then annoynt them with the Å¿aid Oyntment. â. This is very good, for I have often tryed it. Another.

Take of Hempe-Å¿eed, and of Mutton-Å¿uet, of each one pound, bray the Hempe-Å¿eed merveylous well in a Morter, then take of old Bores-greaÅ¿e one pound, VerdegreaÅ¿e, Quick-Å¿ilver, Elebore, Gunpowder, Tartar, of each foure drams, & of BrimÅ¿tone three ounces, make all into very fine powder, that is to be powdred, and mix them well, making them into one body, and then diÅ¿Å¿olve them upon a gentle fi â¢ e, keeping them alwaaies Å¿tirring till it be enough, and Å¿ufficiently diÅ¿Å¿olved, and when it is cold, put it into a cleane Pot, and keep it for your VÅ¿e, and when you have occaÅ¿ion to make uÅ¿e thereof, firÅ¿t Å¿carrify the places, and then annoyt them, holding a hot Barre of iron neere, and in three or foure times thus dreÅ¿Å¿ing, he will be well. â. This is a moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne receipt for this malady, for I have had great proofe thereof. Another whereby to cure the Mainge in the Maine or Tayle.

Make AÅ¿hes of the hearb called AbÅ¿cinthus, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, quick-lime, & Soot, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice: mingle all theÅ¿e together, and with warm water make a Ly thereof, with which you Å¿hall waÅ¿h the Maine and Tayle in the places infected, & this Ly will not only cure this Malady, but alÅ¿o cauÅ¿e the hayre to grow againe very faÅ¿t. This was taught me by a very good MariÅ¿hall of France, but I cold never make uÅ¿e thereof, by reaÅ¿on the hearbe AbÅ¿cinthus was hard to get here. Another.

Take a little BrimÅ¿tone, MaÅ¿culine-FrankinÅ¿ence, Niter of Tartar,
of the Bark of AÅ¿hen-trees, Vitreall, Verdegrece, Black-Helebore, AriÅ¿tolochia Rotunda, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, powder all your Å¿imples, and mixe them well together with the yolks of Egges and Sallet oyle, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o boyle it, and annoynt the place well therewith warm. This Å¿eems to be good, but I never tryed it.

Another for the tayle: Take Mulberries which be not ripe, with the bark of the roots of the Mulberry tree, and Barly, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, boyle all theÅ¿e in faire water, and waÅ¿h the places grieved therewith, and if the Å¿orance do open of it Å¿elfe, then take Sanguis Draconis, the juyce of Leeks, Salt, Pitch, Sallet oyle, and old Bores greaÅ¿e, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and make thereof a Å¿alve, and apply it plaiÅ¿ter wiÅ¿e, but this I never tryed. Another:

Take of Orpin one pound, BrimÅ¿tone and Euforbium, of each one ounce, Cantharides twenty five, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and with Hogs greaÅ¿e make it into an Vnguent, and apply it to the Å¿orance, rubbing it in all along the places viÅ¿ited, and foure or five dayes after, to the end the corruption may the more eaÅ¿ily paÅ¿Å¿e away, annoint him againe with Hogs greaÅ¿e onely, and when the Å¿curfe is falne off, waÅ¿h the necke of the horÅ¿e with Buck-lye made bloud-warme, and he will doe well. â This is a very good receit. Another:

You muÅ¿t firÅ¿t Å¿crape the leprous places till they do bleed; then take of Vineger one pinte, white Elebore, Cantharides, Euforbium, of each one ounce, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and boyle them all well together, and apply it very hot to the place grieved, then when the Å¿curfe or cruÅ¿t is fallen away, waÅ¿h the Å¿orance with Buck-lye mixed with black Sope, and it will be well. â This is a Å¿peciall good receit. Another:

Take of the oyle of HempÅ¿eed, halfe a pinte, BrimÅ¿tone in fine powder, one ounce, Gunpowder finely pulverized, and Quick-Å¿ilver, of each halfe an ounce, and a little Vineger, then beat them all together a long time, and Å¿o apply it cold to the place, and as you do annoynt him, let one Å¿tand by with a hot bar of iron, wherby to cauÅ¿e it the better to Å¿inke in, and this will cure him in few times dreÅ¿Å¿ing, but Å¿uffer the cruÅ¿t to fall away of its own accord. â This is a moÅ¿t pretious receit. Another:

Take of Vineger one pinte and a halfe, Euforbium halfe an ounce, made into fine powder, boyle them well together, and boyling hot, waÅ¿h the Å¿orance therewith, and it will heale it; neither need you to clip away the hayre, unleÅ¿Å¿e you pleaÅ¿e. â This I have often uÅ¿ed. Another:

Take of black or blew Slat, and make it into fine powder, and mingle it with freÅ¿h Butter, of each like much: mixe them well together to a perfect Vnguent, and annoynt the place therewith, and it will cure him, but this I never tryed. Another:

Take of the hearb called in French, Ouraige, one handfull, boyle it in Vineger, two quarts, then take of green Coperas halfe a pound, and of Salt two handfuls, rub the place therewith Å¿o hot as he may well Å¿uffer it, and in few times dreÅ¿Å¿ing him thus, it will cure him. This I had of a French MariÅ¿hall, but becauÅ¿e I could never finde the hearb Ouraige, I did never make tryall thereof. Another:

Take of white Wine Vineger halfe a pinte, Cantharides in fine powder, one ounce, boyle them together, and boyling hot apply it to the Å¿orance, and your HorÅ¿e will Å¿ooner be cured. â This I have often tryed, and it is very good.

Thus I have delivered you many receits for this one malady, which we call the mainge, moÅ¿t of them I have tryed, and can promiÅ¿e them to be Å¿peciall good, whereof many will not onely cure the mainge in the body it Å¿elfe, but in the mayne and tayle alÅ¿o if you pleaÅ¿e to make uÅ¿e of them.
Another moÅ¿t excellent receit for the mainge?

Take Lithurgie of gold, two pound, beat it to very fine powder, and Å¿earce it through a fine Å¿earcer, and put it into a glaÅ¿Å¿e which will hold a potttle; then put thereto of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t and beÅ¿t white Wine Vineger that can be gotten, three pintes or better, and for foure and twenty hours after, Å¿hake it together ever and anone, but the firÅ¿t time it muÅ¿t be beaten or Å¿haken a good time together, to wit, a quarter of an houre at the leaÅ¿t without intermiÅ¿Å¿ion, and then let it Å¿ettle, and Å¿o keep it in the Å¿ame glaÅ¿Å¿e cloÅ¿e Å¿topped for your uÅ¿e. Now when you would uÅ¿e the medicine, you muÅ¿t make it into a Å¿alve after this manner: Take of the oyle of RoÅ¿es two ounces, and of the cleereÅ¿t of the Å¿aid Vineger in the glaÅ¿Å¿e (which muÅ¿t not have any of the Lithurgie in it) two ounces alÅ¿o; beat theÅ¿e together with a wodden Å¿platter, untill you have brought it into a thick Å¿alve: Take then of Quick-Å¿ilver the weight of a Å¿hilling, and firÅ¿t mortifie it very well in a little of the Å¿irrup of Damaske RoÅ¿es, the quantity of Å¿ixe or eight drops, and about three or four drops of the Å¿pirit or oyle of Turpentine; with the Å¿irrup and oyle, mingle and work theÅ¿e things well untill the Quick-Å¿ilver be very well mortified, then mixe it well with the former Å¿alve, and then put it up into a cleane gally-pot, and Å¿o keep it; and firÅ¿t making the places raw, annoynt them with theÅ¿e Vnguents, and it will kill any mainge in the body, mayne, or tayle. â This is very good. Another very good.

Take of Tarre a gallon, of tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, and Bolearmoniack of each two pound, of Pepper one pound, beat the Pepper and Bole-armoniacke to very fine powder, and then mixe all the ingredients together, making them into one body, then firÅ¿t Å¿crape the Å¿orance, Å¿o as you doe raiÅ¿e the Å¿curfe and dry cruÅ¿ty Å¿tuffe, but not to make it raw, or to bleed much, and then annoint all the places infected, rubbing and chafing it in very well, as if it be in winter, let one hold a barre of hot iron neer to the places as you annoint and chafe it in; but
if in Summer, the Å¿unne will do it much better as he runneth at graÅ¿Å¿e; and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e him every three dayes Å¿o long as the unguent laÅ¿teth, and he will be cured. â This is an approved cure.

Another. To perform this cure, the beÅ¿t way is, to give the fire to the place after this manner: the iron being hot, firÅ¿t draw it along either Å¿ide of the chinke, then draw it upon the top of the chink, then draw three Å¿trakes (if need Å¿o require) overthwart, and in Å¿hort time the hoofe will grow again, Å¿o as the chink will be cloÅ¿ed, and remain Å¿ound and whole. And over and above, you may exerciÅ¿e him that very next day after you have thus given him the fire, provided his exerciÅ¿e be not upon hard, but upon Å¿oft or Å¿andy ground. X This is a very able cure taught me by a Å¿ingular MariÅ¿hall of Bruxels, and I have practiÅ¿ed the Å¿ame upon Å¿undry good horÅ¿es here in England.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to cure a Å¿ore Mouth?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e that Å¿ometimes comes by much corrupt bloud, and Å¿ometimes by cold: for this malady moÅ¿t commonly beginneth in the palat of the mouth, which will cauÅ¿e it to look red, and be enflamed, and from the palat it will fall into his chaps, whereby he will not be able to Å¿hut them, as if he had there a convulÅ¿ion. The cure is, if it be but yet in the palate, then let him bloud there, and let him bleed well, then: Take of life Honey four ounces,Mouth Å¿ â¢
Chibbals or young Onions, halfe a handfull, and toÅ¿ted CheeÅ¿e as much as will Å¿uffice, boyle theÅ¿e in faire water very well, and bloud warm waÅ¿h the palat, tongue, and all other places in and about the mouth, well with this liquor four or five times, and he will do well. â This is very good. Another:

After you have let forth the corrupt bloud, then take Verjuyce of the Crab, and Bay-Salt as much as will Å¿uffice, and warm it upon the fire, and bloud warm with a rag waÅ¿h well every part of the mouth and tongue twice or thrice a day till it be well. â This is alÅ¿o very good; but if it be come into his chaps, which you may eaÅ¿ily know by obÅ¿erving his wide yawning and gaping, whereby his chaps will be Å¿o fallen, as that he will not be able to bring them together to Å¿hut cloÅ¿e againe, wherefore Å¿o Å¿oon as you doe perceive him in that poÅ¿ture, Take Verjuyce of the Crab onely, and make it warm, and then faÅ¿tening a rag upon a Å¿tick, waÅ¿h his mouth very well therewith; the Verjuyce being bloud warme, and then with your hand help him to cloÅ¿e up his mouth, and doing thus two or three times, he will be perfectly cured. â theÅ¿e be Å¿peciall good receits.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to cure the MelletMellet. in the heeles?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have Å¿hewed you that cure before, lib. 2. cap. 4. Â§ 9. lit. A. But yet I will give you one receit more,

Take of Honey one pinte, and of Sope three ounces, and of white Wine Vineger five or Å¿ixe Å¿poonfuls, and as much Allum as an Egge, and of Beane flower two Å¿poonfuls, mixe all theÅ¿e together, and apply it to the Å¿orance Å¿o farre as the mellet goeth, and let it lye on five dayes, and then take it away: that done, waÅ¿h the legge, foot, and Å¿orance with warme beefe broth, and Å¿o keep his legges roped up, well moyÅ¿tened in the beefe broth two or three dayes after, and he wil be well. â This I have often uÅ¿ed, and it is a moÅ¿t rare cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is beÅ¿t to mollifie humours?Mollifie humours.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This I have alÅ¿o formerly handled, yet take with you this onely one receit more.

Take of RoÅ¿in three ounces, of freÅ¿h Butter five ounces, of new Waxe one ounce, melt all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and Å¿o bring them to an Vnguent, and herewith annoynt the humours foure or five dayes together, and this will mollifie them very well. â This is moÅ¿t pretious for this cauÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat Å¿hall a man doe to a HorÅ¿e that is morfounded?Morfounded

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Morfounding is but the French word: Å¿ignifying melting of greaÅ¿e or foundring in the body, whereof I have before Å¿ufficiently intreated; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will give you for this malady two Å¿ingular receits, the one I had of an Italian rider in BruÅ¿Å¿els, and the other of a French MariÅ¿hall in Avinion, a man eÅ¿teemed moÅ¿t famous, and of both thoÅ¿e receits I have made often uÅ¿e, and I have perfected them for moÅ¿t rare cures. That which the Italian taught me is this; firÅ¿t open the necke veyne, and draw away the inflamed and corrupt bloud, then take of white Wine one pinte, Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, of Rhubarb and of Aloes, of each two drams, of Senae halfe an ounce, of Agarick three drams, Bay berries halfe an ounce, Saffaron two drams, Duck or Duke powder, and of cordiall powder, of each two drams, make what is to be powdred into very fine powder, and mixe them well together, adding thereunto of life Honey foure ounces, all which being made warme upon the fire, and well brewed together, give it your horÅ¿e bloud warme, but you muÅ¿t withall underÅ¿tand that the Å¿ame day you Å¿hall adminiÅ¿ter this drink unto
him, he do Å¿tand faÅ¿ting upon the Trench three or foure houres before, and as many after; neither muÅ¿t you the Å¿ame day give him any Oates, and let his drink be either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, and keep him warm, and with white water five or Å¿ixe dayes after, and then give him Oates, but in tthe interim in Å¿tead of Oates, let him have either bread made for him of purpoÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e Bran prepared; and when you do give him Oates, put in amongÅ¿t them Fenugrick bruiÅ¿ed. X This is I do aÅ¿Å¿ure you a moÅ¿t excellent receit, with which I Å¿aved the life, and brought to perfect Å¿anity a horÅ¿e of price, which was viÅ¿ited with this infirmity; the Å¿econd receit which I had of the MariÅ¿hall of Avinion is this; (viz) Å¿o Å¿oon as you doe perceive or Å¿uÅ¿pect him to be morfounded,

Take of Salt one handfull, and put to it of faire water one pinte, and give it him to drink, and ride him moderately upon it till he Å¿weate, and this will cure him if it be adminiÅ¿tred Å¿o Å¿oon as you may Å¿uÅ¿pect the malady, but if you Å¿tay three or foure dayes, or longer, before you doe give him this water and Å¿alt, then take of the powder of Hellebore one Å¿poonfull, and of Saffaron one penny worth, of AÅ¿Å¿afaetida, and of Sope of Venice, of each two drams, of Bacca alias the Å¿eeds of Bayes, a farthing worth made alÅ¿o into fine powder, mixe and pound all theÅ¿e together well, putting to them of Vineger one pinte, and give it him bloud warme, then cover him with a wet cloth, and clothe him warme, and Å¿et him upon the Trench, that he may neither lye down, nor vomit, but let him Å¿weat an hour after, and then coole and dry him by degrees, and let him be well rubbed, and he will doe well again. X This is alÅ¿o a very good receit.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WEll now HippoÅ¿erus, let us goe on, what will cure the running at the NoÅ¿e?NoÅ¿e running.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is Å¿o called indeed, but yet all able and skilfull Ferriers doe laugh at thoÅ¿e that give it the Å¿ame EpiphraÅ¿e, for it is none other thing but a Malancholly-bloud, wherewith the creature is oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, for it doth perplex the Heart more then any other member or part of the Body, cauÅ¿ing him in the night time to Å¿weate more then in the day, bereaving him of his Å¿leepe and naturall reÅ¿t, and the beÅ¿t Å¿ignes to know this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, is by obÅ¿erving well the HorÅ¿e when you come unto him in the morning, you Å¿hall perceive him to have Å¿weat aÅ¿well in the Flankes, as Neck, and Short-ribs next to the place where the heart lyeth. sp.speaker: Hippophylus.
sp.p: WHat good Receipt have you, wherewith to Cure old Sores.Old Å¿ores.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.

Mollifie the heeles of the HorÅ¿e with Å¿uppling things, whereof I have given you Å¿tore, then open the Å¿ole of the Foote round about, and dreÅ¿Å¿e the Heele to enlarge it, then when you have made the Sole firme againe, keep his Feete moiÅ¿t with Vnguentum RoÅ¿atum, or Å¿ome

sp.speaker: Hippoph:
sp.p: HOw doe you make Oyle of Oates, and what is it vertue?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: To deale ingeniouÅ¿ly with you, neither my MaÅ¿ter nor my Å¿elfe did ever know the nature of this Oyle, or how to make it, untill Å¿uch time as wee met with MaÅ¿ter Markhams MaÅ¿ter-Peece, from whence Å¿ince we have made very good uÅ¿e thereof, and doe finde it to be a moÅ¿t Å¿ingular receit: I will give it you iuÅ¿t as we have it from him.

Take of Milke eight quarts, and warming it upon the fire put thereunto of burnt Allome foure ounces, which will cauÅ¿e it to run into a Curd like to a PoÅ¿Å¿et; take of the Curd and caÅ¿t it away, and Å¿traine the Whey through a courÅ¿e cloth into a cleane veÅ¿Å¿ell: then take of Oates a quarter of a Peck, dry and cleane husked, that were never dryed, and put them into the Whey, and Å¿o Å¿et the Whey upon the fire, and let them boyle untill the Oats doe burÅ¿t, and be Å¿oft; then take them off, and put them into a Cullender, Å¿o that the Whey may go gently from them without any preÅ¿Å¿ing: (for you muÅ¿t keep the Oats as moiÅ¿t as may be) this done, put the Oates into a frying-Panne, and Å¿et them over the fire, Å¿tirring them continually, till you Å¿ee the vapour or Å¿moke of them, not to aÅ¿cend upwards: But as it were to run about the Pan; then Å¿uddenly take them off: and putting them into a PreÅ¿Å¿e, preÅ¿Å¿e them moÅ¿t exceedingly, and looke what comes from them is only their Oyle, which you muÅ¿t reÅ¿erve in a cloÅ¿e glaÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿o Å¿top it well.

Now there are others more artificiall and curious waies whereby to diÅ¿till and extract this Oyle, yet this above them all, is both the eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t, Å¿ureÅ¿t, and leaÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome way, and the very beÅ¿t for every meane capacitie. â This Oyle of Oates is of all medicines whatÅ¿oever the moÅ¿t excellent, and Å¿overaigne for the Body of the HorÅ¿e, as being abÅ¿tracted from the moÅ¿t naturall, wholeÅ¿ome, and beÅ¿t nouriÅ¿hing food, which doth belong to the Å¿uÅ¿tentation and lively-hood of the HorÅ¿e, this Oyle being given by foure or five Å¿poonfuls
in Å¿weet Wine, one pint, or Å¿trong Ale one quart, and Å¿ome of the Whey poured into his noÅ¿thrils, doth cure the Glanders before all other Medicines. It is alÅ¿o (given in the Å¿ame manner) the beÅ¿t of all Purgations, for it purgeth away all thoÅ¿e venemous and Peccant-humors that feedeth the moÅ¿t incurable Farcin whatÅ¿oever; and for my owne part at what time I can conveniently come by this oyle of Oates, I will never uÅ¿e any other Oyle or vnctious matter in any medicine whatÅ¿oever, to be adminiÅ¿tred inwardly but this only: I having found by good experience, that it is the moÅ¿t Soveraigne of all Å¿imples of that kind, and thus I have Å¿hewed you what MaÅ¿ter Markhams opinion (which is the Å¿ame both with my MaÅ¿ter and my Selfe) is, both of this Oyle and it's vertues, and Å¿o I remit you to the uÅ¿e and practice thereof. â.

sp.speaker: Hippophilus.
sp.p: WHat is that Receipt which I have often-times heard Å¿o highly commended among Ferriers, called PaÅ¿tons, and to what uÅ¿e doth it Å¿erve?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This thing which is called PaÅ¿tons is none other then a plaine PlaiÅ¿ter; only Å¿ome of of our verball Ferriers have gotten hold of the French word PaÅ¿ton, which doth Å¿ignifie a PlayÅ¿ter, and that they deliver and vent among ignorant people, whereby to cry themÅ¿elves vp for learned, and skilfull Doctors in HorÅ¿e-leechcraft; now foraÅ¿much as maladies and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, are of Å¿undry Å¿orts and different natures: Å¿o ought the PaÅ¿tons, PlaiÅ¿ters, and Medicines bee diÅ¿crepant each from other, but Å¿ince you were pleaÅ¿ed to underÅ¿tand the true nature of this word PaÅ¿ton, I have in a word delivered the Å¿ame unto you, and now I will give you the Receipt of one of the PaÅ¿tons which will bee well worth your acceptance, It being the moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne remedy of any that ever I could come to know, which is as good to diÅ¿Å¿olve and take away evill humors, which Å¿hall at any time fall downe into the Legges of your HorÅ¿e, as any other Medicine you can uÅ¿e, And this it is.

Take of common Hony one pound, of Turpentine halfe a pound, of MaÅ¿tick in fine powder two ounces, of FrankincenÅ¿e and Bole-armoniack both made into fine powder, of each four ounces, of Sanguis,
Draconis, three ounces, of new laid Egges Å¿ixe, of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger one pinte, of the flower of Rice Å¿even ounces, mixe all theÅ¿e together, and hereof make a plaiÅ¿ter, and lap the legges of the horÅ¿e from the feet to the upper joynts, and do this but foure or five times, and you Å¿hall Å¿ee it will performe a moÅ¿t Å¿trange and rare cure. â

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to helpe a Å¿train in the p â¢ Å¿terne joynt?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
If it be onely a Å¿traine in or upon the paÅ¿terne joynt, PaÅ¿tern joynt Å¿tr â¢
ned. and not upon the backe Å¿inew:

Take then of Chamber-lye one quart, and boyle it untill the Å¿cum doe ariÅ¿e, then Å¿traine it, and put unto it of TanÅ¿ey and of Mallowes, of each one handfull, and of ordinary Honey two Å¿poonfuls, and of Sheeps tallow foure ounces, chop the hearbs Å¿mall, and then mingle all theÅ¿e ingredients together, and Å¿o boyle them untill the hearbs be well Å¿odden, and Å¿o apply the medicine to the place with a linnen cloth bound up, and Å¿titched cloÅ¿e with a needle and threed, that it may not remove, renewing this plaiÅ¿ter every day once, for three or foure dayes, and he will be Å¿ound and goe upright againe. â This is Å¿peciall good. Another:
