A. and Å¿o he will be cured, this is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: I Would gladly HippoÅ¿erus, learne a good pill for the Glanders.Pill for ãâã Glander â¢

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have delivered you m â¢â¢ y already, but Å¿ince you are pleaÅ¿ed to renew this cure again, I will give you two pils, which Å¿hall be of moÅ¿t Å¿ingular vertue, which Å¿hall cure any violent cold or Glanders; prevent heart-Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, purge away all molten greaÅ¿e, recover a loÅ¿t Å¿tomacke, keep the heart from fainting in and after hard travell, and violent riding and exerciÅ¿e, and theÅ¿e pils will raiÅ¿e a leane HorÅ¿e, and make him fat Å¿uddenly.

Take AnniÅ¿eeds, Comin, dryed Elecampane, Canthamus, of
each two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into very fine powder, and Å¿earce them; then adde unto them of the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, and of the juyce of Licoris, of each one ounce, which Å¿aid juyce of Licoris muÅ¿t be diÅ¿Å¿olved in white Wine one pinte, then take of the oyle of AnniÅ¿eeds, and of the Sirrop of Colts foot, of each one ounce, of Sallet oyle and life Honey, of each halfe a pinte; mixe all theÅ¿e with the former ingredients, and with as much fine wheat flower as will knead it into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and Å¿o make it up into pils Å¿omewhat bigger then a French Walnut, and Å¿o keep them cloÅ¿e Å¿topped in a glaÅ¿Å¿e or galley pot, for they will laÅ¿t good the whole yeare, and when you Å¿hall have occaÅ¿ion to uÅ¿e them, take forth one, and annoynt it all over with Å¿weet Butter, and Å¿o give it your horÅ¿e, and continue thus to do every morning one for Å¿ome time, and ride him a little after the taking thereof gently, if the weather be temperate, and let him Å¿tand upon the Snaffle or trench three houres after, then feed him, and at night you may either give him a MaÅ¿h, or white water. â and thus doe (if it be to prevent Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e) three or foure mornings together, but if it be to take away any infirmity, as Cold, Glanders, or the like, then adminiÅ¿ter it eight or ten dayes together at the leaÅ¿t, but if it be to cleanÅ¿e his body from molten greaÅ¿e, or to take away fouleneÅ¿Å¿e, then give it him either in his heat, or preÅ¿ently after; but if it be to make him fat, being meager, poore, and leane, then uÅ¿e it fifteen dayes at the leaÅ¿t. If you Å¿hall finde any difficulty in the giving of this pill, you may then at your pleaÅ¿ure diÅ¿Å¿olve it, either in Å¿weet Wine, or elÅ¿e in good Ale or Beere, and Å¿o give it him with a horn drench-wiÅ¿e. â The other pill is,

Take of Wheat flower one pound, or Å¿o much as Å¿hall Å¿uffice to make a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, then take of AnniÅ¿eeds, Fenugricke, BrimÅ¿tone, of each two ounces, Sallet oyle one pinte, common Honey one pound and a halfe, white Wine two quarts; make the hard Å¿imples into fine powder, and Å¿earce them, then with the reÅ¿idue make a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and of this paÅ¿te make a pill the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a mans fiÅ¿t, and diÅ¿Å¿olve it into two or three gallons of faire water, by waÅ¿hing and laving the Å¿aid paÅ¿te therin within your hands, & Å¿o let your horÅ¿e drink the Å¿ame at his ordinary watering times, or at any other time, when he is willing to drink, for he cannot drink too much of this water, then ride him to warme it in his belly, but not otherwiÅ¿e, and when the water is Å¿pent, doe not caÅ¿t away the bottome, but filling againe the veÅ¿Å¿ell wherein he drinketh, w â¢â¢ h freÅ¿h water, the next time he drinketh, diÅ¿Å¿olve another ball therein, and thus do for fifteen dayes together at leaÅ¿t, and you Å¿hall Å¿ee Å¿ome wonderfull effects thereof. This water Å¿cowreth, cleanÅ¿eth, and feedeth after an admriable manner, and the former leÅ¿Å¿er pils doe purge the Å¿tomacke and entrals from all fouleneÅ¿Å¿e, it voydeth and carrieth away in his ordure molten and diÅ¿Å¿olved greaÅ¿e, and fortifieth nature Å¿o powerfully, as that it leaveth no evill humours in the body. â This was taught me by a
Scotch man who was Groome in Prince Henry his Stable under MonÅ¿ieur Saint Anthony, and a Å¿ingular good Groome he was. I have often times made proofe and uÅ¿e thereof, and have found it to be right good, and for that reaÅ¿on I doe rather commend it unto you.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good Antidote or preÅ¿ervative have you for the PeÅ¿tilence?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which we call the PeÅ¿tilence or Plague, hath alÅ¿o Å¿undry other names, for Å¿ome doe call it the murraine, others the garget, others the gargill, and the French doe call it mal de montaine; the montaine evill: it is a moÅ¿t contagious, and infectious diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, it is Å¿ometimes engendred of a Å¿urfet by riding, when the horÅ¿e afterwards taketh cold, and Å¿ometimes it commeth of the contagiouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of the ayre; as when a horÅ¿e commeth upon a Å¿udden into fenny or mariÅ¿h places, where he never was before, having been ever bred and kept in pure, Å¿weet, and wholeÅ¿ome ayre, as one hapned to a young Gelding of my own, when I comming into the hundreds in EÅ¿Å¿ex, and travelling late, I came to my Inne, where my HorÅ¿e the very next day fell into a peÅ¿tilent Feaver, whereof he had doubtleÅ¿Å¿e dyed, had I not adminiÅ¿tred help inÅ¿tantly, wherefore whenÅ¿oever you do Å¿uÅ¿pect your horÅ¿e to be never Å¿o little touched with this mallady, remove him preÅ¿ently, leÅ¿t he Å¿hould infect Å¿o many horÅ¿es as be in the Å¿ame Stable with him. This comes alÅ¿o to a horÅ¿e many times by meanes of corrupt bloud and bad humours, which doe lye lurking in his body, which waÅ¿hing, drinking being hot, and Å¿urfets, do often cauÅ¿e, but let it come as it may, it brings with it a peÅ¿tilent Feaver, which is Å¿econded by enÅ¿uing death, if Å¿peedy prevention be not at hand.

The Å¿ignes be theÅ¿e; after that he hath drooped and languiÅ¿hed two, three, or foure dayes at moÅ¿t, he will begin to Å¿well under the roots of his eares, as if he had the vines, and under the chaule, and Å¿o this Å¿welling will run up his cheeks through the malignancy of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and become very hard, he will hang down his head and face, and Å¿eeme alway to Å¿leepe and forÅ¿ake his meat, and his eyes will be yellowiÅ¿h, he will draw his breath Å¿hort, which will be alÅ¿o very hot and offenÅ¿ive, and Å¿ometimes he will put forth Carbuncles, and Å¿wellings in his groine, bigger then a mans fiÅ¿t, and his Å¿tones will hang, but this not alwaies, and this I have known in HorÅ¿es more then in one or two. The cure is,

Take of white Wine one quart, and the hearb called in French, PeÅ¿tile â¢
Mairelle, which we in EngliÅ¿h doe tearme Nighte-Å¿hade: Å¿tamp it, and take the juyce thereof, and boyle it in the Wine, and when it is boyled as much as will Å¿uffice, take then LinÅ¿eed meale, and Barly meale, and Å¿ift out the bran, taking only the flower of them both as much as
will Å¿uffice, and put it into the liquor, and Å¿o boyle them againe to a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and make plaiÅ¿ters thereof, and apply it to the Å¿wellings, but before you lay on the plaiÅ¿ter, Å¿trew upon them the powder of burnt Egge Å¿hels, and thus renewing the plaiÅ¿ters every day once, you Å¿hall either ripen or breake them, or they will drive the Å¿wellings back againe without further trouble, but if the Å¿wellings doe breake, then heale them with your green oyntment Å¿o often Å¿hewed you, but then to drive away the malignancy of the infection from the heart, and to Å¿end it forth, firÅ¿t let him bloud in the necke and weeping veines, and then give him of Diapent two Å¿ponfuls, with white Wine one pinte, and of London Treacle one ounce, and this will recover him. And for your other HorÅ¿es which you may have juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to Å¿uÅ¿pect to be infected, to prevent their danger, give him this preparative.Pre â¢ arative

Take two Walnuts, the kernels onely, and (the older the Nuts be, the better:) take alÅ¿o two Figs, and twenty leaves of Rue, Å¿tamp them all well together, and let every HorÅ¿e have his proportion three or foure mornings together faÅ¿ting, being made up and given in pils, and let them faÅ¿t three houres after, and this will both preÅ¿erve and free them. TheÅ¿e things I have often uÅ¿ed, and found them to be Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good purging pils have you?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.

Take freÅ¿h Butter one pound, Aloes and Fenugrick, of each one ounce, life Honey, and white refined Sugar powdred, of each foure ounces, Agarick halfe an ounce, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and being well incorporated with the Butter and Honey, make pils thereof and give them to your HorÅ¿e, and if he be a Å¿mall or weake HorÅ¿e, then you muÅ¿t give him but two parts of three, but if your horÅ¿e have a Å¿trong cold, and a cough withall, then

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to cure the paines in the Heeles of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a noyÅ¿ome Sorance, comming to a HorÅ¿e, either by ill humours, and corrupt bloud, by meanes of Surfets, proceeding from great heats, by intemperat ridings, as I have Å¿ufficiently declared, before or elÅ¿e through the negligence of his Groome, or Keeper, for want of good rubbing, clenÅ¿ing and picking, this doth grow betweene the Fetlock-ioynt, and the heele, in the very PaÅ¿terne, which will cauÅ¿e the place to Å¿well, and to have chops, from whence will iÅ¿Å¿ue a thin and Å¿tinking water, and thoÅ¿e horÅ¿es which have Å¿haggy, and long hayre upon their Fet-locks, are moÅ¿t Å¿ubiect to this Malady; the Å¿ignes bee eaÅ¿ily knowne, by reaÅ¿on that the chops may be Å¿oone felt, for they will cauÅ¿e the Legges of the horÅ¿e to Å¿well, and much filthy matter will come from the place greived, being of that hot nature, as that it will Å¿cald the very haire from about the Å¿orance, and this will cauÅ¿e the horÅ¿e to go very Å¿tiffe, and lame, at firÅ¿t Å¿etting forth: The cure is.

Take of the Lees of red Wine one pint, of Wheat-branne one handfull of HouÅ¿e-leeke one head, of common Hony, two Å¿poonefuls, of the duÅ¿t of Tanners bark, Allome, and tryed Hogges-greaÅ¿e, of each one pound, & of Verveine halfe a handfull, bray all theÅ¿e well in a Morter, and adde unto them of the leane of of Martlemas or dryed Beefe, burned, and made unto fine powder, halfe a pound, and Å¿o work them to a kind of Å¿alve, and apply it unto the Sorance, Å¿o hot as the horÅ¿e can Å¿uffer it: But before you do apply this medicine, you muÅ¿t draw the skin with a hot iron, a little above the houghes, or knees, or elÅ¿e take up the veines (which I altogether uÅ¿e to do) then take of Tarre, and of Å¿weet Butter, and of Hony, of each two Å¿poonfuls, and warme them upon the fire, and eyther annoynt the places Å¿eared, or elÅ¿e the veine, Å¿o taken up with this Vnguent, once every day, till his Oyntment be all Å¿pent, and by that time, your horÅ¿e will be perfectly cured, eÅ¿pecially if you continue this former EmplayÅ¿ter daily to the Å¿orance, having firÅ¿t clipped, and Å¿haven away the hayre; from about the place greived, â, With this I have cured many horÅ¿e. Another.

Take of Turpentine, Hogges-greaÅ¿e, and Honey, of each like much,PaÅ¿tons. Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, a little Bole-armoniack in fine powder, and yolkes of two Egges: with Å¿o much Wheat-flower, as will thicken all the other ingredients: incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, and Å¿o bring it to a Å¿alve, and PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e apply it to the Sorance, and Å¿o bind it up, renewing it every day, and let him not come out of the Stable, or come into any wet, and he will be Å¿oone cured. â. This is alÅ¿o very good. Another.

Take of tryed Hogges-greaÅ¿e one pound, VerdegreaÅ¿e one penny-worth, of Å¿trong MuÅ¿tard two ounces, Nervall foure ounces, of oyle de Bay, of Hony and Wax, of each halfe a pound, ArÅ¿enick one ounce, Red-lead two ounces, and of white-Wine-Vinegar halfe a pint, powder your VerdegreaÅ¿e, and then boyle all together, and the hayre firÅ¿t clipt away, which muÅ¿t alwaies be done in any of theÅ¿e Cures) apply this Medicine hot to the place, and renew it daily, and it will not only cure the paines, but all manner of Å¿cratches, Å¿cabbed, and kibed Heeles; to waÅ¿h alÅ¿o the Sorance, with Vinegar and Gunpowder is very good to helpe the paines, and Å¿cratches. â. This I have often uÅ¿ed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: DOe you not uÅ¿e to purge a HorÅ¿e that is PurÅ¿ive & Short winded?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea Sir, and I do it after this manner.

PurÅ¿ivenes a pill.Take of the fat of a Boare three pound, mince it very Å¿mall, and lay it in faire Water foure and twenty houres, to the end the Å¿alt (if any be in it) may Å¿oake out of it, then: Take of Agarick, Pulverized two ounces, of Colloquintida in powder halfe an ounce, mel roÅ¿arum Å¿ix ounces, in corporrate all theÅ¿e well together, and worke it to a paÅ¿te; which you muÅ¿t make into Pils, the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of an ordinary tennis Ball, one of which you moÅ¿t give him at a time rowled up within the powder of Lycoris, but the night before you doe adminiÅ¿ter it, you muÅ¿t give him no Oats at all, but a little Hay and wheat-Branne prepared only, then the next morning about Å¿ix or Å¿even of the clocke, give him one of theÅ¿e Pils, and then cover him up warm; and ride or walke him two houres Å¿pace; then bring him in, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench two houres more, then unbridle him, and give him a little Hay Å¿prinkled with water, and eight or nine houres after the taking of his Pill (which will be about three of the clocke, give him white Water to drinke, and let him eate of the Branne, then at night when you are to go to bed, put a muzell upon his mouth, und let him remaine Å¿o all night faÅ¿ting, and let him be warme covered, and the next morning unmuÅ¿ell him, and give him Hay Å¿prinkled with water to eate, and continue to let his drinke bee white Water, only, the third day give him another of theÅ¿e Pils, after which you may begin to give him Oates, but a little at once; but then the dayes he do not take his Pils, you muÅ¿t remember ever more an houre after you give him his white Water, to give him of Agarick, and of Rubarb in powder, of each one ounce, which he muÅ¿t take in freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter made up like to a Pill: This Purgation may be given to any HorÅ¿e, but eÅ¿pecially to that HorÅ¿e you Å¿hall feare is in danger, to become eyther purÅ¿ive of Glandery, and if perhaps the Malady to have beene longer upon him, give him then of Antimony thirty graines,
drams more or leÅ¿Å¿e, according to the Å¿trength and age of the horÅ¿e, and alÅ¿o according to the nature and quality of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e; and if after the application of this medicine your horÅ¿e will not feed (as it may be very probably) you may cheriÅ¿h him with milke mingled with the yolkes of Egges and Sugar, well beaten and brewed together. â This I applyed to a horÅ¿e of more then twelve yeares old, who in Å¿even dayes eate not one bit of any thing but onely the Å¿aid Milke, Egges, and Sugar, and yet in fourteen dayes after, I cured him, and made him perfectly healthy and Å¿ound.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat remedy have you for a horÅ¿e that piÅ¿Å¿eth bloud?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e comes Å¿ometimes being troubled with the Å¿tone, like as we have it often times among men; Å¿ometimes it comes to a horÅ¿e, that being very fat, is put to more then his Å¿trength is well able to performe, like as I once Å¿aw a very proper Gelding (a young Gentleman being upon his back in hunting) who comming to a great leap, and the horÅ¿e being ridden off from his winde, his Rider inconÅ¿iderately forcing him to take that leap, which the Gelding with much difficulty tooke, but withall fell, and was not able to ariÅ¿e but with the help of men, and comming home the Å¿ame night he piÅ¿Å¿ed bloud, whereof he dyed four dayes after, maugre the endeavours of three very able Ferriers, and being opened, they found two veynes broken neere to the kidneys, and much blacke bloud found in the place. This malady may alÅ¿o come by bearing too great a weight, as alÅ¿o when a horÅ¿e is too hard ridden, he will piÅ¿Å¿e water like to bloud: your eye Å¿heweth you the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and therefore it needs no further remonÅ¿trance. The cure is:

Take of AmbroÅ¿io, Sanguinario, alias Bloud-wort, and BurÅ¿a PaÅ¿toris,PiÅ¿Å¿ing of bloud. of each three ounces, Å¿tamp them well, and boyle them in faire water very well, and Å¿o give the liquor thereof being Å¿trained, to the horÅ¿e bloud warme. â Give him this five mornings together, and it will help him. Another:
Take Barly, and boyle it in the juyce of Gumfolly, and give him the Barly to eate, and the liquor to drink, and this will cure him. â This is alÅ¿o very good. Another:

FirÅ¿t cleanÅ¿e his yard from all filth, and his Å¿heath alÅ¿o with broken Beer and Butter, then let him bloud in the necke and mouth, then take the juyce of Leeks or green Onyons, to wit, the water wherein they have been Å¿teeped twelve or Å¿ixteen hours at the leaÅ¿t, the veÅ¿Å¿ell wherein they be Å¿teeped being kept cloÅ¿e Å¿topped.

Take of this liquor, and of white Wine, of each one pinte, and Å¿tir and jumble them together till they become Å¿limy, then give it him to drink, and do this Å¿ixe or Å¿even mornings together, and it will Å¿tay his fluxe of bloud, and bring his urine to its naturall and ordinary colour.
â This is a very good medicine, and I have often tryed it.
Another no whit inferiour to the former.

Take Beane flower finely Å¿ifted, and adde unto it the Suet of a Stagge as much as will Å¿uffice, and give it him three mornings together warme, with a horn, with a Å¿ufficient quantity of red Wine, and during that time, let his drink be either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white wat â¢ r, made with Beane meale. â This is an approved good receit.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good receit have you for a horÅ¿e that hath taken a Å¿urfet by Provender?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This comes commonly to Å¿uch horÅ¿es as are inÅ¿atiable feeders, and therefore it is requiÅ¿ite that they be dyeted, eÅ¿pecially if they have too much reÅ¿t, and too little exerciÅ¿e; for Å¿uch horÅ¿es if they can either breake, or Å¿teale to a Bing of Provender, and drink preÅ¿ently after, will undoubtedly Å¿urfet upon them, for drinking after Oates, PeaÅ¿e, or Beanes, doth cauÅ¿e the Provender to Å¿well in their belly and Å¿tomacke, and Å¿o clogge the Å¿tomacke, as that crudities will ariÅ¿e, and Å¿o cauÅ¿e him to be very Å¿icke, yea and perhaps to no little danger, that you Å¿hall Å¿ee him to Å¿tand with his four legges aÅ¿under, the one farre from the other, and he will Å¿cow â¢ e and caÅ¿t forth of his fundament, corn which will goe forth as whole and entire, as he did greedily Å¿wallow them without chewing, or grinding them. The cure is, firÅ¿t open a veyne in the necke to keep the bloud from inflaming, then draw his yard, and waÅ¿h it with broken Beere, and Butter, then anoynt it with Å¿oft greaÅ¿e, and put into the pipe of his yard a Å¿mall piece of a clove of Garlick, whereby to provoke him to Å¿tale, then rack him, and give him the CliÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed in lib. 2. cap. 6. Sect. 8. CliÅ¿ter 8. C. and it is called a CliÅ¿ter lenative, then keep him warm, and to a Å¿pare dyet, for four or five dayes after, and let his drink be white water during that time. â with this receit I have cured many a horÅ¿e, but one horÅ¿e amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t of very great price, who otherwiÅ¿e had infallibly dyed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure the Poll-evill?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This mallady we do tearm the Poll-evill, becauÅ¿e it breedeth in the top of the Poll behinde the eares of the horÅ¿e, but let it aÅ¿Å¿ume what name it Å¿hall, yet it is none other thing then a FiÅ¿tula in graine, that is a formall FiÅ¿tula which doth begin like all other FiÅ¿tulaes with a great inflamation and impoÅ¿thume in the nape of the necke: Å¿ometimes it comes by meanes of his unruly Å¿triving, the halter being new, and therefore hard, which doth Å¿o pinch and gall him, that the harm thereof by reaÅ¿on that the fleÅ¿h is bruiÅ¿ed,
doth feÅ¿ter and inflame, and from thence is ingendred this moÅ¿t lothÅ¿ome Å¿orance, and Å¿ometimes it comes againe of bilious and evill humours, which do make their approach to that place: Å¿ometimes it comes again by the means of a Å¿troke or blow given by Å¿ome cudgell by his Keeper or Rider, betwixt his eares, whereby it feÅ¿tereth inwardly, and inflaming breedeth an impoÅ¿tumation, Å¿o as if it be not in time taken, it will grow to a very foule FiÅ¿tula, not eaÅ¿ie to be cured; for the poll of the horÅ¿e is Å¿o tender a member, as to be Å¿oon offended, and therefore eaÅ¿ily damnified; I need not to deliver you the Å¿ignes, for the Å¿welling will be Å¿o apparant, as that it cannot be miÅ¿taken, albeit it will putrifie much more inwardly then outwardly; and therefore you ought to apply your diligence to open it, before it do breake of it Å¿elfe. The cure is,
FirÅ¿t to lay unto the place Å¿wollen, Å¿uch things as will ripen it,Poll-evill. and to prepare it ready to be opened: and as touching the ripening thereof,

Take the loame of a mud wall which had never any Lime in it, but much Straw or Litter; and the elder this Loame or mud wall is, the better; boyle Å¿o much as you Å¿hall pleaÅ¿e thereof in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, and let it boyle till it come to be a very PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, then being very hot, lay it to the Å¿welling, renewing it morning and evening till it be ripe enough to be opened, then open it with a red hot iron made Å¿harpe at the end, and let the iron be the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a naile rod, but you muÅ¿t begin below, thruÅ¿ting your inÅ¿truments upwards, cleane through, that it may come forth in the Å¿ofteÅ¿t place, and when it is thus opened, Å¿o as the corruption may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth at eaÅ¿e; anoynt the orifices with tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e two or three dayes together, to get out the fire, but howÅ¿oever faile not to dreÅ¿Å¿e it twice every day with the Å¿aid PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, taynts being dipped in the PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and put down to the bottome, as well to carnifie and heale the FiÅ¿tula at the bottome, as to keep open the orifices, and this PoulteÅ¿Å¿e will cure him. â But withall you muÅ¿t remember to make him a hood or nightcap to keep warm the nape of his neck, and to keep in the taints alÅ¿o: this alÅ¿o cureth the Botch in the groine, hurts in the withers, navell-galles, galled-back, or Sit-faÅ¿ts, &c. Another:

FirÅ¿t ripen it as before, or elÅ¿e with tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e Å¿calding hot, making him a Biggin wherewith to keep his poll very warme, and renew this EmplaiÅ¿ter every day, and it will ripen it the Å¿ooner; then when you finde it to be Å¿ofteÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t likely to breake, open it with a hot iron two inches beneath the Å¿oft place, carrying your hand upward into the Å¿oft and moÅ¿t matterative place, to draw forth the corruption downwards, then taint it with Flaxe or Hurds dipped into molten Hogs greaÅ¿e, and lay alÅ¿o a plaiÅ¿ter of Hogs greaÅ¿e upon it, renewing it for four or five dayes once every day, to get forth the fire: after this, take of Turpentine of Venice, halfe a pound thrice waÅ¿hed, and dryed from the water, the yolks of two Egges, and of
Saffaron one penny worth in powder; incorporate all theÅ¿e together very well, then with a probat Å¿earch the depth of the Å¿orance, and taint it with a Å¿punge full as bigge as the hole of the wound, and as long, and convey the taint down to the very bottome, well anoynted with the Å¿aid medicine: but this muÅ¿t be done with the help of your inÅ¿trument, and then cover it with a plaiÅ¿ter of Hogs greaÅ¿e, renewing it twice a day, but when the Å¿welling is alaid, then uÅ¿e no plaiÅ¿ter, and in Å¿hort time it will be perfectly whole and Å¿ound. X This is a very good cure. Another:
FirÅ¿t ripen and open it as before is taught you, and apply Hogs greaÅ¿e to fetch forth the fire, then heale it thus.

Take Roman Vitreall, Allum and RoÅ¿e water, of each two ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e together on a quick fire till they do come to be as hard as a Å¿tone, and then beat it into a very fine powder, and when you are to dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ore, firÅ¿t dippe a taint into Vnguentum Egiptiacum, and Å¿o rowle it in the Å¿aid powder, and convey the taint with the help of your inÅ¿trument, to the very bottome, and it will in Å¿hort time make it perfectly whole and Å¿ound. â This powder being Å¿trewed upon any old Å¿ore or ulcer, will both heat and dry it up. Another:

Powder for old Å¿ores.Take of Quick-Å¿ilver one ounce, let it be well mortified with faÅ¿ting Å¿pittle, and mixe with it tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e the quantity of a Hens Egge, and BrimÅ¿tone pulveriÅ¿ed; incorporate theÅ¿e very well together, and anoynt the Å¿welling very well with this unguent; having thus done, take preÅ¿ently of red Tarre one penny worth, of the reddeÅ¿t and beÅ¿t, of Hogs greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, and of green Copperas and bay Salt of each one handfull, both made into fine powder; boyle all theÅ¿e on the fire exceeding well, and then boyling hot (even as it comes from the fire) with a clout faÅ¿tened upon the end of a Å¿tick; apply this medicine upon the place (being Å¿o lately anointed with the Quick-Å¿ilver, Hogs greaÅ¿e, and BrimÅ¿tone) and thus by Å¿calding it three or foure mornings together, you Å¿hall after thoÅ¿e mornings but onely warme the Tarre medicine upon the fire, Å¿o that it be but molten, and apply it, and it will be cured; for this Å¿calding of the place doth Å¿o kill the malice of the FiÅ¿tula, that it can never breake to annoy the HorÅ¿e any further. â And thus with this medicine I have not onely cured many poll-evils, but Å¿undry other FiÅ¿tulaes; it cureth all impoÅ¿tumations and foule Vlcers, being thus applyed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good in caÅ¿e of PurÅ¿iveneÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of Breath?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth by two meanes: the firÅ¿t naturall, the Å¿econd accidentall; naturall, as when a horÅ¿e is (as we doe uÅ¿ually Å¿ay) cock-thropled, for that his throppell or winde-pipe being too long, and Å¿o becomes crooked as his winde is thereby Å¿o Å¿traightned or Å¿topped, as that he is not able to draw it in and put it forth with that eaÅ¿e and pleaÅ¿ure that other horÅ¿es doe that are looÅ¿e thropled, for that the winde-pipe is (I Å¿ay) Å¿traightned, which doth convey his breath into his lungs, and vent it forth againe. In like manner, a horÅ¿e becommeth purÅ¿ive and Å¿hort-winded, when the pipe is too much filled, with fat or other phlegmaticke Å¿tuffe, whereby he is very much Å¿uffocated, which cauÅ¿eth his lungs to labour the more, and therefore if you Å¿hall be pleaÅ¿ed to follow my counÅ¿ell, never breed with that horÅ¿e that is cock-thropled.

This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth Å¿econdly by accident, when a horÅ¿e Å¿hall be too hard Å¿trained upon his water, like as many of your ignorant Ioctries uÅ¿e to doe, when morning and evening they doe make them watering courÅ¿es (as they are frequently Å¿o termed) Å¿o alÅ¿o this infirmity commeth by riding, gallopping, or Å¿training a horÅ¿e upon a full Å¿tomacke, before he hath either digeÅ¿ted his meat, or emptied himÅ¿elfe; for by this meanes phlegmaticke humours do diÅ¿till out of the head into the winde-pipe, and Å¿o fall upon the lungs, where they doe reÅ¿t, and there congeale, hindring the drawing of his breath: it comes alÅ¿o by Colds, Glanders, and the like; the Å¿ignes are Å¿o apparant, as that they need no diÅ¿cription, onely this inconvenience (beÅ¿ides many more) it bringeth with it, as to be heavy, Å¿ad, and dull in travell, be marvellous Å¿ubject to Å¿weats, and be ready to fall down if he be but a little Å¿trained. A right skilfull Ferrier not long Å¿ince told me of a Å¿trange cure in this kinde, which a Gentlemans Groome relatd to him of a Gelding which the Groome had in his Å¿aid keeping, who was Å¿o purÅ¿ive (or as we plainely Å¿ay) broken-winded, as that he became almoÅ¿t unuÅ¿efull, and his cure was after this manner; he Å¿uffered his Gelding to eate what he would, as well his fill (viz.) of good Hay, as of Provender, but debarred him of all drink for the Å¿pace of two or three dayes together, then leaping his backe, he rode him upon a foot pace to the water, at which time he Å¿uffered him to drink his fill, then comming forth of the water, he clapt Å¿purres Å¿uddenly to him, and ran him with a looÅ¿e hand upon the top of his Å¿peed Å¿o long, untill for want of breath he fell with him, and for Å¿ome time lay as if he were dead, but recovering breath, he aroÅ¿e, and being well recovered of his winde, he rode him into the water the Å¿econd time, where he alÅ¿o drank, and being come out of the water, he did as
before, and Å¿o being againe ridden from off his wind, he fell like as at firÅ¿t, having thus the Å¿econd time recovered breath, hee gave him water the third time, and then rode him as formerly, but now this third time being fallen, when he began to get breath again he coughed moÅ¿t vehemently, at what time through the violence of his coughing, the Gelding caÅ¿t forth of his mouth, and that out of his wind pipe a hard lumpe of congealed Flegmatick Å¿tuffe of a good bignes, which by this meanes brought up, the Gelding was ever after freed from the malady, and made Å¿ound, and from that houre, had the uÅ¿e of his winde, as ably, and as well as ever before, and this was the Å¿tory which one of the ableÅ¿t Ferriers I do know in England delivered unto me (as he affirmed, and I do beleeve him, for that I do know him to be a right honeÅ¿t man) from the mouth of the Groome, who with many vehement aÅ¿Å¿everations affirmed the thing to be moÅ¿t true, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e albeit I do Mathematically beleeve that the Groome delivered this hiÅ¿tory to the Ferrier, I muÅ¿t Å¿ay with the French man Ie croy en Dieu: But leaving this famous Groome to his rare cure, let us proceed to cures that are more probable, and now of Å¿uch cures as I have met with for this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. You Å¿hall participate.

Take of new Milke one pint, and of Sallet oyle halfe a pint, give him this bloud warme, which done, put downe his throate two new laid Egges,Pu â¢ Å¿ivenes or Å¿hortnes of breath. do thus three or foure mornings together, and then you Å¿hall perceive amendment, but for his Hay, let it be Å¿pinkled with water, and his Oates well wet in good Ale or Beere, and let his drinke bee altogether white water. â. This is very good Another.

Keepe your horÅ¿e three or foure daies to a Å¿pare Diet, before you do adminiÅ¿ter to him; then give him this drinke: Take Fenugreecke three ounces, of Bay-berries one ounce and a halfe, of the inner rind of Elder halfe a pound, the whites of Å¿ix new laid Egges, of browne-Sugar-Candy, water-CreÅ¿Å¿ets, Prim-roÅ¿e leaves, if they may bee had, red Mints, red Fennell, white or Hawethorne leaves, of each one pound, bray all theÅ¿e together in a Morter, (the Spices before beaten by themÅ¿elves) and when they be well powdred, put to the Ingredients Ale one quart, and Å¿o boyle it, and after Å¿traine it, and Å¿o give the liquor thereof to your HorÅ¿e to drinke bloud warme, and Å¿et him upon the Trench, and let him faÅ¿t Å¿ix houres after, then give him meat, and an houre after that, give him a warme MaÅ¿h, or white Water, and let him be kept to a Å¿trickt Dyet, and let his drinke be MaÅ¿hes or white Water, nine daies together after, and his Hay Å¿prinkled with Water, and his Provender wet in Ale or Beere; and thus you may cure him, â. With this medicine I have don very great cures. Another.

Take the guts of a Hedge-hogge, and hang them in an Oven till they be dry, then make them into powder, then take three or foure Å¿poonefuls of the powder, and put it into Å¿weet Wine, Ale, or Beere,
and Å¿o give it him to drinke, and the reÅ¿idue of the powder mix with the powder of AnniÅ¿eeds and Lycoris, and with Å¿weet Butter make it into Pils, and give him two or three of the Pils preÅ¿ently after his drench, and keepe him faÅ¿ting three or foure houres after, then you may give him Hay firÅ¿t Å¿prinkled with water, and after Provender or Bread wet or moiÅ¿tned in good Ale or Beere, putting alÅ¿o thereunto of this powder, and if you have not enough of this powder to Å¿erve, then; Take of Comin, Lycoris, Centaury, and AnniÅ¿eedes, of each like much, make theÅ¿e into fine powder, and give him thereof two Å¿poonfuls with his provender, and put alÅ¿o into his MaÅ¿hes and bread of the powder of Fennell-Å¿eede, mixed with the powder of brimÅ¿ton; this is very good for this malady, for I have Å¿een a horÅ¿e for a month together, to eate no other Provender but what hath been mixed with this powder, and alÅ¿o his MaÅ¿hes and white water, Å¿o made and compounded, and I have alÅ¿o brought him to drinke new Milke mingled with the powder of BrimÅ¿tone, by meanes whereof he hath been the Å¿ooner recovered, and made perfectly Å¿ound: X. and this is very good. Another.

FirÅ¿t let him bloud, then take of Å¿weet Wine one pint, and of the juyce of Hore-hound halfe a pound, of the Oyle of FrankincenÅ¿e halfe an ounce, of the powder of AnniÅ¿eed, Lycoris, and browne-Sugar-Candy of each halfe an ounce, let all theÅ¿e be made into fine powder, incorporated well together, and give it him once or twice in the weeke, for a while, and ride him not at all that day you drench him, but keepe him warme clothed, and well littered, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench foure houres after faÅ¿ting, then give him meat, and three houres after a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h: Putting thereinto of the powder of Lycoris, and Anni-Å¿eeds, of this I never made tryall, but it hath beene highly commended unto me for right good. Another.

Take of Barley, two gallons, Å¿teepe it in water two dayes, and Å¿hift the water every day, then take it cleane from the water wherein it was laÅ¿t Å¿teeped, and boyle it in three gallons of faire cleere water till it burÅ¿t, putting thereto of AnniÅ¿eeds, and Lycoris, and of RaiÅ¿ins of the Sunne Å¿toned of each one pound; and Å¿o let it boyle one houre, then take it from the fire, & Å¿train it very dry, and put unto the liquor of honey one pint, and of Sugar-Candy in powder Å¿ixe ounces, then put the liquor into a clean earthen Pot, or bottle keeping it cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and thereof give your horÅ¿e bloud warme, foure mornings together, the quantity of an Ale pint at a time, and let him eate the Barly if he will, howÅ¿oever put it not away; but heat Å¿ome of it every day: and being hot, put it into a bagge, and therewith perfume his head. â. This is very good, for I have often uÅ¿ed it. Another.
FirÅ¿t you muÅ¿t keep him to a very Å¿pace Dyet and inure him, five or Å¿ixe daies to eate his Oates Å¿teeped in Chamber-ly, and after that.

Take of Bayberries, Fennell, Cummin, Smallege, Fenugreak, Fearne-roots dryed, and Lycoris foure ounces in the whole, or, of each halfe an ounce, according to the bignes, age, Å¿trength, or Corpulency of the HorÅ¿e, make all theÅ¿e into powder, then take one part of the powder, and put unto it of freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter halfe a pound, and of new Milke halfe a pint, and Å¿o give it your horÅ¿e bloud warm: the next day do the like with the other halfe of the powder, and the third day let him not forth of the Stable, & give it him Å¿o long as he Å¿hall be in PhyÅ¿icke, for his drinke let it be white water made of Barly meale, but not with Wheate bran, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench, at leaÅ¿t two houres before his drench, and two houres after, then after that give him that which followeth.

Take of freÅ¿h Butter halfe a pound of good Agarick, night-Å¿hade, and CaÅ¿Å¿ia, of each one ounce, make all theÅ¿e into Pils (being firÅ¿t powdered, Å¿earced, and well mixed,) and adminiÅ¿ter them to your HorÅ¿e, then give him of white Wine halfe a pint, whereby the better to cauÅ¿e him to Å¿wallow Pils, the fift day let him reÅ¿t, and keepe him alwaies warme covered, and well littered, and if you do percive him to bee looÅ¿e in his body, and that hee hath purged well, let him reÅ¿t three or foure daies quiet, without doing any thing unto him, but if he hath not purged after one daies reÅ¿t only, then give him this drinke.

Take Mithridate, Diacartami, Senae of each two ounces, and of good white Wine one pint, mixe and brew all theÅ¿e together, and Å¿o give it him to drinke, and let him reÅ¿t three daies, giving him every one of theÅ¿e three dayes about noone of freÅ¿h Butter onely, halfe a pound, made into the manner of Pils, theÅ¿e three dayes being ended, you muÅ¿t adminiÅ¿ter unto him as followeth, and continue it weekely till he be perfectly cured.

Take of Agarick, Alloes, and of Diacartami of each one ounce, of Saffaron, Mirrh halfe an ounce, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and Å¿o make them into Pils with freÅ¿h Butter foure ounces, and give it to your HorÅ¿e, and then preÅ¿ently after give him of white Wine one pint, to waÅ¿h down the Pils. â. This is a moÅ¿t excellent cure, and by me often practiÅ¿ed. Another.

Take of white Wine one pint, of Sallet-oyle three quarts, of Alloes, & Lycoris, of each one ounce, of Colloquintida, of Agarick, & Mirrh, of each halfe an ounce, of AriÅ¿tolochia-rotunda three drams, of Night-Å¿hade one ounce, of Bay-berries three drammes, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, then take of Venice Turpentine two drams, of mel roÅ¿arum three ounces, mix all theÅ¿e together, and make it bloud warme, and Å¿o give it your HorÅ¿e to drinke with a horne, but give him no Oates in fifeteene daies, and let his drinke be white water, it will not bee good to give him much Hay, but Wheate flower, which Å¿hould not be much beaten or threÅ¿hed, and inÅ¿tead of his Oates give him Wheate bran, or Barly meale, and keepe him warme Å¿ix dayes
after let him bloud, in the Neck. â. Let him have this drink twice to wit, after the firÅ¿t drinke let him reÅ¿t one day, and then drench him againe, as you did before. Another. FirÅ¿t give him this purgation.

Take of freÅ¿h Butter halfe a pound, of Sene, and of Agarick, of each halfe an ounce, made into fine powder, of Alloes, and of loafe Sugar, both powdred of each one ounce, of Cordiall powder halfe an ounce, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder; then

Take common-hony foure ounces, mix and beat all theÅ¿e together, and Å¿o make them into Pils, and give them to your HorÅ¿e, but before you do, adminiÅ¿ter theÅ¿e Pils, he muÅ¿t Å¿tand upon the Trench two houres, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e two houres after; that day give him no Oates, and let his drinke be white water, and for your other directions you may give him his allowance of Oates all the other daies, but you muÅ¿t then wet them either in Å¿trong Ale or good Beere, and you may travell or give him exerciÅ¿e, but with moderation all thoÅ¿e other daies, and three times every day you Å¿hall give him three or foure handfuls of Wheate bran prepared, as before is Å¿hewed you in lib. 2. Chap. 9. Â§. 4. F. and thus continue him to this dyet at your pleaÅ¿ure. â. I have made tryall of this cure, and I doe know it to bee right good, for in a month or Å¿ix weekes I have brought a Gaunt and PurÅ¿ive HorÅ¿e to have a belly as round, freÅ¿h, & as cleer, as that of a Å¿ucking Colt, nor is this cure very chargable or coÅ¿tly; you muÅ¿t give him Wheate Å¿traw inÅ¿teed of Hay, only in the night you may give him Hay, provided it be Å¿prinkled with water.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a HorÅ¿e that is Prickt?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This Sorance hath many names; It is called Accloyed, Cloyd, Retraite, Prick't, &c. All which names, wee for the moÅ¿t part do fetch from the French, and all is but only plaine Prick't, which occurreth to the horÅ¿e eyther through the unskilfulnes or negligence of the Ferrier, in the driving of his Nayles, or in the weak-neÅ¿Å¿e of the Nayles of their evill pointing, or if a Nayle Å¿hould fortune to breake in the quick, and not be immediatly drawne f â¢ rth, it will in Å¿hort time feÅ¿ter in the fleÅ¿h, and Å¿oone after impoÅ¿tunate, and Å¿o in time beget a fowle Sore, which may aske much Art to Cure. The Å¿ignes be, that he will complaine when he treadeth upon Å¿tony or hard ground Å¿pecially, which Å¿o Å¿oone as you perceive, you have then iuÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to Å¿uÅ¿pect him to bee Prick't if hee were lately Å¿hod, wherefore the better to make tryall, your way muÅ¿t be to Å¿earch the foote whereof he complaineth, and you Å¿hall no Å¿ooner put your PinÅ¿ors, to the place, but that he will preÅ¿ently Å¿hrinke in his foote by reaÅ¿on that the nipping of the PinÅ¿ons doth paine him in the quick, or if you do but caÅ¿t water upon the foote whereon he halteth, in Å¿hort time
you Å¿hall perceive the hoofe to be Å¿ooner dry againÅ¿t the nayle or place which grieveth him, before any other part of the hoofe. Again, if you Å¿hall with your hammer knock upon the top of the clenches, when you do come to that nayle which grieveth him, he will lift up his foot; Å¿o likewiÅ¿e there be many other Å¿uch like Å¿ignes, whereby to diÅ¿cover the place prickt, Prickt. which be familiar to every common Smith, and therefore I Å¿hall not need to Å¿peake any more thereof. But let us now paÅ¿Å¿e to the Cure.

FirÅ¿t therefore after you have made tryall with your PinÅ¿ons, or otherwiÅ¿e, as before is inculcated; pluck off the Å¿hooe, and either with your drawing iron, or your Butter, Å¿earch the place to the very bottome, and if you can Å¿ee or feele any Å¿tub of any naile therein, leave not till you have got it away; and if the place be feÅ¿tered or matterative, wipe or waÅ¿h the wound very well, Å¿o as you may leave no part thereof behinde; then take of the tender tops of red Nettles, a little handfull, and Å¿tamp them in a morter, of Badgers greaÅ¿e two ounces, of red Wine Vineger, and of black Sope, of each two Å¿poonfuls, or for want of Badgers greaÅ¿e, take the like quantity of the fat of Bacon, which is Å¿alt: Beat all theÅ¿e together in a morter to an Vnguent, and Å¿top the wound well therewith, and after cover it with Hurds, and Å¿o tack on the Å¿hooe again, and do not remove it in two dayes, and when you dreÅ¿Å¿e it the Å¿econd time with the Å¿aid Vnguent, you may Å¿hooe him up, but drive no naile at that place, and Å¿o you may travell him, for he will be whole and Å¿ound. â This is an excellent Cure, and I have often uÅ¿ed the Å¿ame. Another:

Open the Å¿orance well as before is Å¿hewed you, and waÅ¿h it cleane with Vineger and Salt, and then lay unto it the tender tops of Elder buds beaten to a very Vnguent, if it be in Summer that thoÅ¿e buds or leaves may be had, if not, then in Winter, take inward rinde of Elder Å¿o pounded and brayed, and upon that, melt into the wound hard Tallow with a hot iron, and then lay upon it to keep it cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, Å¿ome Hurds, and Å¿o tack on the Å¿hooe, and in few times dreÅ¿Å¿ing, he will be whole. â With theÅ¿e two receits I have done many (whereof Å¿ome have been very great) Cures. Another.

FirÅ¿t open the place, cleanÅ¿e the Å¿ore well as before; then take red Nettles, and Bay Salt, of each like much: beat them unto a Å¿alve, then fill up the hole of the wound therewith; that done, lay upon it bolÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e Hurds, and melt upon the Hurds hard Tallow to keep wet, durt, and gravell from it, which would annoy the Å¿orance; then tack on the Å¿hooe, cauÅ¿ing the foot to be well pared, and drive no nayle neere the place, and after twice or thrice dreÅ¿Å¿ing, you may ride him, for then the more exerciÅ¿e he hath, the Å¿ooner will he be whole. â This is Å¿peciall good. Another:

Take off the Å¿hooe, and cauÅ¿e him to be well pared and Å¿earched as before, then take of Turpentine, brown Sugar Candy powdred, and white Ginger in powder alÅ¿o, of each the quantity of a Garden-Beane,
then melt them all together in an iron Å¿poon, and Å¿o poure it into the wound hot, and lay Hurds upon it, and after do as you are directed in the former Cures. â This alÅ¿o is very good. Another:

Search the place as before is Å¿hewed, then take Roch-Allum, and burn it, and make it into fine powder, and Å¿o fill the hole therewith, and lay a boulÅ¿ter of Hurds upon it, and after do as before you are taught. â And this is very good. Another:

Search the place as before is Å¿hewed, then take of Goats greaÅ¿e, or for want thereof, Deers-Å¿uet, or Sheeps-Å¿uet, of Turpentine, Sallet oyle, and new waxe, of each two ounces, melt them all together, and whilÅ¿t it is upon the fire, adde thereunto of ordinary Honey, three ounces, and of Sanguis Draconis one dram made into fine powder, incorporate all theÅ¿e together upon a gentle fire, and bring it to an oyntment, and of this you muÅ¿t poure a Å¿ufficient quantity into the wound warm, then put on Hurds, and do as before is preÅ¿cribed you, and let the foot be very well Å¿topped, and let him come in no wet if you can prevent the Å¿ame, neither let any nayle be driven neer the grieved place. â This is one of the beÅ¿t Receits of this kinde. Another:

Search the place as before, and cleanÅ¿e it with Salt and Vineger. Then take Salt, and make it into fine powder, then take foure times Å¿o much Turpentine, and boyle them together, and Å¿o poure it hot into the wound, and then put upon it the powder of BrimÅ¿tone diÅ¿Å¿olved in white Wine, and lay upon it Hurds, and then do as before is declared. â Very good. Another moÅ¿t Å¿ingular receit which the French do call a Retoire. FirÅ¿t Å¿earch and waÅ¿h as before. Then

Take of oyle de Bay four ounces, of Orpin, of Cantharides, and of Euforbium, of each two ounces, make them all into fine powder, and Å¿et it upon a gentle fire, Å¿tirring it, till you have brought it to an Vnguent, with which dreÅ¿Å¿e him as before is taught you.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat hold you good wherewith to perfume a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Perfumes are very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be applyed to horÅ¿es in Å¿ome caÅ¿es, viz. in Colds, Glanders, Rhumes, Murs, Pozes, Catars, &c. for the better expiation of which maladies, Perfumes are admirable helps, for Å¿ometimes they breake a cold, Å¿ometimes they diÅ¿Å¿ipate congealed humours, which do annoy the head, braine, and Å¿tomacke of the horÅ¿e, Å¿ometimes they expell and cauÅ¿e the horÅ¿e to vent, and to Å¿end away at his noÅ¿e and mouth, much filth and corruption, which doth Å¿top, clog, and peÅ¿ter his head and body, and Å¿ometimes they do ficcicate and dry up many bad humours, which are engendred in the head and braine, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e many vertues Perfumes have whereof very many of our Ferriers here in England are moÅ¿t ignorant: for did they truly know the nature of Perfumes,
and how rightly to apply them in their proper places, they might eaÅ¿ily do cures for which they Å¿hould be not a little admired. The ingredients and Å¿imples wherewith we uÅ¿ually perfume Å¿icke horÅ¿es, are many, as FrankincenÅ¿e, Storax, Benjamin, BrimÅ¿tone, Olibanum, &c. Å¿ometimes Hearbs, Roots, Graine or Corne, and Å¿uch like things, which are very much behoofefull for the cures of Å¿uch diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, for which they are frequently adminiÅ¿tred, as you Å¿hall finde in many of my Cures Å¿et you down at large: yet I will for example Å¿ake Å¿et you down two or three for your better Å¿atisfaction.

Perfume. 1 Take the beÅ¿t Olibanum, Storax, Benjamin, and FrankincenÅ¿e, of each one ounce, bruiÅ¿e all theÅ¿e, and mixe them well together, but not too Å¿mall, and when you are to perfume your HorÅ¿e, take all theÅ¿e, Å¿o well mixed, and putting thereof upon a Chafing-diÅ¿h and coles, cover the coles with a Tunnell, and Å¿o apply the Å¿mall end to one noÅ¿trill at once, and after to the other, to the end he may receive the Å¿moke or fume up into his head, and let him be thus perfumed a quarter of an houre together. â Another:

Perfume. 2 Take BrimÅ¿tone made into fine powder, and mixe with it freÅ¿h Butter and Sallet oyle as much as will Å¿uffice, let him not take this with fire, like as he did the former, but let it be conveyed into his noÅ¿e with a linnen clowt rowled up in the faÅ¿hion of a great Taynt, and this will bring forth much bad matter. â Another:

Perfume. 3 Take Penny-royall, Sage, and Wheate, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and boyle them in faire water till the Wheat do burÅ¿t, put the Wheat and Hearbs being firÅ¿t drayned from the water Å¿o hot as it commeth from the fire, and Å¿o faÅ¿ten the bag unto the head of the horÅ¿e, whereby he may receiue the fume up into his head. And thus you may perfume him at pleaÅ¿ure, and as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e. â The reÅ¿idue of perfumes, and the manner how to apply them, you Å¿hall finde among my Cures, and therefore it will be Å¿uperfluous for me to intreat any further of them.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is the beÅ¿t manner of adminiÅ¿tring Purgations to a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
As touching Purgations, I have Å¿poken before very largely, as well for inward purging, as for outward, and therefore what I Å¿hall Å¿ay more, is in effect but one and the Å¿ame thing: nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e for your further Å¿atisfaction, I will briefly deliver unto you, what can be Å¿aid of Purgations. Five wayes we have whereby to purge a horÅ¿e, viz. by Pils, Potions, CliÅ¿ters, SuppoÅ¿itories, and GraÅ¿Å¿e. Pils for the moÅ¿t part do purge and cleanÅ¿e the head and braine, by drawing the peccant humours down into the body, and Å¿o Å¿ending them forth with the excrements. Potions do free the Å¿tomack, belly and guts, from Å¿uch naughty humours which Glanders, Colds, and Surfets have engendred
in the body. CliÅ¿ters are of Å¿undry, and thoÅ¿e of different natures, Å¿ome to eaÅ¿e and app â¢ aÅ¿e griefes, Å¿ome to allay the biliouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿harpneÅ¿Å¿e of evill humours, Å¿ome to binde, and Å¿ome to looÅ¿en, and Å¿ome to heale as in caÅ¿e of Vlcers and old Sores within the body principally, and thoÅ¿e do alÅ¿o cleanÅ¿e the guts, refreÅ¿h the inward parts and Å¿pirits vitall, and prepare the body before hand for the receiving of purging pils or potions. SuppoÅ¿itories help the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es in the guts, being of nature and condition more gentle then CliÅ¿ters are, and may be applyed when CliÅ¿ters cannot. It therefore remaineth that the skill of the Ferrier be Å¿uch, as to be able judiciouÅ¿ly to underÅ¿tand the Å¿everall natures of every of theÅ¿e things, to know how to make choice of his ingredients and Å¿imples aptly, to underÅ¿tand how to compound them punctually and artificially, to diÅ¿cern rightly before he do adminiÅ¿ter what be the humours and maladies wherewith the creature is annoyed and viÅ¿ited, as whether (V. G.) it be Choler, Melancholy, Flegme, or Rhume, as alÅ¿o in what part of the body the humour offenÅ¿ive, is moÅ¿t predominant, and what Å¿imples will purge or remove thoÅ¿e evill humours, for it is requiÅ¿ite he be able to know right well, and ad unguem, the nature and property of every one of them in particular, by reaÅ¿on that Å¿ome are much more aÅ¿perous and violent then others be, yea many Å¿imples are Å¿trong poyÅ¿ons if they be not well prepared and corrected, and yet their qualities well weighed and compounded by true Art, and great good judgement, will work wonderfull effects. ThoÅ¿e Å¿imples which be Å¿trong, are Colloquintida, Scamony, Elebore, &c. the more gentle are Manna, CaÅ¿Å¿ia, Whey, Prunes, &c. But thoÅ¿e that be of the meane, or indifferent working, are Rubarb, Agarick, Aloes, Sene, &c. and this I am bold to intimate unto you, to the end you may the better underÅ¿tand their natures, vertues, and qualities, and come to know the more Å¿ecurely how to work when occaÅ¿ion Å¿hall be offered. The fift and laÅ¿t way of purging is by graÅ¿Å¿e, eÅ¿pecially if the horÅ¿e be Å¿urfetted, and hath been over-toyled the Winter before, for this muÅ¿t be done in the Summer time, when graÅ¿Å¿e is in its beÅ¿t heart; but that graÅ¿Å¿e which will Å¿coure and purge moÅ¿t, is a new mown meadow, for that will rake his guts very well, nor will he in Å¿uch a place gather fleÅ¿h; I do therefore counÅ¿ell you not to Å¿uffer him to remain in Å¿uch grounds above fourteen or fifteen dayes, and then take him forth, and put him into Å¿ome other paÅ¿ture, where the graÅ¿Å¿e hath not been touched with the Sithe, for then he will belly well, and in Å¿hort time recover much fleÅ¿h, and become fat and luÅ¿ty. This manner of Å¿cowring will cauÅ¿e him to empty himÅ¿elfe well, to purge, and Å¿end away all his bad humours and Å¿urfets, eaÅ¿e his limbs marvellouÅ¿ly well, do his legges and feet very much good, refine his corrupt bloud, and make him agill and full of Å¿pirit. To mow green Rye before it be eared, is alÅ¿o moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome, for it Å¿cowreth, cleanÅ¿eth, and cooleth the body very much; Å¿o doth the leaves of Sallowes, and of the Elme: but as touching
the adminiÅ¿tring of Scowrings and Purgations in the Stable, you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that Å¿ome skilfull Ferriers who have been far travelled in this MyÅ¿tery, have very diligently and Å¿tudiouÅ¿ly Å¿et you down many very good rudiments and inÅ¿tructions, wherewith to worke with all Å¿ecurity, whoÅ¿e obÅ¿ervations I do adviÅ¿e you punctually to obÅ¿erve: as firÅ¿t the Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the yeere are to be pondred: (V. G.) in winter, if his body be to be purged, it muÅ¿t be firÅ¿t prepared by Phlebothomy or Bloud-letting, together with artificiall dyet, therefore you Å¿hall adminiÅ¿ter eyther SuppoÅ¿itory, ClyÅ¿ter, Potion, or Pill, &c. You muÅ¿t keep him a day or two from hay, Å¿traw, or Å¿uch like hard-meats of digeÅ¿tion, for that thoÅ¿e things will be a great impediment to the working of phyÅ¿icke or medicine, and he muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be kept for a time from meate, becauÅ¿e emptineÅ¿Å¿e is a great helpe to phyÅ¿icall operation, otherwiÅ¿e it may happen (as it doth oftentimes) that more danger then good may accrew to the HorÅ¿e. Wherefore two or three dayes before you do intend to purge him, let his meate be eyther Wheate or Rye-bran prepared, like as before is taught you, and give him alÅ¿o either good bread made of purpoÅ¿e with Beanes, PeaÅ¿e, and Å¿ome Rye in it, or elÅ¿e Oates well Å¿ifted which muÅ¿t be dry and Å¿weet, and let his drinke be white water onely, and that morning you intend to give him a purge, let him befaÅ¿ting from either meate or drinke, but about Å¿ix or Å¿even a clock in the morning, give him this or Å¿ome other purge, which I have already taught you, or Å¿hall hereafter, which muÅ¿t be correÅ¿pondent unto the malady, for which you are to purge him, for one Purgation will not Å¿ort to every infirmity, but this purge is moÅ¿t profitable for the cauÅ¿es which I Å¿hall preÅ¿ently deliver unto you: And this it is, viz.

Purgation 1 Take of white Wine one pint, or of Å¿trong new Ale one quart, Å¿o much of the powder of Mechoacan of the beÅ¿t, and choyceÅ¿t as you may take up upon a Å¿hilling at foure times, give him this drinke warm with a horne, then Trot him but a matter of a Mile gently upon good ground, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warme, and let him Å¿tand upon the Trench till one of the clock, then give him a warme MaÅ¿h. This will purge and fetch away his filth and Å¿lime, and carry away his peccant humours, which Surfets have engended; halfe an houre after hee hath had his MaÅ¿h, give him Bread or elÅ¿e a few Oats mingled with wheat bran, and that little and oft for feare of cloying his Å¿tomacke, and at night give him white water, and Å¿o give him bread and hay Å¿prinkled with water for all night. â. This is an excellent Purge. Another.

Purgation 2 If it be in the Å¿pring prepare him as before, then for three or foure daies together give him, greene Rye Å¿o much as he will eate, and after feed him with Bread, or elÅ¿e Oates and Bran, like as you are told before, but inÅ¿teed of Hay, continue him thoÅ¿e nights with greene Rye, by reaÅ¿on his teeth will be on edge. â. This cooleth his body, and cleareth it from all Flegmatique and Rhumatique humours: as
for his bloud-letting, let that bee according as your judgement Å¿hall dictate unto you, and you may uÅ¿e this Å¿o long as you may Å¿ee cauÅ¿e â. If you doe perceive your HorÅ¿e to bee Å¿icke, Surfetted, full of colds, or otherwiÅ¿e ill diÅ¿poÅ¿ed, whether in Summer or in Winter, after you have opened a Veine, give him this Purge.

Take of Alloes, Siccatrina, made into fine powder two ounces, Purgation 3 and make it up into pils with freÅ¿h or Å¿weete Butter, and give it to your HorÅ¿e over night, he having beene kept faÅ¿ting the whole day before, and prepared alÅ¿o with the Dyet before preÅ¿cribed; and after he hath taken thoÅ¿e pils, give him either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water the next morning early, for that will cauÅ¿e his pils to work the more kindly, that day, and Å¿o let him faÅ¿t till night, during which time he will purge freely; then at night (he having Å¿tood upon the Trench all day,) give him white water, and after Oates and Branne, and then give him Hay Å¿prinkled with water for all night, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e he may not the firÅ¿t day purge, by reaÅ¿on that Å¿ome horÅ¿es are of Å¿o Å¿trong a ConÅ¿titution, as that PhyÅ¿icke will not eaÅ¿ily or Å¿oddenly worke, but then bee you confident it will the next day: you muÅ¿t therefore be carefull how you do order him. After his purging keep him Å¿till warm clothed and well littered, take him from the Trench, and put on his Coller-halter, give him Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water, and after feed him well, but by diÅ¿cretion, both with Hay, Oates, and Bran, and keepe him to white water two or three dayes after, or longer, if you Å¿hall Å¿o pleaÅ¿e, and when you give him cold water, let it bee with exerciÅ¿e. â. This I have often tryed. Another.

If your horÅ¿e bee newly taken from GraÅ¿Å¿e, and that you hold it needful his body be cleanÅ¿ed, & to free him of his many bad humous, which eyther his GraÅ¿Å¿e or former Surfets might bring: Then firÅ¿t Rake him, and adminiÅ¿ter unto him the ClyÅ¿ter preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. cap. 6. Â§. 8. letter C. ClyÅ¿ter 4. and the next day after give him this drinke.

Take of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Ale-wort one quart, of ordinary Honey a Purgation 4 quarter of a pint, of London Treacle two ounces, mixe and brew all together well, and Å¿o give it him bloud-warme: this done, keepe him upon the Trench warme clothed, and well littered Å¿ixe houres after, and let his drinke be a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, and let his Racke meate be Å¿weet Wheate-Å¿traw, Oates, and Branne. X. This both purgeth and comforteth. Another which muÅ¿t bee given the next day.

Purgation 6 Take of Gentian two ounces, Å¿lice it into very Å¿mall Å¿lices, then boyle it in Beer one quart, till it come to one pinte, and give it him bloud warm, but it will make him very Å¿ick for a Å¿hort time, but have no feare, for the potion will do him much good: let him faÅ¿t upon it four or five hours at leaÅ¿t, then give him a warm MaÅ¿h, or white water, and the next day give him this receit.

Take of Life-Honey, or for default thereof, ordinary Honey, and mingle it with his Oates that he is to eate, which muÅ¿t be mixed by rubbing the Oates and Honey betwixt your hands, Å¿o that the Honey may be very well mixed, let him eate his Oates thus mingled, untill you do finde him to be quite cured, which will be when he hath quite done running at the noÅ¿e. â This is one of the beÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t certain cordials that I know, neither have I made uÅ¿e of any Å¿o much as of this, for the time I have known the Å¿ame, for this diÅ¿perÅ¿eth all flegme and choler; it alÅ¿o purgeth the head and brain; it purifieth the bloud, it venteth the evill humours; it cauÅ¿eth good digeÅ¿tion, and freeth a HorÅ¿e from Glanders, Colds, Catars, Rhumes, Running at the noÅ¿e, and the like.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat cure have you for the quick or running Scab?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This is a noyÅ¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿e and infectious, a very formall mainge, and meer neighbour to the leproÅ¿ie, or Elephantique diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. It commeth by Å¿urfet taken by over-riding, when the bloud is over-hot; it doth putrifie and corrupt the bloud, and conÅ¿equently the fleÅ¿h, and at the laÅ¿t, breaketh forth into this malady, which we call the Quick-Å¿cab. Quick Å¿ â¢
And the reaÅ¿on why we do give it this name is, for that it runneth from one member of the horÅ¿e to the other, Å¿ometimes it will be in the neck, and at other times in the breaÅ¿t of the horÅ¿e, now in the maine, and then in the tayle, &c. The cure is,

FirÅ¿t Å¿h â¢ ve o â¢ clip away the hayre from that place viÅ¿ited, Å¿o cloÅ¿e as may be, and take off the Å¿curfe and Å¿cabs with Å¿ome old Curry-Comb, OyÅ¿ter-Å¿hell, or Å¿ome Å¿uch like thing. Then

Take faire cold water, with a linnen cloth, waÅ¿h and bathe the places very well, and lay the linnen cloth well wet upon the place, and Å¿o touch it no more in ten dayes, and if in that time the quick-Å¿cab do not heale, then dreÅ¿Å¿e it as before, and Å¿o a third time, or a fourth, or Å¿o oft as neceÅ¿Å¿ity requireth, till it be throughly healed. But remember that the day before you thus dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿orance after this manner, you take (to a reaÅ¿onable quantity) of bloud from the neck-vein. â This is an approved cure. Another as good as the former.

FirÅ¿t let him bloud, and then Å¿have or clip away the hayre cloÅ¿e, as in the former cure. Then take Mallowes, and MarÅ¿h-Mallowes, of each like much, and boyle them in faire water as much as will Å¿uffice, till the hearbs be Å¿oft, and with the hearbs and decoction, bathe and waÅ¿h the Å¿orance two or three dayes together warme; then take of common Honey one pinte, Coperas, Allum of glaÅ¿Å¿e, and Verdigrece, all made into fine powder, of each four ounces, Turpentine and Quick-Å¿ilver mortified, of each two ounces; boyle all theÅ¿e together with the Honey unto an Vnguent, and herewith dreÅ¿Å¿e him every day till he be whole. â This I Å¿ay is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure a Quitter-bone?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commeth to a horÅ¿e by Å¿ome hurt he hath taken in the foot, either by a pricke with a nayle in Å¿hooing, or by graveling, or by a Å¿tub, or the like, when it was not Å¿o well healed, that it impoÅ¿tumated, and Å¿o brake out above the cronet, which bred the malady; or elÅ¿e being neglected, it brake out above the hoofe before it was perceived. It is bred alÅ¿o Å¿ometimes by a hurt upon the hoofe, by a blow, or by Å¿triking one foot upon the other; and Å¿ometimes it commeth by evill humours which fall down into that place, and it groweth moÅ¿t uÅ¿ually upon the in-Å¿ide of the foot, where when it beginneth, it cauÅ¿eth a hard round Å¿welling upon the cronet of the hoofe, betwixt the heele and the quarter of the long talent, it begetteth an Vlcer at what time it doth beginne to impoÅ¿tumate, and it breaketh out above the Cronet, like as I Å¿aid before. The Å¿ignes I have already given you, for the place will be Å¿welled the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a haÅ¿le nut, and the horÅ¿e will hault right down. The cure is, Å¿o Å¿oon as it is eÅ¿pied, to open it above; if it doe begin to be Å¿oft, then

Take Auripigmentum made into fine powder, and infuÅ¿e it in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger can be gotten, forty eight houres, and then apply it to the Å¿ore, and it will Å¿o eat about the Quitter-bone, Quitter-bone. as that you may pluck it away with your finger or pliers, which Å¿o Å¿oon as the bone or griÅ¿tle is taken forth, you may heale up the wound with your Coperas water, and green oyntment preÅ¿cribed in lib. 2. cap. 10. Â§ 4. G. till it be whole, but he muÅ¿t not come into any wet during the time of the cure. â This is very good. Another:
FirÅ¿t cut the hoofe to the quicke, then

Take a Snake the greateÅ¿t you can get, and cut off his head and taile, and flea it, and Å¿o boyle it in water till the fleÅ¿h come from the bone, and then you may bring the fleÅ¿h to be a very oyntment; put of this into the Å¿orance down to the bottome, and this will kill the Quitter-bone, and dry up and heale it; but you muÅ¿t not Å¿uffer him to come into any wet, dirt, or gravell, during the time you have him in cure. â With this medicine I cured one horÅ¿e onely, for that I had no cauÅ¿e to uÅ¿e it to any other Å¿ince. Another:

Take of ArÅ¿enick the quantity of a Å¿mall beane, make it into powder, and put it into the hole of the Sorance, conveying it downe unto the bottome with your inÅ¿trument, and then Å¿top the mouth of the wound with Hurds, and binde it on with a cloth, and a rowler, that the HorÅ¿e may not bit it away; and Å¿o let it remaine foure and twenty houres: then open it, and if you Å¿hall perceive the wound to looke blacke within, it is a token that the ArÅ¿enick did its office in well working, then to allay the fire, and to reÅ¿tore the fleÅ¿h that is thereby
become mortified, taynt the hole with Turpentine and Hogs-greaÅ¿e molten together. Then take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, and Waxe, of each like much, and of Turpentine as much as of all the other three, and melt them and Å¿o make a PlaiÅ¿ter of Leather, with which you muÅ¿t cover the top of the Sorance, but firÅ¿t be Å¿ure to convey the aforeÅ¿aid taint to the bottome, and then lay on your PlaiÅ¿ter, and thus dreÅ¿Å¿e him dayly till you have gotten forth the Core, or Å¿harpe GriÅ¿tle, if the ArÅ¿enick have not eaten it out before, for if the GriÅ¿tle be in the bottome of the wound and uncovered, you may raiÅ¿e it with your Fingers or InÅ¿trument, and Å¿o pluck it quite away, for till that be out, the Sorance will not heale; that done, heale it up with your green oyntment, or elÅ¿e with this Vnguent.

Take of common-Hony, and of Verdegrece in fine powder, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, boyle this till it bee red, and therewith Taint the wound till it be whole, keeping evermore the mouth of the wound open, leaÅ¿t it heale up above before it be well healed at the bottome, neyther let your HorÅ¿e come into any wet, or go forth of the Stable untill he be throughly cured. â. Thus I have cured many Quitter-bones. Another.

Cut the place to the quick, then take Virgin-wax, Pitch of Greece, Galbanum, MaÅ¿tick, Sagapenum, Olibanum, and Sallet-oyle, of each one ounce, and of Deere or Sheeps-Å¿uet halfe a pound, melt theÅ¿e upon a Å¿oft fire, and incorporate them well together, and therewith Taint and dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ame till it be whole. â. This is alÅ¿o very good.

sp.speaker: Hippophilus.
sp.p: WHat is good to cure the Red-water?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This Red-water is that which iÅ¿Å¿ueth out of old incurable Vlcers, and Sores, which when you Å¿hall Å¿ee it to come forth of any wound, then be you aÅ¿Å¿ured that it is very hardly or Å¿eldome cured, till that Water be gotten away; for it is a Å¿igne that the wound is poyÅ¿oned with the Å¿aid Red-water: nor could I ever finde any cure for the Red water, Red waeter. but only one which a MariÅ¿hall of France taught me, which is this, viz.

Take of the root of the hearb called Emanuell, alias Bonus-Henricus, or good King-Henry, or All-good: boyle the Rootes thereof in water, and give it him drench-wiÅ¿e with a horne bloud-warme, and this will take away the Red-water and you may then cure the wound with your other Salves or Vnguents.

This I had never cauÅ¿e to make tryall off in England; but I have beene an Eye witneÅ¿Å¿e to two or three cures in this kinde, which the MariÅ¿hall of whom I had the Receipt did very Å¿ufficiently perfect. The French calleth this Malady, La Eu RouÅ¿e.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you make a ReÅ¿tringent charge?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This ReÅ¿tringent charge ReÅ¿tringent charge. is to be applyed to broken bones, or to bones diÅ¿located or out of joynt, being firÅ¿t Å¿et, as alÅ¿o take moiÅ¿t humours from weeping wounds, and Å¿o dry up bad humours which do preoccupate the body. I will commend unto you one onely receit which Å¿hall be Å¿peciall good.

Take of oyle de Bay, four ounces, Orpin, Cantharides, and Euphorbium, of each two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder and mixe them with your oyle de Bay very well, and therewith Charge the place greived. â. This is alÅ¿o very good to Charge the Å¿welling of a Back-Å¿inew Å¿praine.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a Ring-bone?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A Ring-bone commeth two waies, to wit, eyther by Nature, or by Accident; by Nature, when as either the Stallion or Mare have it, from whom the Colt is ingendred, whereby he taketh it as hereditary from them, and therefore (as I have formerly admoniÅ¿hed) I will diÅ¿Å¿wade you from breeding upon any Å¿uch HorÅ¿e or Mare that either had or have this malady. It commeth alÅ¿o accidentally by Å¿ome knock or blow given either by Å¿ome other HorÅ¿e, or by his Keeper or other perÅ¿on, and Å¿ometimes by Å¿ome evill humour, which through over-heats do fall down into the legges, and maketh its reÅ¿idence upon the top of the cronet. It beginneth firÅ¿t with a Å¿limy humour, which in time groweth to a hard griÅ¿tle; you Å¿hall know it, for that there will be a Å¿welling round about the cronet of the hoofe, adjoyning unto the lower part of the paÅ¿terne, and the hayre will Å¿tare, and be briÅ¿tly, and it will cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to hault. The cure is: firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the pla â¢â¢ , and Å¿have away the hayre, then

Take quick or unÅ¿laked Lime, newly taken from the Kill,Ring- â¢
which muÅ¿t be well burned, the beÅ¿t burned you may know by its lightneÅ¿Å¿e, make your lime into fine powder, and lay it upon the place Å¿welled all along of a good thickneÅ¿Å¿e, and binde upon it a linnen cloth made faÅ¿t about the foot, and Å¿o put the horÅ¿e into the water, and let him Å¿tand in the water a pretty while, then take him forth, and unbinde the foot, and he is infallibly cured, for the burning of the Lime doth kill the Ring-bone, even unto the very root thereof. â With this receit I have cured not Å¿o few as a hundred horÅ¿es at the leaÅ¿t, but when you are thus to dreÅ¿Å¿e your horÅ¿e, let him be brought cloÅ¿e to the water whereinto he is to be ridden, that Å¿o Å¿oon as you have applyed your Lime unto the Å¿orance, you may preÅ¿ently put him into the water. Another. FirÅ¿t, Å¿have away the hayre as before is adviÅ¿ed, then Å¿carifie the place.

Take then Cantharides halfe an ounce, Euphorbium, and oyle de Bay of each one ounce, your Cantharides and Euphorbium muÅ¿t be made into fine powder, and then boyled with your oyle de Bay, Å¿tirring it continually, that it run not over, then with two or three feathers lay it boyling-hot upon the Å¿orance good and thick, let him be dreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Å¿ame place where uÅ¿ually he Å¿tandeth in the Stable, and let him have no litter neer him, but tye up his head Å¿o as he may not reach the medicine with his mouth; but when the hayre do begin to grow again, give the fire to the Å¿orance, to wit, three or four Å¿traight lines right downwards, drawing the Å¿welling quite croÅ¿Å¿e, and let the edge of the iron be no thicker then the back of an ordinary knife, neither muÅ¿t you burn him any deeper then that the skin may look yellow. that done, apply to the place this charge.

Take of Pitch and RoÅ¿in, of each like much, let them be molten together, and whilÅ¿t it is hot, apply it to the place all along, from the one end of the Å¿welling to the other, & before it be cold, clap Flocks upon it, and about three dayes after, lay on more of the Å¿aid charge, and new Flocks again upon that charge, and Å¿o let it remain untill the Flokcs and charge fall off of its own accord. â This is alÅ¿o very good. Another. FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and Å¿have, and Å¿carrifie, as before, then

Excretion to cure.Take gray-Sope, and ArÅ¿nick pulverized, of each the quantity of a Wall-nut, which being very well mixed, Å¿pread it upon the Å¿orance Å¿o far as the Ring-bone goeth, and having thus Å¿pread it, apply upon it a few Hurds, and binde a cleane linnen cloth upon it to keep it on, neither let it be removed in four and twenty hours, then take it away, and Å¿tir not the asker or Å¿cab, but onely annoint it with freÅ¿h Butter, till it doe fall away of it Å¿elfe, and Å¿o heale it up with Å¿ome healing Å¿alve, whereof I have given you plenty. â This I have tryed, and have found to be very good. This medicine will cure a bone-Spaven, Splint, Curb, or any other bony excretion.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HAve you any way to recover and make Å¿ound a HorÅ¿e that is rotten?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Truely Sir, for any man to promiÅ¿e that, were great precipitation, onely thus far he may wade therein, as to give eaÅ¿e and help to a horÅ¿e that hath the rot, for it is one thing for a HorÅ¿e to be rotten, and another thing for him to have the rot. For a horÅ¿e to be rotten, is to have his inward parts waÅ¿ted and conÅ¿umed, or at leaÅ¿t Å¿o rotten, as never poÅ¿Å¿ibly to be recovered, to wit, his Liver, Lights, &c. But for a horÅ¿e to have the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called the rot, I doe finde the Å¿ame to be either a formall aropÅ¿ie, or elÅ¿e a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e Å¿o allied neerly thereunto, as not to be diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed eaÅ¿ily: as we Å¿ay, a Sheep is rotten, when his Liver is become foule and tainted; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e men doe eate the carkas, and doe averre it to be good meat, wherefore the Sheep is not rotten, but hath the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e called the rot. This malady commeth oft times to horÅ¿es unhandled, to wit, in their youth, whilÅ¿t they be yet Colts, which be bred, and do feed in Fenny-MarÅ¿h, and wet grounds, and Å¿ometimes it commeth to them after they have bin backed and ridden, when they haue too hard and violent riding, being yet but young, whereby the bloud is firÅ¿t enflamed, and after putrified and corrupted, begetting obÅ¿tructions in the Liver, and thoÅ¿e do cauÅ¿e putrefaction, and Å¿o knots and puÅ¿tils do engender in the Liver, which breedeth either a DropÅ¿ie, a Feltricke, or a rot. The Å¿ignes how to know this infirmity, are theÅ¿e: After his journeyes his hayre will Å¿tare his legges Å¿well and burn, and when you Å¿hall preÅ¿Å¿e the places Å¿woln with your finger, upon taking your finger away, there
will remaine a pit or dint, hee will forbeare his meat very much, and when he doth eate, it will be without any Å¿tomacke or appetite, he will pant much, lift and beat in the flanks many times, he will Å¿well under the belly, neither will he caÅ¿t his coat in Å¿eaÅ¿onable time, when other HorÅ¿es that be Å¿ound do, and he will be Å¿o faint of body, as that he will become lunt, and utterly to have loÅ¿t his mettle. TheÅ¿e and Å¿uch like be the Å¿ymptomes of this malady. Now come I to the cure.
Let him firÅ¿t bleed well under the taile, then

Take of Mares-milke two quarts, if the Å¿ame may be had, if not,Rot. the like quantity of the milke of a red Cow, then take a lump of Arement, then take a young horÅ¿e of or about the age of foure yeares, and of colour blacke, if it may be, if not, then of Å¿ome other colour, run and chafe him about that he may Å¿weate much, then with a Å¿poone, or with Å¿ome other Å¿uch like inÅ¿trument, rake the Å¿weate from his head, necke, breaÅ¿t, backe, Å¿ides, ribbes, buttocks, legges, and in a word, from each part or member of the Å¿aid horÅ¿e, and get off the Å¿weat Å¿o much as you can poÅ¿Å¿ibly, and Å¿o put your Arement and your Å¿weat into the milke, which all being well mixed, give him this by equall portions three mornings together, till he hath taken it all, and let him drinke none other drinke after it in Å¿ixe or Å¿even houres, but immediately after his drink, let him be led forth into Å¿ome paÅ¿ture where other horÅ¿es be, the better to cauÅ¿e him to neeÅ¿e, Å¿tale, dung, and empty himÅ¿elfe; for it is very wholeÅ¿ome for him Å¿o to doe, before he either eate or drink. Having thus done, Å¿et him up warm and well littered, and if the Å¿eaÅ¿on do Å¿erve, give him of the green blades of Rye, if not, give him Barly Å¿teeped in milk three dayes, but renewed every day once. Then after every of theÅ¿e drinks, if you feele him cold in the paÅ¿terne joynts, or that he trippeth or Å¿tumbleth as you leade him in your hand, meddle no further with him, for that he is paÅ¿t cure, otherwiÅ¿e for nine dayes together, after morning and evening give him white water onely, unleÅ¿Å¿e now and then a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, and Å¿ometimes give him milke with his white water, if the HorÅ¿e be not above nine years old, and Å¿o you may cure him: but if he be elder, this may prolong his life, whereby he may do the more Å¿ervice. This I never did experience, but a Noble Knight, and a very friend told me, that he hath thus recovered Å¿undry HorÅ¿es which have beene viÅ¿ited with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e.

p.hi: WHat good Salves have you wherewith to heale up Å¿ores and wounds?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I have many, according as I have before Å¿hewed you, but yet I will give you many more, the greateÅ¿t number of which I have tryed, and I am able to commend them unto you for very good, and thoÅ¿e not SalvesSalve. onely, but Vnguents, Powders, and Waters, which be moÅ¿t Å¿overaign.

Take of PeroÅ¿en, and of hard RoÅ¿in, of each one pound, of FrankincenÅ¿e, Virgin-Wax, or for want thereof new Waxe and Sheeps Å¿uet, of each halfe a pound, of old tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e one pound and a quarter, boyle the Gummes and Waxe in white Wine halfe a pint, and then put unto it your Sheeps tallow and Hogs greaÅ¿e, and when all is well molten and incorporated, Å¿traine it, and whilÅ¿t it is yet hot, put in of Venice Turpentine one ounce, and Å¿o work all well together, and when it is cold, poure in the liquor from the Å¿alve, which put up into a cleane galley pot, or other cleane veÅ¿Å¿ell for your uÅ¿e. â This is a moÅ¿t Å¿overaign Treate or Salve wherewith to heale any wound (that is not come to an Vlcer) and Å¿o dry it up. Another moÅ¿t excellent powder.Powder.

Take unÅ¿laked Lime, the dry duÅ¿t of Tanners Oken Bark and old Å¿hooe Å¿oles burned to a cole, of each like much, make theÅ¿e into fine powder, and mixe them well, and keep it in a cleane boxe or glaÅ¿Å¿e for your uÅ¿e. â This powder healeth the buds or knots of the Farcin, after they be broken, and it skinneth them, and if they be firÅ¿t waÅ¿hed with the juyce of Vervine and Å¿trong Vineger mingled together, and then this powder being caÅ¿t upon them, will (I Å¿ay) heale and skin them. It alÅ¿o healeth and skinneth all other Å¿ores. Another:

Oyntment.Take tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, Verdigrece in fine powder one penny worth, boyle theÅ¿e upon the fire two or three walms, then take it off, and put unto it of Venice Turpentine halfe an ounce, and Å¿tirre it well together till it be cold. â This Vnguent will heale any wound or Å¿ore in a HorÅ¿e. Another:

Oyntment.Take of Roch-Allum a good quantity, and burn it, and as much bay Salt, and burn that alÅ¿o, make both theÅ¿e together into fine powder, then take of common Honey, and of Å¿weet Butter, of each like much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate the Allum and Salt with the
Honey and Butter by melting them over a gentle fire, and with a taint or plaiÅ¿ter apply it. â And this cureth any foule Å¿ore. This I have often tryed. Another:

Take of faire waterWater. one pinte, and put into it of green Coperas, and of bay Salt, of each the quantity of a good haÅ¿le nut, both made into very fine powder; let theÅ¿e boyle a little upon the fire. With this waÅ¿h any Å¿ore before you do apply your Salves, Vnguents, or Powders. â This is a right good water. Another:

Take of common Honey two ounces, Roch-Allum, Verdigrece, and Vineger, of each one ounce, make your Allum and Verdigrece into very fine powder, then take of Sublimate finely powdred, two ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e a walme or two on the fire; this laid on a Spatula plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e once a day, or if the wounds be deep, with a taint, cureth both Å¿peedily and Å¿oundly; but before you dreÅ¿Å¿e him with this Salve, let the Sore be well waÅ¿hed and injected with the water laÅ¿t above mentioned, made of faire water, Coperas, and bay Salt. â This is a moÅ¿t approved cure, and good beyond all peradventure, for it cureth not onely Å¿ores and wounds in any part in the body of the HorÅ¿e, but in the foot which way Å¿oever it may happen, and it cleanÅ¿eth any wound from dead or proud fleÅ¿h. Another:
