Take the buds or tendreÅ¿t tops of the leaves of Elder, one handfull, and firÅ¿t Å¿hred, and after pound them very well, till you bring them to a perfect Salve,Salve. and apply this to the Å¿ore, binding a cloth upon it to keep it from falling off. â This will cure any old or new Å¿ore whatÅ¿oever in any part of the body, as galled backs, Spurregals, gravelling, prickt, or accloyed, the wound being dreÅ¿Å¿ed herewith every day once, it will cure any FiÅ¿tula if the juyce thereof be injected to the bottome. With this one thing alone I have done cures which very good Ferriers could not cure. Another:

Take common Honey and Verdigrece finely pulverized,Aegyptiacum. of each as much as will Å¿uffice, boyle them together till the medicine waxe red, and this will heale up any old or green Å¿ore in Å¿hort Å¿pace. â This is alÅ¿o very good. Another:

Take the white of a new laid Egge,Oyntment. and Sallet oyle as much as will Å¿uffice, and beat them well together, and before you do apply it unto the wound, poure into the wound burnt Butter, and then lay on your medicine with Hurds plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, and this will cure any green wound. â This is very good. And thus much for Å¿ores.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good for a HorÅ¿e that hath gotten wrench in his Å¿houlder?Shoulder wrench.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If you do finde that the griefe be in the Å¿houlder, and that you do know it to be a wrench, make this charge, and charge the grieved Å¿houlder therewith.

Take Wheate-meale two pound, and allay it with red Wine in a Pipkin or PoÅ¿tnet, as if you would make thereof a paÅ¿te, then take of Bolearmoniack made into fine powder halfe a pound, of ordinary Honey one pound, boyle all theÅ¿e together, and adde thereunto in the boyling, of Pitch halfe a pound, and Å¿o keep it continually Å¿tirring untill your Pitch be throughly molten, but before you take it from the fire, put into it of ordinary Turpentine halfe a pound, of Comin, oyle de Bay, Dialthea, Sanguis Draconis, Bay-berries, Fenugrick, LinÅ¿eed flowre, of each, two ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, then take of the oyle of AÅ¿pick one ounce, boyle and mixe all theÅ¿e very well together, that done, chargeCharge. the grieved Å¿houlder all over very well, even down the knees. â This charge is moÅ¿t Å¿overaign for any wrench or Å¿traine in the Å¿houlder, knees, or hips; it alÅ¿o cureth Kibes, Scratches, and all Å¿uch like Å¿orances, it is alÅ¿o moÅ¿t excellent to comfort the Å¿inewes offended or hurt; it is very good for a back-Å¿inew-Å¿praine, it draweth away all bad humours, and abateth Å¿wellings. X I have often made uÅ¿e of this receit, but if it be a Å¿houlder-pight, or joynt-diÅ¿located, then thus he is to be cured, viz.

Shoulders diÅ¿located.FirÅ¿t caÅ¿t him and lay him upon that Å¿ide which is not hurt, then faÅ¿ten with a cord the foot of the Å¿ame legge all along a board, and Å¿o faÅ¿ten the foot to Å¿ome tree or poÅ¿t which muÅ¿t be Å¿ome two or three paces diÅ¿tant from the horÅ¿e, and neer to the ground, and let one Å¿tand at the middle of the boord with a Å¿tick to turn it eaÅ¿ily and by degrees in the middle thereof, and whilÅ¿t that is in doing, let another with a paile of cold water, rub, waÅ¿h, and bathe the grieved place with his hand or foot, and that very hard, and in Å¿o doing, he muÅ¿t take up the member grieved, which he muÅ¿t chafe from the very top to the farther end of the legge, and by thus doing you Å¿hall put in the bone which was out, into its right place, and after this is done, you muÅ¿t raiÅ¿e him as gently as may be, and when he is up, let him bloud in the breaÅ¿t-veine on that Å¿ide the griefe lyeth, putting a Patten-Å¿hooe upon the contrary foot, and let his forefeet be tramelled fifteen dayes after at the leaÅ¿t, to hinder him from lying down, and charge the grieved Å¿houlder daily with a reÅ¿tringent charge, and look upon the grieved member every two or three dayes, by the Å¿pace of fifteene dayes; after that you have thus Å¿et the Å¿ame, neither let him be removed out of his place during that time, and after Å¿wim him, and apply
bathes unto the Å¿houlder made of good hearbs, Å¿uch as I have preÅ¿cribed you in the Section of bathes, and laÅ¿tly annoint him with this Vnguent:

Take oyle de Bay, the oyle de Petra, oyle de Spike, and Nervall, of each like much: and thus ordering him, he will be Å¿ound and well again. â I have proved this upon Å¿ixe horÅ¿es, and cured them all. Another:

If the Å¿houlder be either Å¿trained or diÅ¿located, it were uery good to Å¿wimme him, then take bloud from the breaÅ¿t veyne on that Å¿ide the griefe lyeth, then tramell his fore-feet that he do not lye down, and Å¿o let him remaine three weeks, then anoynt the member grieved with Sallet oyle onely, and the firÅ¿t time you Å¿hall take but of Sallet oyle halfe a pound, which you muÅ¿t rub in againÅ¿t the hayre very hard, both upon the Å¿houlder and the breaÅ¿t, by the Å¿pace of halfe an houre, the next day after you Å¿hall likewiÅ¿e rub and chafe the Å¿houlder and breaÅ¿t, by the Å¿pace of halfe an houre more;Shoulders Å¿trained. without applying any thing unto them, and Å¿o continue rubbing and chafing him for the Å¿pace of eight or ten dayes together; as for the Sallet oyle, you muÅ¿t take four ounces thereof every third day, wherewith to chafe, rub, and anoynt the Å¿houlder, and the other two dayes betwixt, you muÅ¿t not rub and chafe it with any oyle at all, and at the end of eight or ten dayes, his Å¿houlder will be Å¿welled down to the very knee, then take off the oyle, and apply a reÅ¿tringent charge to the part grieved and Å¿welled, and adde to it of ordinary Turpentine halfe a pound, to cauÅ¿e the charge to remaine on the better, and the next day, and all other dayes after in Å¿tead of this reÅ¿tringent charge,

Take Vineger and bathe the Å¿houlder therewith upon the Å¿aid charge, and by degrees the haire will fall away, and when the Å¿welling is aÅ¿Å¿waged, Å¿end your horÅ¿e in the beginning to the water, upon a foot pace, and he will be cured; this receit certainly is very good, and not coÅ¿tly; but I did never make tryall thereof, albeit it was highly recommended unto me by a famous French MariÅ¿hall, who averred that he hath recovered very many horÅ¿es therewith, but for a horÅ¿e that hath gotten a wrench or Å¿lip, the onely remedy is to put in a French rowell, and then to blow him, and put on a Patten Å¿hooe, and let his Keeper turne the rowell every day once, as well to cauÅ¿e the putrefaction the better to iÅ¿Å¿ue forth from growing to the fleÅ¿h, and after twenty dayes you may take it forth at your pleaÅ¿ure. â This is good for a new Å¿traine.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVEre it not much better HippoÅ¿erus, that after you have thus rowelled and blown him, and Å¿et a Patten-Å¿hooe upon the contrary foot, that he were turned forth to graÅ¿Å¿e, for that the horÅ¿e keeping himÅ¿elfe in continuall agitation and motion, as hee feedeth in the paÅ¿ture, the humour may the better deÅ¿cend, and Å¿o iÅ¿Å¿ue forth, whereby he may Å¿ooner be cured?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, I anÅ¿wer negatively to your aÅ¿Å¿ertion, for by his being abroad, the winde will take the wound, and cauÅ¿e him to Å¿well, and thereby doe the horÅ¿e more harme then you are aware of: Å¿econdly I Å¿ay, if when he is abroad there might happen to fall raine, that the place rowelled might take wet and cold,Shoulder rowelled. it might thereby endanger a Gangrene, and therewith endanger the life of your HorÅ¿e, for the like I my Å¿elfe have done; but having rowelled your horÅ¿e, and that you be to blow him, if you uÅ¿e to take Tobacco, then forbeare to blow him your Å¿elfe, but let Å¿ome other who taketh not any, to blow him, for the very Å¿cent and Å¿teame of Tobacco will cauÅ¿e your HorÅ¿e to Å¿well both in the Å¿houlder, and all along under his belly, even to the Å¿heath and Å¿tones moÅ¿t violently, and the effect thereof I have very often Å¿een. â With rowelling I have cured very many horÅ¿es, if the Å¿traine be newly taken, but if the horÅ¿e have gotten hurt on his Å¿houlder, that the skin be broken,Shoulder the skin broken. then firÅ¿t cut away all the dead and bad fleÅ¿h if there be any, then

Take the white of an Egge, and beat it, and lay it upon a few Hurds plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, but firÅ¿t waÅ¿h the wound with a little white Wine made bloud warme, and then apply your plaiÅ¿ter to the Å¿orance, and then anoynt the Å¿houlder round about the Å¿orance with Å¿weet Butter: do this every day once, and it will be whole. â This I have often tryed. Another:
Take your lancet or fleame, and make a little hole in the skin upon the pitch of the Å¿houlder, and blow the place with a quill, that the skin may ariÅ¿e from the fleÅ¿h, then

Take of Å¿tale Vrine two quarts, and boyle it to a moyety, then Å¿traine it, and put thereto of Å¿weet Butter, and of tried Hogs greaÅ¿e, of each halfe a pound, then take of Mallowes, TanÅ¿ey, Vervine, red Nettles, Sothernwood, and of the tender tops of broome, of each halfe a handfull, chop all theÅ¿e together, and boyle them in the Vrine till they be Å¿oft, and then firÅ¿t bathe the Å¿houlder with the decoction or Vrine, and after anoynt the Å¿houlder with the hearbs, being firÅ¿t m â¢ de into an Vnguent, uÅ¿ing thus to doe every day once or twice till it be well; but during this cure, the horÅ¿e muÅ¿t be kept within doores, and in a few dayes he will goe Å¿ound againe. â This is very good, for I have often tryed it. Another:

If your horÅ¿e have any griefe in his Å¿houlder, firÅ¿t put into it a
French rowell, and blow it, and put a patten-Å¿hooe upon the contrary foot, then apply this charge unto the place: take of Pitch and RoÅ¿in, of each one pound, and of Tarre halfe a pinte, melt them upon the fire, and before it be cold, charge the Å¿houlder therewith, and clap Flaxe upon it, and let the charge lye on till it fall away of it Å¿elfe, and once a day turn the rowell for fifteen dayes together at leaÅ¿t, then take out the rowell, and heale up the wound, (then if the Å¿eaÅ¿on be fit for it) turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e with his patten-Å¿hooe on, and let him runne three or foure moneths, and he will goe upright againe. â This is very good, Another,
FirÅ¿t Å¿wimme him, (as you may doe well to doe for any griefe in the Å¿houlder or hips) and before you do rowell him, apply unto the grieved member this bathe and unguent.

Take Pimpernell an arme full, Bay berries, PrimroÅ¿e leaves, Camomil, Crow-foot, Mallowes, Fennell, RoÅ¿emary, and fine upland Hay (which was cut about MidÅ¿ummer) of each like much, and of each a good quantity, put all theÅ¿e into a Leade or Cauldron, and there let it Å¿teep in faire water two dayes and two nights, then boile it untill the hearbs be Å¿oft, and bathe your HorÅ¿e therewith every day once good and warm, and binde of theÅ¿e hearbs with the Hay to the Å¿houlder or place grieved, in what place or joynt Å¿oever it be, uÅ¿e this bathe foure dayes, and at the expiration of foure dayes, let him bloud in the breaÅ¿t, on that Å¿ide the griefe lyeth, if the griefe be in the Å¿houlder, but if in the knee or fetlock joynt, then let him bloud in the paÅ¿tern veyne, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e if the paine be behinde, and let him bleed well, but if you have not skill or knowledge enough to open any of theÅ¿e veynes, then pare the foot very cloÅ¿e, and open the toe veyne, and there let him bleed well; after this his foure daies bathing, when he is dry againe, anoynt the grieved member with this Vnguent.

Take Petroleum, Nervall, Patch or piece greaÅ¿e, and oyle of Wormes, of each like much, and anoynt him herewith by the Å¿pace of halfe an houre, and then for halfe an houre after, trot him in your hand in a faire Å¿oft ground, then bring him into the Stable, and obÅ¿erve if any of the Å¿aid oyntment be come forth, or doth Å¿tick to his hayre, which if it doe, let it be rubbed and chafed in againe; alÅ¿o bathe him morning and evening, and at noon anoynt him, and trot him as before is adviÅ¿ed, but at night onely binde or rope on the hearbs, and this is the cure. VÅ¿e this but foure dayes onely, for feare of making his joynts too Å¿upple and weake (and if this help not, as I do beleeve it will) then rowell him, this I never tryed, but my opininn is that it is a very good receit. Another.

If your HorÅ¿e be Å¿houlder Å¿plat, Shoulder Å¿plat. then put upon him a paire of Å¿hort paÅ¿ternes upon his fore-feet, then take of Dialthea one ounce, of Sallet oyle one pinte, of oyle de Bay halfe a pinte, of freÅ¿h Butter halfe a pound, melt all theÅ¿e together in a Pipkin, and anoynt the grieved
place round about (viz.) as well all over the Å¿houlder, as the breaÅ¿t, and betwixt the fore-legs, upon and about the brisket, and in two or three houres after, all the Å¿houlder will be Å¿welled, then with your fleame Å¿trike the Å¿welling in very many places, that the corruption may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth, and continue to anoynt him with the Å¿aid ointment, and if it gather to a head (as it is likely it will) when it is ripe enough, open it, where you doe finde it to be Å¿ofteÅ¿t, and then heale it up with your green oyntment Å¿o often commended unto you, and thus your horÅ¿e will goe Å¿ound againe. â This I have often tryed, and let this Å¿uffice for this malady.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: YOu have delivered your Å¿elfe very well, but yet HippoÅ¿erus (but yet) I am to Å¿eeke to know and underÅ¿tand when I Å¿ee a horÅ¿e doth hault or complaine, where the griefe lyeth, being a thing moÅ¿t needfull for a Gentleman to be very perfect in, but more eÅ¿pecially for him that is a Ferrier, who is to cure and Å¿et upright the HorÅ¿e that is lame.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
You Å¿peake pure truth Sir, and therefore I will give you Å¿uch aÅ¿Å¿ured rudiments, whereby you Å¿hall not at any time faile in the diÅ¿covery of the leaÅ¿t lameneÅ¿Å¿e that Å¿hall proffer it Å¿elfe to your eye, if you will be pleaÅ¿ed diligently to obÅ¿erve my documents, you muÅ¿t therefore firÅ¿t underÅ¿tand,Rules how to know where a horÅ¿e halteth either before or behinde. that if he do hault before, his griefe muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be, either in the Å¿houlder, or in the knee, or in the Å¿hanke, or in the paÅ¿terne, or in the foot; if it be in the Å¿houlder, it muÅ¿t be either towards the withers, or in the pitch of the Å¿houlder, or in the elbow; if in any of theÅ¿e places of the Å¿houlder, you may know it, in that he will a little draw his legge after him, and not handle it Å¿o nimbly and dexterouÅ¿ly as he doth the other; if he caÅ¿t his legge more outward then he doth the other, it is a manifeÅ¿t Å¿igne that he is lame, and that the griefe lyeth in his Å¿houlder, and for the better tryall thereof, let your man but turn him Å¿hort on either hand, and in that Å¿houlder where the lameneÅ¿Å¿e is, you Å¿hall perceive him to complaine, and to yeeld, for he will either favour that legge, or trip in the turning: you may alÅ¿o finde his lameneÅ¿Å¿e by his Å¿tanding in the Å¿table, for there he will hold forwards his lame legge more then the other, but yet you come not to underÅ¿tand in what part of the Å¿houlder the griefe lyeth; wherefore take for an infallible rule, that if he doe complaine more when a man is upon his backe, then otherwiÅ¿e, when he is from his back, then be you confident that the griefe lyeth in the withers, and gripe him hard, and you Å¿hall perceive him to Å¿hrinke, and perhaps offer to bite if the HorÅ¿e doe tread thicke and Å¿hort before, then is the griefe upon the pitch of the Å¿houlder cloÅ¿e to the breaÅ¿t, which you may eaÅ¿ily finde by Å¿etting your thumb hard to the place, and by thruÅ¿ting him with it as if you would have him to goe back, whereat
he will Å¿hrinke, and put back his legge; foot, and body; if the griefe be in the elbow, you Å¿hall diÅ¿cover it by pinching him with your fore-finger and thumb, good and hard upon that place, at the doing whereof you Å¿hall perceive him to Å¿hrinke and hold up his legge, and to offer to bite; and theÅ¿e be all the griefes which doe lye in the Å¿houlders of the HorÅ¿e, which not being viÅ¿ible, you Å¿hall thus diÅ¿cover them, as touching thoÅ¿e griefes which lye lower, they muÅ¿t be either in the knee, in the Å¿hin, in the paÅ¿terne, or in the foot. If it be in the knee, When in t â¢ knee. you Å¿hall finde it by his Å¿tiffe going, for he will not bend it Å¿o actively as he doth the other; if it be in the Å¿hanke or Å¿hin-bone, you may both Å¿ee and feele the Å¿ame, it being then a backe Å¿inew Å¿praine, Å¿plent,When in th â¢ Å¿hanke. or Å¿ome Å¿uch like Å¿orance or anoyance, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e if it be in the bending of the knee, then it is a malender, which is alÅ¿o moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ily deÅ¿cryed; if it be in the paÅ¿tern or joynt, When in th â¢ paÅ¿terne. then may you know it by his not bending it Å¿o well as the other; beÅ¿ides if you put your hand upon the place, you Å¿hall finde it to be very hot, and to burn much: firÅ¿t if it be in the foot, it muÅ¿t then be either in the cronet, or in the Å¿ole; if in the cronet, it is then probable it came by Å¿ome Å¿traine or wrench, if in the heele, then it came by Å¿ome over-reach, or elÅ¿e by Å¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿e in or about the FruÅ¿h; if in the Å¿ole, then it came by Å¿ome pricke, accloy, retoire, cannel nayle, Å¿tub, Å¿tone, or gravell. And thus have I diÅ¿covered unto you all the Å¿everall Å¿orts which cauÅ¿eth a HorÅ¿e to hault before, and how to know and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the places grieved, together with the occaÅ¿ion of every particular griefe. It followeth that we diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e yet further the meanes how to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h an old griefe, from a new taken Å¿traine or hurt, which without an exact Å¿crutiny, cannot eaÅ¿ily be diÅ¿covered, for oft times a horÅ¿e hath gotten a Å¿traine, for which he is preÅ¿ently turned to graÅ¿Å¿e, where peradventure he runs the whole Summer, and Å¿o by that meanes Å¿eemeth to goe upright, till he be heated and Å¿trained anew, and then will it appeare again, howbeit upon his firÅ¿t riding it may not appeare: you have therefore three wayes whereby to finde our his lameneÅ¿Å¿e,Three waies to finde out lameneÅ¿Å¿e. in what joynt, limb, or member of the body Å¿oever it lyeth. 1 The firÅ¿t way is to take him out of the Stable, and to cauÅ¿e him to be turned at the halters end on either hand Å¿uddenly and Å¿wiftly upon as hard a way as you can pick out, and if he have any ache, wrench, or griefe in his fore-parts, it will appeare, for that when he Å¿hall turne upon that hand in which the griefe is, you Å¿hall perceive him to favour that legge, and Å¿o likewiÅ¿e run both towards you and from you, eÅ¿pecially down a little yeelding hill, and if he have any â¢â¢ perfection, he will Å¿oon Å¿hew it, for that he will favour that legge
â¢ herein the griefe reÅ¿ideth; but if you be not able to finde out his lameneÅ¿Å¿e this way. 2 Then your Å¿econd way muÅ¿t be for you to take his backe, and to ride him out a good round trot or pace a full houre, or Å¿o long untill Å¿uch time as you have throughly heat him, then Å¿et him up, and let him Å¿tand quiet two or three houres, and then either take his backe againe, or
elÅ¿e turne him at the halters end as before, and by thus doing, you may diÅ¿cover the leaÅ¿t griefe that may be in him, eÅ¿pecially when you thus Å¿tir him, if it be done upon Å¿tony or hard ground, for then he can neither will or chooÅ¿e, but either to favour the member grieved, or elÅ¿e to hault right downe. 3 A third way we have, and that is, to know whether the griefe doth proceed from a hot or cold cauÅ¿e, for if it proceed from a hot cauÅ¿e, then will the HorÅ¿e hault moÅ¿t, when he is hot, and in the middeÅ¿t of his travell; but if it be of a cold cauÅ¿e, then will he hault leaÅ¿t whilÅ¿t he is hot and moÅ¿t ridden and travelled, and moÅ¿t at his firÅ¿t Å¿etting forth, whilÅ¿t he is cold; and thus much for lameneÅ¿Å¿e and halting before.

Now you perceiving your horÅ¿e to hault, and that you be aÅ¿Å¿ured that his lameneÅ¿Å¿e is not before, then may you be confident it muÅ¿t be behinde, which being Å¿o, the griefe muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ity be either in the foot, or in the nether joynt, in the paÅ¿terne, or in the legge, in the hamme, or in the hough, in the Å¿tifling place, or joynt, or in the hip. If the griefe be either in the legge, paÅ¿terne, or foot, if you doe obÅ¿erve him well, you Å¿hall underÅ¿tand it by the very Å¿ame Å¿ignes which I have inculcated already in the legges, paÅ¿ternes, or feet, for that the Å¿ignes be the very Å¿ame; if it be in the bending of the hamme, you may then eaÅ¿ily know it to be a plaine Selander. If it be in the hough, then is it either a bone or bloud-Spaven, which is eaÅ¿ily enough to be diÅ¿cerned, or elÅ¿e it muÅ¿t come of Å¿ome blow, wrench, or Å¿traine, neither then will the Å¿welling eaÅ¿ily appeare, but you Å¿hall perceive it either by the Å¿tifneÅ¿Å¿e of the joynt, or elÅ¿e you Å¿hall finde the place to be hot and burning if the paine Å¿hall lye in the Å¿tifling place, it is manifeÅ¿tly diÅ¿covered by his gate, for then you may perceive him in his going, to caÅ¿t the Å¿tifle ioynt outward, and you may plainely Å¿ee the bone on the inÅ¿ide to be bigger then the other, beÅ¿ides, his toe will hardly touch the ground. If it be in the Hip, which is upon the Å¿ide of the buttock, and if the hurt or wrench be newly taken, you Å¿hall eaÅ¿ily know it, in that the HorÅ¿e will goe Å¿ide-long like a Crab, not being able Å¿o well to follow with the grieved legge as he can doe with the other. NotwithÅ¿tanding if it be a hurt taken, long before, you Å¿hall perceive the Hip to be falne lower then the other, and the fleÅ¿h to Å¿hrinke, you may alÅ¿o perceive it the better, as by going up a hill, or upon yeelding ground, by reaÅ¿on he cannot goe with Å¿o great eaÅ¿e, as when he goeth upon even or plaine ground. But the better to diÅ¿cover in what part behinde the griefe lyeth, let his Keeper take him out of the Stable in a long raine or coller-haulter, and let him runne him in his hand the full length of the rayne, for that in which legge Å¿oever the griefe is, you Å¿hall perceive him to favour it, but if you finde him to goe upright, without favouring any legge, then let your man take his backe, and ride him out a good trot or hand gallop, till he be warmed, then Å¿et him up, and let him Å¿tand an houre or two till he be cold, then take him forth againe, and
let your man trot him in his hand at the end of the Rayne as he did before, and thus you Å¿hall perceive him to hault and complaine, and well obÅ¿erving him and his gate or going, you may eaÅ¿ily finde the place grieved. And if any lameneÅ¿Å¿e whether before or behinde, doe proceed from any hot cauÅ¿e, then you Å¿hall beÅ¿t know it, for that the more you travell or exerciÅ¿e him, and the warmer he is, the more he will hault. But if his griefe Å¿hall proceed from any cold cauÅ¿e, then will he halt moÅ¿t, being cold after he hath been travelled and Å¿et up warme.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: YOu have Å¿poken well of lameneÅ¿Å¿e in generall termes, but yet would I gladly underÅ¿tand from you Å¿omewhat more in particular, as (V. G.) I would know how to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h between a pinch in the Å¿houlder, and a wrench in the Å¿houlder, as alÅ¿o betwixt a Å¿houlder Å¿plat, and of the Å¿houlder pight, and Å¿o of the other members?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
In anÅ¿wer to this demand, I Å¿ay that if you be cautelous in obÅ¿erving duely and juÅ¿tly the poÅ¿tures and geÅ¿tures of your HorÅ¿e, may very eaÅ¿ily come to know in what member, joynt, or limb the griefe lieth, and from whence it proceeds; for you muÅ¿t underÅ¿tand that when a horÅ¿e is pinched in the Å¿houlder, it muÅ¿t come either by carrying too heavy burthens, or by being put to draw, and be over-laboured too young, his ioynts and limbs not being knit, and this you may eaÅ¿ily finde, in that the horÅ¿e will appeare to your eye to be very narrow breÅ¿ted, and to conÅ¿ume and waÅ¿te in his fleÅ¿h from thoÅ¿e parts where griefe remaineth, and you may alÅ¿o perceive it, in that the Å¿houlder bone will Å¿ticke out further then the other, and thus you may finde it; but if he hath gotten a wrench in the Å¿houlder, it comes commonly by meanes of Å¿ome Å¿lip, or by cauÅ¿ing him to make too Å¿udden a Å¿top upon falÅ¿e ground, or by Å¿ome fall upon yeelding or Å¿lippery ground, or by too Å¿hort or Å¿udden turning him upon falÅ¿e grounds, or upon the planks in a Stable, or by Å¿ome raÅ¿h going out of a doore, or other narrow place, or by Å¿ome Å¿troke given by another horÅ¿e, you Å¿hall know it (like as before I told you) by his not well lifting and handling his legge with that dexterity he doth the other, as alÅ¿o by taking him upon the pitch of the Å¿houlder bone, and as touching a Å¿houlder Å¿plat, Shoulder-Å¿plat. which alÅ¿o commeth by a Å¿lide or Å¿lip, eÅ¿pecially upon Å¿ome Å¿ide or yeeld â¢â¢ g ground, where one legge doth Å¿lide from the other; whereby he teareth the fleÅ¿h which is in the inÅ¿ide neere the brisket, which cauÅ¿eth a bauke to be underneath the body, which will after be Å¿welled, and the horÅ¿e will thereupon hault right down, and he will draw his legge after him; but if he be Å¿houlder-pight, Shoulder-pight. this commeth by Å¿ome bruÅ¿h, Å¿traine, or fall, which the HorÅ¿e receiveth by Å¿ome leap, skip, Å¿troke, or bruiÅ¿e againÅ¿t Å¿ome doore, tree, or the like: inÅ¿omuch that often times the ioynt is diÅ¿located, and this will alÅ¿o cauÅ¿e him
to hault down right: wherefore your cures for each of theÅ¿e miÅ¿chiefes and miÅ¿haps, muÅ¿t be handled accordingly, and if the paine doe lye in any of the nether joynts, it commeth moÅ¿t commonly by meanes of Å¿ome wrench, as by putting his foot into Å¿ome cart roote of rough uneven ground, or by going upon looÅ¿e Å¿tones, and many times by turning him too Å¿hort in places that may be dangerous for his limbs, for by Å¿uch like cauÅ¿es doe occurre lameneÅ¿Å¿e to a HorÅ¿e, which when it Å¿hall happen, you Å¿hall thus know them, and know alÅ¿o in what ioynt or member the griefe hath its abode, and the manner of curing each of theÅ¿e Å¿everall griefes, I have already Å¿ufficiently Å¿hewed you, and therefore now let us paÅ¿Å¿e to other matters.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVEll then tell me what is good to cure the Scratches?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Of this malady we have Å¿undry Å¿orts and degrees, unto which albeit we doe give Å¿everall names, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e they be all in effect but one and the Å¿ame diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, as Mules, Kibes, Rats tayles, Crepanches, paines, &c. every of which are none other thing but the very Scratches, being certaine Å¿cabs which ingender betwixt the heele and the paÅ¿terne ioynt, and Å¿o goeth many times above the paÅ¿terne, even up to the hough, and albeit you may have this Å¿orance Å¿ometimes upon all foure legges, yet not ordinary, for that it breedeth moÅ¿t commonly in the hinder legges, this is a noyÅ¿ome Å¿orance, and comes Å¿ometimes through the negligence of the Groome, in that he doth not daily anoint the horÅ¿e heeles with Å¿tore of elbow greaÅ¿e, (as we tearme it) eÅ¿pecially after journeyes and hard travell; or when he brings his horÅ¿e in from water, and then doth not rub his legges and heeles dry, for that the Å¿and and durt doth burne and fret his heeles, which doe occaÅ¿ion Å¿wellings, and Å¿uch like Å¿wellings doe occaÅ¿ion the Scratches. It is therefore requiÅ¿ite that the Groome doe clip away the long Å¿hag haire from about the paÅ¿ternes (if he have any) and fetlocks: as alÅ¿o from the inÅ¿ide of his legs, unto the bending of the knee, by meanes whereof he may the better keep the legges of his horÅ¿e from this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e; Å¿ometimes it alÅ¿o comes from the corruption of the bloud after great heats and Å¿urfets taken, Å¿ometimes againe for that the horÅ¿e hath been bred in marriÅ¿h, fenny, and watery grounds, Å¿ometimes it is ingendered from melancholy humours
â¢ hich doe fall down to the legges, and Å¿ometimes by Å¿tanding continually upon his owne dung, which will through the heat and Å¿teame thereof, breed the Scratches without other help, and Å¿ometimes again, the Scratches will fall down into the heeles of the horÅ¿e, and there make its way forth after a deÅ¿perate Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e taken by a Å¿urfet; and laÅ¿tly it comes by reaÅ¿on the greaÅ¿e of the horÅ¿e had been moulten by over-riding or labour, whereby the greaÅ¿e falleth down and reÅ¿teth in the paÅ¿terne and fetlocks, and Å¿o cauÅ¿eth the Scratches to be ingendered. It beginneth
firÅ¿t with a dry Å¿cab, and after it Å¿endeth forth fretting, watriÅ¿h, and matterative Å¿tuffe, which will Å¿tinke and be moÅ¿t noyÅ¿ome, and his paÅ¿ternes and fetlocke ioynts will be full of chaps and chinkes, Å¿ometimes all along, Å¿ometimes right down, and Å¿ometimes overthwart, and the places will Å¿well, and the cracks or chinkes will cauÅ¿e the legs to be very gourdy, and to run with much noyÅ¿ome and offenÅ¿ive matter, and the horÅ¿e will be many times Å¿o lame, as not to be well able at firÅ¿t Å¿etting forth to goe, but with much trouble, and no leÅ¿Å¿e paine, and by theÅ¿e very Å¿ignes you Å¿hall know this malady: neither Å¿hall you want Å¿tore of receits wherewith to cure it; the French doe call this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e grappes, grapes, and Iavars, and ArraiÅ¿tes, as alÅ¿o Å¿uch other like tearmes and epithetons, all which (as before is touched) makes but onely one and the Å¿ame diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: the firÅ¿t thing which is to be done towards the cure, is to bathe and waÅ¿h the places all about, and then either to Å¿have or clip away the hayre very cloÅ¿e, otherwiÅ¿e you can hardly make a perfect cure thereof; then

Take the Å¿pawne of Toads,Scratches. which in the beginning of March you Å¿hall finde in pooles, ponds, ditches, and Å¿tanding water; and firÅ¿t draine the water from the Å¿aid Å¿pawn, and then diÅ¿till it, and keep the water in a glaÅ¿Å¿e cloÅ¿e Å¿topped to Å¿erve you for the whole yeare, and herewith waÅ¿h and bathe the places every day warm, and in Å¿hort Å¿pace it will cure them: this I have often uÅ¿ed. Another:

Take Honey and Pepper made into very fine powder, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and boyle them together and anoint the Å¿orance therewith, and they will Å¿oon heale and dry up; this I did never try, but a famous Ferrier of France taught it me. Another.

Take Lime and Salt, and make them both into fine powder, which being well mixed, apply it to the places grieved good and thick, then take Hurds, and cut them very Å¿mall, and clap them upon it, and Å¿o binde up the place with a linnen cloth, that it doth not remove, and Å¿o let it remaine two whole dayes and nights, and this will cauÅ¿e the Å¿orance to purge, and after heale it up very kindely: This I did never try. Another:
Take Verdigrece and the fat of Bacon, and pound them to a formall Salve, and Å¿o plaiÅ¿terwiÅ¿e apply it to the Å¿ore, and it will heale up the Å¿cratches in Å¿hort time. This is very good. Another.

Take old Bores greaÅ¿e and common Honey, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and worke it to an Vnguent, anoynt the Å¿orance therewith, four or five dayes, and no longer, and it will cure the Scratches. â. This is very good. Another.

Take Verdigrece in fine powder, Gals, BrimÅ¿tone, and Bolearmoniack, of each one ounce, make all into fine powder, and mixe them with Bores greaÅ¿e as much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿o bring it to an Vnguent, and anoint the Å¿orance therewith, and this will both heale and dry them up. â This I have often tryed. Another.

FirÅ¿t cauterize five Å¿trakes on either Å¿ide, and your iron muÅ¿t be
Å¿omewhat broad and you muÅ¿t go but only one croÅ¿Å¿e-wiÅ¿e, and after heale it up as it is uÅ¿uall in Cures in your Cures of Cauterize this I never did practiÅ¿e. Another.

Take Pepper, Garlick, Cole-wort-leaves, and old Boares-greaÅ¿e, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, pound them together to an Vnguent, and herewith anoint the Sorance, and in few daies it will ripen the Scratches, and kill the mallice of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and heale it up. X. of this Receipt I have made often uÅ¿e, and it is good; you muÅ¿t not faile alwaies before you dreÅ¿Å¿e any horÅ¿e that hath the Scratches, firÅ¿t to waÅ¿h and bathe the place well with warme water, and then to Å¿haw or clip away the haire very cloÅ¿e, alÅ¿o every time you are to dreÅ¿Å¿e any horÅ¿e of this malady, waÅ¿h the place with Chamberly and greene Copperas boyled together, and after dreÅ¿Å¿e him up with your other Salves, Vnguent, &c. Another.
Take Hogs-greaÅ¿e and Å¿trong MuÅ¿tard, and anoint the Sorance therewith, and in Å¿hort time he will be whole, â. This is very good. Another.

Take firÅ¿t of white-Wine-Vineger one pint, and put unto it of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t Tobacco in the Rowle you can get one ounce, open the leaves, and Å¿hread the Tobacco Å¿mall, and boile it untill the Vineger do begin to conÅ¿ume, then take it from the fire, and Å¿train it wringing it hard, then take white-Wine one pint, of Roach Allome the quantity of a Walnut, of Bay-Å¿alt, and of common Honey, of each one Spoonefull, red Sage, Rue, Hony-Å¿uckle-leaves. Yarrow, Plantaine, Rib-wort, Bramble-leaves, of each like much, halfe a handfull in the whole; boile all theÅ¿e in the Wine till one quart be conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine this water alÅ¿o, and mix them both together, and Å¿et it upon the fire till it begin to boile, then take it off, and when it is through cold, put it up into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o keep it cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, that no ayre come unto it, and when you would uÅ¿e it for the Scratches, waÅ¿h the Sorance, and then put upon it the powder of burnt Allome; and this will cure the Scratches. â. This I have often tryed, and it is Å¿ingular good. Another.

Take VerdegreaÅ¿e and make it into fine powder, and then take common hony, and worke them together to an Vnguent, and therewith anoynt the Å¿orance, and in Å¿hort time it will infallibly cure him. â. With this Receipt I have cured very many HorÅ¿es. Another.

Take tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e, and Gun-powder, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, firÅ¿t beat your Gun-powder to very fine powder, and incorporate them very well together, and anoynt the places greived once a day therewith, and it will Å¿oone cure the Scratches. â. This is a Å¿peciall good receipt. Another.

Take Trayne oyle, white-lead, made into very fine powder, and the Ielly which you Å¿hall find upon the ground, which many do report to be the falling of a Star in the night where it Å¿hooteth, of each
like much, incorporate theÅ¿e well together, and anoynt the Å¿ore twice every day therewith, but if you cannot get of this Ielly then adde to the former ingredients a little ArÅ¿enick pulveriÅ¿ed, and in ten or twelve daies this will heale him. X. This alÅ¿o is very good. Another.

Take the tender tops of Elder buds, and the berries of the bramble while they be red, and before they be rip, of each one handfull, boil them in Wort two quarts, and put unto it of Allome the quantity of an Egge, and therewith waÅ¿h and bathe the Sorance good and hot twice every day, and this water will cure him, X. This is alÅ¿o very good. Another.

Take of Hemlocke a good quantity, Å¿hread it very Å¿mall, then take of Creame one quart, and boyle it with the Hemlock till the Creame do turne into an oyle, which done take it from the fire, and Å¿traine it into a cleane galley pot, and keepe it for your uÅ¿e: with this anoint the Sorance and it will Å¿oone heale it; of this I never had tryall. Another.

Take BrimÅ¿tone, and make it into fine powder, and mix with it of Å¿weet Butter, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, to bring it to an Vnguent, which will be of the colour of Gold, herewith anoint the Å¿ores and it will cure them. This I never tryed. Another.

Take unÅ¿laked Lime, Salt, and Soot, of each like much, all made into very fine powder: boyle this in the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger you can get Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, till it become as thicke as a Pultis: then Å¿often it with tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e, and Å¿o worke it to an Vnguent, and herewith anoint the places greived till they be perfectly cured. â. This is very good; but to prevent all Å¿orts of Scratches, Kibes, Rat-tayles, &c. take up the Thigh-veynes, and your HorÅ¿e Å¿hall never have any of theÅ¿e Maladies, or if he have them, yet by Å¿o doing, they will of themÅ¿elves be cured. â. This I have oft experienced.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure a Sit-faÅ¿t?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This Malady the French do call Mal de la Corn; it is an hard knob which hath beene formerly a Saddle-gald, but by reaÅ¿on that the Owner of the HorÅ¿e was unwilling to Å¿pare his worke till it was fully cured; it is converted into a Sit-faÅ¿t, Sit-faÅ¿t. which is oftimes troubleÅ¿ome to the HorÅ¿e, by reaÅ¿on it is growne to a dry knob Å¿o hard as a horne. The cure is.

Take the greene outward leaves of a Cabbadge, and Å¿tamp them with old Boares-greaÅ¿e, or tryed Hogs-greaÅ¿e, and worke them to an Oyntment; and then mount his Back, and then Å¿et the Saddle, to the end that the Oyntment may the better enter, or Å¿inke into his Backe, and in a few daies it will Cure him. â This is a very good cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: THere be yet certaine Scabbes which doe grow upon HorÅ¿e-heeles, which Ferriers doe deny to be the Scratches, but they will have it to bee a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e wholy different. How doe you cure them?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, men may Å¿ay what they Å¿hall pleaÅ¿e, but I doe aÅ¿Å¿ure you, theÅ¿e are alÅ¿o plaine Scratches. But yet I will give a few Receipts for them.

Scabs and Scratches.Take of Salet-oyle three ounces, Red-wax-gummed one ounce, common Hony two ounces, mixe and melt all theÅ¿e together, and make them into an Vuguent, with which you muÅ¿t oft anoint the Sores, and this will cure them. â. I have often uÅ¿ed it. Another.

Take ordinary Turpentine two ounces, new Wax, oyle de Bay, Quick-BrimÅ¿tone, of each three ounces, common Hony one ounce, Allome and Zacacon, of each halfe an ounce, mixe, melt, and incorporate all thoÅ¿e well together, and every evening anoint the places grieved therewith, having firÅ¿t cleanÅ¿ed the Sorances, as before is taught you. This I did never try, but I hold it to be very good. Another.

Take the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white-Wine-Vineger, MuÅ¿tard, and Soote, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and mix them well, them adde to them the yolkes of two Egges, and of Hogs-greaÅ¿e one ounce, Rape-oyle, and new Wax, of each two ounces, quick-BrimÅ¿tone in fine powder halfe an ounce, melt all theÅ¿e, and make it into an Vnguent, and therewith, anoint the grieved Sorances. â. This I have often tryed, and I know it to be very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good for a HorÅ¿e that can neither Stale or Dunge?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This accident oftimes hapneth to a HorÅ¿e that is Å¿uddenly travelled, being newly taken from GraÅ¿Å¿e, or that hath beene long time kept and pampered in the Stable without any execiÅ¿e at all, for as thoÅ¿e who be too hard Riders do Å¿oone Å¿urfet their HorÅ¿es, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e do theÅ¿e terribly wrong their HorÅ¿es who be too indulgent, and tender of them, and therefore the golden meane is evermore the beÅ¿t. The Å¿ignes to know this Malady is plaine, for that his paine will bee Å¿o great as that it will cauÅ¿e him oft to lye downe and tumble, as if he had the Bots. I will give you one onely Receipt which a famous French MariÅ¿hall gave me, with which I cured one HorÅ¿e, for that I had never occaÅ¿ion to practiÅ¿e it upon any Å¿ince, but I do hold it to be moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne in a caÅ¿e of this nature.

Take the root of Male-Brake or Fearne, and put a piece thereof upon his tongue, and it will cauÅ¿e him both to Å¿tale and dung, Stale or dung. and Å¿o he will be cured. The male of Fearne is to be knowne by the root, from the female, for if you take a Fearne-root, and cut it in two pieces, you Å¿hall Å¿ee the perfect figure of an Eagle, and thereby you may know it to be the male, which is for your turne. And the female root will beare other effigies different from the male, which wanteth its vertue to perfect this cure. â This (I Å¿ay) I have once tryed.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to be done to a HorÅ¿e that falleth Å¿icke in his iourney or travell? Sicke in travell.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This alÅ¿o hapneth as the former doth, but yet oftner and Å¿ooner, eÅ¿pecially if he be very fat and purÅ¿ive, and wanting breath, as alÅ¿o if he be travelled being fat and heavy, the Sunne Å¿hining and Å¿corching much, for Å¿uch a horÅ¿e is in danger either to tire, or to fall deÅ¿perately Å¿icke, which may alÅ¿o endanger his life, as I have frequently knowne. The cure muÅ¿t be.

Take Muskadine or Å¿weet Sacke one pinte, Aqua vitae a quarter of a pinte, of London Treacle two ounces, and of the beÅ¿t Sallet oyle a quarter of a pinte: warme all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and brew it well, and give him one hornfull thereof, then take his tongue in your hand, and put down his throat a new laid Egge, breaking it with your fingers as you put it forth of your hand; then give him a Å¿econd horne full, and then another Egge, and after all the reÅ¿idue of the drinke, and Å¿o after that a third Egge, then let him bloud in the palat, and rub it well with white Salt, then Å¿et him upon the Trench, cloath, Å¿top, and litter him againe warme, and let him faÅ¿t an hour or two after it, and then feed him by degrees, both with Hay and Oates, giving him either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water, and he will doe well againe. This drink refreÅ¿heth all the Å¿pirits, being over-laied through heate and labour, and cauÅ¿eth a good appetite to meat. â With this drinke I have cured many Å¿icke horÅ¿es, as well of mine own, as of my friends, which have faln away very deÅ¿perately Å¿ick upon the way in travell; but if I do finde that his bloud is inflamed, as many times it will be, I then uÅ¿e to open a veyne in the neck.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt what is to be given to a HorÅ¿e that falleth Å¿uddenly Å¿ick? Sudden Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: FirÅ¿t let him bloud in both breÅ¿t veines, or if you have not skill Å¿ufficient to open theÅ¿e veynes, then let him bloud in both Å¿ides the necke, and let him bleed well nigh two quarts, then give him this comfortable drink.

Take of Å¿weet Sacke one quart, and burn it with Graines, Cloves, and Cinamon, of each like much, being all beaten groÅ¿Å¿e, put to it of Suger three ounces, and when it is burnt, adde unto it of Sallet oyle halfe a pinte, and of London Treacle two ounces, warm all theÅ¿e, and brew them well together, and Å¿o give it to your horÅ¿e bloud warme, then ride him gently untill he do begin to Å¿weate, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warm clothed and littered, but be Å¿ure to keep his head and heart warme, neither muÅ¿t you Å¿tuffe and cloth him too hot; for this drink will cauÅ¿e him to Å¿weate Å¿ufficiently of it Å¿elfe, yet litter him well, keeping the Stable cloÅ¿e, and Å¿o let him faÅ¿t Å¿ixe hours after, againÅ¿t which time, let him be rubbed very dry, and give him to eate Å¿weet Wheat Å¿traw, and after give him either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water, and boile therein of Mallowes and Water-creÅ¿Å¿es, of each one handfull, of Fennell-Å¿eed, and of PerÅ¿ley-Å¿eed, of each one ounce, if he will drink the Å¿ame. After that morning and evening (your horÅ¿e being faÅ¿ting) ride him a mile or two, to the end he may take the ayre, which is very wholeÅ¿ome for him, if the weather be temperate, and let his meat be Å¿weet Å¿traw, old clean dry Oats, and Å¿ome Wheat, and PeaÅ¿e mixed therewith: give him a little at once, and often, untill you doe perceive his Å¿tomacke to come well unto him, and let him be daily well rubbed, and warm clothed, to provoke him to Å¿weat, and let him be alÅ¿o well littered, and his drink either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white water: and by this manner of keeping and ordering of him, in Å¿hort time he will recover his priÅ¿tine Å¿anity. â This I have often tryed, and it is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a Selender?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is the very Å¿ame with the Melander, but the Å¿ole difference is, in that the malander breedeth upon the bending of the knee, or the legge before, and the Selender engendreth of the bending of the hough in the legge behinde: but it commeth juÅ¿t as doth the Malander, and the cure is the very Å¿ame with it: but yet I will give you one good receit which will cure both: firÅ¿t, waÅ¿h and Å¿have away the hayre, and rub the Å¿orance with a wiÅ¿pe or hayre cloth till it be raw:
ãâ¦ã . then take the Å¿hreds of white leather untanned, which Glovers doe make, and boyle them in Vineger till they be Å¿oft, and binde of this hot to the place, but if you do not finde that
by once or twice dreÅ¿Å¿ing, taketh not away the Å¿curfe or Å¿cab, renew it daily untill it doth, for by this meanes the roots of the briÅ¿tly haire which groweth in and about the Å¿orance, is the onely thing that feedeth the Malander, wherefore the roots of the hayre being taken off (which this medicine will doe) the Å¿orance will Å¿oon be cured; and to heale up the rawneÅ¿Å¿e thereof,

Take freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter, bay Salt, and FrankincenÅ¿e, both made into fine powder, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, and boyle them all together on the fire, and with a ragge upon a Å¿ticke apply this medicine to the place Å¿calding hot two mornings together, and after heale it up, and cauÅ¿e the hayre to come againe, being daily anointed with Mallowes and Å¿weet Butter made into an Vnguent. â This is a very good cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to be given to a HorÅ¿e Å¿icke, Å¿urfetted, Sick or Å¿urfetted. and his greaÅ¿e molten?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: The onely way is firÅ¿t to take bloud from him, if there be juÅ¿t cauÅ¿e, and after to Å¿cowre his guts with this purge.

Take CaÅ¿Å¿ia one ounce, Filonio-perÅ¿io, or PerÅ¿ico, and Trifora magna, of each halfe an ounce, Å¿irrop of Violets two ounces, diÅ¿Å¿olve theÅ¿e in mel RoÅ¿arum four ounces, and give it him with a horne in a morning faÅ¿ting, and after either ride him gently, or elÅ¿e walk him up and down an houre or better, and for an houre after at the leaÅ¿t let him Å¿tand upon the Trench, then give him a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, which when he hath diÅ¿patched, give him old dry Oates cleane and well Å¿ifted, and after Å¿weet Hay, neither let him have any cold water in eight dayes after, nor after that time, but with exerciÅ¿e. â And this is a Å¿peciall good cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: NOw let us come to the Å¿inewes, what Å¿ay you to a Å¿inew Å¿praine?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: I have already handled this point Å¿ufficiently in lib. 2. cap. 4. Â§ 9. A. for an Attaint upper, nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will give you more receits for a Å¿inew Å¿praine, albeit it be the Å¿ame malady: the firÅ¿t Å¿hall be for a Å¿inew Å¿prung, Sinew Å¿prung. or when the Å¿inew is broken, and Å¿evered from the fleÅ¿h, as many times it falleth out, then

Take Tartar, and the lees of Claret or red Wine, of each three ounces, Wheate Bran one handfull, boyle theÅ¿e with the juyce of Smalledge, two handfuls or better, and when you take it from the fire, put into it of Turpentine one ounce, binde this to the Å¿inew grieved, Å¿o hot as he may well Å¿uffer it, and uÅ¿ing this medicine foure or fiue dayes, he will be Å¿ound againe. â This is very good: Another,
if the Å¿inew or artery be broken with CoraÅ¿ives, or other accident, to cauÅ¿e it to Å¿oder or joyne againe.

Take the leaves and roots of Solomons Å¿eate, and of great Cumfrey, of each like much, pound them Å¿mall, and infuÅ¿e it in white Wine foure and twenty houres, bathe the Å¿orance herewith warme (you having firÅ¿t boyled it) and after you have bathed the place well, binde the hearbs and roots to the place grieved, dreÅ¿Å¿ing him every day once, untill he be perfectly conÅ¿olidate. And if the fleÅ¿h be Å¿till broken, when you do finde the Å¿inew to be knit, Å¿trew theron the powder of Lime and Honey, which will heale and skin it in Å¿hort time. â This is good, for I have often tryed it. Another for a Å¿inew grieved.Sinew grieved.
If the Å¿inew be Å¿o farre grieved, whereby to cauÅ¿e the horÅ¿e to complaine, and to hault,

Take then of Mallowes a good quantity, and boyle them in faire water, untill they Å¿hall become tender, then draine the water from the hearbs, and Å¿o Å¿tamp them to maÅ¿h, and apply them to the member grieved hot over night, and the next morning he will be upright againe, but then he muÅ¿t haue eight or ten daies reÅ¿t at the leaÅ¿t after. But if it be a Å¿inew Å¿praine, then clip away the hayre cloÅ¿e, or Å¿have it, then

Take of the oyle of Sulphur, and of the oyle of Turpentine, of each one ounce, take firÅ¿t the one halfe thereof being well mixed, and chafe and rub it into the Å¿inew well, and Å¿o let him be tyed up to the Rack, that he may not come unto it with his mouth, for that it will greatly perplexe him for four or five hours after his dreÅ¿Å¿ing, and the next day anoint him, as you did the day before, & he wil be cured, but the place will be raw, and therefore heale him up with Å¿weet Butter, or Hogs greaÅ¿e, and when the place healeth, the skin will peele, and yet the hayre will come again, but he muÅ¿t either runne at graÅ¿Å¿e, or elÅ¿e be kept in the Stable without any exerciÅ¿e at all by the Å¿pace of a moneth at leaÅ¿t. If the Å¿inew be cut,Sinew cut. then

Take new Waxe, and Gumme-Arabick, of each two ounces, of the marrow of an Oxe or Cow, four ounces, of the oyle of RoÅ¿es three ounces, melt and incorporate all theÅ¿e on the fire, and Å¿o keep it for your uÅ¿e, and when you are to uÅ¿e it, warme it, and Å¿o apply it either unguent wiÅ¿e, or taint wiÅ¿e, or plaiÅ¿ter wiÅ¿e, according as you Å¿hall Å¿ee cauÅ¿e, and it will cure any Å¿orance of this nature. â This I have often tryed. Another.
If your HorÅ¿e have a Å¿inew Å¿prained Sinew Å¿prain by an over-reach, Å¿troke, or otherwiÅ¿e weakened, the better to Å¿trengthen the Å¿ame,

Take tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, HorÅ¿e greaÅ¿e, May or freÅ¿h Butter, Sallet oyle, of each Å¿ixe ounces: take alÅ¿o of the oyntment called Agrippa, two drams, or new Waxe, two ounces and a halfe, and of Camphier a third part to all the reÅ¿t, melt them all together upon the fire, and Å¿o work it to an unguent, and good and warme, anoint the Å¿welled or grieved part therewith morning and evening, and what remaineth
of this medicine, let it be reÅ¿erved in a galley pot for other times, for it will keep a whole yeare. â This is very good. Another, if it be a Å¿inew Å¿praine onely, then

Take Goats, Kids, or Deeres Å¿uet, and RoÅ¿in, of each one pound, Fig duÅ¿t halfe a pound, Verdigrece in fine powder, halfe a pound, melt and mixe all theÅ¿e well, and therewith anoint the Å¿inew grieved every day, and chafe it into the Å¿inew by holding a hot bar of iron neer it. This will both comfort and Å¿trengthen the Å¿inew, but I did never make tryall thereof.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: BVt HippoÅ¿erus, is it needfull that by applying your Vnguents, you doe evermore worke them in with a hot bar of iron?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Truely Sir, thoÅ¿e that are for Straines, Aches, Mainges, Farcins, and Å¿uch like maladies and Å¿orances, the further they doe Å¿inke into the skinne and fleÅ¿h, the Å¿ooner and better will the cure be performed, and therefore albeit I do not alwaies put you in minde of the hot bar of iron in every of my receits, yet it is needfull to be uÅ¿ed. But to proceed with another receit for a Å¿inew Å¿praine. Sinew Å¿prain.

Take ordinary Sope, and Aqua vitae, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, boyle them, and in the boyling, keep it by continuall Å¿tirring, then take it off, and (Å¿o hot as he can well Å¿uffer it) bathe and chafe in the oyntment, and he will be Å¿ound again. This was commended unto me for moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne, but I never made tryall thereof. Another for a Å¿traine taken in travell.

Take Å¿o mu â¢ h of the beÅ¿t gray Sope as will Å¿erve to anoint the Å¿inew Å¿trained, but before you do anoint him, having cauÅ¿ed his legge to be cleanÅ¿ed from dirt, Å¿and, or gravell, and made dry again, anoint him therewith, and then Å¿wathe the leg with a thumband of Hay, and Å¿o let him Å¿tand all night, and the next morning he will be Å¿ound again, Å¿o that you may Å¿ecurely travell him againe, without feare. â This I have often uÅ¿ed, and it is very good. Another if it be a Å¿traine newly taken.Straine newly taken.

Take then of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger you can get, one pinte, and May or freÅ¿h Butter halfe an ounce, then put to it of Wheat bran as much as will Å¿uffice, which by boyling will bring it to a PoulteÅ¿Å¿e, and apply it Å¿o hot as he can Å¿uffer it; doe this morning and evening, untill the Å¿welling be aÅ¿Å¿waged. â This is very good. Another, but if it be an old taken Å¿traine, then

Take Mallowes and Chickweed, of each like much, boyle them either in the grounds of Ale or Beere, or elÅ¿e in old Chamberlye, and apply it to the place. â This is a Å¿peciall good cure. Another for an old Å¿traine which is thought to be incurable, inÅ¿omuch as the Å¿inew being Å¿welled, is become very hard and knotty.

St aine old.Take Patch-greaÅ¿e, alias Peere or Peece-greaÅ¿e, as much as will Å¿uffice, melt it upon the fire, and anoint the Å¿traine therewith very hot, and chafe and heat it very well, then rope the place as before is Å¿hewed you, but before you rope him up, wrap a rowler of linnen upon the place, and do thus daily, and it will diÅ¿Å¿olve the hardneÅ¿Å¿e, and make him Å¿ound again. â This is moÅ¿t excellent. Another for a Å¿praine of the Å¿ame nature.

Take Nervall, Bolearmoniack, Bores greaÅ¿e, black Sope, of each like much, melt them together, but firÅ¿t pulverize your Bolearmoniack, and anoint the Å¿orance herewith, chafing and heating in very well; continue thus to do twice a day till it be well. â This is alÅ¿o very Å¿overaign.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good for a HorÅ¿e that hath a Å¿tinking Breath?Stinking breath.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commeth by means of corrupted and infected lungs, the Å¿igns how to know it is by the Å¿mell onely, the cure is,

Take Cinamon, Cloves, Galingall, Comine and Coriander Å¿eeds, of each three ounces, Fenugrick eight ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and Å¿earce and mixe them well with Wheat flowre two pound, and put thereto Å¿o much white Wine as will bring it to a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and make a cake thereof and bake it in an Oven till it be as dry and as hard as bisket, and when it is cold, beat it to fine powder, and give him every morning an houre at leaÅ¿t before his water, of this powder four Å¿poonfuls in white Wine or Å¿trong Ale, of each one pinte. This will take away all the corrupt and evill Å¿avours of his breath, for this powder healeth all his inward parts that be putrified, from whence his bad breath taketh its origen. â This is very good and approved, and a better remedy you Å¿hall finde none.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is the beÅ¿t way to cure or take off a Splent?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This is to be done many waies, but becauÅ¿e we are come to treat of this cure, I hold it not amiÅ¿Å¿e to make you underÅ¿tand what a Å¿plent is, by what meanes it commeth, how to know it, and which way to cure the Å¿ame, and to take it cleane away. A Å¿plent is in the beginning, a very griÅ¿tle, howbeit if it be long let alone, it will come to be a hard bone or excreÅ¿ion, and then it will not be Å¿o eaÅ¿ily cured. It commeth to a HorÅ¿e by meanes of too hard travell and Å¿ore riding, whilÅ¿t he is very yong, or by bearing in his youth too heavy burthens, by both which meanes the greaÅ¿e being molten, falleth down into his legges, and Å¿o breedeth this Å¿orance, you Å¿hall have it bigger or leÅ¿Å¿er, according as the cauÅ¿e of its comming
was; it taketh its reÅ¿idence for the moÅ¿t part upon the inÅ¿ide of the Å¿hanke about the middle thereof, but Å¿ometimes again higher even adjoyning to the knee, which if it be there, then it is more difficile to cure. It will many times cauÅ¿e the HorÅ¿e to hault, but howÅ¿oever it will make him oft to Å¿tumble, and to trip, and many times to fall in his travell. Sometimes it commeth to a horÅ¿e hereditarily, like as doth the Å¿paven, and other Å¿orances and maladies: as if either the Stalion or Mare be viÅ¿ited therewith, as I have formerly intimated. The Å¿ignes how to know it are moÅ¿t facile, viz. either by the Å¿ight or feeling, for that you may both Å¿ee and feele its Å¿welling. Now to the cure, for which I Å¿hall give you very many receits.

FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h the place with warme water, and Å¿have away the hayre, then with your inciÅ¿ion knife Å¿lit a hole cleane through the skin, more then the length of a Barly corne, and then convey into the Å¿aid hole Å¿o much ArÅ¿nicke as the fourth part of a haÅ¿le Nut, which muÅ¿t be bound on with a boulÅ¿ter and rowler of linnen, and made faÅ¿t with a needle and threed, and Å¿o let remaine untouched three whole daies and nights, in which time the ArÅ¿nicke will eate and corrode cleane away the Å¿plent, Splent. then to kill the fire, anoint the place (having firÅ¿t taken off the rowler and boulÅ¿ter, and waÅ¿hed cleane the Å¿orance) with Å¿weet or freÅ¿h Butter molten, eight or ten dayes after, and it will be whole. â With this I have done very many cures of this kinde. Another:

FirÅ¿t, anoynt the place with ordinary Å¿oft waÅ¿hing Sope, then tye a red woollen cloth about the legge, juÅ¿t upon the Å¿plent, that done, heat a Brick glowing hot, and lay it upon the cloth againÅ¿t the place where the Å¿plent is, and hold it Å¿o cloÅ¿e unto it a pretty Å¿pace, then Å¿o Å¿oone as you doe take that away, have another as hot in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, and clap that too alÅ¿o, doing as before, and Å¿o a third, or Å¿o many as Å¿hall be needfull, till you doe finde that the Å¿plent is diÅ¿Å¿olved and taken away, which commonly will be in applying two or three hot Bricks. â With this I have taken off very many Å¿plents. Another:
FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and Å¿have away the hayre, then knock, rubbe, and pricke it with your bloud Å¿taffe and fleame, and after you have Å¿o done, rub and knock it again, then

Take Vervine and Salt, of each one handfull, pound them together to an Vnguent, and apply it to the place, and binde it up with a rowler Å¿titched on faÅ¿t with a needle and threed, and Å¿o let it remaine foure and twenty houres, and then unbinde it, and it is cured without any more to doe. â This is very good. Another:

WaÅ¿h and Å¿have as before, and rub and knock as before alÅ¿o, then with your inciÅ¿ion knife lay open the place a little, then knocke and rubbe againe with a little Salt, then apply unto it this oyntment which the French do tearme a Retoyre.

Take of oyle de Bay foure ounces, Cantharides, Euforbium, and
Orpin, of each one ounce, all theÅ¿e being made into fine power, let them be well incorporate into the Å¿aid oyle, and wrought to an Vnguent, lay of this to the Å¿plent, and bind it up with a BowlÅ¿ter and Rowler, and Å¿ew it up faÅ¿t, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o by the Å¿pace of three houres upon the Trench, Å¿o tyed up as that he bite not off the rowler and Medicine â¢ at three houres end, unrowle the place, and put unto it againe the Å¿aid Retore or Oyntment, being made warme, and let the HorÅ¿e Å¿tand trameled foure dayes, and at foure daies end Å¿end him to the water a foote pace, where every day he muÅ¿t be ridden up and downe, to the belly: If you doe love the horÅ¿e, and have a deÅ¿ire to have him perfectly cured, let him not bee ridden more then a foote pace to the water in a moneth after, for indangering the growing of it againe, for nothing can bee more Å¿overaigne for him then reÅ¿t. â. This Retore is a Å¿peciall good thing for this Malady, and I have often uÅ¿ed it, and it did never faile me. I had this in France of a famous MariÅ¿hall who cured many horÅ¿es therewith in my preÅ¿ence. Another.

After you have waÅ¿hed and Å¿haven, knocked, rubbed, and laid it open, as before is taught you, take a head of Garlicke, picked and pilled, three or foure drops of the beÅ¿t white Wine Vineger, a penny weight of greene Coppras, all well beaten together, apply it to the Å¿plent, and then bind and Å¿tich it up, and let it lye on foure and twenty houres, then open it, and if the Å¿plent be not taken quite away, make more of the Å¿ame Medicine, and adminiÅ¿ter it againe, binding it up as before, and after other foure and twenty houres take of the medicine, and then you Å¿hall need do nothing more unto him, but only what you are preÅ¿cribed in the precedent cure. This I did never try. Another. FirÅ¿t burne away the haire with a hot tyle, then Å¿have it cloÅ¿e with your RaÅ¿or, that done have in a readineÅ¿Å¿e a peece of Leather, the breadth of the Sorance, and bind it hard upon it, and let it Å¿o remaine by the Å¿pace of an houre, then take him off, and leade to the water, without doing any more unto him, and hee is cured. This cure I never tryed. Another.

Take MuÅ¿tard Å¿eed, and beat it, and let it Å¿teepe a little in fayre water, and after make a PlaiÅ¿ter thereof, and lay it to the place, and three dayes after take it away, but have a care your horÅ¿e come not unto it with his teeth, the hayre alÅ¿o being Å¿haven away before you do apply your PlaiÅ¿ter, and this will cure him. This alÅ¿o I never proved. Another. FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and Å¿have away the hayre, then take of the tender tops of Wormewood, Smalage, Pellitory, and of Brauca-vrÅ¿ina, of each like much, and beat them together with old Bores-greaÅ¿e, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and apply it to the place: neither did I try this. Another. FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and Å¿have as before, and knocke, beat, and rub the Å¿plent three or foure times, then take marÅ¿h mallow rootes, boyled with the skin on, and laid to the place, and it will take away the Splent: This I never made uÅ¿e of, but a very good
Ferrier taught it mee, who avowed it to bee right good. Another.
Take MuÅ¿tard-Å¿eede, Mallow rootes, and Oxe dung, all Å¿tamped and boyled together, and plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e apply it to the place three or foure times. This I never uÅ¿ed. Another.

Take Auripigmentum made into fine powder, and lay it upon the Splent, and it will take it off; but beware that this powder doe touch neither veine nor Å¿inew, for it is a very coroding thing, â. Another.

Take two heads of Garlick and pill them, and cut them Å¿mall, but do neither Å¿tamp or bruiÅ¿e them: then take of Salt the like quantity, and mix them with your Garlicke, and divide them into two equall parts, & Å¿o put them into two fine linen cloutes, and bind them upon the ends of two Å¿ticks, of a foote in length a peece of the faÅ¿hion of two Å¿hort woodden foyles but nothing Å¿o long, being not above twelve inches a peece. Take then your bloud Å¿ticke, and rub, knock, and beat, the Splent therewith very well to Å¿often it, then pricke it through the skin with your bloud Å¿taffe and Fleame; then take of the oyle of Nuts one pint, and put it into a Å¿mall Pipkin, and Å¿et it upon the fire in a ChafingdiÅ¿h with coles, and make it boyling hot, and when it is ready to boyle, put into it your Å¿hort Å¿ticks or foyles which hath the Garlicke and Salt faÅ¿tned unto them, and firÅ¿t with the one foyle, and then with the other (I meane by turnes) apply them hot unto the Splent, and between whiles, rub and Å¿troke the Splent downwards, with your thumbe, whereby to bring forth the bloud, till having with the foyles very well mollefied the Å¿aid Splent, you may the more eaÅ¿ily cruÅ¿h forth the bloud whereof the Splent is ingendred, and formed; it being indeede compact of bad and corrupt bloud: and thus is the Splent cured, only you muÅ¿t remember to anoint the place two or three times after with Å¿weet or freÅ¿h Butter, â. This of all the cures I have is the beÅ¿t, for this Malady, howbeit it may Å¿eeme intricate; I gate it of a French Rider to a Noble Knight in England, and I have herewith taken off more then one hundred Splents, I have uÅ¿ed this more then thirty yeares Å¿ince. Another.

Take up the contrary Legge, and beat the Splent with your bloud-Å¿taffe till it do begin to be Å¿oft, then with your Fleame prick it in Å¿undry places that the bloud may iÅ¿Å¿ue forth. Take then the greateÅ¿t red Onion, and cut off the top, and picke out the core, and put into it Å¿o much of the powder of VerdegreaÅ¿e as the end of your thumbe, then put on the top again, and wrap it up in a wet brown paper, and Å¿o roÅ¿t it in the hot embers, as you do a Warden, till it be as Å¿oft as pap, then take it out of the Embers, and put away the paper and all that is burnt from about it, and Å¿tamp it, and being yet very hot apply it unto the Splent, and lay a BowlÅ¿ter upon it, and then Å¿wathe it up with a linnen Rowler, Å¿titching it faÅ¿t, and Å¿o let it remaine five or Å¿ixe dayes, and then open it, and after anoint the place every day once, with Å¿weete
Butter till it be whole. â This is a very good cure. Another.

Take a great Onyon, and pick out the core, and put into it of the powder of unÅ¿laked Lime, and of the powder of Verdigrece, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, but Å¿o much as will fill it up, then roÅ¿t it, as before is Å¿hewed you, and Å¿tamp it in a morter well, then Å¿lit the skinne a little, that the medicine may come unto it, to eate away the Å¿plent, and Å¿have not away the hayre, but lay on the medicine and boulÅ¿ter, and bind it up faÅ¿t, and Å¿o let it remaine on three dayes, without Å¿tirring it, then unbind it and waÅ¿h it cleane, and anoint it every day with Å¿weet Butter, till it be whole. â This is very good. Another.

Take an Elecampane root, and make it cleane, and wrap it up in a brown paper, and roÅ¿t it in the embers as you did the Onions, and being Å¿oft like pap, apply it to the Å¿plent, you having firÅ¿t rubbed, knocked, and prickt it as before is taught you, the hayre alÅ¿o being waÅ¿hed and Å¿haven off, it muÅ¿t be laid on Å¿o hot as he is able to Å¿uffer it, and let it lye on two dayes and two nights, then take off that, and lay on a Å¿econd, and after a third, till the Å¿plent be quite conÅ¿umed, and then anoynt the place with freÅ¿h butter onely every day till it be whole. â This is Å¿peciall good. Another.

Take of the oyle of Exeter, and taking every day once or twice a little thereof upon the brawn of your thumbe, rub and anoint the place therewith, and thus doing, it will take it quite away, but this will aske long time to do. â This I have tryed. Thus have I given you very many receits for this malady, moÅ¿t of which I know to be good from my own experience: the reÅ¿idue which I never tryed, were cryed up unto me by very skilfull Ferriers and MariÅ¿hals, for very good. The French do call this malady Surots, and Epineles, or EÅ¿pinuls.

p.hi: VVHat helpe have you for Å¿tumbling?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This inconvenience commeth many wayes, Å¿ometimes it commeth naturally, and Å¿ometimes accidentally, it commeth naturally by reaÅ¿on the Å¿inewes of the fore-legs are Å¿omewhat Å¿traight, Å¿o that the horÅ¿e is not able to handle his legges with that dexterity and agility he Å¿hould, and the onely remedy to cure him of this defect is, to cut him of the Cords (as we terme it) viz. by cuting a Å¿lit upon the very top of his noÅ¿e, and with your cornet to take up the two great Å¿inewes which you Å¿hall there finde, and Å¿o cut them in Å¿under, and after to heale it up againe with Å¿ome healing Salve, and this will doe him no harme, but good, for by this doing, it will give him the uÅ¿e of his legges Å¿o perfectly, as that he will Å¿eldome or never after trip any more, and this can every ordinary Smith doe. â And my counÅ¿ell is, that when at any time you
Å¿hall either breed or buy a yong horÅ¿e, before, or preÅ¿ently after you Å¿hall backe him, let him be thus cut of the cords, and you will finde great profit thereby. The Å¿econd cauÅ¿e that maketh a horÅ¿e to Å¿tumble, is accidentall, and this commeth either by meanes of the putting forth of a Å¿plent, or a ridge bone, or about wind gals, or by Å¿ome detriment taken in the foot, as by being hot, foundred, prickt, Å¿tubd, graveld, or the like, or by Å¿ome Å¿inew Å¿praine, or Å¿ome hurt or wrench in the Å¿houlder, or by Å¿ome pinch in the withers; and it commeth alÅ¿o by over-riding, and then negligently Å¿et up, which cauÅ¿eth him to goe Å¿tiffe, and then the cure muÅ¿t be done with bathes and unguents, wherby to Å¿tretch, Å¿upple, mollifie, and to comfort the Å¿tiffe members, for remedy and eaÅ¿e whereof, I have given you very many good receits before preÅ¿cribed you, as well of bathes as of unguents. But yet I will give you one more which I have often made uÅ¿e of, and have done much good therewith for Å¿tiffe legges,Stiffe legge viz.

Take of Hogs greaÅ¿e one pound, of freÅ¿h Butter, Altheae, and of oyle de Bay, of each halfe a pound, mixe and incorporate all theÅ¿e well together, and therewith anoynt, rub, and chafe the legges and Å¿inewes of the horÅ¿e, every third day three times a day, and let his Å¿hooes be made wide enough, eÅ¿pecially at the heeles, and let him be pared thin; the Å¿inewes being well Å¿uppled, it is needfull he be alÅ¿o cut of the cords, which will prevent his Å¿tumbling the better. Stumbling commeth alÅ¿o by meanes of carrying heavy burthens, and when the rider is a man of an extraordinary weight, eÅ¿pecially if the HorÅ¿e be young. â This is a very good cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to be given to a HorÅ¿e that cannot Stale or PiÅ¿Å¿e?Stale or piÅ¿Å¿e.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This infirmity commeth either of the collicke, or by meanes of too much hard riding: the cure is,

Take Grummell Å¿eed, Saxafrage-Å¿eed, and the roots, of each halfe an ounce, make them into fine powder, boyle them a walme or two in white Wine one quart, and give it him warme. â This is very good. Another.

Take the tops of green Broom, and burne a good quantity of them, Å¿o as you may have Å¿o many of the aÅ¿hes as will come to be a pretty handfull, Å¿earce them, and put them into white Wine a pinte, and after it hath infuÅ¿ed an houre, give him the Wine, but not the aÅ¿hes. â This is very good. Another.

Take black buds of the AÅ¿hen tree, and burn them, then take the aÅ¿hes cleanÅ¿ed, and as before is Å¿hewed you of the Broome aÅ¿hes, and adminiÅ¿ter it to the HorÅ¿e juÅ¿t as you did the other. X This is a moÅ¿t approved cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good cure have you for the Stavers?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is Å¿ecundum vulgus, called the Staggers, Of melancholy. but the true name thereof is the Stavers, it is a dizzineÅ¿Å¿e in the head, neerly allyed unto the frenzy when it Å¿eazeth the braine. It is ingendred Å¿ometimes of corrupt bloud, and heavy and bad humours, which do intoxicate and oppreÅ¿Å¿e the braine. It is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e incident to almoÅ¿t every horÅ¿e, yea and that moÅ¿t dangerous if it be not Å¿oone eÅ¿pied. Sometimes it commeth by feeding and grazing, at what time the HorÅ¿e is hard ridden, that he be hot and Å¿weateth, for by his feeding and holding down his head Å¿o low as to graze upon the ground, the peccant humours doe fall down to the head, and there Å¿ettle, and in Å¿hort time Å¿eazeth the braine, which bringeth this mortall diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. Sometimes it commeth by what was occaÅ¿ioned by hard and over-violent riding, whereby the whole body became diÅ¿tempered, and the bloud inflamed and putrified: and Å¿ometimes it commeth by eating over-much,Corrupt bloud. for thereby is the Å¿tomack Å¿o overcharged with meat, as not to be able to digeÅ¿t and convert it all as it ought into good bloud and nutriment, and therefore muÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿arily breed evill humours, which attaching the head and braine, it is in concluÅ¿ion the cauÅ¿e of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. The Å¿ymptomes whereby to diÅ¿cover it, is, in that his Å¿ight will faile him, and he will hardly be able to Å¿ee a white Wall, he will Å¿laver at the mouth, and his eyes will be Å¿welled, and runne with much water and other filth, and his gate will be reeling and Å¿tagge â¢ ing, he will oft lye down and beat his head againÅ¿t the planks, floore, and walles, and when he is laid, his body will quiver and Å¿hake, and he will forÅ¿ake his meat; and theÅ¿e be moÅ¿t certaine Å¿ignes which I have ever obÅ¿erved to be in horÅ¿es oppreÅ¿Å¿ed and exerciÅ¿ed with this infirmity.

But now to come to the cure: I will give you firÅ¿t a cure which a French MariÅ¿hal taught me, which by reaÅ¿on it Å¿ounded to be Å¿o much improbable, I would never make tryall thereof, but Å¿uch as it is you Å¿hall have it. FaÅ¿ten unto the end of a Å¿tick a linnen ragge, and anoint it well with Barbary Sope, and put it up into his noÅ¿e gently, and by degrees, and Å¿o draw it out again as treatably. Another.

If you do perceive your horÅ¿e in his travell to fall Å¿icke Å¿uddenly of the Stavers, Stavers. and that you be in Å¿uch a place, where for the preÅ¿ent you can get no help, then thruÅ¿t up the greater end of your riding rod into either noÅ¿trill good and hard, cauÅ¿ing him thereby to bleed well, and this will preÅ¿erve him for the time, till you come where you may meet with better remedy: then take a piece of Wheaten leaven, bay Salt, Rue, Aqua vitae, and Å¿trong white Wine Vineger, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, bray all theÅ¿e in a Å¿tone morter very well, then put this medicine into two thin fine linnen clothes or rags,
by equall portions, and then moiÅ¿ten it well in the liquor, and Å¿o convey thoÅ¿e clouts into either of his eares one, and then Å¿titch them up cloÅ¿e, that he get not the medicine forth, but that the Å¿ubÅ¿tance thereof may be diffuÅ¿ed into his head, and let the medicine remaine Å¿o foure and twenty hours, then take forth the rags, and this will make him a Å¿ound and whole horÅ¿e. â But before you apply this medicine to his eares, run him through the griÅ¿tle of the noÅ¿e with a long iron Bodkin, and the next day after let him bloud in the neck and mouth, and then giue him this drink, which will keep off the Yellowes for comming too faÅ¿t upon him; then take Turmerick, Mirrha, Ivory, or Harts-horne, of each one ounce, of Saffaron one penny worth, pound all theÅ¿e by themÅ¿elves to very fine powder, then take Seladine a good handfull, Å¿tamp it and Å¿traine it, and put the juyce thereof to the other ingredients, then put unto it of Muskadine or Å¿weet Sack, one pinte, or for want thereof, of Å¿trong Ale one quart, adding unto it of London Treacle one ounce, Å¿et theÅ¿e upon the fire, and let it boyle one walme or two, and in the taking off, put unto it of Å¿weet Butter the quantity of an Egge, and Å¿o having well brewed the Å¿ame, give it him bloud warme, and for three or foure dayes, give him either Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white water. â This is very good. Another.

FirÅ¿t take bloud from him in the necke and mouth, and let him chew and Å¿wallow down his own bloud, being moÅ¿t wholeÅ¿ome for him; and whilÅ¿t he is thus bleeding, thruÅ¿t an iron Bodkin through the griÅ¿tle of his noÅ¿e, skin and all, then

Take AÅ¿Å¿afetida, the quantity of a haÅ¿le nut, and diÅ¿Å¿olve it into a Å¿awcer full of white Wine Vineger, then take Lint or fine Flax, and dip it into the liquor, and Å¿o Å¿top both your HorÅ¿e eares therewith, and Å¿o Å¿titch them up, and at the end of foure and twenty houres, unÅ¿titch them, and he is cured. â This is very good. Another.
FirÅ¿t let him bloud in both the weeping veynes, and in the mouth, then

Take of bitter Almonds one ounce and a halfe, of the gall of an Oxe two drams, of black Ellebore made into fine powder, a halfe penny worth, of Graynes, CaÅ¿toreum, Vineger, and of VarniÅ¿h, of each five drams, boyle all theÅ¿e together, untill the Vineger be all conÅ¿umed, then Å¿traine it, and put it into his eares, and do as before. â This is very good. Another. Bloudy him as before, then with your inciÅ¿ion knife, make a Å¿lit down his forehead an inch long and better, and with your cornet looÅ¿en the skin round about, but moÅ¿t toward the foretop, then put into the place the root of a red great Dock, cut thin, and let it remaine there fourteen or fifteen dayes, and once in two dayes at furmoÅ¿t, cruÅ¿h out the mattrative Å¿tuffe, and then take forth the Dock roots, and heale up the place with your healing Salve, and give him during theÅ¿e fourteen dayes, white water onely, and he will doe well. â This I aÅ¿Å¿ure you is very good. Another
Bloudy, &c. Then take Aqua-vitae, and Garlicke, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, Å¿tamp them together, and convey it into his eares doing vt Å¿upra, â. This is Å¿ingular good. Another. Let him bleede well in the neck and mouth (for the abundance of bad bloud is the cauÅ¿e of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e) then with your InciÅ¿ion knife Å¿lit the forehead of the HorÅ¿e, and with your Cronet raiÅ¿e the skin eÅ¿pecially upwards, & put in three or foure cloves of Garlick pilled, & put upon it a little lint or fine Flax to keepe away the Wind (for that is dangerous) and then give the Orifice a Å¿titch to keep in the Medicine the better. Then.

Take the Å¿eeds of CreÅ¿Å¿es, of Poppy, of Smallage, of ParÅ¿ly, of Dill (I Å¿ay the Å¿eeds only of theÅ¿e hearbs) and take alÅ¿o pepper, and Saffaron, of each two drammes, make them all into fine powder, and put unto them of Barley water two quarts, as it commeth boyling from the fire, and let it infuÅ¿e therein three houres, and then Å¿traine it, and give him one quart thereof, if it may be in the morning faÅ¿ting bloud-warme, and walke him up and downe an houre and better, and then Å¿et him up warme, and give him Hay Å¿prinkled with water, and the next day give him the other quart faÅ¿ting, and then doe as before, neither let him drinke any cold water in foure or five daies after, but only white water, unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ometimes a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h: And thus doing he will be cured. X. This is a moÅ¿t excellent Receipt, and I have often uÅ¿ed it.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat remedy have you for a HorÅ¿e that hath Swelled-Legges?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This Malady of Å¿welled or Gourdy-Legs commeth eft-Å¿oones by long Å¿tanding in the Stable, when as the upper parts of the plancks at his fore-feete, are much higher then that at the hinder feete, as I have before obÅ¿erved in lib. 1. cap. 4. for by that meanes the HorÅ¿e not Å¿tanding even, and therefore not at his caÅ¿e, the bloud Å¿etleth in the hinder-Legges, which cauÅ¿eth them to Å¿well. Sometimes they doe come by reaÅ¿on the HorÅ¿e being hard ridden, was brought into the Stable too hot, and careleÅ¿ly Å¿et up, who taking cold, the bloud, greaÅ¿e, and humours do fall downe into the Legges, and Å¿o cauÅ¿e them to Å¿well. Sometimes it commeth by over-riding, whereby the HorÅ¿e hath his bloud Å¿tirred, and his greaÅ¿e melted, which falleth down, and reÅ¿teth in the hinder-Legges, cauÅ¿ing them to Å¿well. Sometimes by being ridden and gallopping upon hard waies in the Heates, and by that meanes the bloud and greaÅ¿e falleth downe into his Legges, congealeth there, whereby they do become gowty and gourdy. And Å¿ometimes gourdy-Legges cometh by Å¿icknes and Å¿urfets taken, which after remedy had, yet the faeces or dregges thereof Å¿till remayning in the body of the horÅ¿e, falleth downe, and cauÅ¿eth the legges to Å¿well, as
I have frequently Å¿eene. And theÅ¿e be the primme cauÅ¿es and reaÅ¿ons which we have obÅ¿erved for this Malady.Swelled-Legges. The Å¿ignes your eie doth demonÅ¿trate, and you may without teaching point to it with your finger, and therefore we may Å¿ay nothing thereof. Wherefore now we will to the cure.
