If the Å¿welling come by ordinary meanes, then take up the Thigh-veines, and then you neede doe no more, for that alone will cure him, and after open the heele-veines, and lay a Retoyre to the Legges, or elÅ¿e give him the fire which will Å¿iccicate & dry up the bad humours, which muÅ¿t be given gently, and lightly, neither would I have you give him the fire, unleÅ¿Å¿e you might thinke or find it in your iudgement to be very requiÅ¿ite. But my meaning is not that this remedy of the fire bee applyed, but only to an old griefe, otherwiÅ¿e not at all. â. This is good. But if beÅ¿ides his Å¿welled-Legges, they alÅ¿o be Å¿tiffe, comming to him after much labour and travell; therefore.

Take of Violet-leaves, PrimroÅ¿e-leaves, and Strawberry-leaves, of each a handfull, boyle all theÅ¿e in new-Milke till they become very Å¿oft, and then take it from the fire, and put to it of the oyle of Nervall, of Petroleum, and of Pamphilion, of each one ounce, and Å¿o Å¿tirre all together untill it becometh bloud-warme, and therewith chafe, rub, and anoint the Legges, Nerves, Sinewes, and Ioynts, holding a hot barre of Iron neere to the place, to cauÅ¿e the Vnguent to Å¿inke the better in: Anoint him thus with this Vnguent, five or Å¿ixe daies together, and it will helpe him. â. This I have often uÅ¿ed. Another.

Take Traine-oyle, and warme it upon the fire, and therewith bathe his legges morning and evening, and in Å¿hort time he will be well. â. This is very good; alÅ¿o to ride your HorÅ¿e into the water morning and evening up to the belly, doth take away the Å¿welling of his legges. X. This is mervelous good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to aÅ¿Å¿wage the Å¿welling of the Cods in a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This Malady commeth many waies, to wit, by violent riding & heats, when there was not Å¿ufficient care had of him, but was neglected in the Å¿etting up; alÅ¿o it commeth by waÅ¿hing, walking, and cold taken after immoderate labour, and Å¿ometimes by feeding to intemperately upon Provender, and Å¿ometimes by feeding upon unwholeÅ¿ome meate. The Å¿ignes to know it, are, his Å¿tomacke may be peradventure good to his meate, but yet it will do him little good, for he will be alwaies meagre and leane, his hayre will Å¿tare, neither will he caÅ¿t his coate at uÅ¿uall times like as other HorÅ¿es doe, he will looÅ¿e his mettle, and become very lunt, and his eyes will run with water and matter, and his Å¿tones will Å¿well; in a word, he will be out of
ioynt, that is, out of good temper throughout every part and member of his Body. Other cauÅ¿es there bee of this Malady whereof I have intreated before in lib. 2. cap. 6. Â§. 9. let. C. to which place I do referre you; nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will give you a Receipt or two which I have often uÅ¿ed, and doe know them to be right good.

Swelled codsTake Turmerick and long-Pepper, of each a penny-worth, AnniÅ¿eeds, and Fenugrick, of each a halfe penny-worth, Å¿weet Butter Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, boyle all theÅ¿e (being firÅ¿t powdred) in Ale three pints, till one pint be conÅ¿umed, and then take it from the fire, and Å¿traine it, and diÅ¿Å¿olve into it in London Treacle one ounce, and Å¿o well brewed, give it your HorÅ¿e bloud-warme, let him have this drinke Å¿undry times, and let otherwiÅ¿e his drinke be white water, and Å¿ometimes a Å¿weete MaÅ¿h till he be well. â. This is very good. Another.

Take of the beÅ¿t Tarre two Å¿poonefuls, life-honey one Å¿poonefull, black-Å¿ope the quantity of a Nutmegge, Diapente one ounce, and of Bay-Å¿alt two Å¿poonefuls, mix all theÅ¿e well together, and convey it into two or three Egges-Å¿hels, the tops being Å¿o opened as that you may but get forth the meate, then fill up the Å¿hels with this Medicine, and Å¿o put them downe his throate in a morning faÅ¿ting, and give him preÅ¿ently after it two or three hornefuls of Ale or Beere to Å¿end downe the Medicine the better, but the Å¿urpluÅ¿age of what remaineth of the Medicine, let it be Å¿pred upon the roofe of his mouth, doe thus every morning for eight dayes together, and when he hath taken his Medicine, let him be ridden gently an houre or two, and then Å¿et him up warme cloathed and littered, and Å¿et him upon the Trench three houres, and let his drinke bee white water, and Å¿ometimes a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, both then and for Å¿ometime after. â. This is alÅ¿o very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you take off a Spongy-Wart?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
A Spongy-Wart, Spongy-wart. is that very thing which our Ferriers cal an Anberry, which is kind of wen, which Å¿welleth Å¿omtimes to a great bigneÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿ometimes againe it will bee but Å¿mall, but then commonly they are many, and do grow into cluÅ¿ters, this commeth by meanes of peccant humours cauÅ¿ed of bad bloud, and that horÅ¿e that is inclined to Warts, will Å¿eldome be ever free of them, for take them off in one place, and he will put forth more in other parts of his body, but to breed of eyther HorÅ¿e or Mare inclined to them I will diÅ¿wade you: for moÅ¿t commonly hee will put them forth about the eyes, yea, and oft-times Å¿o neere to the eye it Å¿elfe as to endanger the Å¿ight thereof; They be eaÅ¿ily knowne by reaÅ¿on they be Å¿o apparently Å¿eene, and therefore need no further deÅ¿cription. The cure is. It were good firÅ¿t to purge him, and to take bloud from that MaÅ¿ter-veine
which you doe finde doth moÅ¿t feed them, as well to divert as to Å¿top the malice of that bad humour which doth occaÅ¿ion the malady. If the Wart or Anberry be farre enough extant from the skin, then tye two of his Å¿trongeÅ¿t hayres taken from his tayle, hard about the Å¿orance Å¿o faÅ¿t as you poÅ¿Å¿ibly can, and Å¿o as that it may not looÅ¿en, and in few dayes it will fret and eate it cleane off, which done, Å¿trew upon it the powder of Verdegrece to kill it at the root, and after heale it up againe with your green Å¿alve. But if you cannot come to tye it either with hayre or threed, then either with your inciÅ¿ion knife cut it away cloÅ¿e to the skin, or elÅ¿e burn off with an hot iron, and then firÅ¿t kill the fire with Turpentine and Hogs greaÅ¿e molten together, and after heale it up as before is preÅ¿cribed you. â This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to be applyed to a HorÅ¿e that is Surbated?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Two wayes a horÅ¿e doth Å¿urbate; the firÅ¿t is when a horÅ¿e is newly backt and weighed, upon his firÅ¿t Å¿hooing, and when the owner of the horÅ¿e will not have patience with him, but will preÅ¿ently journey him upon hard and Å¿tony wayes, his hoofes and feet being yet but tender to what they will be afterwards, and Å¿o the horÅ¿e muÅ¿t needs Å¿urbate. The Å¿econd way is, when a horÅ¿e hath of himÅ¿elfe bad feet, and is alÅ¿o either ill Å¿hod, or elÅ¿e his Å¿hooes be very thinne worne, or that they be too narrow or too Å¿hort, and that he be ridden upon bad, hard, Å¿tony, and rough wayes; in Å¿uch like caÅ¿es your horÅ¿e will Å¿urbate; you Å¿hall finde it by the handling of his feet, eÅ¿pecially the next day after a long journey, by reaÅ¿on he will not Å¿tand Å¿till long upon his feet without hitching them up, and removing them, for that they will be Å¿o Å¿ore; as that he will not know how or where to place them, and you Å¿hall alÅ¿o perceive him to be Å¿urbated, by reaÅ¿on that after a journey he will lye much, Å¿tanding being painefull unto him, and in his lying you Å¿hall Å¿ee him covet to lye and Å¿tretch himÅ¿elf all along upon one Å¿ide, and if you feele the coffins of his hoofes, you Å¿hall finde them to burne very hot, and his hoofes to be very dry. The cure is very facile.

Take two new laid Egges,Surbated feet. and after you have well picked his fore-feet, breake them raw into the Å¿oles, and then Å¿top them up with Oxe or Cow dung, and he will be well by the next morning. â This is an approved good cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you cure a HorÅ¿e that is Å¿tifled?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This miÅ¿chiefe commeth accidentally, to wit, either by a Å¿traine in leaping, or by a Å¿lip in travell, or by the Å¿troke of Å¿ome other horÅ¿e, and thus the bone is either out of its place, or elÅ¿e the joynt is very much Å¿trained or hurt. The Å¿ignes to know it is; if the bone be out, you may Å¿ee it plainely, for beÅ¿ides his halting, the bone diÅ¿located will Å¿o Å¿tick out, as that the horÅ¿e can do no more then touch the ground with his toe, til it be put in again, and the way to put it in is thus. FirÅ¿t tye down his head to the Manger, then take a cord and faÅ¿ten it to the paÅ¿terne of the Å¿tifled Stifled. legge, and draw his legge forwards, and Å¿o the bone will come right by helping it with your hand, which being in, your care then muÅ¿t be to keep it in with your hand, and then tye the other end of the cord to the Rack, Å¿o as he may not put back his legge to diÅ¿locate the bone any more for an houre or two after till it be Å¿etled and dreÅ¿Å¿ed. Wherefore let his Keeper Å¿tand by him all the time, leÅ¿t the horÅ¿e Å¿hould lye down, or be unruly. This done, take pitch which you muÅ¿t have molten in a pot, in a readineÅ¿Å¿e, and with a clout upon a Å¿tick annoint the Å¿tifling three or foure inches broad at the leaÅ¿t, and ten inches long, and preÅ¿ently before the pitch can coole, have a Å¿trong piece of new Canvas cut fit for the purpoÅ¿e, which being made very warme by a fire, clap it upon the place Å¿o neatly, that the bone cannot goe forth againe. This plaiÅ¿ter muÅ¿t not lye towards the flanke and foot longÅ¿t-wayes, but croÅ¿Å¿e-wayes upon the joynt, as it were about the thigh, otherwiÅ¿e it cannot hold in the bone. Having thus done, anoint the plaiÅ¿ter on the out-Å¿ide all over with the Å¿aid molten pitch, and whilÅ¿t it is warm, clap flocks of the horÅ¿es colour all over upon the out-Å¿ide of the Canvas, and let the plaiÅ¿ter remaine on untill it fall away of it Å¿elfe, and after that you may apply Å¿uch good Vnguents as you may thinke to be moÅ¿t expedient for the malady. But if the bone be not out, then put in a French Rowell a little beneath the Å¿tifling-place, and let the Rowell remain in fifteen dayes, turning it once every day, and at fifteen dayes end take it forth, and heale up the orifice, like as before you have been taught. â This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat remedy may be had for a HorÅ¿e that is troubled with the Stone?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This is a very troubleÅ¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and it commeth of groÅ¿Å¿e and bad humours, gotten principally by violent exerciÅ¿e, and intemperate riding, and it commeth from the Liver and Spleen, which falling down into the kidneyes and bladder, Å¿ettleth there, whereby there groweth in the mouth of the conduct certaine inflamed hard
knots which Å¿toppeth his urine, whereby he is not able to piÅ¿Å¿e, but with great difficulty, by reaÅ¿on the Å¿inewes and the pores about the necke of the bladder are benummed, which taketh away the Å¿enÅ¿e and feeling of the bladder. And Å¿ometimes this infirmity commeth by reaÅ¿on that in his travell, the horÅ¿e is kept Å¿o long in agitation, as not to Å¿uffer him to Å¿tale and piÅ¿Å¿e, for the water being made hot by exerciÅ¿e, doth conglutinate, and becommeth viÅ¿cous and thick, Å¿o as it cannot paÅ¿Å¿e away from him, as nature requireth it Å¿hould do, whereby there is made too great a retention of the Vrine, by meanes of the obÅ¿tructions he hath in his kidneyes, which engendreth gravell, Å¿ometimes red, and Å¿ometimes grey, which falling down into the conducts, ingendreth phlegmaticke and groÅ¿Å¿e humours, which occaÅ¿ioneth conglutination, and Å¿o becommeth to be the Å¿tone, waxing Å¿o hard, and thereby Å¿topping the current of his water, Å¿o as he will not be able to piÅ¿Å¿e or Å¿tale. And you may come eaÅ¿ily to know it, by reaÅ¿on that he can neither draw his yard, nor piÅ¿Å¿e, but with great paine and difficulty in his Å¿heath, and that many times drop by drop.

The cure is, take Saxafrage, Nettle-roots, ParÅ¿ley-roots,Stone. Fennell-roots, Sperage-roots, and of Dodder, of each one handfull, bruiÅ¿e all theÅ¿e things, and boyle them on a gentle fire with white Wine, untill a third part be conÅ¿umed, then put unto it of Salt one handfull, of Sallet oyle, and of the Lard of a Goat, of each three ounces, Honey halfe a pound; when all this is boyled, Å¿traine it, and wring it very hard, and of this give your HorÅ¿e one pinte every morning faÅ¿ting, made bloud warme, and if in the boyling or by Å¿tanding, it happen to become thicke, diÅ¿Å¿olve it again with white Wine, and after the firÅ¿t boyling it muÅ¿t be but onely warmed. And give to him this drinke every morning Å¿o long as it will laÅ¿t. â This is very good, for I have often tryed it. Another as good as the former.

Take of Å¿trong Ale one quart, and put it into a pottle pot, then take Å¿o many of the reddeÅ¿t RadiÅ¿h roots, cleane waÅ¿hed and Å¿liced into Å¿mall pieces as will fill up the pot, then Å¿top up the pot Å¿o cloÅ¿e, as that the ayre cannot get in, and let it remaine foure and twenty hours, then Å¿traine the roots from the Ale very hard into Å¿ome other clean pot, and Å¿o give it him in a morning faÅ¿ting with a horne, then ride him a while upon it, and Å¿o Å¿et him up warme covered and well littered, and in a little while you Å¿hall Å¿ee him piÅ¿Å¿e, give him this drink Å¿undry mornings together; and during this cure, let him have but onely white water to drink. â This is Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for a String-hault?String-hault.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a malady which for the moÅ¿t part the beÅ¿t mettled horÅ¿es be many times troubled with; it commeth meerly of cold, as by taking cold Å¿uddenly after hard riding, eÅ¿pecially when by being waÅ¿hed, for the bloud and Å¿inewes being by that meanes Å¿tupified and benummed, is the cauÅ¿e of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e by reaÅ¿on the Å¿enÅ¿e and feeling of the member is taken from him; you may eaÅ¿ily know it by the manner of the unÅ¿ightly lifting, and Å¿udden Å¿natching up of his legge much higher then the other, and it commonly commeth into the hinder legge, rather then into the fore-legge. The cure is, firÅ¿t to take up the veine in the thigh, and after to anoint all the legge and the thigh from the body down unto the very foot a long time together, one holding a red hot Barre of iron neere to the place, and let him be anointed with this oyntment.

Take of the oyle of Petroleum, of the oyle of Wormes, of the oyle of Nervall, of Patch or Piece greaÅ¿e, of the oyle of Spike, of each one ounce, of London Treacle two ounces, and of Hogs greaÅ¿e one pound, melt all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and then take it off, and keep it with continuall Å¿tirring til it be thorough cold, and with this anoint the viÅ¿ited member every day once, and then wiÅ¿pe him up with a Å¿oft thumb band of Hay from the paÅ¿terne to the top of the hoofe, and thus do for ten dayes together, rubbing and chafing in the ointment very well a long time together, holding (as before I have adviÅ¿ed) a hot barre of iron neere to it, to cauÅ¿e this Vnguent the better to Å¿inke into the Å¿inewes, nerves, and joynts. But after you have done anointing him, you muÅ¿t keep him warme and well littered, and let the thumb band be daily made leÅ¿Å¿er and leÅ¿Å¿er, and Å¿horter and Å¿horter, till you perceive him to handle both legges alike, and your HorÅ¿e to be recovered; but you muÅ¿t not ride him that he may Å¿weat much in a moneth after, and Å¿o Å¿oon as warme weather commeth, turne him to graÅ¿Å¿e into Å¿ome dry paÅ¿ture where is water, and take him up againe about Bartholomew Tide, or before the cold commeth, and whilÅ¿t he doth remaine in the Stable, keep him warm, and Å¿o he will be free of his String-hault, and be a Å¿ound horÅ¿e againe. To anoynt him alÅ¿o with Acopum is very good. â Thus I have recovered Å¿undry horÅ¿es of this malady.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is the nature of SuppoÅ¿itories?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: The nature of SuppoÅ¿itories are to helpe a horÅ¿e that cannot well empty himÅ¿elfe; for a SuppoÅ¿itory cauÅ¿eth him to diÅ¿charge himÅ¿elfe of many Å¿uperfluous and evill humours which do diÅ¿turb, annoy, and diÅ¿temper his body with their peccant qualities and conditions, for they breed bad nutriment, which oft times good dyet cannot amend, and therefore muÅ¿t be Å¿ent away by purgation, that is to Å¿ay, by SuppoÅ¿itory, or CliÅ¿ter, or Potion; I have Å¿poken already Å¿ufficiently, and therefore I will now intreat of SuppoÅ¿itories onely, which of all other wayes is the gentleÅ¿t, wherewith to purge and cleanÅ¿e the guts: for a SuppoÅ¿itory is but a preparative to a CliÅ¿ter or Potion, whereby to looÅ¿en the guts, which may be bound and clogged with dry, hot, and hard excrements, which a SuppoÅ¿itory rather then a CliÅ¿ter can looÅ¿en; and as I have already given you receits for CliÅ¿ters, Å¿o now will I give you for SuppoÅ¿itories, whereof you may make uÅ¿e according as occaÅ¿ion and neceÅ¿Å¿ity Å¿hall require.

Take a great Candle of four in the pound, and cut off three inches SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 1 at the Å¿maller end, and then anoint the bigger and longer part either with Sallet oyle, or freÅ¿h or Å¿weet Butter, and Å¿o convey it into his fundament, then with your hand hold his tayle to his tuell a good halfe houre, or elÅ¿e tye his tayle with a Å¿trap to his girt or SurÅ¿ingle, by which time the SuppoÅ¿itory will be diÅ¿Å¿olved, then let looÅ¿e his taile, and then preÅ¿ently leap his backe and trot him up and down till he do begin to empty and purge himÅ¿elfe, for by this meanes it will worke the better and more kindely. â This is the moÅ¿t gentle of all SuppoÅ¿itories can be given. â This diÅ¿Å¿olveth all hard, dry, and hot excrements, and Å¿endeth them forth, and beÅ¿ides it Å¿uppleth the guts. Another, If you doe finde your horÅ¿e to be Å¿o exceeding weake, as that you dare not without perill of his life, adminiÅ¿ter unto him any Potion or purging medicine, then give him this SuppoÅ¿itory.

Take of common Honey Å¿ixe ounces, of Salt-Niter one ounce and SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 2 a halfe, of Wheate flowre, and of AnniÅ¿eeds in fine powder, of each one ounce, boile all theÅ¿e to a Å¿tiffe thickneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o make it into Å¿uppoÅ¿itories, then take one of them and anoint it all over with Sallet oyle, and your hand alÅ¿o, and Å¿o put it up into his fundament the length of your hand, then tye his tayle betwixt his legges, as before is Å¿hewed, and let it remaine Å¿o halfe an houre, by which time the Å¿uppoÅ¿itory will be diÅ¿Å¿olved, then ride and order him as before. â This is alÅ¿o very good, eÅ¿pecially in caÅ¿e of Å¿urfets or inward Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e. Another.

Take a piece of CaÅ¿tle-Sope, and paring it bring it into the faÅ¿hion SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 3 of a Å¿uppoÅ¿itory, and apply it, and order him as before is taught you. â This is Å¿peciall good to purge phlegme, & it is very gentle. Another.

SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 4 Take Saven, Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and Å¿tamp it to maÅ¿h, and Å¿tamp with in StaveÅ¿aker and Salt, of each two ounces, boyle theÅ¿e in common Hony Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, till it be thick, and Å¿o make it up into SuppoÅ¿itories and adminiÅ¿ter one of them, like as you are before Å¿hewed, and order him Å¿o likewiÅ¿e. â. This purgeth Choler. Another.
SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 5 Take an angry red Onion and pill it, and iagge it croÅ¿Å¿e wayes with your knife, and Å¿o adminiÅ¿ter it, and order him as before. X. This purgeth Melancholy. Another.

SuppoÅ¿iâ£tory. 6 Take common-hony one pint, and boyle it till it be thick, & make it up into SuppoÅ¿itories as it cooleth, and adminiÅ¿ter it, and order him as before is preÅ¿cribed you. â, This purgeth evill humours, it cooleth and comforteth the body very much, and cauÅ¿eth a good appetite to meate. All theÅ¿e I have often uÅ¿ed and I do know them to bee very good. But you muÅ¿t take with you Å¿ome inÅ¿tructions fit to bee knowne, which are; FirÅ¿t, when at any time you do adminiÅ¿ter eyther SuppoÅ¿itoriesâª ClyÅ¿ters, Potions, you muÅ¿t doe it in a morning faÅ¿ting unleÅ¿Å¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ity urge the contrary: Secondly, you muÅ¿t not at thoÅ¿e times Å¿uffer him to drinke any cold water, no not with exerciÅ¿e, but eyther Å¿weet MaÅ¿hes, or white water. Thirdly, it is very needfull that before you Å¿hall adminiÅ¿ter eyther SuppoÅ¿itory, ClyÅ¿ter, or Potion, that the HorÅ¿e bee raked. And fourthly that he be after kept warme.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat benefit commeth to a HorÅ¿e by Sweating?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
Truely Sir very much, for by moderat and iudicious giving of Sweates, as well in his cloathes in the Stable, as abroad in his exerciÅ¿e, you may cure him of many Maladies and prevent, many infirmities which otherwiÅ¿e might accrew unto him. For Sweating doth open the pores, & Å¿endeth forth thoÅ¿e peccant and malignant humours which doe annoy, oppreÅ¿Å¿e, and vexe him. But as touching this manner of Å¿weating by you propoÅ¿ed, it hath relation unto what I have already handled in lib. 2. cap. 2. where I intreating of what is to be done to a HorÅ¿e, newly taken from graÅ¿Å¿e, I there tooke occaÅ¿ion to adviÅ¿e Å¿weating, and there I referred you to this place, and therefore I will here illuÅ¿trate it. Wherefore if you bee in the way of enÅ¿ayning your HorÅ¿e having already purged, bloudied and cleanÅ¿ed him, and prepared his body fit for Å¿weating Sweating. (if neede Å¿hall require) Then if the weather be faire and warme, ride him a mile upon his trot, and then home againe, then preÅ¿ently litter him very well, and cloath him up Å¿o warme as that he may Å¿weate, but not yet Å¿o violently as to Å¿tirre the humours in his body too much, neyther let him Å¿weate above an houre, and then coole him againe by degrees, and that with
great care and moderation; and thus ride and Å¿weate him for three dayes together; then for Å¿ixe dayes together keepe him warme, but not to Å¿weate any more, and during the time of his Å¿weating, and Å¿ixe or eight dayes after, let him have no cold drinke, but white water, and Å¿ometimes a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h. And thus briefly of Å¿weating. â. This manner of giving Å¿weates I have often uÅ¿ed, and with great commodity to the HorÅ¿e. But let us paÅ¿Å¿e on to another Chapter.

sp.speaker: Hippophilus.
sp.p: WHat cure have you for a HorÅ¿e whoÅ¿e Tongue is hurt? Tong hurt

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This Malady commeth by accident, as with with a Bit, Halter, or the like.

Take therefore of Arman halfe an ounce, and roÅ¿t it in the embers till it be red-hot, then take it up and beat it to very fine powder: then take of life-hony a Sawcer-full, and of white Wine one pint mixe and Å¿teepe theÅ¿e with the powder together, and Å¿o let it boyle over the fire, Å¿tirring it continually, then take it off, and let it coole, and Å¿o waÅ¿h his tongue therewith morning and evening, or as you Å¿hall pleaÅ¿e till it be whole. â. This is very good. Another.

Take the iuyce of Salendine, and waÅ¿h the hurt-tongue therewith nine dayes together, and it will cure it, albeit it be halfe cut in Å¿under, for the iuyce of Salendine well conglutinat and Å¿odder the tongue together being cut or wounded. â. This alÅ¿o is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you helpe a HorÅ¿e that hath an Itch in his Tayle?Taile an itch.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This commeth of rankneÅ¿Å¿e of bloud, and therefore it is requiÅ¿ite that firÅ¿t he be let bloud in the Tayle, and that hee bleed well. After.

Take Buck-lye, and with a Ragge or Hurds in the Lye waÅ¿h the place infected every day often, or as many times as it Å¿halbe dry, and continue thus doing foure or five dayes, and this will cure it. â. This
is very good. Another. But if the hayre do fall away with the Mainge, or Itch, then Å¿lit the skin from within two inches of the Tuell to the fourth ioynt, and with your Cornet take out a certaine bone or griÅ¿tle, which the French do call Bariuole, then fill up the clift with Salt made into fine powder, and with a hot iron burne the tayle in Å¿undry places, and waÅ¿h it with Buck-lye, as before; But your Lye muÅ¿t bee made very Å¿trong. This cure I never practiÅ¿ed, but I once Å¿aw a MariÅ¿hall of Paris dreÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o cured a HorÅ¿e in this manner of this malady, of whom I had the cure.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you make your Vnguentum Theriacum?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This Vnguentum Theriacum Theriacum Vnguentum. is moÅ¿t Å¿overaigne for any Ach in any of the Ioynts; it is alÅ¿o Å¿peciall good for HorÅ¿es that doe fall lame, if the griefe be in the Hip, Stifling-place, legs, Å¿houlders, PaÅ¿ternes, or any other part of the legges, a back-Å¿inew-Å¿prain only excepted. And thus I do make it.

Take of Nervell, of Oyle of Pamphilion, and of black-Sope, of each two ounces, and of tryed-hogs-greaÅ¿e halfe a pound, melt all theÅ¿e upon a gentle fire, and being molten put into it of ordinary Treacle two penny-worth, then take it from the fire, then with a Splatter or Spoone, keepe it by continuall Å¿tirring till it be through cold, then will it be of a dun-colour, keep this in a gally-pot for your uÅ¿e. And thus is it made. â. This is moÅ¿t excellent to raiÅ¿e the veine from the Å¿inew at what time you are to take up the veine, I have tryed it Å¿aepÃ¨ et Å¿aepiÃ¹s.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you deÅ¿troy a Tetter?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.

Take the rootes of Elicampane, and the rootes of the red-Dock, of each like much, Å¿lice them thinne, and put them into vrine three quarts with Bay-Å¿alt, two handfuls, let it boyle untill one quart bee conÅ¿umed, then take it off, and with a clout faÅ¿tned to a Å¿tick waÅ¿h the Sorance very hot. VÅ¿e this foure or five mornings together, and it will kill it. â. This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to be done to a horÅ¿e that tyreth in travell, and falleth Å¿icke?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: For a HorÅ¿e to tire upon the way, the cauÅ¿es are many: FirÅ¿t, for that he is travelled when he Å¿hall be too young; Secondly, in that he is lately taken from graÅ¿Å¿e whilÅ¿t he is yet foule and foggy, before he be well enÅ¿aimed; thirdly, in that he hath beene long kept and pampered in the Stable, without giving him breath or moderate exerciÅ¿e; Fourthly, by being travelled beyond his Å¿trength in longer journeyes, and deeper waies then he was well able to performe; Fiftly, it might be through the covetouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e or careleÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of his rider, in not feeding or Å¿eeing him fed Å¿o well as was fitting; Sixtly and laÅ¿tly, by reaÅ¿on the HorÅ¿e might have Å¿ome Å¿ecret infirmity whereof his maÅ¿ter might be ignorant. Wherefore if your HorÅ¿e may happen in his travell to tire or faint, have patience with him, and do not force him beyond what he may be able to performe, either by Å¿purring or beating him, like as many cholericke and paÅ¿sionate people doe uÅ¿ually, but get to Å¿ome houÅ¿e or Inne Å¿o Å¿oone as conveniently you may, when firÅ¿t you Å¿ee him begin to Å¿inke or to faint under you, Å¿et him preÅ¿ently up warme clothed, and well littered, that he take no cold, and let his Keeper or the OÅ¿tler of the Inne rubbe and chafe him all over with freÅ¿h dry Å¿traw, but eÅ¿pecially let him rub him againÅ¿t the hayre, and let him have no meat till two houres or more after you have given him this drinke.

Take of the beÅ¿t Å¿weet Sack one pinte, but if that cannot be had,Tyring in travell. then take the Å¿ame quantity of White or Claret Wine, and put therto of Cinamon, Ginger, Nutmegs, Graines, Cloves, AnniÅ¿eeds, and Fennell-Å¿eds, of each one ounce, all made into fine powder: then take red Sage, RoÅ¿emary-tops, Mints, Camomill, and wilde Thyme, of each like much, Å¿o that in all they amount to halfe a handfull, chop the hearbs very Å¿mall, and then put all theÅ¿e Hearbs and Spices into the Wine, and then boyle them a pretty while, then take it from the fire, and Å¿traine it hard, and unbit your horÅ¿e, and give him this drink bloud warme; this done, Bit him up againe, and with a Å¿witch Å¿tir him up and down as he Å¿tandeth in his place tyed to the Rack, then coole him, and two houres after his drink, give him firÅ¿t Å¿ome Hay, and halfe an houre after that, give him either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h, or white water, and after feed him at your pleaÅ¿ure, but be you conÅ¿iderate in giving him his Provender by little at once and often, and howÅ¿oever feed him well, and thus ordering him, by morning he will be well recovered, and able to travell againe. â This is an excellent drink, and of great vertue for any HorÅ¿e that tyreth or falleth Å¿ick upon the way. It is alÅ¿o very requiÅ¿ite that with a Syringe you do inject of this drinke into his noÅ¿trils. Another. If you doe feare that
your horÅ¿e may tire in his journey, for prevention, carry with you a boxe of powder of dryed Elecampane roots, and let the powder be alÅ¿o Å¿earced, and when you do come unto your Inne, let him not be walked, but Å¿et up warme in the Stable clothed and littered, his legs, body, head, and necke, be by the Groome or OÅ¿tler well rubbed, but chiefly his Poll betwixt his eares. Then take of Å¿trong Ale one quart, or of Å¿weet Sack one pinte, which is much better, and put into it of your Elecampane halfe an ounce, brew them well together, and give it him with a horne, then bridle him, and tie him to the Racke, but not too high, Å¿o as he may put down his noÅ¿e, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o an houre, then unbridle him, and give him Hay, and an houre or better after that, give him either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water, and then Provender Å¿ufficient, but with diÅ¿cretion and by degrees, and Å¿o alÅ¿o in the morning, give him both Oates and Bread, whether he will eate beÅ¿t, feeding him by little and little Å¿o long as he will eate, and in the morning when you are ready to take his backe, give him the Å¿ame drinke againe, and you Å¿hall finde him to travell with Å¿pirit and mettle; and if you tye a branch of Penny-royall upon his Bit, it will greatly comfort him. But yet for all that which hath been Å¿aid, if he happen to tire, then

Take ArÅ¿mart, and rub his bare backe where the Saddle reÅ¿teth, and lay alÅ¿o Å¿ome of the leaves upon his backe under the Saddle, and Å¿o clap on the Saddle, and this will cauÅ¿e him the better to hold out. â This is good. Another.

Take the beÅ¿t SpaniÅ¿h Tobacco you can get, Å¿hred it Å¿mall, and dry it, and make it into fine powder, and mixe therewith the powder of Cockle Å¿hels of the like quantity, which muÅ¿t be Å¿earced, and put this powder into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, keeping it cloÅ¿e Å¿topped, and Å¿o keep it to your uÅ¿e. And when you are to uÅ¿e it, take of this powder, and mixe therewith of the oyle of Dill, and of the oyle of Cloves Å¿uch a quantity as will make this powder into a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and Å¿o make it into pils, every Pill the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a Walnut, which muÅ¿t be dried in the Å¿hade (theÅ¿e Pils muÅ¿t be made in the Canicular or Dog dayes onely) then keep them cloÅ¿e Å¿topped in Å¿ome glaÅ¿Å¿e or gally pot, that no ayre can get into it, and when you have cauÅ¿e to uÅ¿e any of them, give him one of them at what time you Å¿hall perceive your horÅ¿e to faint or tire, or that you do perceive him to have taken a cold or Å¿urfet, which may very well be the cauÅ¿e of his debility, give him (I Å¿ay) one of theÅ¿e Pils when you do come unto your Inne. But if hee hath taken a cold or Å¿urfet, then give him a Pill in the morning faÅ¿ting, and let him be well rubbed, clothed warme, and well littered, and Å¿uffer him not to drink any cold water, but either a Å¿weet MaÅ¿h or white water, for there is not any thing more noxious then to give a horÅ¿e in this caÅ¿e cold water, and let his travell be moderate and with great diÅ¿cretion, and he will both hold out his journey, and get Å¿trength and fleÅ¿h alÅ¿o in his travell. â And this I have often tryed both upon my own
horÅ¿es and others in whoÅ¿e company I have travelled, as well in England as in parts abroad.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you preÅ¿cribe a Vomit to a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Of this I have Å¿poken a little already, where I did remit you to this place. We doe uÅ¿ually give vomits unto horÅ¿es newly taken up from graÅ¿Å¿e, by reaÅ¿on they are thereby full of very groÅ¿Å¿e and phlegmaticke humours, which doe abound in the Å¿tomacke and head, which if they be not fetched from the horÅ¿e in its due time, will be a meanes to impaire greatly the health of the horÅ¿e, which muÅ¿t oft times be neceÅ¿Å¿arily expulÅ¿ed by vomit, and you Å¿hall have a receit of a vomit which I had in France from a Å¿peciall Ferrier there, who (as I have before touched) hath in my preÅ¿ence adminiÅ¿tred to Å¿undry horÅ¿es, which did worke very kindely upon them, and I my Å¿elfe have adminiÅ¿tred the Å¿ame to Å¿undry HorÅ¿es here in England to very great profit unto them. The receit is this.

Take two of the greateÅ¿t roots of Polipodium you can get from the Oke, waÅ¿h and Å¿crape them very cleane, and tye it to his Snaffle,Vomiting. Trench, or Bit, then let it be Å¿teeped in the oyle of Spike a whole night, and in the morning faÅ¿ting put on his bridle with the Å¿aid roots, and ride him with it in his mouth an houre or better faire and Å¿oftly, and if he be troubled with any rhumaticke or phlegmaticke humour, or with any cold or other filthy matter which may any way peÅ¿ter, clogge, or annoy his Å¿tomacke; this thing will force him to vent them at his mouth and noÅ¿e, and it wil cauÅ¿e him to cough and neeze, whereby he will Å¿end forth a great abundance of filth and evill Å¿limy Å¿tuffe from off his Å¿tomacke and head, as that in Å¿hort time he will become very cleane in his body, for this will both refine his bloud, and exhauÅ¿t all his watry humours, in Å¿uch Å¿ort as by temperate ordering him, and doing as I have here preÅ¿cribed you, you may be confident to keep him a long Å¿ound, perfect, and Å¿erviceable horÅ¿e. And this is not to be applied onely to a horÅ¿e newly taken from graÅ¿Å¿e, but to any other horÅ¿e that hath taken a cold, or to any ketty, foule, foggy, or purÅ¿ive horÅ¿e whatÅ¿oever. â This may Å¿eeme Å¿trange here
amongÅ¿t us, but let any man make tryall, and he Å¿hall finde it to be moÅ¿t admirable.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is to be given to a HorÅ¿e that hath a violent Cough?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: If this great and very violent Cough Violent Cough. proceed from a cold (as commonly all Coughs doe) then give him firÅ¿t Wheat Bran prepared, as Å¿undry times before is preÅ¿cribed you, and take bloud from the necke veine, then with his Oates give him this powder following, viz.

Take of Comen, Fenugrick, Sileris-Montani, alias SiÅ¿ileos, Nutmegs, Cloves, Ginger, LinÅ¿eed, of each two ounces, Quick-BrimÅ¿tone Å¿ixe ounces, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and of this powder give him every night with his Oates one Å¿poonfull. But becauÅ¿e this powder diÅ¿perÅ¿eth the corrupt, groÅ¿Å¿e, and phlegmaticke humours which are predominant in the body of the horÅ¿e, which doe occaÅ¿ion the Å¿aid violent Cough, Å¿o Å¿oone as you Å¿hall perceive that with this powder he hath purged Å¿ufficiently, uÅ¿e it then no longer, but faile not to continue his white water, but before you give him his water, take a Å¿ticke about the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of your thumb at leaÅ¿t, and well-nigh a foot long, and wrap a fine ragge about it foure or five times Å¿teeped before hand in oyle de Bay, and Å¿o put it into his mouth, like as you would doe a Snaffle, and with Å¿traps made faÅ¿t to the ends of the Å¿ticke, faÅ¿tned then over his Poll, like as Smiths uÅ¿e to doe when they burne horÅ¿es for the Lampas, and let him drinke with it in his mouth, that done, let him Å¿tand with it in his mouth one houre after at the leaÅ¿t, to the end he may lick and Å¿uck up the Å¿aid oyle upon the ragge or cloth, and when you doe give him his Oates, mixe them with this powder following, viz.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: FOr what cauÅ¿es doe you take up Veines?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
As touching taking up of veines, you Å¿hall underÅ¿tand that it is a thing in many caÅ¿es Å¿o much behoofefull, as that many times the moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿ite Ferrier living, Å¿hall not be able to perfect this cure but by that way and meanes, for unleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uch veines be either taken up, or Å¿ome wayes Å¿topped, which are noxious to the cure, by feeding the malady with its peccant humours, the Ferrier
can never worke by true Art. Againe, veynes well taken up, doe prevent many maladies wherunto many horÅ¿es are much more propenÅ¿e then others are. And laÅ¿tly, the taking up of veynes, cureth Å¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which could otherwiÅ¿e never be cured. For by taking up of the thigh-veines, Å¿endeth away Spavens, Splents, Curbs, Kibed-heeles, Swelled-legges, Scratches, Malenders, Faricion in the legs and the like Å¿orances; beÅ¿ides it eaÅ¿eth all paines, aches, Å¿traines, Å¿tiffneÅ¿Å¿e in the limbs, &c. Take up the Shackle-veynes, Voynes to take up. and it preventeth the Quitter-bone, Ring-bone, Å¿wellings in the lower-joynts, foundrings, &c. Wherefore foraÅ¿much as ignorant people, whatÅ¿oever opinion they may have of their Å¿uperabundant skill, yet are they very much to Å¿eeke in that they doe Å¿o much exclaime againÅ¿t taking up of veyns, abÅ¿urdly affirming it to be a great meanes of laming of HorÅ¿es: but let them not miÅ¿take themÅ¿elves, for aÅ¿Å¿uredly it is the beÅ¿t and onely remedy againÅ¿t theÅ¿e and many more maladies, and when they Å¿hall have made triall, they will not be of Å¿o prejudicate opinions.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat good thing have you wherewith to preÅ¿erve the winde Winde to preÅ¿erve. of a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Sir, for this infirmity I make a CataplaÅ¿me which is this.

Take Wheate flowre foure pound, Elecampane and Gentian, of each one ounce, AnniÅ¿eeds, Fenugrick, Comyn, BrimÅ¿tone, and Licoris, of each halfe a pound, let all theÅ¿e be made into very fine powder and Å¿earced, then put unto it of common EngliÅ¿h Honey halfe a pound, and Å¿o much white Wine as will make all theÅ¿e things into a CataplaÅ¿me, boyle all theÅ¿e Å¿ufficiently, till it be Å¿o thicke that you may make it into Pils, and give your horÅ¿e of them three or foure at a time for Å¿ixe or eight mornings together. VÅ¿e this often, for it will conÅ¿erve a horÅ¿e in health, and keepeth him Å¿ound of his body, winde, and courage. â This is moÅ¿t excellent. But if you doe perceive a taint in his winde, then

Take a cloÅ¿e earthen Pot or Pipkin, and put thereinto of the Å¿trongeÅ¿t white Wine Vineger three pints, and foure new laid Egges unbroken,
and foure heads of Garlicke cleane pilled and bruiÅ¿ed, then cover the pot very cloÅ¿e, and bury it in a Mixen or Dung-hill twelve houres, then take it up, and take forth the Egges, but breake them not, then Å¿traine the Vineger and Garlick through a fine linnen cloth, putting unto the liquor of life-honey foure ounces, and of browne Sugar-Candy, AnniÅ¿eedes and Licoris, all made into very fine powder, of each two ounces, and your horÅ¿e having faÅ¿ted all night till morning, give him one of the Å¿teeped Egges, and then one hornefull of this liquor or drinke, and then another Egge, and after that another hornefull, and Å¿o a third Egge, and then an hornefull, and laÅ¿tly a fourth Egge, and Å¿o the reÅ¿idue of the liquor, remembring to give him into eyther noÅ¿ethrill halfe a hornefull of his drinke, and it muÅ¿t be adminiÅ¿tred bloud-warme, then Å¿et him upon the Trench, cloth, Å¿top, and litter him warme, and let him Å¿tand Å¿o foure houres, then unbit him, and if it be in Winter time give him Å¿weet Wheate-Å¿traw, but no Hay, and if it be in Summer, give him graÅ¿Å¿e, greene-corne, or the leaves of Sallowes, and for nine dayes give him eyther Å¿weete MaÅ¿hes, or white water, putting therein Å¿ome Salet-oyle, and be you aÅ¿Å¿ured hee will doe well againe. â. This is alÅ¿o very good. Another.

Take a Hedge-hogge alive, and Bake him in the Oven in an earthen-pot, cloÅ¿e Å¿topped untill he do become Å¿o dry as that you may make him into powder: give him alÅ¿o this powder one Å¿poonefull, in a quart of good Ale every other day, and this will infinitely helpe and preÅ¿erve his winde. â. This is alÅ¿o Å¿peciall good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: IS there Å¿uch a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e which is called the Wilde-Fire?Wild-fire.

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Yea Sir, there is, and it is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e moÅ¿t dangerous and very difficult to cure, but by a Receipt of a powder which once I obtained of a skilfull Chirurgion, which Å¿aid powder is not fit to bee applyed to any living creature, but to a horÅ¿e only it is Å¿o terrible. And thus it is to be made, viz.

Take of living Toades foure, the greateÅ¿t and blackeÅ¿t can bee found, living Moles or Ants three, and of old Shoo-Å¿oles Å¿ixe, and heads of Garlick unpilled, and with their beards or roots remaining upon them forty, then take of the leaneÅ¿t and Å¿alteÅ¿t Martlemas-beefe three pounds, cut it into thin and Å¿wall peeces and Å¿lices, Å¿uch Martlemas-beefe I meane which hath longeÅ¿t hanged in the Å¿moake: take alÅ¿o of Oates eight pints, and of old woollen-ragges the couÅ¿er the better two pounds; take alÅ¿o of Swallowes-dung a good quantity, and foure or five living Swallowes, put all theÅ¿e things into an Earthen-pot new, and well nayled, and let it bee big enough to be able
to hold all the Ingredients, and put alÅ¿o all thoÅ¿e living-creatures among them alive, and then make a Cake of Clay, and therewith lute up the Pot Å¿o cloÅ¿e, as that neyther Å¿moake nor ayre can eyther get in or out; having Å¿o done carry your Pot into Å¿ome Orchard or other CloÅ¿e, or Back-Å¿ide, from HouÅ¿ing or Straw, and there place it, and Å¿o make a great fire both round about it, and upon it, and Å¿o keep the fire unto the Pot, till it bee as red-hot as the very fiery-coles themÅ¿elves, and let the fire continue Å¿o great after the pot is red-hot by the Å¿pace of halfe an hour at the leaÅ¿t: then let the fire remaine untouched untill it be all conÅ¿umed to aÅ¿hes, and Å¿o go forth of it Å¿elfe, without eyther quenching the Å¿ame, or taking away any of the fire about it, and Å¿o let it Å¿tand till it be through cold, which will hardly be done the Å¿ame day, Å¿o when the Pot is through cold, take it from the place, and opening it, take forth the Å¿tuffe, and put it into Å¿ome Trough or great Morter made for the purpoÅ¿e, which muÅ¿t Å¿tand in Å¿ome out or open place where no winde can come, the Trough or Morter being covered with a cloth, that the powder may not fly away, there pound and Å¿tamp theÅ¿e things together into fine powder, and in the Å¿tamping, adde thereunto of unÅ¿lacked-Lime one pound. Let him that Å¿tampeth it be cloÅ¿e muffled, and his eyes covered with a glaÅ¿Å¿e-caÅ¿e made for the purpoÅ¿e for feare of hurting them; and when it is throughly powdred, Å¿earÅ¿e the powder through a courÅ¿e Haire-cloth, and Å¿o keepe the very fineÅ¿t of the powder for your uÅ¿e, in Å¿ome cleane glaÅ¿Å¿e or gally-pot. This powder killeth all Wilde-fires whatÅ¿oever, and all running Sorances and Vlcers, provided it be applyed to fleÅ¿hy-places, and not to places where veines or Å¿inewes be, for that it will burne them in Å¿under. X. This I have made Å¿undry times, and often uÅ¿ed it, and to cure and dry up old Å¿ores and Vlcers (this powder being diÅ¿creetly uÅ¿ed and rightly applyed) a better thing then this truly I know not, eÅ¿pecially if the cure be eyther deÅ¿perate or dangerous.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat good PlaiÅ¿ter have you to lay upon a Wound, whereby to keepe in the Taint or Salve?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, MaÅ¿tick, Turpentine, Hogge-greaÅ¿e, of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, melt all theÅ¿e together, and Å¿o keepe it: and when you would uÅ¿e it, Å¿pread what will Å¿erve upon a plaiÅ¿ter of Leather, and Å¿o cover the wound Wounds. therewith. â. This Å¿alve doth infinitely comfort a wound greene or old, bee the Å¿ame FiÅ¿tula or otherwiÅ¿e. Very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: HOw doe you take away a Wen, or other excretion ariÅ¿ing in the FleÅ¿h?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: A Wenne is a hard riÅ¿ing out of the fleÅ¿h, which commeth Å¿ometimes by bad-humours, but moÅ¿t commonly by Å¿ome Hurt, Stroke, BruiÅ¿e, Blow, or with a Å¿tone throwne at that place, it is outwardly fleÅ¿hie, but towards the roote it is matterative, you neede no Å¿ignes whereby to know it, for it will betray it Å¿elfe by its Å¿welling, The cure is.

If you cannot come to tye a double threed about it whereby to eate it off,Wen or excretion. as I have formerly Å¿hewed you in the cure of a Spongy-Wart: then with your InciÅ¿ionknife cut it a croÅ¿Å¿e into four equal parts or quarters to the very bottome, but beware you touch not either veynes or Å¿inewes, then with Mercury eate away the foure quarters, or elÅ¿e burne them off with your hot-iron; then heale the place with your healing Å¿alve. â. This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good to take away Wind-gaules?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Wind gaules are terrible Sorances, which do breed in the legges of a HorÅ¿e, as well on the outÅ¿ide as on the inÅ¿ide, a little above the Fet-locke ioynt, and by their Å¿welling are plainly diÅ¿covered, and made viÅ¿ible to the Eye, for they bee bladders, wherein lyeth a Ielly, which being let forth is thicke, and of the colour of the yolke of an Egge, whereof Å¿ome will be bigger, and Å¿ome leÅ¿Å¿er. It commeth moÅ¿t commoly to HorÅ¿es in the Summer-time, by reaÅ¿on they are ridden upon hard ground, and the HorÅ¿e being over-heat by too hard riding, his greaÅ¿e falleth downe into his legges, and Å¿etleth there, and by that meanes breedeth this Malady, wee call Wind-gaules, Wind-galles and they will be Å¿o painefull unto him, as to cauÅ¿e him many times to halt. The Å¿ignes to know them are by the Å¿wellings in that place before named, which be moÅ¿t eaÅ¿ie to be Å¿een and felt. The cure is eyther to Å¿tricke with your Fleame or to open them with your InciÅ¿ion-knife, and to let and cruÅ¿h out all the congealed Å¿tuffe which is therein, opening the place no further then through the skin, and you muÅ¿t be carefull of the Å¿inew, which lyeth cloÅ¿e to that place: then.

Take the white of an Egge, and Oyle-de Bay Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate them together, and apply it with Hurds PlaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e, and in three or foure dayes thus dreÅ¿Å¿ing it, he will be cured. â. Thus have I cured many HorÅ¿es. Another. After you have let forth the Ielly.

Take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, and MaÅ¿ticke, of each like much, boyl or but
melt them together, and as it cooleth, make it up into rowles bigger or leÅ¿Å¿er at your pleaÅ¿ure, and being thorough cold, apply it with a hot iron to the orifice, and Å¿o round about the place of the Å¿orance on either Å¿ide of the legge, and Å¿o Å¿oon as you have layed on this charge, and before it can be cold, clap on Flocks, and this will dry up the Wind-gaules, and heale them. â This is Å¿peciall good. But during not onely theÅ¿e two cures, but all other for this malady, you muÅ¿t not Å¿uffer your horÅ¿e to come into any Well by any means. Another. FirÅ¿t Å¿have away the hayre as you muÅ¿t doe in all theÅ¿e kinde of cures, then open the Å¿orance as before is taught you, and cruÅ¿h forth the jelly and filth, then

Take Tacha-Mahacha, MaÅ¿ticke, ParroÅ¿in, of each to the quantity of a haÅ¿le nut, and of Stone-Pitch to the quantity of a Wall-nut, with a little BrimÅ¿tone powdred, melt all theÅ¿e together, and when it is molten, put in Å¿o much Turpentine as a Wall-nut, and Å¿o Å¿tirre them together, and when it is cold, make a plaiÅ¿ter thereof upon leather, and apply it warme to the place upon the out-Å¿ide onely upon the orifice, which ought evermore to be made on the out-Å¿ide, then put on the plaiÅ¿ter it Å¿elfe, and round about it with the Å¿ame Salve, and clap Flocks upon it, and Å¿o let him reÅ¿t in the Stable, and by keeping him from wet till he be whole, and let the plaiÅ¿ter remaine on untill it Å¿hall fall away of it Å¿elfe â This is a moÅ¿t excellent cure, and I have often made good uÅ¿e thereof. Another.

Take the oyle of Vineger, and dip your thumb therein, and rub the Å¿orance therewith every day till the haire do fall off, which will cauÅ¿e the Wind-gaules to breake, run, and bleed, then heale and cure the Wind-gaules well and Å¿oundly. â This is as good as the former. Another. WaÅ¿h and Å¿have as formerly is Å¿hewed you, then give fire to the place, that done, open the Wind-gaules juÅ¿t in the middle line or Å¿troke, halfe an inch at leaÅ¿t, and Å¿o cruÅ¿h forth the jelly with your thumb, then

Take Pitch, RoÅ¿in, and MaÅ¿tick, of each like much, and therewith charge the place as before is taught you. This is very good. Another. FirÅ¿t waÅ¿h and Å¿have, and open the place with your fleame, &c. then take of oyle de Bay, and of Turpentine, of each one Å¿poonfull, Verdigrece in fine powder, one penny worth, the white of an Egge, and of red Leade two ounces in powder, boyle all theÅ¿e to a Salve, and adminiÅ¿ter it to the place plaiÅ¿ter-wiÅ¿e. â This is one of the beÅ¿t cures for Wind-gaules that I doe know.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat is good for a HorÅ¿e that is wrung or hurt in the Withers?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This is a thing that I have handled before, yet I will give you a few more receits. Having travelled him, and comming home, or to your Inne, when you take off the Å¿addle, and that you doe finde the horÅ¿e to be wrung in the withers, and his backe or withers thereby to be Å¿welled, immediately clap on the Saddle againe, and lay upon the Å¿wolne place Å¿ome wet litter, and Å¿o let the Saddle abide on againe;Wither-wrung. then cut up a thin Turfe of graÅ¿Å¿e and earth together, that done, put the Turfe upon the fire, and let it there remaine till it becommeth red hot, and being well burned, take it from the fire, and moiÅ¿ten the graÅ¿Å¿y Å¿ide very well with white Wine Vineger, then take off the wet litter, and lay the Turfe very hot with the graÅ¿Å¿y-Å¿ide next to the place, and Å¿o put on the Saddle againe, and let it Å¿o remaine for all night, and this preÅ¿ently helpeth any Å¿wellings in the withers, or any other part of the backe, as alÅ¿o any Å¿wellings by Spur-gaules or Navell-gaules. â This is very good. Another. If the skin be broken or ulcerated, then

Take Å¿weet Butter, Bay-Å¿alt, and powder of FrankincenÅ¿e, of each as much as will Å¿uffice, boile all theÅ¿e upon the fire, and with a clowt faÅ¿tened to the end of a Å¿ticke, even as it commeth boyling from the fire, Å¿cald it two or three times, but if it be full of corruption, then make inciÅ¿ion on both Å¿ides from beneath, that the matterative Å¿tuffe may the more eaÅ¿ily void away downewards, and after uÅ¿e none other thing wherewith to heale it up, but onely your uÅ¿uall powder of Lime and Honey, which will heale that, or dry other Å¿uch like hurts. â This is moÅ¿t excellent, I have often experimented the Å¿ame. Another. But if it be a wrinckle either in the Å¿houlder, or in any other joynt or member, then

Take of white Wine one pinte, halfe a porringer full of Wheate flower, of common Honey one pinte, of Syzes three ounces, boyle all theÅ¿e together to an Vnguent, and anoint the places grieved therewith. And this alÅ¿o is very Å¿overaigne for Cones, Cracks, and Chops in the heeles of the horÅ¿e. â This I often uÅ¿ing have found it to be very good. Another.

Take three great Onyons, picke forth the cores, making a concavity or hollowneÅ¿Å¿e in them, then fill them up with the powder of FrankincenÅ¿e, then wrap them up in three or four handfuls of Hurds or Tow, then wet the Hurds, and Å¿o cover and heale them up in the hot embers, and lay upon the top of the embers a good Shovell-full of hot burning coles, and Å¿o let it remaine untill the Onions be throughly roÅ¿ted, then take them forth, and Å¿eparate the Hurds and
burned part from the other, and the Å¿oft and pappy part you Å¿hall apply to the Å¿orance very hot, and let it remain three daies before it be removed, and do thus Å¿o oft as need Å¿hall require, untill it be through whole; but unleÅ¿Å¿e the hurt or bruiÅ¿e be very great, it will be cured at firÅ¿t dreÅ¿Å¿ing. â This is very good. Another. But if the place grieved be broken,

Take then of the oyle of Worms, of Turpentine, and common Honey, of each two ounces, incorporate all theÅ¿e together very well till you have brought them to be one body, and either by Taint or PlaiÅ¿ter dreÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿orance therewith, and it will heale it up Å¿ound. â And this alÅ¿o is very good. Another. If your HorÅ¿e hath taken a wreÌch in the Å¿houlder, or in the hippe, knee, or hoofe; then firÅ¿t Å¿wim him, then after for thirteen or fourteen dayes together, annoynt the member grieved all over, and a good way about with this unguent.

Take of the oyle de Bay, of Nervall, of Dialthea, of tryed Hogs greaÅ¿e, of each two ounces, melt all theÅ¿e together, and Å¿tirre them well till they be well incorporated, and herewith anoint him againÅ¿t the haire, with a hot bar of iron to be holden before you as you annoint him. and after let him be rowelled with a French Rowell, and let a Patten-Å¿hooe be put upon the contrary foot, and let him be kept in the houÅ¿e, and the Rowell turned daily, and the corruption put forth, and then let him be either gently ridden or walked every day halfe an houre, and let the Rowell remain in the HorÅ¿e fourteen daies at the leaÅ¿t, then take it out, and heale up the orifice with your green Oyntment, and Å¿o Å¿oon as he is whole, with your cauterizing-iron draw croÅ¿Å¿e lines eight or nine inches long over againÅ¿t the joynt that was pained, Å¿o as the rowelled place may be in the middle, but yet burn him no deeper then that the skin may look yellow, and then charge all that place with this charge.

Take Pitch one pound, RoÅ¿in halfe a pound, and Tarre half a pint, melt theÅ¿e together, and whilÅ¿t it is warm, charge the place therwith, and clap Flocks upon the charge, and then if the Å¿eaÅ¿on of the yeare will Å¿erve, let him be turned to graÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿o let him run three moneths at the leaÅ¿t. â This is very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is good to cure wormes Wormes. of what Å¿ort Å¿oever in a HorÅ¿e?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: Of this malady I have entreated Å¿ufficiently before in the Â§ of Bots, where I have given you many good receits. NevertheleÅ¿Å¿e I will give you one or two more for wormes onely, and Å¿o leave you to practiÅ¿e.

Take the entrails of a great Chick, and with the powder of BrimÅ¿tone and Bay-Salt rowled in the Å¿aid entrails, give it him down his throat, and cauÅ¿e him to Å¿wallow them Å¿o warm as they come out of
the belly of the Chicken, but caÅ¿t away the Gizard, give him this three mornings together, and every time ride or walk him till he dungeth, and keep him warm, and give him white water, and at three dayes end, give him Rice boyled in water, and after dryed in the Sun, and give him alÅ¿o to eate the leaves of Sallowes, and it will cauÅ¿e him to voyd the Worms with his ordure, but if you Å¿hall rake him firÅ¿t, it will be the better. â This is very good. Another.

Take the tender tops of Broom and Saven, of each halfe a handfull, chop them very Å¿mall, and work them into Pils with Å¿weet Butter, and having kept your HorÅ¿e faÅ¿ting over night, give him them in the morning, to wit, three of thoÅ¿e Pils at a time, and then Å¿et him upon the Trench for two or three hours after, and then give him meat, but no drink at all till night by any meanes, and then let him have warm, but no white water. â This I have often experienced, and do know it to be a moÅ¿t excellent receit.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: WHat is your beÅ¿t cure for the Yellowes?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p:
This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of the Yellowes in a HorÅ¿e is the very Å¿ame that PhyÅ¿itians do call the IaundiÅ¿e in a man; and as there be two Å¿orts of IaundiÅ¿e in a man, Å¿o alÅ¿o are there the like in a HorÅ¿e, viz. the Yellow and the Black, the yellow being moyÅ¿t, the black dry; the yellow proceeding from the over-flowing of the gall, occaÅ¿ioned of choller, and the black comming from the over-working of the Spleen, by means of over-much malancholy, both bad infirmities, but the black worÅ¿t, more dangerous and moÅ¿t mortall, the yellow is more eaÅ¿ily diÅ¿covered by reaÅ¿on of its colour, for it coloureth the whites of the eyes, the tongue, the lips, and the inward parts of the noÅ¿trils, which the black IaundiÅ¿e doth not apparantly, albeit by due and Å¿trict obÅ¿ervation, you may come to know when your HorÅ¿e hath a black IaundiÅ¿e, for then you Å¿hall perceive the whites of his eyes, lips, tongue, and mouth to be of a thick and duskiÅ¿h colour, and not Å¿o cleere and Å¿anguine as before when he was not viÅ¿ited with any Å¿uch infirmity, both which are Å¿o mortall (eÅ¿pecially the latter) as that if very great care be not taken whereby to pry into its Å¿ymptomes, the HorÅ¿e may
fall downe upon a Å¿udden (as I have often Å¿een and known) even as he travelleth, and dye, or elÅ¿e he appearing to be Å¿ound and healthy, and to eate his meat like as he was accuÅ¿tomed over night when you left him, comming again unto him in the morning, you may finde him dead, Å¿tiffe, and cold. And the origen of this malady commeth principally of unkindely and unnaturall heats given him by moÅ¿t violent and intemperate riding, whereby the Liver becommeth inflamed; the Liver, the Bloud, Gall, and the Spleen, which cauÅ¿eth choller to have Å¿overaignty and dominion over the other humours, and Å¿o engendreth this perilous diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, which Å¿eldome bringeth a lingring or languiÅ¿hing death, but that which endeth him Å¿uddenly, and therefore it is moÅ¿t requiÅ¿ite that the greater eye and care be had unto it. The beÅ¿t Å¿ymptomes how to know it is thus. Your HorÅ¿e will be dry in his body, mouth, and noÅ¿trils, being marvellous hot through the abundance of choller that reigneth in him, and he will be very gaunt in his belly towards the flanks, he will be alÅ¿o very faint, and not onely Å¿weat upon every the leaÅ¿t motion, but alÅ¿o as he Å¿tandeth in the Stable: his eyes, the inÅ¿ides of his lips, mouth, and tongue, will be yellow as Saffron, and he will Å¿eldome lye down, and being layd, he will Å¿ometimes grone. The cure. FirÅ¿t let him bloud in the neck and mouth, and let him bleed well, then give him this drink.

Take of Turmerick and long Pepper, of each one penniworth,Yellowes. AnniÅ¿eeds and Licoris in fine powder and Å¿earced, of each halfe a Å¿poonfull, Selendine, the leaves and roots one handfull chop, Å¿tamp, and Å¿traine the Selendine, and Å¿o put all theÅ¿e together into Å¿trong Ale one quart, warm this upon the fire, and in the warming adde unto it of London Treacle one ounce, and of Å¿weet Butter the quantity of an Egge, and give it him bloud warm, and after keep him warme, and give him white water, and he will do well. â This is very good. Another. FirÅ¿t bloudy him as before, and then

Take Turmerick, Myrrah, Ivory or Harts-horn, of each halfe an ounce, Saffron one penny worth, make all theÅ¿e into fine powder, and Å¿earce them, and put unto it of the juyce of Selendine a good quantity, put all theÅ¿e into Muskadine one pinte, Sack or Ale, and let it boile upon the fire a walm or two, then put unto it of Å¿weet Butter as much as will Å¿uffice, and of London Treacle one ounce, and Å¿o give it him bloud warm, but let him firÅ¿t be raked. This is very good. Another. FirÅ¿t bloudy him as before, then

Take of white wine one quart, of Saffron two drams, and of Turmerick halfe an ounce, and a good quantity of the juyce of Selendine; give him this bloud warm, and keep him warm, and give him white water. â This is very good. Another. FirÅ¿t let him bloud as you are preÅ¿cribed before. Then

Take of Å¿weete Wine one pinte, of Å¿tronge Ale and Beere one quart, and put unto it of the iuyce of Salendine Å¿ix Å¿poonefuls, and of
the iuyce of Rue two Å¿poonefuls, and let all theÅ¿e boyle upon the fire a little, then Å¿traine into it of EngliÅ¿h Saffaron halfe an ounce, and put into it of life hony three ounces, and Å¿o give it him bloud-warme, then leap his backe, and Å¿o ride or elÅ¿e walke him a foot-pace a quarter of an houre, then Å¿et him up warme, letting him to faÅ¿t three houres after, and after give him meat, and a Å¿weete MaÅ¿h, or white-water. â. This is very good. Another. Bloudy him as before. Then

Take of the beÅ¿t life hony halfe a pound, of Saffaron made into fine powder, and of the powder of Fenugrick of each Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, incorporate theÅ¿e with your Hony to a Å¿tiffe paÅ¿te, and Å¿o make thereof three Pils, and dipping them into Salet-oyle give them to your HorÅ¿e, which after he hath taken, ride or walke him gently an houre, then Å¿et him up warme, and order him as before. â. This is a particular good Pill. Another. FirÅ¿t let him bloud as before; Then

Take of white-Wine one quart or Ale to the Å¿ame quantity, and put therein of Saffaron one ounce, and Turmerick one ounce, both made into fine powder, with the iuyce of Salendine Å¿o much as will Å¿uffice, and give him this bloud-warme, and order him as before. â. This is alÅ¿o very good.

sp.speaker: Hippoph.
sp.p: VVHat cure have you for the mattering of the Yard?

sp.speaker: HippoÅ¿.
sp.p: This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e commeth commonly in Covering time by overmuch Å¿pending upon Mares, for that the heat of the Mares, & the HorÅ¿e his own heate and Coity, doth burne the HorÅ¿e giving him the running of the reines, as we may truly terme it: And the Å¿ignes to know it, is, you Å¿hall perceive the end of the Yard to be Å¿welled, & when he piÅ¿Å¿eth you may obÅ¿erve him to do it with much paine, and you may alÅ¿o Å¿ee at other times the Yard to drop with yellow matter. The cure. Give him firÅ¿t a purge preÅ¿cribed you in lib. 2. cap. 16. Â§. 14. let P. & it is the firÅ¿t purgation which will eaÅ¿e his pain in piÅ¿Å¿ing; then the next day,

Take Roch-Allome one ounce, and white-Wine one pinte, boyle them till the Allome be diÅ¿Å¿olved, then bloud-warme iniect this Lotion with a Syringe, putting it up into his Yard, Å¿o far as may be, foure or five times a day till he be well. â. This is a perfect cure, nor Å¿hall you need any other.
